HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Coffee Prices Surge Again On Worries of Tight Supply

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Coffee futures prices leaped higher yesterday in heavy trading on New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange amid mounting worries about the availability of Brazilian and Central American beans.
Oil futures, meanwhile, fell as home-heating oil declined with warming temperatures in Europe. 
 Coffee settled 3.1 cents to 4 cents higher, with the contract for delivery in March at 91.2 cents a pound, a two-month high.
Coffee futures have made several jumps in the last week since the start of a dock workers' strike at the Brazilian port of Santos, the leading coffee port of the world's biggest coffee-producing country.
"If the strike were to persist, it would be very disruptive to the coffee market," said Arthur Stevenson, coffee analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc.
He said coffee futures were also supported by continued tight availability of high-quality beans, especially from Central America.
 
Cut in Crop Estimate
 Other analysts said buying interest was stirred by a downward revision Tuesday of the Agriculture Department's estimate of this year's Brazilian coffee crop to 25 million 132-pound bags from 31 million.
Celeste Georgakis, an analyst with Cargill Investor Services Inc., said the Agriculture Department typically overestimated Brazilian production. She said the new estimate was close to previous industry estimates of 21 million to 24 million bags, but that some Brazilian growers had since lowered their crop projections by another 2 million bags.
She said production estimates were falling because Brazilian economic reforms had reduced agricultural loans, leaving farmers with less to spend on fertilizer and crop care.
Oil prices eased on the New York Mercantile Exchange as home-heating oil futures fell after a rally based on cold weather in Europe ended.
Light sweet crude oil finished 37 cents to 41 cents higher, with March at $22.56 a barrel; heating oil was 0.05 cent to 3.69 cents lower, with March at 67.11 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 0.81 cent to 1.3 cents gasoline was 0.81 cent to 1.3 cents lower, with March at 62.38 cents a gallon, and natural gas was 0.5 cent lower to 1.3 cent higher, with March at $1.35 per 1,000 cubic feet.
Orange juice futures recovered almost all of the steep losses posted Tuesday on the New York Cotton Exchange amid forecasts for chilly temperatures in Florida.
There is little threat to this year's orange crop, which is nearly all harvested, but traders fear the cold temperatures expected on Saturday morning could hurt trees that are now in bloom and damage next year's crop, Ms. Georgakis said.
Frozen concentrated orange juice settled 3.5 cents to 4.15 cents higher, with March at $1.2215 a pound.

HEADLINE: OTAY MESA JOURNAL;
Can One Airport Unite Two Nations?

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OTAY MESA, Calif.

 BODY:
For years the flat scrub lands here have been best known for nightly wrangles between illegal Mexican immigrants and the United States Border Patrol. But these days, Otay Mesa has also come to symbolize a far different vision of Mexican-American relations: a proposed binational airport that would join the two countries in a new experiment in cross-border cooperation.
Otay (pronounced oh-TIE) Mesa, thousands of acres of largely undeveloped land on the southern edge of California, is just 40 minutes from San Diego and is one of the few potential sites that city has found for replacing, or at least relieving, its overburdened downtown airport. 
 The mesa's terrain is so flat and mostly treeless that the Mexican side is already home to the Tijuana airport. But low mountains nearby make it impossible to build a new airport on American soil that would operate separately from the Mexican airport.
For many San Diego city officials and politicians, the answer to that problem would be to join a new San Diego airport with the existing Tijuana field in what would be one of the few -- and certainly the largest -- binational airport in the world. Straddling the border, the airport would have separate customs and immigration terminals but enable both countries to share runways that could handle the largest passenger jets.
The idea has provoked sharp opposition from some residents on the American side, who say the complex would create unacceptable noise and other disruptions in an area that had been set aside for industrial, commercial and residential developments. More important, the proposal has received only mixed reactions from the Mexican Government, which would have to approve any cross-border airport.
But proponents remain undaunted, and have gathered a formidable body of technical analyses and political support. In mid-1990, the San Diego Association of Governments, the regional authority charged with overseeing airport development, made public a federally financed study stating the feasibility of the proposed Otay Mesa airport. In late November, a delegation approached Mexican officials for the first time to promote direct government-to-government talks.
"This would change the whole psychology of the region," said Michael C. Abrams, an aide to Councilman Ron Roberts, who has been a big supporter of the airport.
Under the most ambitious plans yet discussed, the airport would cost about $2 billion, cover some 4,000 acres and be able to handle up to 40 million passengers and 400,000 takeoffs and landings a year. San Diego's current airport, Lindbergh Field, has 471 acres and handles 11.5 million passengers a year.
Some who fear the noise and other disturbances such a huge airport would create want a scaled-back version, with only one large new runway and associated terminal buildings.
But all of the configurations would be aimed at giving Otay Mesa the ability to handle long-haul flights of aircraft as large as the Boeing 747, directly linking the region for the first time with such trading partners as Japan and Taiwan.
Together with a new $200 million aircraft maintentance complex now being constructed on the site of the current Tijuana airport, proponents say, the new airport would make the border region a vital new gateway to international trade.
The most formidable obstacle is winning approval of the Mexican Government for a binational commission to study the project. Although many business leaders have expressed support for the plan, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has taken no formal position on it, and Mexico's Secretary of Communications and Transport, Andres Caso Lombardo, has opposed the project.
"The questions of national sovereignty are very important," said San Diego's Deputy Mayor, Bob Filner, whose City Council district includes Otay Mesa, which is administered by San Diego. "Why would either side want to put a major transportation network under the control of the other side?"
But advocates say that, even if President Salinas attempts to derail or postpone the Otay Mesa idea, the pressures generated by northern Mexico's own economic growth will eventually overcome nationalist resistance.
As Jack Koerper, director of special projects for the San Diego government group, put it, "In a few years, they will be coming to us, just like we are coming to them now."

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Fall 0.9%, Hurt by Drop in Autos

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13

 BODY:
Retail sales in January were nine-tenths of 1 percent lower than in December, the Commerce Department said today, with a sharp drop in auto sales largely responsible for the decline.
Some economists said the figures were better than expected and indicated an end of the unwillingness of consumers to spend. But others said that a sharp revision downward of the December figures was evidence that the end was not in sight. 
 December sales were revised to a 1.5 percent decline from November. They had been reported last month as having declined four-tenths of 1 percent. The adjustment was largely because of lower auto sales.
Falling demand for new cars and cheaper gasoline were the major culprits behind the slumping sales in both January and December, the department reported.
 
Decline From Last Year
 On a year-to-year basis, January retail sales were 1.4 percent lower than in January 1990, when they were valued at $150.3 billion. That represented the first year-to-year decline in nearly 30 years.
The United States Chamber of Commerce said the steeper-than-anticipated drop in December indicated the economy was weakening even faster than was thought at the end of the year.
"The sharp downward revision in December retail sales, along with the decline in January, show the consumer is not ready yet to lead the economy out of recession," the business group said.
Retail sales are considered crucial by economists because consumer spending accounts for about two-thirds of economic activity.
 
Some Expected Worse
 January's decline was less extreme, however, than some analysts had feared. Retail sales had been expected to tumble 1.7 percent as shoppers worried about their jobs and the the Middle East war cut spending.
After excluding cars, sales in January were unchanged after falling seven-tenths of 1 percent in December without cars included. Some categories of sales, including department stores, food stores and restaurants, rose last month.
"This report shows sales were a good deal stronger than was expected on discretionary items," said Russ Sheldon, senior economist with the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh.
Analysts noted, however, that the January sales data could be revised downward, particularly if spending weakened dramatically after war broke out in the middle of the month.
 
The Auto and Gas Factor
 The Commerce Department said auto dealer sales fell 4.4 percent in both January and December. Car makers have been lowering assembly rates since late last year with sales falling. The other significant factor in January was cheaper gasoline; dealer sales in the month fell 2.3 percent, after a 1.7 percent December decline.
Jean Sundrla, an economist with Evans Economics Inc. of Washington, said that it was too soon to say whether consumers were growing more confident, but that it was time to watch for signs that lower interest rates were having an impact.
"We expect to see signs of recovery because of the very big interest rate cuts we've already had," Mrs. Sundrla said. The Federal Reserve Board, she noted, "is accommodating this economy now and political pressure is on to get interest rates even lower."
 
Drop in Durables Sales
 Sales of durable goods -- items meant to last at least three years -- were down 2.8 percent in January after falling 3.4 percent in December. Sales of nondurable goods, like food and disposable items, rose one-tenth of 1 percent after falling four-tenths of 1 percent in December.
Sales at general-merchandise stores rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in January after a 1.1 percent fall in December.
Food-store sales increased four-tenths of 1 percent last month after a two-tenths of 1 percent December rise.

HEADLINE: Early-Month Vehicle Sales Down 23.6%

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 13

 BODY:
Sales of domestically made cars and light trucks dropped 23.6 percent earlier in the month as most buyers remained out of the market because of concerns over war and the weak economy.
Dealers and automotive analysts have been saying that most sales in the last month were to fleets and to customers forced to buy a new vehicle, as opposed to those trading in for a newer or more luxurious model. 
 Seasonally adjusted, domestic cars sold at a 6.2 million rate, compared with 7.4 million in the 1990 period.
 
Truck Sales Plunge 31.2%
 The nation's nine domestic auto makers posted sales of 124,885 for Feb. 1-10, compared with 173,859 in the corresponding period last year. The latest period had eight selling days, compared with nine last year.
Light-truck sales plunged 31.2 percent from a year ago, to 52,295 from 96,903. Light-truck sales were harder hit because they are less fuel-efficient and because they reflect the cost-cutting in many businesses, analysts speculated.
"The good news is it hasn't gotten any worse" than in January, said Joel H. Pitcoff, sales analyst for the Ford Motor Company. "The bad news is it isn't any better."
"The loss in volume is certainly no reason to be encouraged," said John Casesa, automotive analyst for Wertheim Schroder & Company in New York. He noted that popular Japanese brands were experiencing declines as well. "When the most desirable products in the market are off 25 percent it's clear that business is very bad," he said.
Ford's sales declined disproportionately because of comparisons with an unusually strong period last year, Mr. Pitcoff said. The company's car sales were off 35.9 percent, to 32,573. The sales of the Probe, Mustang and Thunderbird models were especially soft, compared with last year
Ford's light-truck sales dropped 31.3 percent, to 21,903 from 35,881. The one bright spot was the new four-door Ford Explorer utility vehicle, which continues to sell strongly.
 
G.M. Posts 12.6% Drop
 The General Motors Corporation outperformed the overall decline in cars. G.M.'s car sales dropped 12.6 percent, to 62,363, from 80,239 last year. The Buick and Pontiac divisions each posted gains. G.M.'s truck sales, however, were worse than average, falling 39.7 percent, to 24,153 from 40,046.
The Chrysler Corporation declines to provide 10-day sales totals. But Ward's Automotive Reports, an industry publication, estimated its car sales at 13,800 in the period, a 14.4 percent decline from last year. Light-truck sales were estimated at 11,100, a 31 percent decline from last year.
The Honda Motor Company posted a 14 percent decline in car sales, to 6,217. The Nissan Motor Company's car sales dropped 6 percent, to 1,363, and the Toyota Motor Corporation had a 44.4 percent decline, to 3,458.
But Toyota reported that sales of its Lexus luxury cars, which are imported, declined only 14.7 percent, while its imported cars over all declined 32.1 percent.
Nissan's light-truck sales were off 44.3 percent, to 1,647.
 
Less Production
 Most domestic auto makers have been trimming production to prevent inventories from rising too sharply. But the inventory of domestically built light trucks was 115 days of supply at the beginning of February, compared with 96 a month earlier, Ward's said. The car supply was 91 days, compared with 74 days a month earlier. A 65-day supply is normal.
Honda's inventory set a record at the beginning of the month, hitting 88 days' supply, from 70 a month earlier and 39 a year ago. Honda recently said it would trim production to bring inventories in line with sales.
The Big Three this week are operating 27 of their 55 North American car and truck assembly plants. All 12 "transplants" -- factories owned or partly owned by foreign auto makers -- were operating.

HEADLINE: Oil Imports and Inventories Reported Down

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Imports of crude oil and oil products were down sharply last month, the American Petroleum Institute said yesterday, and inventories were also off sharply.
The report echoes a finding by the Energy Department on Monday that crude and product stocks in January were at their lowest levels in several years, with "the potential for creating tight product markets and rising prices in the coming months if major unforeseen problems should develop." 
 Heating oil inventories are down, partly because cold weather in Europe has raised prices there and product stocks are flowing that way. Gasoline inventories are also down.
The Energy Department suggested the reason might be low margins for refiners, and a belief that crude prices would decline, providing a disincentive to make more gasoline now.
 
7.3 Million Barrels a Day
 According to the Washington-based institute, the industry's primary trade organization, imports last month averaged 7.3 million barrels a day, down 20 percent from the previous January. Although last January's imports were unusually high, because of a cold spell, the drop last month follows a trend stretching back to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, on Aug. 2, of lower oil imports.
Experts say several factors are at work. Oil users may be wary of holding high invetories, because of the potential for another crash. With a slow economy and warm weather, domestic demand is down; the institute said yesterday that deliveries were 1.4 percent lower than last January.
Peter C. Beutel, an analyst at Pegasus Econometric Group, in Hoboken, N.J., said he thought that the leading oil companies had made a tacit agreement with the White House to draw down inventories rather than bid up prices.

HEADLINE: F.C.C. Acts On Cellular Competition

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13

 BODY:
Setting a significant regulatory precedent, the Federal Communications Commission decided today to allow a new form of mobile telephone service in six cities, including New York.
The action erodes current Federal rules that permit only two cellular telephone companies in each city. The new system makes it possible for a company that now provides mobile communications for car and truck fleets to provide mobile telephone service to hundreds of thousands of individuals in a city. 
 Because the new system would closely resemble a third cellular service, it could force cellular companies to cut prices. F.C.C. officials made it clear they would approve similar applications for other cities.
 
Threat in the Long Run
 Industry analysts said traditional cellular companies would still have several practical advantages over the new service, but could lose ground over time.
"Certainly, there is no threat in the near term, but over time this increases the competitive intensity of the business," said Edward Greenberg, a telecommunications analyst for Morgan Stanley & Company.
The cellular industry, which bitterly opposed the new service, denounced the decision and said it was unfair. Robert W. Maher, president of the Cellular Telecommunications Industry Association in Washington, said the group might challenge the F.C.C. decision. Charging that the new service would face fewer restrictions than those placed on cellular companies, Mr. Maher said the F.C.C. had imposed a fundamental policy change without holding a public debate.
 
Benefit Seen for Consumers
 Officials of the company that made the proposal, Fleet Call Inc., based in Bloomfield, N.J., were ecstatic. "I'm delighted," said Brian McAuley, the firm's president. "The industry is going to benefit from this, as will consumers. There is no question that another choice for those seeking wireless communications will bring more competitive pricing."
The company plans to build systems in New York, San Francisco, Los Angeles, Chicago, Houston and Dallas. A system in Los Angeles should begin operating by early 1993, Mr. McAuley said, and New York should be ready by later that year. The F.C.C. has given the company five years to complete construction.
Much like ordinary cellular service, the system would allow individuals to have conversations without being heard by other customers. It would also be able to patch calls from mobile telephones into the local telephone network, allowing customers to speak with people using regular telephones.
Previously, only two services had been allowed in each city because the available radio spectrum could handle no more. A third service would use a different part of the spectrum, but it would be difficult to find space for more than three.
F.C.C. officials generally applauded Fleet Call's effort to use the radio spectrum more efficiently.
 
'This is a Turning Point'
 "Truly, this is a turning point in the private, land-mobile community," said Ralph Haller, chief of the F.C.C.'s private radio bureau.
But industry experts noted that cellular companies offer several advantages for individual consumers seeking mobile telephones. The biggest advantage is that local cellular companies offer "roaming" service, which allows customers to make or receive calls in distant cities. The Fleet Call system, by contrast, would be limited to use in one locale.
Numerous analysts predicted that Fleet Call's mobile telephones would be more expensive than standard cellular phones, because they would be made in smaller production volumes for a more limited market.
One key issue is whether other providers of mobile radio service will follow Fleet Call's lead in additional cities. If so, it becomes easier to develop nationwide technical standards for the new service.
"Before there can be real competition, this will have to spread beyond Fleet Call" to other companies, said Andrew Roscoe, president of Economic and Management Consultants International, a market research firm in Washington.
 
Microwave Channels for TV
 The F.C.C. also decided today to make it easier to distribute cable television programming over microwave channels. The action could eliminate one of the practical difficulties confronted by "wireless cable" companies that compete against local cable television franchises.
Wireless companies, which typically broadcast programming over microwave frequencies, can reach customers only in their direct line of sight and have difficulty in cities where tall buildings block views.
In today's action, the F.C.C. allowed such companies to use additional microwave frequencies for relaying signals to more locations.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Fleet Call's chairman, Morgan O'Brian, left, and Brian McAuley, the firm's chief executive, spoke to reporters at their lawyers' offices in Washingtonyesterday after hearing that the F.C.C. had endorsed their new radio-based mobile telephone system, an alternative to existing cellular systems. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times) (pg. D7)

HEADLINE: U.S. and Japan to Start Talks on Chips

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 13

 BODY:
Japan will reluctantly begin quiet negotiations Thursday over extending a trade agreement that government and industry officials here would much rather let die -- the five-year-old semiconductor accord with the United States.
Officially, the Japanese Government says it sees no need to extend the pact because American chip makers have significantly improved access to the Japanese market. 
 But privately, Japanese officials acknowledge that a new agreement is inevitable, largely to forestall threats of further trade action by Congress. The decision by the Ministry of International Trade and Industry to send a delegation to Washington this week seemed to send a clear signal to Japanese industry that some kind of new agreement is on the way.
 
Agreement Signed in 1986
 The agreement was signed in 1986 after one of the most politically charged trade battles of the 1980's. The negotiations followed American complaints that Japan "dumped" memory chips -- sold them below their fair market value -- to drive American makers of dynamic random access memory chips out of the market. In fact, by the time the agreement was signed in 1986, most of the American makers of those chips had left the business. Even under the protection of the accord, none have re-entered it.
The reason for a new agreement is not clear. The Japanese practice of dumping ended several years ago. Critics of the accord say the practice would have stopped without an agreement, once the Japanese manufacturers gained more than an 80 percent share of the market -- and could raise prices at will.
Indeed, the agreement tended to raise prices, and computer makers have complained that the biggest losers were American consumers, who were forced to pay, indirectly, for higher-priced chips.
 
Retaliatory Tariffs
 Japanese electronics makers continue to be rankled by the Reagan Administration's decision in 1987 to impose retaliatory tariffs, after the United States accused the Japanese of failing to comply with the agreement in its first months. These companies have made little secret of their opposition to any extension.
"When the time comes that this agreement expires, our belief is that we will no longer need anything of this nature," Tsuyoshi Kawanishi, the senior executive vice president of the Toshiba Corporation and the head of its semiconductor operations, said last week.
For the Bush Administration, the prospect of a new accord also poses some difficult questions of economic ideology, mostly surrounding the Administration's avowed distaste for "managed trade."
One provision of the 1986 agreement, contained in a secret side letter, the text of which was widely circulated in Washington and Tokyo, set a target of 20 percent penetration of the Japanese market by American semiconductor makers.
The secrecy allowed Japan to maintain the polite fiction that it never committed itself to surrendering a fifth of its market. It also allowed the United States to contend that it was simply clearing away trade barriers so that American makers could freely compete.
Soon after she took office in 1989, Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, was harshly critical of the quota, saying it might serve as a limitation on American companies. But now the Bush Administration is under intense pressure from the American semiconductor industry to renew the 20 percent figure, which is now referred to as a goal rather than a quota.
"Our access, while improving, is still far short of 20 percent," Roger Mathus, who heads the Tokyo office of the Semiconductor Industry Association, told a meeting of journalists here today. A joint committee of American semiconductor makers and computer makers said in October that Japan's commitment to a 20 percent market share for foreign companies should be attained at the end of 1992, with perhaps a new target set for later years.
The success of the 1986 agreement is difficult to measure. The two sides still argue bitterly about who is at fault for the relatively poor performance of American chip makers in Japan, and they cannot agree on how much of the market the United States now holds.
The figures cited by American makers indicate that the United States now holds a little more than 13 percent of Japan's market, about three percentage points higher than in 1986. The market itself has grown enormously since 1986.
The Japanese say the market share of American makers is a few percentage points higher. Their numbers include "captive suppliers" like the International Business Machines Corporation, which makes chips in the United States and sells them to its Japanese subsidiary.
Most American suppliers here are now in strategic alliances with Japanese chip makers, sharing the cost of developing products. Others say they have enjoyed some modest success getting their chips designed into future Japanese cars, telecommunications equipment, facsimile machines and a few consumer electronics products, where American chip makers are weakest.
They argue that extending the agreement is important because its pressure is needed to keep Japan using American chips. "Things have gotten better in the last two years," Mr. Mathus said. "But two years is just not long enough to demonstrate the longevity of this."
 
Not Enough Designers
 Japanese companies contend that while the quality of American-made chips has improved, few companies have placed enough designers, support staff and fabrication operations in Japan to provide the kind of service that Japanese suppliers offer. And they argue, as they did five years ago, that the United States has few competitive offerings. American companies dismiss that: Texas Instruments says it produces 45,000 different types of chips and its market penetration in Japan is half its penetration elsewhere in the world. It is also one of the very few American companies that makes its chips here.
Under a new agreement, an elaborate system set up by the United States to assess the fair market value of Japanese chips is likely to be abandoned. Less certain is what will happen to the market access goal. Japanese press reports say the United States has already informally notified Tokyo that it will seek to renew the 20 percent figure. The Japanese contend the target constitutes government interference in the market and there is sufficient political pressure to assure that American market share will grow steadily.
Those American companies whose products Japan cannot replicate or live without do have booming businesses here. NEC and Toshiba are among the biggest customers of the Intel Corporation, which sells the microprocessors used in millions of Japanese portable and desktop computers.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Advances Overseas; Gold Falls a Bit in New York

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar advanced on foreign exchange markets yesterday, helped by a British interest rate drop and by signals that the major industrial nations do not want the United States currency to decline further.
Gold prices were mixed, falling slightly in New York after rising overseas. Gold fell 80 cents on the Commodity Exchange in New York, closing at $367.20 an ounce. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $366.55, down 20 cents. 
 The decline in British interest rates and a cut that is expected in Japanese rates helped send the dollar higher, said Robert Ryan, corporate foreign exchange manager for the Bank of New York.
The Bank of England cut its base rate by one-half of a percentage point, to 13.5 percent, making the pound a less attractive investment. All currencies are supported by higher rates in their home countries and lower rates abroad, so a drop in British yields is a positive sign for the dollar.
Analysts said the dollar was also aided by comments by United States and Japanese officials that the Group of Seven industrial nations did not want the dollar slide any further.
Treasury Under Secretary Charles H. Dallara said in a speech yesterday that the United States did not want a lower dollar. The Bank of Japan governor, Yasushi Mieno, said earlier that the Group of Seven would take coordinated steps to counter a sharp dollar decline. The group consists of Germany, Britain, France, Canada Italy, Japan and the United States.
Central bank intervention on Tuesday on behalf of the dollar also helped the currency yesterday.
The British pound fell to $1.9840 in New York from late Tuesday's $1.9910.
The dollar rose to 129.67 Japanese yen in New York, from 128.65 yen late Tuesday. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar rose to a closing 128.70 yen from 127.70; in London, it rose to 129.05 yen.
Against the German currency, the dollar rose in New York to 1.46395 marks, up from 1.4542.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's prices, included: 1.2530 Swiss francs, up from 1.2460; 4.9875 French francs, up from 4.9565; 1,100.75 Italian lire, up from 1,094.75, and 1.15365 Canadian dollars, up from 1.15355.
Earlier, gold rose in London to a late bid price of $367.50 a troy ounce, up from $365.95 late Tuesday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $367, up from $365.10. Hong Kong's gold market was closed for the week-long New Year holiday.
Silver rose 3.9 cents on the Commodity Exchange, closing at $3.743 a troy ounce. Earlier, silver rose in London to a late bid price of $3.75 an ounce, up from $3.70 on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: U.S.-Canada Air Travel

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13

 BODY:
Restrictions on air travel between the United States and Canada costs $9.5 billion a year in lost economic activity, according to a study released Tuesday. Liberalizing air travel rules could create up to 210,000 jobs, according to United States Airports for Better International Service, a coalition of 23 American cities, states and airport authorities. The group said limited seat capacity, restricted air routes and poorly situated air transport hubs caused slow growth in air travel between the countries.

HEADLINE: Agents Take Aim at Drugs in Projects

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER

 BODY:
The door of a ninth-floor apartment in a Brooklyn housing project swung open at daybreak yesterday, and Sgt. Jeffrey Cea lunged inside with his pistol drawn. With a grab of a shirt front, he swung a startled man into a hallway filled with police officers and Federal agents.
Within minutes, a half-dozen other people were yanked half-asleep out of other apartments in the Red Hook Houses as the New York City Housing Authority police and the Drug Enforcement Administration ended seven months of undercover work against two crack gangs that had been distributing to dealers throughout Brooklyn. 
 The joint operation was an example of how new law-enforcement power is being brought to bear in the city's housing projects, where drug distributors and dealers have outmaneuvered the thinly stretched ranks of the special housing police and have become a deeply entrenched criminal force, law-enforcement officials say.
"In the past we've targeted our agents on high-level international cases," said the head of the Drug Enforcement Administration in New York, Robert A. Bryden. "Now we're starting to divert some of our resources to work with the housing police."
 
'Little One-Upsmanship'
 Assistant Chief Joseph Keeney of the housing police said drug dealers and distributors can more easily conceal their activities in the projects, with their maze of hundreds of apartments in each building, than on the streets and tenements.
"They know the layouts of the projects," he said, "and this gives them a little one-upsmanship."
Apartments are used to store cash, drugs and equipment, Chief Keeney said, but often sales and deliveries take place on the streets outside the projects.
Crime in general in the city's 323 projects usually occurs at about half the rate of the city as a whole, said Val Coleman, a spokesman for the Housing Authority. But the 182 killings last year and 180 the year before, many of them involving drugs, gave public housing a murder rate about equal to that of the whole city.
 
'A Special Problem'
 "This says to us," Mr. Coleman said, "that guns and drugs are a special problem."
In one of their first operations together, the housing police and the Drug Enforcement Administration arrested 36 people and shut down a heroin distribution ring at the Lillian Wald Houses on the Lower East Side last May.
The investigation in the Red Hook Houses, a complex of 28 buildings with 8,000 residents, began with a casual conversation between a housing police undercover officer and a young woman who lived there.
In a short time, the woman, who was among those arrested yesterday, had introduced the agent to the leaders of the two gangs. Soon, about a dozen crack distributors were selling drugs to the housing officer and to Federal agents.
 
'He's O.K. He Ain't a Cop.'
 "It snowballed," said one drug enforcement investigator. "The other dealers saw one guy dealing with our guy, and everybody wanted a piece of the action."
One of the undercover housing officers, who spoke on condition that he not be identified, said the man whom Sergeant Cea pulled out of the apartment at 82 Dwight Street, identified as Wayne Franklin, 33 years old, was one of the first people who had offered to sell him crack.
"He did the negotiating," the undercover officer said. "He told the other guy, 'He's O.K. He ain't a cop.' "
On that advice, the police said, Alexander Williams, 32, handed over 50 vials of crack for $450 in cash. The police seized Mr. Williams in the apartment where Mr. Franklin had been arrested as Mr. Williams was rising from his bed and swung his feet to the floor.
The police also took 300 vials of crack from the apartment as well as a safe that two officers struggled to lift into an elevator.
 
'Hard-Working Man'
 Lying on the floor of the hallway in handcuffs, Mr. Franklin insisted he was an unemployed construction worker.
"I'm not in the cocaine business," he said. "I'm a hard-working man."
The chairwoman of the Housing Authority, Laura D. Blackburne, accompanied some of the nearly 100 police officers and Federal agents in the raids and announced that she was setting up a special telephone line, 1-718-HA-DRUGS, to receive anonymous reports from the city's half-million project residents of drug-dealing incidents.
"This line is direct to the police operations center," she said," and that means that if you spot drug activity something will be done about it and something will be done about it fast."
Saying she wanted to "get guns out of the projects," Ms. Blackburne also appealed to people to turn in weapons and promised that no criminal charges would be pursued in connection with them.
"I want those guns out of circulation," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Laura D. Blackburne, chairwoman of the Housing Authority, led Drug Enforcement Administration and New York City Housing Authority police in anundercover drug operation in Red Hook Houses complex in Brooklyn. Man on floor was Wayne Franklin, suspected of being a crack dealer. (Jim Estrin for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Police Plan New Version Of Foot Duty

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL

 BODY:
The vision of a new activist police force -- blanketing city streets with foot patrols, defusing crime before it happens and organizing neighborhoods -- was set forth yesterday by New York City officials charting the next stage of a sweeping, if still clouded, police reform program.
The changes, termed revolutionary by Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown at a City Hall briefing, are part of a blueprint for restructuring the department into a modernized version of the beat system abandoned decades ago. It followed this week's approval in Albany of a tax package to finance the expansion of the department to a record total of 31,400 officers, from the present 26,809, over the next three years. 
 Through the tax package and various economies, the number of officers in uniform would increase by 24 percent and the number of officers on patrol by more than 50 percent.
 
Precincts to Be Phased In
 Under the plan announced yesterday, one model precinct, the 72d in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn, would be totally converted to the new system of community policing by April. The 74 other precincts would be phased in by 1994.
Officials said the plan, aimed at explaining how an expanded Police Department would be deployed, would mean the following for New Yorkers by 1994:
*Almost all uniformed officers would be assigned specific territory, amounting to just a few blocks in many neighborhoods, and would collect intelligence on emerging problems, like drug trafficking and prostitution.
*The officers would be, in effect, community organizers and advocates, empowered to devise creative solutions to persistent problems.
*Precinct detectives would be given specific territory as their primary responsibility, instead of working cases throughout the precinct.
*Nonemergency calls to 911 would be diverted to individual precinct officers most familiar with local conditions.
Beyond patrolling, the plan foresees changes in virtually every aspect of police organization, including the recruiting, screening and training of officers and the creation of new ways to link rewards to performance.
But much about the planned transformation remained unclear, including such central questions as: Which neighborhoods deserve the most protection? How large will the officers' territories be? How will officers be retrained for their new responsibilities?
There are also questions about how eager officers will be to exercise their new responsibilities as community organizers and whether the police bureaucracy, which has stifled initiatives in the past, will respond positively to the changes. It also was not clear how well officers would interact with growing numbers of civilian employees.
One sensitive area is the intention to form peer groups in each precinct to review the performance of officers. The police unions have traditionally held that only supervisors can judge performance.
 
'Hardest' Step Acknowledged
 Both Mr. Brown and Mayor David N. Dinkins acknowledged the uncertainties of the plan at the City Hall briefing. The Mayor called it "a detailed second step, a careful strategy for change." But he added, "The third step, and the hardest, is implementation of the innovative strategies and the aggressive schedule."
The Police Commissioner, who has made community policing a leitmotif of his earlier career in Oregon, Atlanta and Houston, also called the changes "evolutionary" because, he said, "they will take time to achieve." But he added: "Organizationally and philosophically it is indeed revolutionary."
Initial reaction to the plan was cautious and fragmentary, reflecting in part its scope, lack of specifics and long secrecy. The report, titled "Policing New York City in the 1990's," was prepared over six months by three consultants -- Georgette S. Bennett, Stephen J. Gaffigan and Robert Wasserman -- working with a committee of department chiefs under the First Deputy Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly.
Thomas Reppetto, president of the Citizens Crime Commission, a business-sponsored watchdog group and usually an outspoken commentator on law-enforcement issues, was uncharacteristically noncomittal. "The bottom line is how well they translate this into reality on the local level," he said.
 
Some Initial Resistance
 Lieut. Roger Perrino, an integrity control officer in the 34th Precinct in upper Manhattan, said: "I think it absolutely can be achieved. It's just going to take time."
But other officers -- who did not want their names used -- voiced resistance, particularly detectives in precinct squads who bridled at the idea of being assigned to territories.
Perhaps the main feature of the new plan is a commitment to provide a "community policing presence" -- that is, one or more police officers for every neighborhood in the city. Some precinct and community board boundaries may also have to be redrawn so neighborhoods are not divided, the report suggested.
Mr. Brown cautioned that every street would not have its own officer, but rather that every street would be the responsibility of one designated officer or group.
With redeployments and the expansion of the force by 1994, the number of available officers for specific neighborhood duty will increase dramatically from some 750 to 17,400, plus 3,991 precinct supervisors and detectives, the report said.
 
Innovative Solutions Sought
 Currently each of the 75 precincts has at least one team of 10 foot-patrol officers in the Community Patrol Officers Program, but most are stretched too thin to cover all parts of the precinct.
The more than 21,000 officers, supervisors and detectives available for neighborhood duty under the new plan would be encouraged to devise innovative solutions to head off crime problems, like lights for dark alleys. Creativity would be prized and rewards devised to elevate patrol from a largely disdained to a prestigious function.
To obtain proper neighborhood officers, screening, recruiting and training would all have to be revamped to stress the service nature of the job instead of adventurism, the report said. It recommended raising the cutoff age for a police officer to 35 from the current 29 to widen the pool of candidates.
One of the plan's more provocative aspects is revamping the 911 emergency call system, which the department considers vastly overused. At present eight million calls a year are received, only half of which result in the dispatching of a police officer. But even the four million remaining calls consume some 90 percent of the time of all radio-car officers.
The plan foresees nearly doubling to 1,800 the number of radio cars on duty in a 24-hour period, allowing radio-car officers to spend no more than 60 percent of their time responding to emergencies and the rest walking around their neighborhoods.

HEADLINE: Demand Is Brisk for New York Bonds

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
Two days after a rating agency downgraded New York City's bonds, New York City officials sold $1 billion in bonds yesterday and said they found demand strong, suggesting the downgrading had little effect.
But despite what officials viewed as heartening news, the city continues to pay a steep price for its fiscal problems, paying far higher interest to attract bond buyers than it did before the city's current fiscal problems surfaced last October. 
 By late yesterday, prices on longer-term tax-exempt bonds were set to yield 8.35 percent to investors, about the same levels the bonds were trading at in the days before Moody's Investors Service cut the city's rating to the second-lowest investment-grade rating.
By one count -- measuring the change in the city's interest rates against the changes for other similar bonds -- the city is now paying about a full percentage point more in interest than it did last September.
Underwriters said there was strong demand for many of the bonds, particularly the $800 million in tax-exempt bonds that made up most of the issue. As a result, the city added $50 million more in bonds to the sale late yesterday and negotiated a slightly lower interest cost on $300 million of the issue.
 
Stable Market for City Bonds
 City officials hailed the sale as a clear demonstration that there was a stable market for city bonds despite months of declining revenues and worries over a growing city budget gap. "It would be nice to be boring for a change," said Darcy Bradbury, a deputy city comptroller.
Even so, the officials acknowledged that the city continued to pay considerably higher rates than state and local governments whose bonds had similar investment-grade ratings. Yields to investors on New York City bonds rose sharply in October, when Mr. Dinkins first warned that there would be a budget gap. The gap has grown to about $3 billion over 19 months.
The Moody's downgrading had little effect, they said, because the city's tax-exempt bonds were already selling at rates comparable to bonds that had already been downgraded.
Stanley Ciemniecki, an executive vice president at Lehman Brothers, which led a syndicate of 22 underwriting firms, said yesterday's sale and another large one last December "prove there has been a definite market, good demand, established for New York City securities." But he acknowledged that the demand came "at a high price."
If the city is paying about 1 percent more than it would have without the fiscal problems, the higher rate would translate into $1 million more a year in interest rates for each $100 million in bonds outstanding. The terms of the bonds range from one to 30 years. Assuming all the bonds were for 15 years, the extra interest paid because of the city's financial troubles would total $142 million.
 
An Ambitious Plan
 On Monday, Moody's announced that it had downgraded $16 billion in city bonds, including yesterday's issue, from A to Baa1, because of concern that the Dinkins administration might have difficulty carrying out an ambitious plan to pare down city goverment.
Another rating agency, Standard & Poor's, also considered downgrading the city's bonds but decided instead to reaffirm its previous rating of A-, while warning that the city's outlook remained negative.
But when city bonds maturing in 15 years are compared against bonds from other cities and states, the city paid 1.15 percentage points more than on typical bonds rated Baa by Moody's -- its lowest investment grade rating.
While the tax-exempt bonds sold well, some of the $200 million in taxable bonds included in the sale attracted few buyers. The city agreed to change the yields on the bonds offered and increase their maturity dates. The longest-term taxable bonds, due in 2010, were priced to yield 10.95.
City officials conceded that the Moody's downgrading might have affected the demand for the bonds. Major buyers of tax-exempt bonds have long been familiar with the city's fiscal strengths, they said, but buyers of relatively new taxable issues are not.
 
Largest Borrower
 City officials attribute at least some of the city's higher costs to the fact that it is the largest borrower in the municipal marketplace -- borrowing more than $4 billion a year -- rather than to the city's fiscal uncertainties. Some of the city's traditional buyers -- like bond mutual funds -- already have about as many city bonds as their company rules allow them to hold.
But some bond traders say that with the city facing such heavy future borrowing needs, more bad news, including further downgradings, could yet raise the city's costs in selling bonds.
To attract new buyers for the city bonds, city officials have been trying to set up new marketing devices, including bonds with variable interest rates and zero-coupon "CitySaver" bonds, which are sold at a discount and pay no interest. Yesterday's sale included $60 million in zero-coupon bonds.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Holds Court at a Town Meeting in Queens

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins, in his first foray under a new strategy for getting his message out to the public, charmed and cajoled a warm audience last night as he took easy control of a town meeting at Forest Hills High School in Queens.
Although only about 400 people showed up to take seats in an auditorium that holds 1,100, many seemed impressed by the Mayor's efforts to reach them. 
 Mr. Dinkins was relaxed and amiable, even laughing when he was mistakenly referred to as Mayor Koch, as he fielded a barrage of questions about firehouse closings, the economy, crime and education.
Many wanted to know what Mr. Dinkins was doing to keep the middle class in a city that corporations are fleeing and where crime is increasing.
 
'A Nut for Kids'
 Mr. Dinkins's answer was that he was trying to streamline government to do more for less.
He told Jane Brody, a teacher worried about education cuts, that he was "a nut for kids" who "cares desperately about education."
As an example, he cited the controversial 5.5 percent wage increase teachers won in negotiations with him.
He told Maria Kaplan, who said that lives were at stake with the closing of Engine Company 294: "I wish we could have an engine company on every two blocks. We don't have the capacity to do that."
Much of last night's meeting was an attempt by Mr. Dinkins to convey what his administration is doing to improve the quality of life in a city whose resources are dwindling.
He plans to hold a series of town meetings to help combat what he acknowledges is a difficulty in conveying his message to the public.
 
Meetings Planned Last Year
 He announced plans for the series last August, when residents were demanding to know what he was going to do about the summer's wave of crime.
City officials said yesterday that the meetings were delayed as the administration confronted new fiscal bad news and began wrangling with the City Council.
Last night, buoyed by the passage of his anti-crime bill in Albany, Mr Dinkins and an entourage that included the police, fire, parks and finance commissioners, took his show on the road. The 90-minute question-and-answer format was similar to the forums held by his predecessor, Edward I. Koch.
The first reviews said Mr. Dinkins was doing a better job than Mr. Koch under difficult circumstances.
"He was open, he was flexible," said Marion A. Howe, an administrative assistant who lives in Queens Village. "There's no comparison to Koch. He's better. I hear what this man has to say."
"I think he's trying his best," said Janack Surujnauth, a private duty nurse in Rego Park. "It's a difficult situation with the economy and everything that is going on. He thinks before he says something. Koch would just say something."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mayor David N. Dinkins during yesterday's town meeting at Forest Hills High School in Queens. (Vic DeLucia/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

HEADLINE: Weicker Proposes an Income Tax In Fiscal Overhaul for Connecticut

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Feb. 13

 BODY:
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. tonight proposed to overhaul Connecticut's tax system by imposing a personal income tax on wages beginning on July 1 while cutting the state's 8 percent sales tax almost in half.
The changes, which Mr. Weicker said would lay the foundation for a recovery from recession as well as help the state close a $2.4 billion budget gap, would leave little of the state's current system of raising and spending public money untouched. 
 An income tax, which could be enacted only through the action of the state legislature, the General Assembly, would end Connecticut's status as a tax haven from its neighbors, all of which have personal income taxes. Connecticut is one of only 10 states that do not tax wages.
Budget officials said the new income tax, when combined with a cut in the sales tax -- now the highest statewide rate in the nation -- would reduce the total tax burden on Connecticut's poorest families while raising the state taxes paid by most residents.
 
Debacle of '71
 It also thrusts Mr. Weicker, a former Republican who was elected last year as an independent Governor with no members of his own party in the Assembly, into the center of an issue that has worried and divided Connecticut for decades. Mr. Weicker's predecessor, William A. O'Neill, a Democrat, vowed for 10 years to veto any bill calling for an income tax, and left his party, which controls both chambers of the Assembly, deeply divided on the question. The Republicans, members of Mr. Weicker's former party, have been almost completely united in their opposition, and tonight showed no sign of bending.
Many members in both parties still recall the great debacle of 1971, when the Assembly actually passed an income tax. It lasted a matter of weeks before being repealed under a storm of public protest.
The co-chairman of the Assembly's joint tax-writing committee, Representative Richard T. Mulready, a Democrat from West Hartford, said tonight that he would push for the plan, but he a gave a 50-50 chance of passage, at best.
Mr. Weicker said in defending his proposals: "This plan takes care of the past and starts tomorrow today. Without it, our Connecticut, as we envision it, would slip away."
Under Mr. Weicker's proposal, the sales tax would be reduced to 4.25 percent but would be expanded to include many items that are now exempt, including gasoline, movies and haircuts, though the exemption for groceries would be retained. A 13.8 percent tax on corporate profits, now the highest in the nation, would be cut to 11.5 percent.
 
A Flat Rate of 6%
 Existing taxes on dividends and interest, with a top rate of 14 percent, and on capital gains, with a rate of 7 percent, would be eliminated. Instead, all personal income would be taxed at a flat rate of 6 percent.
The plan, presented tonight to the General Assembly and broadcast live to the state on television, was linked to a series of deep cuts in spending that would slash about $1.1 billion from agency budgets and eliminate about 1,800 jobs from the state payroll, including 1,100 layoffs.
"Few in a generation have the chance to make history," Mr. Weicker told lawmakers. "Everyone within and without this chamber starts at such a threshold this evening."
Mr. Weicker, a former United States Senator, repeatedly couched his proposals in terms of dark contrast to what the other options might have been to resolve the state's huge revenue shortfall. The phrasing, combined with the stringent cuts in spending, seemed aimed at allaying the great fear that has surrounded the introduction of a wage tax for the state -- that it would lead to out-of-control increases in spending.
 
Decline in Spending
 For example, Mr. Weicker said that under his plan the income tax would become overnight the biggest single source of state revenue, with a projected collection of $2.1 billion in the first year. But the overall size of the general fund budget would actually decline by 2.8 percent in the year that begins on July 1, to $6.8 billion, not counting such one-time expenditures as the cost of setting up the wage tax system. The total budget, including capital spending for transportation, would be $7.4 billion.
Several lawmakers said the fact that the Governor had stepped out front to sponsor and endorse an income tax would make it easier for some Assembly members to go along.
"The key element here is that a lot of people now have political cover," said Mr. Mulready, the co-chairman of the Assembly's Finance Revenue and Bonding Committee. "People can say, 'You elected him to settle this problem, and while I don't neccessarily agree with his tax, let's give him a shot.' "
 
'War on the Middle Class'
 But Representative Richard Foley Jr., a Republican from Oxford who is also his party's state chairman, said, "It's a declaration of war on the middle class."
Revenue from the state's two main taxes, the corporate profits tax and the sales tax, which together account for more than half of the budget, have plummeted. Collections under the state's 13.8 percent corporate tax were projected last year, for example, to raise $958 million for the year that ends on July 1. Actual collections are now expected to fall almost 20 percent short of that target as companies earn less money, or lose money, in the recession.
Collections from the sales tax are also expected to fall well below last year's level, as residents have cut back on consumer purchases, especially the major household appliances that were linked to the now dashed 1980's real-estate spiral of buying, building and furnishing new homes.
But, as Mr. Weicker and legislators repeatedly pointed out in the weeks leading up to tonight's address, simply filling in the blanks with tax increases and spending cuts was only half of the equation. The less tangible aspects over which Mr. Weicker in particular has publicly wrestled concerned who must bear the burden and how the overall package could affect an economy already in recession.
Mr. Weicker sought to retain all options. But he said again and again during the campaign that imposing an income tax during a time of economic stress would be like "pouring gasoline on a fire."

GRAPHIC: Graph: 'Big Responsibility For the New Tax' shows proposed figures for Connecticut's revenues in '91 and '92 (Source: Office of Policy Management (pg. B8)
 
Table: 'Impact of the New Tax Plan' compares taxes owed by Connecticut families under current law and the tax they would owe under Gov. Weicker's proposal
 
Chart: 'Taxes in the Region'
 The personal income tax proposed by Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. would impose a flat rate, compared with graduated rates in New York and New Jersey.
 
Connecticut
 A flat 6 percent tax would be imposed on adjusted gross income reported on Federal tax forms - that is, before deductions - in excess of $25,000 for couples, and $12,500 for individuals.
 
New York
 A graduated tax is imposed on adjusted gross income minus deductions, ranging from a beginning rate of 3.9 percent and rising to a top rate of 7.875 percent on income over $65,000.
 
New Jersey
 A 3.5 percent tax is imposed on adjusted gross income of up to $70,000 for couples and $35,000 for individuals. The rate then rises to a maximum of 7 percent on income over $150,000 for couples and $75,000 for individuals. (pg. B8)

HEADLINE: Travel Resurges Across U.S. As Americans Adjust to War

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 13

 BODY:
Almost a month has passed since the country went to war, and many Americans are tying yellow ribbons to their car antennas and heading off for a long weekend of skiing or sightseeing.
Although the recession and fears of possible terrorism have depressed the travel industry for weeks, spokesmen for travel, hotel, cruise and recreation companies and spot-checks at dozens of tourist destinations show signs that people are beginning to relax and enjoy themselves again. 
 War is still on people's minds, and visitors to Mel's Diner at Universal Studios in Hollywood are plucking the tiny paper American flags off their hamburgers and sticking them into their lapels.
But after a sharp drop in travel and bookings in the first weeks of the war, people in the travel industry say they see an easing in what they had come to call "the CNN effect" in which the television news took over lives.
"When the war first started I didn't want to leave the television set, let alone travel," said Bridgid McDonnell, a nanny who was visiting Universal Studios this week from her home in Washington, D.C. "But your interest becomes less and less. You begin to feel that the war is going to go on for a long time, and you begin to adjust to it."
One reason for the signs of a possible upturn in domestic travel, say a number of people in the industry, is a cutback in travel abroad because of fears of terrorism.
"People are coming in and asking about places like Santa Fe, N.M.," said Estelle Lessack, who heads Travel Trends, a small agency in Fort Lee, N.J. "There is definitely a fear about crossing the water."
Shawn Flaherty, a spokeswoman at the Travel Industry Association, said that although the industry as a whole was suffering in the recession, a number of travel sectors were reporting signs of improvement after big drops at the start of the war.
 
Signs of a Comeback
 "People are telling me that the short-term effects were a drastic downturn," she said. "But they are encouraged because bookings are coming back compared to Jan. 15."
In Boston, landmarks along the Freedom Trail got high attendance as travelers apparently cancel more expensive or distant trips, said Nina Zannieri, director of the Paul Revere House.
In New York, the number of visitors to the Empire State Building has been up recently, although officials there say that may have been because of unusually mild weather.
Washington, where security concerns are perhaps more pronouced than other destinations, remained an exception. Group visits by schoolchildren have been canceled at the Kennedy Center and at landmarks controlled by the National Park Service. The Smithsonian Institution reported that 100,000 fewer people had visited its museums so far this year than in the same period last year. And museum officials said they did not expect much of a turnaround soon.
 
Has Fear Peaked?
 With some airlines, cruise companies and resorts offering special rates and with no terrorist incidents in this country, some large travel agencies report an increase in bookings in the past week.
"We may have seen the fear hit its peak," said Steve Heydt, the vice president of marketing for Liberty Travel, a chain with 165 offices on the East Coast.
He said that in the past few days, for the first time this year, bookings at some offices were higher than during the same week last year.
Henry Blinder, vice president of marketing for Thomas Cook, said that travel "right now seems to be on the rebound," including record bookings with a businessmen's service called Thomas Cook Express.
He said that leisure travel had dropped 15 to 20 percent since the Persian Gulf war started but that price cutting by airlines and special offerings by the cruise industry had helped bring back business.
At the American Hotel and Motel Association, Michele Kelley, a spokeswoman, said "the phones are ringing" after a severe slump.
Michael Ribero, senior vice president of marketing for the Hilton Hotels Corporation in Los Angeles, also reported the beginnings of a resurgence after what he called the worst tailspin the United States travel industry had experienced. "The days after the Persian Gulf crisis began were literally the days the earth stood still for the travel industry," he said.
 
Economic Factors Cited
 Delta Airlines is booking about 7,200 passengers per day traveling to and from the Boston area, he said, compared to about 7,000 bookings during this period last year. American Airlines has booked 5 percent more passengers than last year. And the number of Northwest Airlines bookings has gone from about 8,000 to 8,400 per day.
"Total numbers for the year will probably be down, but this weekend people are traveling," he said.
John Garrish, a 21-year-old painter from Scituate, Mass., said he was going ahead with a trip to visit his girlfriend in San Francisco. He had postponed it when war broke out because "nobody really knew what Saddam Hussein was up to." Now he was headed for the airport.
"I don't want to sound corny," he said, "but some things just can't wait forever."
Tim Smith, a spokesman for American Airlines, said its recent cut in fares had brought more bookings and travel, and several industry analysts attributed a boost in travel to a half-price promotion by America West.
Mr. Smith said domestic air travel was affected more by the economy than by the war, and was slow even before Jan. 15.
A spokesman for Amtrak, Pat Kelly, said business had remained basically steady over the past months, with rail travel less dependent than air or road travel on fluctuating oil prices.
At the Breakers in Palm Beach, Fla., Gretchen deWeese, acting director of public relations for the hotel, said, "There was a lull right around the 15th, 16th, 17th of January." But she said this had been softened by an increase in bookings by groups that had canceled trips to Europe.
Spokesmen for cruise lines also said they were doing well after a sharp drop in bookings in the middle of January. For Carnival Cruise Lines, Jan. 28 was the fifth-busiest day and Feb. 4 was the third- busiest day in the 17-year history of the company, said a spokesman, Tim Gallagher.
At the Chamber of Commerce in Aspen, Colo., Carol Pasternak said snow conditions were excellent and bookings this year have been up from last year every week except for the week of Jan. 13.
At Universal Studios Florida, Matthew L. Palmer, a spokesman, said, "The gulf war and the recession haven't affected us."
Gamblers seemed to be somewhat more hesitant than skiers or movie buffs, as bookings slumped and hotels continued to lay off employees. But with an eye out for a switch in fortune, the Las Vegas Convention and Visitors Authority is plugging for more visitors.
"After the war we pulled our television spots for two weeks because at that time, when people were still pretty much in shock about the war, we thought it was in poor taste," said a spokesman, Rob Powers. "But we've started up again in the last few days."

HEADLINE: White House Details 5-Year Transit Plan

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13

 BODY:
The Bush Administration today proposed to Congress a five-year, $105 billion program of Federal aid to the states for highways and mass transit that would increase combined highway spending by the Federal and state governments by one-third in 1992.
But whether the states can afford their share of such a program is a major point of disagreement in what is expected to be a contentious debate over programs that affect almost everybody every day. 
 Another contested issue is the contention by advocates of mass transit that the program shortchanges public transportation in favor of highway spending. The program includes an overhaul of the nation's major roads, creating a new network of Federal highways.
The broad outlines of the bill, drafted over the past two years, have been known for some time. Its particulars were met with considerable skepticism by groups that are to join in the debate.
 
Skinner Predicts Approval
 Congress must enact a new bill by September, when the current five-year law expires.
Stressing the proposal's potential for eventually reducing traffic congestion and increasing economic productivity,Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner predicted that Congress would accept most of the Administration's recommendations.
"We are submitting a good bill," he said at a White House appearance with President Bush this morning. "We believe our agenda will receive broad support on the Hill."
But Representative Robert A. Roe, the New Jersey Democrat who is chairman of the House Public Works and Transportation Committee, withheld endorsement.
"The Administration proposal has some good ideas, but I am concerned that in some cases they are masking reduced funding with philosophy and rhetoric," he said. "I don't know how the states, with all their financial problems, are going to come up with the money that's needed." His committee will hold hearings on the proposal beginning next week.
 
Criticism on Mass Transit
 Although several lawmakers criticized the Administration for barely increasing spending on mass transit, the proposal's highway provisions are likely to prove appealing. The plan calls for a rapid increase in Federal aid to local projects, and the money that will be spent has already been raised, thanks to the increase last year in the Federal tax on gasoline.
But to match the increased Federal aid with their own contributions, many states may have to further increase their own gasoline taxes. The National Conference of State Legislatures said today that over half the states would consider such increases this year.
If the bill becomes law, it could mean a major infusion of money into road building projects almost immediately. Such projects traditionally have been a major stimulus to local economies gripped by recession.
The Administration estimated that $14.3 billion in Federal funds and an additional $4.9 billion in state funds would be spent in 1992, the first year of the program, an increase of more than a third over highway spending in the current fiscal year. By 1996, state and Federal highway spending would reach $27.6 billion.
The Federal share of highway spending would total about $87 billion over the five year period.
 
More Jobs Projected
 The Transportation Department said that for every $1 billion in capital investment under the program, about 10,000 construction jobs could be generated. The new jobs would in turn carry the stimulus throughout the economy, the department argued.
The Administration's most striking proposal calls for a new 150,000-mile network of highways that includes both the 47,000-mile Interstate Highway System and a vast new network of other major highways. Almost all these roads already exist. But the highway program envisions widening many of them and making some of them resemble Interstates.
These roads, which will be selected on the basis of traffic volume and the importance of the economic centers they link, will be given most of the Federal highway funds.
At least 700,000 miles of roads would also be eligible for Federal aid but at lower levels than the major national highways.
The program also includes money for repairing and replacing bridges, rising to $2.8 billion in 1996 from $1.8 billion in 1992.
There would be other notable changes in financing. For example, for the first time Federal funds could be used to pay for toll highways, and in some cases the private sector would build and operate toll roads.
Although spending on highways would increase markedly under the proposal, the percentage contributed by the Federal Government would decline. For example, in the program of the network of national highways the Federal share would be only 75 percent, as against its contribution of up to 90 percent during construction of the Interstate highways.
In contrast to the highway program, Federal spending on mass transit would increase only slightly, rising slowly from the current year's level of $3.2 billion to about $3.3 billion in 1996.
There would be major changes in how the mass transit money is distributed, including sharp reductions in Federal payments for operating expenses, and the increased use of traffic patterns, rather than political decisions, to determine which states get the most money.
Jack Gilstrap, executive vice president of the American Public Transit Association, a lobbying group for local transit agencies, called the proposal "a recipe for more traffic jams, air pollution and wasted energy."
But Administration officials defended the plan, pointing out that unlike previous transportation programs it would allow state and local officials to choose for themselves whether to spend large parts of the Federal aid for local roads or mass transit.
Hal Rives, Commissioner of Transportation in Georgia and president of the American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials, said: "The concept is good. But the funding is clearly inadequate to meet our national transportation needs, and what money is there is not fairly distributed."

HEADLINE: Soldiers and Barbie Aiming at Nintendo

BYLINE: By CAROL LAWSON

 BODY:
THE noise of war was deafening, and a lone soldier dressed in beige desert camouflage stood ready for battle. But this soldier, a 6-foot-tall mannequin, held in his hand not a lethal weapon but a new board game, "A Line in the Sand," in which the allied forces fight the army of Iraq on a map of the Middle East.
That was the scene in one showroom this week at the 88th American International Toy Fair. In another, there was familiar background music, a song that most Americans stay up to hear once a year way past their bedtimes. 
 "There she is, Miss America. . . . "
And there she really was. Miss America, Marjorie Judith Vincent, regally attired, beauty-queen style, in a body-hugging, neckline-plunging black and gold gown. She was there to introduce "Miss America," a new line of beauty-queen dolls that are packaged with individual names and identities. Raquel, for one, is "a majorette with political aspirations."
War-related toys and new dolls were among the attractions at the fair, the industry's annual shopping spree. Twenty-thousand buyers came to play with new toys, climb into the mindsets of children and bet on merchandise that will line the shelves of toy stores. The fair, which is open to the trade only, continues at several Manhattan sites through Wednesday.
The toy fair is always a mixture of the serious and the silly, and this year was no exception: a buyer could place an order for millions of dollars' worth of merchandise and then bump into a gigantic Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtle roaming the corridors. But with the country faced by an economic recession and war in the Persian Gulf, the mood was more somber and unsettled than usual.
This year's fair came at a time of dismal toy sales and worries about the futures of some well-known manufacturers and retailers. George D. Ditomassi, chairman of the Toy Manufacturers of America Inc., the trade association that sponsors the show, reported at a news conference that retail sales were $13.4 billion last year, virtually unchanged from the previous year.
There is also controversy within the industry over the propriety of toys that capitalize on the war. David Miller, president of the Toy Manufacturers of America, said that while increases in sales of model kits and action figures related to combat were inevitable, he found some war-related toys "tasteless."
At TSR Inc., the manufacturer of "A Line in the Sand," there was much debate over the game. "It took a lot of soul-searching to bring this out," said Justin McCormack, TSR's West Coast publisher. "We expected that people would question our intentions, but since they are aboveboard, to provide an educational simulation, we feel we are doing the right thing."
Kenner is also aware of a potential image problem with its stuffed Proudheart Bear, which it rushed into production after American troops were sent to Saudi Arabia last August. The bear is white, with a heart-shaped version of the American flag across its chest. Ginger Kent, Kenner's vice president for marketing, said the company is "internally arguing" about what to do with profits from the bear. "All or part of the proceeds will go to charity," she said.
Mattel 's new All-American Barbie, dressed in denim with patches of stars and stripes, is attracting "a strong response from retail buyers," said Glenn Bozarth, vice president for corporate communications. "The line was in development prior to the war, but it was obviously well timed."
As for other toys, among the nearly 6,000 new items on display were several designed to exploit a growing interest for many children: the environment. These included kits that allow children to test air and water for pollution, action figures that are environmental heroes and board games with names like Recycling and Earthalert. Two new lines of action figures, Toxic Crusaders and Captain Planet, not only emphasize concern for the environment but, like an increasing number of toys, are also packaged with recycled material.
Buyers saw a multitude of scaled-down replicas of professional wrestling heroes, high-speed racing cars that are controlled with a turn of a glove worn by the operator, an electronic game that transforms the television screen into a full-color drawing pad, dolls based on the film "The Little Mermaid" and numerous Saturday morning television shows, and an electronic learning aid for -- yes! -- the crib. The manufacturer, Video Technology , says a baby can press the keypad to make five different animals "talk."
This year manufacturers introduced an unusual number of new action figures. They say they hope these toys will benefit from a slowing in the growth of Nintendo video games.
The success of Nintendo, which does not exhibit at the fair, hung like a dark cloud, as it has for the last five years. Manufacturers of traditional toys complain that Nintendo, which reported sales of $3.4 billion in the United States last year, has stunted the growth of the rest of the toy business.
"They accuse us of being the Grinch that stole Christmas," said Peter T. Main, vice president of marketing for Nintendo of America Inc.
Toy industry analysts say Nintendo's future largely depends on the growth of Game Boy, a hand-held system, and a more powerful 16-computer-bit system that will be on the market later this year.
For girls there were dolls that slurp and burp and make funny faces. There was also one that eats a fake chocolate ice cream cone. Hasbro , the manufacturer, decided that little girls would like nothing better than to clean up the mess.
Larry Carlat, editor of Toy & Hobby World, said he saw "nothing that will get the industry out of its five-year slump, no compelling toy that is going to bring people back into the stores."
Sean McGowan, a toy industry analyst for Gerard, Klauer, Mattison & Company, a securities brokerage firm, was more optimistic. "Everybody has the sense there is nothing hot," he said. "But guess what: There will be something hot. Nobody knows where it will come from."
Dan Lauer offers an answer. Mr. Lauer, a 30-year-old former banker from St. Louis, decided that life behind a desk was "non-creative." So he quit his job as a bank vice president to chase his dream: he wanted to invent a doll. He assembled it with condoms and balloons and filled it with water. Thus his Water Babies were born.
Most major toy companies were not impressed. But Playmates , which made a fortune with another toy that had its share of rejections, Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles, said yes. The company liked this water-filled doll because "it jiggles, like a real baby," said Richard Sallis, senior vice president. Playmates has since refined the doll from its condom stage and plans to promote it with $3 million in advertising.
"You can imagine the abuse I took from my friends for playing with dolls," Mr. Lauer remarked. "But now they all want to work for me."
