HEADLINE: SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
Will the Mets Sign 'Enough Pitching?'

BYLINE: By Dave Anderson

 BODY:
For decades, the Yankees were known as the "best franchise in sports" until, bluster by bluster, George Steinbrenner destroyed it. With the title vacated, several franchises in various sports can argue that with their success over the years each now deserves to be hailed as the best. The San Francisco 49ers. The Boston Celtics, the Los Angeles Lakers. The Edmonton Oilers. And in baseball, the Oakland Athletics, the Los Angeles Dodgers.
But in a casual moment last year, Frank Cashen, whose Mets title is now senior executive vice president as well as chief operating officer and general manager, proposed that the Mets were now the best franchise. 
 After all, Cashen explained, the Mets were always a contender, the Mets were always above or approaching the three million mark in attendance, the Mets had a fat television contract, the Mets had a national appeal, the Mets had a productive farm system, the Mets had two owners (Nelson Doubleday and Fred Wilpon) who didn't try to upstage the team.
"The Mets," Cashen concluded, "are now the best franchise in sports."
At the time, the Mets were also the best second-place team in baseball. Until proven otherwise, they still are. But if the Mets are to justify Cashen's boast as being "the best franchise in sports," he must justify his favorite baseball phrase.
"You never have enough pitching," Cashen likes to say.
If you never have enough pitching, you never quibble about signing Dwight Gooden and Frank Viola to new contracts. No matter how many millions it takes. No matter how many millions Roger Clemens collected from the Boston Red Sox last week: $21,521,000 over four years, a $5.38 million average. That's a new high in a baseball economy that doesn't recognize the recession in the national economy.
But according to Al Harazin, who negotiates the Mets' salaries, the Clemens contract will make it "difficult" for the Mets to sign both Gooden and Viola.
What's so difficult? Harazin presumably understands Cashen's belief that "you never have enough pitching." Harazin presumably understands Cashen's belief that the Mets are the "best franchise in sports." If those two tenets are observed, the "best franchise" will assure itself "enough pitching" by signing both Gooden and Viola soon in order to eliminate the possibility that either or both will test the free-agent market after the season ends.
Only time will determine the wisdom of Cashen and Harazin in allowing Darryl Strawberry to join the Dodgers as a free agent. If they were to allow Gooden or Viola, or both, to depart, Cashen and Harazin will risk being linked in infamy to their front-office predecessor, M. Donald Grant, who traded Tom Seaver to the Cincinnati Reds in 1977.
Without Strawberry's bat, the Mets will be depending on Gooden and Viola more than ever before. Of the other 25 major league teams, only the Athletics possess two such premier pitchers: Dave Stewart and Bob Welch. Stewart is now in the first year of a two-year $7 million contract, a $3.5 million average. Welch recently signed a four-year $13.8 million contract, a $3.45 million average.
But now that Clemens will be earning more than $5 million annually, Gooden and Viola understandably deserve to be considered at that plateau.
Over the last seven seasons, Viola has a 126-86 record, Gooden 119-48 and Clemens 116-51. In earned run average, Gooden is low at 2.82, with Clemens at 2.89 and Viola at 3.38. Clemens has the most strikeouts with 1,424, to Gooden's 1,391 and Viola's 1,258.
In last season's stats, Clemens was 21-6 with a 1.93 earned run average and 209 strikeouts, Viola was 20-12, 2.67 and 182, Gooden was 19-7, 3.83 and 223.
Looking to future durability, Clemens, who will be 29 years old in August, had a sore shoulder late last season. Gooden, who was 26 in November, had a sore shoulder the year before that limited him to a 9-4 reccord in only 17 starts. Viola, who will be 31 in April, has been an iron man, averaging nearly 250 innings and about 36 starts in each of the last eight seasons.
The pitching arm is the most fragile item in sports. Any pitcher's career might end with his next pitch, meaning that a team can be stuck with a multimillion-dollar contract. But because a dominant pitcher is so rare, teams assume the financial risk.
Even a not-so-dominant pitcher, like Bud Black, was signed as a free agent by the San Francisco Giants for $10 million over four years. If Bud Black, with a career 83-82 record, was worth that much, Roger Clemens was worth even more than $5-million-plus a year.
And now Dwight Gooden and Frank Viola will discover how much they're worth to the "best franchise in sports" that believes "you never have enough pitching."

HEADLINE: Blue Skies for Mr. Bush's Economists

 BODY:
An overview of the current and future economy could be a valuable source of analysis and a stirring call to action. But you won't find either in the latest Annual Report of the Council of Economic Advisers. Slavishly opposed to government intervention, including any new taxes, President Bush's economists address few pressing problems. Indeed, they devote more attention to Eastern Europe and South America than to matters at home.
The council drifts from topic to topic, never committing the Administration to very much and always leaving the reader with a rosy view of the future. Worried about recession? Don't be. The downturn is sure to be shallow and short; free enterprise will handle it. The council's devotion to unfettered markets borders on the mindless. First-year economics students learn that unregulated factories and families will ignore the effects of their energy consumption on the environment. But nowhere does this council call for higher energy taxes to correct a blatant market failure.
More discouraging is what the report doesn't say. Worried about the growing gap between wages of college and high-school graduates? It isn't even worth discussing. Worried about slums, homelessness, crack babies? Turn your attention instead to intellectual property rights in Brazil or privatization in Czechoslovakia.
Eastern Europeans and South Americans might find the report mildly interesting. But for Americans, only the up-to-date statistical tables at the back of the volume will justify the $12 price.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: I'm Ready To Run in '92

BYLINE: By George McGovern; George McGovern was the Democratic nominee for President in 1972.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Perhaps because of my long opposition to the Vietnam War, I am constantly asked what a citizen does who is opposed to the war with Iraq but doesn't want to appear unpatriotic or ineffectual in protesting the war policy. It's a complicated question.
If I were still in the Senate, I would have voted with the 47 Senators to continue the economic sanctions, with war only as a last resort. But with American forces committed to battle, with low casualties and high television coverage of the most dramatic aspects of aerial attack, it is not very effective to stand in front of the White House and shout, "Stop the war!" 
 The proper course for me is not antiwar rallies, although I respect those who choose that course. Rather, I'm going to seek out a Presidential candidate who challenges the policies that set the stage for the present war and other difficulties gripping the nation. The Presidential campaign arena is the best place to focus attention on the need for new policies.
The Democratic loyal opposition should be mobilizing now. It needs at least one strong Presidential contender to make clear that the 1990's call for policies dramatically different from those applauded in the 1980's.
We need a President who recognizes that the American dream and our role in the world must be grounded in enduring values, a healthy economy, a just society and a government of the people. In two years, while turning away from challenges and opportunities at home, President Bush has given us two wars -- a small one in Panama to seize Gen. Manuel Noriega and a larger one in the gulf to stop Saddam Hussein.
George Bush and Ronald Reagan supported Saddam Hussein for years, including selling him $1.5 billion worth of equipment that he used to build chemical and nuclear war facilities. Mr. Bush, as Director of Central Intelligence had Mr. Noriega on his payroll and helped pave the way for his rise to power in Panama.
I would support a Presidential candidate who pledged to take the following steps:
* Curtail the giving of arms to dictators and carefully re-examine our current role as global policeman.
* Stop committing young Americans to military campaigns unless the security of the U. S. clearly requires it and Congress so determines.
* Develop an energy policy based on conservation and increased energy efficiency, improved public transportation and renewable resources to reduce our dependence on Persian Gulf oil -- the real cause of the present war.
* With the end of the cold war, utilize much of our obsolete military budget to reduce the national debt, strengthen the environment, convert to a peacetime economy and rebuild decaying public facilities.
* At the end of the war in the Persian Gulf, press for a comprehensive Middle East settlement and for a "new world order" based not on Pax Americana but on peace through law with a stronger U.N. and World Court.
I would be pleased to support a Democratic candidate with views similar to these. But if no such candidate gets into the arena soon, I will and I will go all out to win.
I've told an exploratory group pressing me to announce for the Presidency to qualify me first for Federal matching funds. If we meet that goal, and first signs are encouraging, it becomes practical to launch a Presidential campaign. Both the nation and the Democratic party would profit from a candidate who looks honestly at the nation's problems, proposes common sense solutions and raises the pride of the American people in their constitutional democracy.
In my soul, I know my qualifications for the Presidency -- wisdom, wit, historical perspective, toughness -- are better at 68 than they were at 48. Perhaps another candidate is even now waiting in the wings to announce. If not, get ready for McGovern in '92.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Elect McGovern in '72" campaign button

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 414 words

HEADLINE: Layoff of New Jersey Workers Will Hurt State

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The "harsh but necessary menu" for New Jersey that you endorse in "The Bad News Boys: Mr. Florio Cuts Back" (editorial, Feb. 2), including massive layoffs of state workers, would go far to cripple the state's essential public services, its civil service system and the union movement. Is it sound economic strategy in an economic downturn to fire thousands of public employees? Franklin D. Roosevelt thought otherwise. His strategy was to create public jobs for the unemployed, enfranchise labor and expand the minimum wage. The way out of the Depression, President Roosevelt believed, was to boost purchasing power and generate demand.
And where President Roosevelt declared that if he went to work in a factory, "the first thing I'd do would be to join a union," Gov. James Florio's tactics are designed to break the unions that represent 78,000 state workers. He's seeking to scrap the three-year contract he signed only last year and to fire as many as 10,000 critically needed state employees if they don't swallow massive pay givebacks of 20 percent and agree to pension and health pay reductions.
Since management claims that state workers are denied the right to strike, it is axiomatic that legal contracts be scrupulously observed. But Governor Florio, by breaking his own contract, would turn back the clock to the open shop of the 1920's. Tragically, the majority of those Governor Florio seeks to fire are clerical and professional workers, particularly working women, who make up, for example, 72 percent of my union local, a great many of them single, African-American working mothers.
The Governor's companion budget-reduction scenario involves cutting back much of the essential services provided by these employees: aid to the blind, the mentally ill, the poor, the autistic, the elderly and veterans, to cite just a few. How much sense does it make to balance a budget by slashing tens of millions in Medicaid clinic visits, thus inviting higher future bills for extended hospital stays? But this is precisely his approach.
As you have pointed out in your news columns, New Jersey's budget shortfall is only about 6 percent. Accordingly, there is absolutely no need to achieve balance at the expense of public employees and the people they assist, primarily the poor, when so many creative alternatives have not been explored.
 
TIM ADAMS
Executive Vice President
Local 1039, Communications
Workers of America
Trenton, Feb. 4, 1991

LENGTH: 233 words

HEADLINE: We Can't Afford the High Price of Cheap Oil

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Oil Prices and Profits; What Goes Up . . . " (Op-Ed, Jan. 26), Mark Green, New York City Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, asserts that lower gasoline prices could "spur more home building and retail buying, lower overall business costs and hasten the recovery by adding a half point of growth to the gross national product." While cheap oil stimulates economic growth short-term, cheap oil encourages the United States to continue to use energy unwisely.
Energy complacency causes extra pollution, pays for Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries whims, swells our trade deficit massively and funnels money out of our economy. Raising the taxes on fossil fuels and lowering income or other taxes on modest-income Americans would discourage energy waste and raise our long-term competitiveness.
If income taxes were a little lower and gas was a little more expensive, it would be profitable for industry to develop new energy technologies. Solar and wind power provide limitless and pollution-free alternatives. Cheap fossil fuels in the United States are the principal reason we lag behind Germany and other countries that are investing far more heavily in the emerging energy technologies that are so critical for future economic growth.
 
THOMAS P. O'BRIEN
Director for Research
Horizon Institute for Policy Solutions
Charlottesville, Va., Jan. 29, 1991

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Interest in Ski Dorms Goes Beyond Weekends

BYLINE: By JANET NELSON

 BODY:
Ski dorms have been around since young people began sliding down snow-covered hills. The dorms were attractive because they provided warm beds, a menu of hearty food and they were cheap. They offered few frills, but the atmosphere was informal and friendly.
Over the years, ski dorms have continued to appeal to high school and college students, church groups, ski clubs and racing teams, particularly on weekends and holiday weeks. But the dorms haven't increased in number even as the number of skiers increased. But in this recession year, the concept of dormitory accommodations is taking on a new appeal. 
 Moreover, a new dormitory has come on the scene and is attracting crowds as well as good reviews. The Snow Cap Lodge at Sunday River, Me., (800) 543-2754, which opened in December 1989, has two two-story wings and each floor of a wing holds one busload of 50 people. Rooms accommodate four to eight people in bunk beds and have a bath. There is even a private room for the bus driver of the group.
The two-day weekend rate for the Snow Cap dorm, including two breakfasts, one dinner and lift tickets for two days, is $125 a person. Skiers can also book accommodations without meals at $25 a person a night on weekends or a night midweek.
While the Snow Cap, and most other ski dorms in New England, are booked for winter weekends, there are often midweek vacancies and dorm managers are reporting an increase in business.
"We're seeing more families during the week," said Skip King, public relations manager for Sunday River. "Midweek business is up about 20 percent this year over last year."
Individuals must still share rooms during the week, but a two-day package with meals and lift tickets is $117.
The Vermont State Ski Dormitory in Stowe, Vt., built by the C.C.C. in 1933, is the oldest ski dorm in New England and was originally run by the state, but for the last two years has been under the management of Lillie Ferris. Two rooms -- one with 26 bunk beds for men and one with 24 bunk beds for women -- are usually filled on weekends, but midweek there are vacancies. The telephone number is (802) 253-4010.
"We've had people from three months to 85 years old here," said Ferris. "It's rustic, but homey with a big fireplace in the living room and you may be asked to bring in wood to keep the fire going."
Breakfast and dinner are included in the $35-a-day rate and there is free shuttle service to the ski lifts. Like most of the dormitories, the Vermont Ski Dorm has a recreation room, but unlike others, it also has a ski room with facilities for tuning skis.
Another old-time ski dorm in Stowe is the Round Hearth, which was built in 1947. Most of the rooms sleep four to eight people in bunk beds, and there are a few rooms with private or semiprivate baths. Meals are served cafeteria style in a large dining room that has a round fireplace in the middle. The telephone number is (802) 253-7223.
The nightly rate, including breakfast and dinner, is $32 a person, but groups of 10 or more get a 10 percent discount. For five nights the rate is $130. Most weekends are booked, but midweeks when families stay three to five nights, for each adult, one child under 12 can have free accommodations and free skiing at the mountain. The Round Hearth management will also arrange bus transportation from major cities and discounted lift tickets for groups.
The Trailside Lodge near Killington, Vt., has more resort-type amenities than most of the ski dorms with rooms, each with a private bath, accommodating six people in bunk beds. Besides a living room and a game room, there is an outdoor hot tub, a full service bar and live entertainment on Wednesday and Saturday evenings and sleigh rides on Tuesdays and Saturdays. A professional ski tuner comes by every evening to prep the guest's skis. The telephone number is (802) 422-3532.
The midseason weekend rate is $100 a person including three meals, but it can be as low as $55 in early and late season. Midweeks, the rate for five nights with breakfast and dinner every day is $139 a person and can be as low as $99 during special periods. There is a free shuttle to Killington.
The Vagabond Lodge in Jamaica, Vt., is about 15 minutes from Stratton and 20 to 30 minutes to Bromley and Magic. It has 96 beds in rooms that accommodate from four to 15 people each, which makes it appropriate for families during midweeks. The telephone number is (802) 874-4096.
The weekend rate is $54 a person for two nights with two breakfasts and Saturday dinner. Midweeks, when meals are not served, the rate is $19 per person. The lodge also sells lift tickets for Stratton at $3 off the regular rate.
Near Gore Mountain, N.Y., the Inn at Gore (518-251-2111) has eight four-bedded rooms with doubles and bunks. The rates are $75 a person a night for two people or $99 for four people on weekends and $49 and $73 during midweeks. Dinner prices run from $5 to $13 and many people brown-bag breakfasts of cereal, milk and fruit.
Sugarloaf Ski Adventures near the Sugarloaf ski area in Maine, is geared almost entirely to elementary and high school skiers who come for weekends. The three-story building has six rooms with 194 beds and six large bathrooms. The telephone number is (207) 265-2041.

HEADLINE: Business Sales Off 2.3%, Steepest Drop in 4 Years

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14

 BODY:
Business sales plunged 2.3 percent in December, the steepest in four years, the Government said today in a report that analysts said showed the economy in a significant decline.
The report, however, provided a slight touch of good news, as the Commerce Department said business inventories had fallen. In past recessions, goods piled up on shelves and backlots, causing production cutbacks and job layoffs as businesses struggled to sell backlogs. In December, however, business inventories dropped seven-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $810.7 billion, after advancing two-tenths of 1 percent in November and four-tenths of 1 percent in October. 
Business sales in December, the Commerce Department said, slowed to a seasonally adjusted $530.9 billion, even worse than the 1.5 percent decline in November and the biggest drop since January 1987, when they fell 3.1 percent.
The report on overall sales came a day after the department said sales on the retail level continued to fall in January. The nine-tenths of 1 percent decline followed a 1.5 percent drop in December for the first back-to-back decreases in seven months.
Retail sales, which were flat in November, have not risen since a barely perceptible one-tenth of 1 percent advance in October.
The overall activity pushed the ratio of inventories-to-sales to 1.53, from 1.5 in November. The ratio means it would take 1.53 months to exhaust the backlog at the December sales pace. It stood at 1.5 in November and 1.48 in October.
The ratio jumped to 1.74 during the 1981-82 recession and to 1.75 in the 1974-75 downturn, and analysts noted that businesses are using new techniques to keep backlogs under control.
"Instead of waiting until later in the recession to cut back on inventories, companies clearly are cutting back early," said Bruce Steinberg, an economist with Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York. "To some extent, that will moderate the decline."
But at the same time, Mr. Steinberg said, "the consumer sector is retrenching at this point about as much as had happened in the early 80's and 70's," when the two deepest postwar recessions occurred.
"Inventories are going to contribute to a lesser extent to the overall economic decline," he said. But he added that consumer cutbacks "are more severe than they usually are and therefore the overall economy is declining significantly."
In addition to the 1.5 percent decline in retail purchases, manufacturing sales plunged 3.4 percent after a 2.5 percent drop in November. Sales on the wholesale level were off 1.2 percent after falling 1.5 percent the previous month.
Retail inventories, on the other hand, declined eight-tenths of 1 percent in December and two-tenths of 1 percent in November. They were off a similar eight-tenths of 1 percent on the manufacturing level and three-tenths of 1 percent on the wholesale level. Manufacturing inventories had risen two-tenths of 1 percent in November, while wholesale backlogs grew seven-tenths of 1 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up in Slow Trading; Gold Prices Are Also Higher

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar advanced yesterday in uneventful dealings on the world's currency markets.
Gold prices also moved higher. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $368.20, up $1 a troy ounce from Wednesday. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for gold of $367.65, up $1.10 an ounce. 
 Currency dealers worldwide said trading was light and lackluster, with no fresh news to influence the dollar's direction.
John McCarthy, chief dealer at Algemene Bank Nederland, attributed the United States currency's advance to a market being "tired of selling dollars."
Some traders said they were awaiting the release of a new round of United States economic data today, including producer prices and industrial production figures for January.
The reports are expected to show a continued slowdown in economic activity. Earl Johnson, a vice president at Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago, said that fundamentals "point to lower interest rates, and that means a weak dollar."
Many expect the Federal Reserve to nudge interest rates lower to stimulate growth. But lower interest rates make dollar-denominated securities less attractive to investors.
Still, Mr. McCarthy predicted the dollar would be little changed unless the figures are out of line with market expectations, since traders will not want to be short dollars ahead of the Washington's Birthday holiday on Monday.
 
Direction of Interest Rates
 Separately, he said there was a "sense that rates might be peaking and coming lower in Europe." Investors typically move money to the highest-yielding instruments. Lower interest rates overseas would dampen the advantage of foreign investments while enhancing the value of United States securities.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose 1.05 yen, to a closing 129.75 yen. Later in London, it was quoted at 129.75 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 129.67 yen, unchanged from Wednesday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.9805, from $1.9945 late Wednesday. In New York it cost $1.9796 to buy one pound, less expensive than Wednesday's $1.9840.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.4665 German marks, up from 1.4640; 1.2570 Swiss francs, up from 1.2530; 4.9950 French francs, up from 4.9875; 1,103.25 Italian lire, up from 1,100.75, and $1.1523 Canadian dollars, down from $1.1537.
Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $368 a troy ounce, from $367.50 bid late Wednesday. In Zurich, it rose to a closing bid of $367.75 from $367. Hong Kong markets were closed for a weeklong national holiday.
Silver prices also gained. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $3.826 a troy ounce, up from $3.743 on Wednesday. In London the metal rose to a late bid price of $3.81 an ounce from $3.75.

HEADLINE: New Life for Rechargeable Battery

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
Several companies are offering new lines of rechargeable batteries to try to get consumers to throw away their disposable alkalines for good.
Companies like Sanyo and Gates have brought out new brands, under the names Sanyo and Millennium, with changes they hope will make them more appealing to consumers. Rechargeables have been available for decades, but aside from their use in small appliances like hand-held vacuums and tools, they have yet to catch on with the public. 
 Technical refinements in the recharging units have shortened the time needed to replenish the batteries' strength. The prices of some models have fallen, and some have been repackaged to look more attractive and less boxy.
 
8% Market Share
 American consumers use 2.5 billion batteries a year, and rechargeable nickel cadmium batteries, known as ni-cads, account for only 8 percent of the $2.8 billion market. But rechargeables have the potential to account for up to 20 percent of the market, said Joseph A. Carcone, vice president of marketing and sales for Sanyo, a division of the Sanyo Electric Company of Japan.
"It is probably the fastest-growing segment of the battery industry," said Terry Telzrow, manager of standards and product safety for the Eveready Battery Company, the nation's No. 1 battery maker and a unit of the Ralston Purina Company.
To stimulate new growth, some companies are also hoping to capitalize on the perception that rechargeable batteries are less harmful to the environment. Regular batteries, which must be thrown away after several hours' use, contain carcinogenic chemicals, like mercury, that can poison the environment. Rechargeable batteries can be reused hundreds of times.
But an environmental pitch might backfire, some battery makers warn. Rechargeables contain cadmium, a carcinogen that is highly toxic to aquatic life and can cause kidney ailments in people who eat the contaminated fish.
That makes an environmental appeal "a double-edged sword," said Jay Pomeroy of the General Electric Company, an early proponent of rechargeables. He said the cadmium content had prevented company officials from "beating our chest" about the environmental benefits.
That has not stopped others from recommending rechargeables as products for a new age. The Sanyo Energy U.S.A. Corporation of San Diego trumpets its new rechargeables and chargers as "environmentally responsible." Sanyo, which for years was one of the world's largest makers of rechargeables for industrial uses, introduced a line of rechargeable batteries for consumers in January.
Gates Energy Products Inc., a Gainesville, Fla., battery maker that introduced its line of Millennium rechargeables for consumers last year, says in its promotional material, "All of us are learning we haven't been as kind to our planet as we should have been."
 
No Recycling Center
 Sanyo and Gates will accept used rechargeables for recycling, if consumers send them in, but there is no cadmium recycling operation in the United States. The battery makers say they will ship the dead batteries to East Asia for recycling.
Other companies making a strong push into rechargeables include SAFT America Inc. of Valdosta, Ga., a subsidiary of Compagnie General d'Electricite of France, and the Panasonic Industrial Company, a division of the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company of Japan.
SAFT and Gates executives say consumers are buying 25 percent more rechargeables each year.
A sharp drop in recharging time -- from overnight to as short as an hour -- may also make the batteries more appealing to consumers.
Batteries generate an electric current by creating a chemical reaction. In alkaline and other regular batteries, the reaction is one way and the battery eventually goes dead. In rechargeables, the chemical reaction is reversed by applying electricity. This returns the chemicals to their original state, and the battery can again produce electricity.
The technical refinements that have shortened recharging time include improvements in the electrolyte, the fluid used as a medium for the electric current in batteries, allowing for faster recharging.
 
Signs of a Trend
 Because of such improvements and perceptions that rechargeables are better for the environment than throw-away batteries, Richard Thalheimer, founder and president of the Sharper Image stores, predicts that consumers will soon be flocking to rechargeables.
Mr. Thalheimer said the shift would be partly driven by the new rechargers reaching the market. Sanyo is selling a sleek black recharger that looks like a portable compact disk player.
Panasonic calls its streamlined version the Slim Charger, and is telling retailers to sell it as an "affordable impulse or gift item" for teen-agers, who are big consumers of batteries for items like Walkman-style stereos.
The Panasonic charger will sell for about $14, compared with more than twice as much for chargers already on the market.
But rechargeable batteries are still not a marketer's dream.
They cost nearly four times as much as akalaine batteries, and they last only one-sixth to one-third as long before they need recharging. A child's toy can drain a fully charged set of rechargeables in 12 minutes, compared with 72 minutes for an alkaline set, said Mr. Telzrow of Eveready. Rechargeables account for less than 10 percent of sales at Eveready, the world's largest battery maker.
A pair of AA-size rechargeables costs about $7, compared with about $3 for a four-pack of of disposable alkaline batteries.
Even advocates of rechargeables, like Mr. Carcone of Sanyo, acknowledge that "the convenience of aklaline totally outweighs the hassle of rechargeables."
Another problem with rechargeables is that they are not suited for all uses because their power drains even when the toy or appliance is turned off. Rechargeables should probably not be used in smoke detectors or other safety devices.
The main advantage is economic. Once a charger is bought, a set of rechargeable batteries can take the place of up to 300 alkaline batteries.
Despite some companies' attempts to portray nickel-cadmium batteries as being better for the environment than alkaline batteries, environmentalists and some battery executives say the choice is not so clear.
"There's not a real easy answer," said Tim Forker of the Environmental Action Coalition, a not-for-profit environmental group.
Under pressure from environmental groups, battery makers have begun reducing the mercury content of alkaline batteries. Encouraging consumers to use rechargeables would result in introducing large volumes of toxic cadmium into the environment.
A research effort is under way to replace the cadmium in rechargeables with a safer metal, probably nickel metal hydride.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gates Energy Products Inc. introduced its Millennium line of rechargeable nickel-cadmium batteries last year. It includes rechargeables in a variety of commonly used sizes and several types of rapid rechargers. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Scant Success for California Efforts To Put Women in Construction Jobs

BYLINE: By KATHERINE BISHOP, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 14

 BODY:
After more than a decade of organized effort to recruit women for the construction trades, few women in California have succeeded in breaking into such jobs through the state's broad network of certified apprenticeship programs.
Statistics compiled by advocates for women seeking the jobs show that the number of women who are able to get the training to become plasterers, bricklayers and sheet metal workers remains very low. 
 In 1978, Federal and state officials set goals of 20 percent female participation in the apprenticeship programs overseen by the state. But today, California is still about the same as the rest of the country, where women constitute only 2 percent of the construction industry work force, a figure that has remained virtually unchanged since 1983.
In a public hearing here last month, the Coalition for Equality in the Trades, a group of 15 organizations interested in issues involving women and minority groups, charged that the State Division of Apprenticeship Standards, which oversees hundreds of apprenticeship programs, had failed to integrate women into the construction trades.
 
Number May Have Fallen
 Representatives for the coalition testified that in California, women hold less than 5 percent of the spaces in the construction trades apprenticeship programs that the division oversees. Moreover, they said, calculations from the agency's annual reports suggest that the number dropped to 4.9 percent in 1989 from 5.14 percent in 1988.
They recommended that the Division of Apprenticeship Standards be required to refuse to certify apprenticeship programs unless goals for female participation are met and to institute sanctions against those that do not comply.
"If they don't bring women into the apprenticeship programs, the programs should not be allowed to continue," said Judith E. Kurtz, senior staff lawyer for Equal Rights Advocates, a San Francisco public interest law firm that is part of the coalition. "Because if they continue, you then have discrimination under state approval."
Gail W. Jesswein, chief of the state agency, noted that women now hold nearly 6,000 of the 51,000 total apprenticeship slots statewide, including those in the construction trades as well as others that are overseen by his division. That number represents an increase to 11 percent in 1989 from 8 percent in 1983.
"We are doing our job for the public and I resent any implication it's our responsibility and fault there aren't 20 percent women in these programs," he said.
He disputed the calculations that showed a possible decline in women in the 31,000 construction apprenticeship positions. Although he said neither he nor his staff had checked the advocacy groups' calculations, he said that "since the overall numbers are up, they must be up in the construction trades, too; it's just logical."
Ms. Kurtz said an analysis of the division's statistics showed that most of the gain by women was in training programs for jobs like psychiatric technicians and correctional officers. "When you eliminate those two jobs from the data, the numbers really drop for women," she said.
The primary responsibility of the division is to develop apprenticeship programs with private employers and insure that the employers have plans for recruitment and training of women. While the division has the power to decertify apprenticeship programs that fail to meet these affirmative action goals, it has never done so.
The complaints in California are similar to those expressed last March at hearings before the New York City Human Rights Commission regarding the construction trades in Manhattan, where women hold about 4 percent of approximately 100,000 jobs.
 
Treatment Becomes an Obstacles
 Helen R. Neuborne, the executive director of the National Organization for Women's Legal Defense and Education Fund, which compiled statistics for those hearings, said that even when women succeed at winning slots in apprenticeship programs, their on-the-job treatment often becomes an obstacle to advancement.
"They're sent for coffee, they're put off by themselves, they're sexually harrassed, men urinate next to them," she said. "There is so very little incentive to stay."
The hearing here last month was conducted by the California Commission on State Government Organization and Economy, a bipartisan panel that investigates complaints about the functioning of public agencies.
Mary Gaddis, who in 1979 became the first woman in the 1,800-member Federation of Plumbers and Pipefitters Local 393, has worked on major construction projects, including the San Jose sewage treatment plant. She testified about sexual harrassment of women on the job.
Included in her presentation were photographs of sexually degrading graffiti in the women's portable outhouse, some of it aimed specifically at her.
 
Abuse on the Job
 Similarly, Linda Jofuku, a former carpenter who is now the business representative for the International Federation of Professional and Technical Engineers, testified that she was doused with water while working with electrical wires and grabbed and fondled while carrying heavy loads up ladders. "You get really sick of it," she said.
"It's not enough to have affirmative action goals," she said. "You need to support women once they are in the programs."
The commission is expected to issue a report to the Legislature this spring suggesting legislation to improve the apprenticeship program.
"On the face of it, it doesn't look real good," said Kathleen Johnson, research manager for the commission. "The whole point of the report will be to overhaul the Division of Apprenticeship Standards, to have them not function as they have been."

HEADLINE: Real Estate Group Buys G.M. Building

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
One of the country's largest private real estate investment groups quietly acquired the landmark General Motors Building in Manhattan last month, people at G.M. said yesterday. The headquarters building was sold for $500 million plus other unspecified considerations, they said.
The 50-story building was acquired by Corporate Property Investors, the real estate investment trust that refinanced the property for G.M. in the early 1980's and in exchange received the option to acquire the building, on Fifth Avenue at the southeastern corner of Central Park, which opened in 1968. 
 To raise cash in the early 1980's, G.M. got a 10-year, $500 million mortgage on the marble-clad tower from the investment group at 10 percent interest, which was favorable considering that 10-year Treasury bills carried interest rates of 14 percent. At the time of the deal, it represented the largest mortgage ever put on a New York office tower. In exchange for the favorable interest rate, Corporate Property Investors got the option to acquire the property at the end of the 10-year period in exchange for the $500 million mortgage.
But at least one person at General Motors said the auto maker received additional considerations for the building. As a result of the transaction, which closed early last month, G.M. will record a special, one-time gain of about $600 million, but it was not clear what the additional $100 million represented.
Telephone messages to Hans C. Mautner, the chairman and chief executive of Corporate Property Investors, were not returned.
The Manhattan-based realty group, which was started in 1971, is one of the most successful real estate investors in the country. With about 21 million shares and about $3.4 billion in shareholders' equity, the investment trust, which is not traded publicly, has some of the nation's largest public and private pension funds as shareholders. A.T.&T.'s pension fund is believed to be the largest shareholder. In addition, it also has major foreign shareholders like the Kuwaiti Investment Office.
Its annual return to shareholders has averaged about 17 percent over the last 15 years. Originally, shares sold for $25 apiece but today a single share costs about $162. Dividends, too, have risen sharply, from about $1.90 for the first dividend to about $6.90 recently.
The group has a portfolio that is 80 percent large, regional shopping malls -- the best performing segment of the commercial real estate market at present -- with the remaining 20 percent in prime office buildings.

HEADLINE: At the Movies

BYLINE: By Lawrence Van Gelder

 BODY:

Long, Not Too Long
Five hours 11 minutes for the uncut "1900." Three hours 10 minutes for "Dances With Wolves." Two hours 41 minutes for "The Godfather Part III."
"Not every movie can be very long, but there are good examples," said the Italian director Bernardo Bertolucci, whose 1977 epic, "1900," has finally been released at the length he intended. 
 "1900" has long been a prime example of the penchant of distributors and exhibitors to cringe at leisurely storytelling, preferring instead films that run two hours or less. The theory being: There's more money to be gleaned from a movie that can be shown in a theater six times a day than from one that can be shown only two or three times.
"I have not seen it," Mr. Bertolucci said of "Dances With Wolves," "but I hear Kevin Costner's movie is three hours, and it works very well.
"We say in Italy, the last chicken that sings has made the eggs. They always follow the last success. So after Kevin Costner's film, there will be more room for long movies for a while."
Mr. Bertolucci is, of course, the Academy Award-winning director of "The Last Emperor," the 1987 film that won nine Oscars, including that for best picture.
"When I did 'The Last Emperor,' which was 2 hours 45 minutes," Mr. Bertolucci said, "the distributors were terrified at the beginning. Then the movie did well, and they said it is, in fact, the right length."
Although his latest film, "The Sheltering Sky" (2 hours, 17 minutes), is in the theaters, Mr. Bertolucci has not yet decided on his next project.
"There is an idea of doing a movie about Buddha, which is very fascinating," he said. "But I cannot say at the moment that movie will be my next project. That will take years of study. Maybe I have to become a Buddhist before doing it."
 
Accolades at Last
 If length was Bernardo Bertolucci's problem with "1900," content was Jiri Menzel's concern with "Larks on a String."
Mr. Menzel, the Czechoslovak director who won an Academy Award for his 1966 film "Closely Watched Trains," made the 69-minute "Larks on a String" in 1969, in the aftermath of the Soviet invasion of Prague. The film, about a group of intellectuals being re-educated through manual labor under the Communist regime, was promptly banned.
When "Larks on a String" was finally released last year, it went on to win a Golden Bear, the top award at the Berlin Film Festival; it opens today in New York at Film Forum 1.
"It's a nice surprise for me," said Mr. Menzel, noting he had long hoped that "Larks on a String" would be released in Czechoslovakia but never anticipated that the film would prove interesting to audiences in other countries.
"It think basically it's very easy to understand," he said. The message, he added, is: Don't hate your enemies. "For the future to be better," he explained, "you have to try to understand both sides and together go forward."
Going forward himself, Mr. Menzel, hopeful of an autumn release, is beginning to edit his latest movie, an adaptation of Vaclav Havel's stage adaptation of "The Beggar's Opera," by John Gay. And he is preparing for two more films.
One is "The Engineer of Human Souls," an adaptation of a novel by the exiled writer Josef Skvorecky. "It's his memories of his youth during the war in a small town in Czechoslovakia compared with his life now in Canada," Mr. Menzel said.
The other is "Fadeout," a true story of wartime Prague that is a project for the producer David Puttnam.
Having sampled both Communist repression and new freedom in Czechoslovakia, Mr. Menzel said he found the current atmosphere a bit difficult for film makers because the rules have changed. Now, he said: "It's economic censorship. It's as bad as ideological censorship. It's very difficult to start a new movie, because we don't have enough money.
"The solution is, first, to make movies for a large public, also to try to make co-productions and also push banks or rich people or the state to help us."
So he finds the outlook uncertain. "It's a big problem," he said. "If we are not successful, it will be bad for the future. During socialism, Czech movies were independent of the box office, but now it is a different time."
 
2 Who Produced
 Richard Zanuck and David Brown, the producers who brought audiences such films as "The Sting," "Jaws" and "The Sugarland Express," have been chosen by the board of governors of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences to receive the organization's Irving G. Thalberg Memorial Award.
The award honors "a creative producer whose body of work reflects a consistently high quality of motion picture production" and is conferred only in years when the board feels there is a deserving recipient. It has been presented 29 times in 62 years of academy history, and this year's presentation, during the ceremonies March 25, will be the first to a pair of producers.
Mr. Zanuck and Mr. Brown, who formed the Zanuck-Brown Company in 1972, produced 17 films before going their separate ways after 15 years. Mr. Zanuck, with his wife, Lili Fini Zanuck, produced last year's best picture, "Driving Miss Daisy."

HEADLINE: Review/Film;
Thwarted Expectations

BYLINE: "H-2 Worker" was shown as part of the 1990 New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Caryn James's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 24, 1990. The film opens today at the Collective for Living Cinema, 41 White Street in Manhattan.

 BODY:
As black workers cut sugar cane in the 1940's, a narrator notes that these happy laborers are following the "hereditary urge to go back to the plantation." That archival clip, included in Stephanie Black's "H-2 Worker," suggests how little the plantation mentality has changed in nearly 50 years, though today the sugar-cane growers rely on Jamaicans imported to Florida for six months every year.
Ms. Black's documentary follows the men who arrive on H-2 visas, temporary permits that allow foreigners to take jobs for which employers cannot find Americans. According to the film, each year 10,000 Jamaicans respond to the promise of more money than they can make at home, and become virtual prisoners, crowded into dormitories that resemble Army barracks, paid at most $5 an hour -- minus transportation and housing fees -- for grueling field work. 
 Although Ms. Black's sympathy with the laborers is manifest, "H-2 Worker" is that rare hybrid that succeeds as both film and advocacy. The documentary's look and form is smooth and sophisticated, combining reggae music, voice-overs of letters between the Jamaicans and their families at home, interviews with the workers and with a sugar industry representative, and archival material that sets the current situation in historical context. Ms. Black is not artistically innovative, but she has mastered some fundamental rules of effective documentary film making. She assumes a calm, objective tone, allowing the visual images and interviews to speak for themselves. She lures viewers to her point of view rather than bludgeoning them.
Maryse Alberti's cinematography is a major element of the film's convincing realism. Ms. Alberti creates rich images of the men in the fields, bending to cut cane that stands taller than they do; even a glimpse suggests the strain on one's back. The dormitory, with laundry strung between the bunks, looks stark and demoralizing, but not exaggeratedly gruesome. Most important, the film never looks picturesque or condescending.
The workers are quietly angry, dignified and often resigned as they describe their thwarted expectations. One man has been returning to Florida for 14 years, suggesting the dilemma facing poor people with limited opportunities. When the workers stage a stoppage to complain about low wages, the police are brought in to remove them from the camp; within a week, 300 replacement workers are flown in from Jamaica.
"H-2 Worker" does not pretend to offer any answers, but it solidly frames issues about the economy, employment and the treatment of workers who seem just steps away from slavery.

HEADLINE: First Executive Loss Likely

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 14

 BODY:
The First Executive Corporation said today that it expected to report a loss "of a material amount" for the fourth quarter and the full year.
The life insurance company said the loss would be caused partly by a 4 percent decline in the value of its investment portfolio in the period. The portfolio is largely made up of high-risk, high-yield "junk bonds." The company said the results would also be affected by the outcome of a review by the Securities and Exchange Commission of First Executive's plan to restructure its preferred stock.
First Executive, which is based in Los Angeles, also said it had completed a previously announced restructuring of its senior debt.
First Executive, which was among the largest purchasers of junk bonds in the past decade, has been scrambling for several years to avoid a financial crisis brought on by the decline in junk bond prices. The company said it was continuing to negotiate or consider a number of other deals to strengthen its financial condition.

HEADLINE: Slump in Reading, Pa.: From Threat to Reality

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY, Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: READING, Pa., Feb. 9

 BODY:
In the last two months, recession has quietly infiltrated this blue-collar city on the edge of the Pennsylvania Dutch country, transforming an impending threat into a grim reality for residents like Herbert Cook.
"It's getting tough," said Mr. Cook, co-owner of two Midas muffler shops. At the shop on Kutztown Road his gaze fell on a repaired Oldsmobile that has languished for weeks because the customer can't afford to pay the bill. With revenues down 10 percent in December and January from levels a year earlier, Mr. Cook plans to cut his workers' hours if business doesn't pick up this month. "I just don't have the cash flow," he said. 
 As in other cities across America, the economic pulse of Reading, named for the ancestral home of the William Penn family in England, and its environs has clearly weakened since an initial visit here just after Thanksgiving. And while no city or county can stand for the nation as a whole, the Reading area, with its diverse economic base, provides a snapshot of how a fairly typical East Coast manufacturing city is adapting to a slump.
Despite its broad business base, small shops like Mr. Cook's and large companies like the Dana Corporation are hurting all across Reading, most of which is visible from the Japanese-style pagoda atop Mount Penn that has become the city's symbol.
To be sure, there are businesses that have yet to feel any significant pinch from what has developed into the nation's ninth postwar recession.
In fact, some enterprises, like Jack O'Reilly's tuxedo-rentals, seem to be thriving. Mr. O'Reilly, who moved into larger quarters last month, outfitted 13 weddings last week. He said his biggest problem was the competition from bridal shops that offered free tuxedos for bridegrooms.
But for most enterprises, conditions are sobering.
"No question, there is further economic slowdown," said Fred D. Hafer, head of the Metropolitan Edison Company, the main supplier of electricity to the city and surrounding Berks County. Both homes and businesses are using less power, he said, and even though factory use was up slightly in December, the January figure was 8.2 percent below the level of January 1990.
"Business is poor," said Ezekiel S. Ketchum, president of Meridian Bancorp Inc., which has 36 percent of the county's banking market. He dissented from predictions by the Bush Administration and most private economists that the recession would end by midyear. "I'm not that optimistic myself," he said.
Probably the most serious single blow to the Reading job market in the last two months was the decision by Dana, which laid off 60 of its 2,400 local workers in October, to idle another 400 employees who had been working short weeks.
 
Slump in Used Cars, Too
 "We're suffering due to the hard economic times in Detroit," said Richard Harman, division controller of the company, which is based in Toledo, Ohio. The Dana plant here makes frames for Chevrolets and Cadillacs and side rails for light-truck chassis.
Over all, the Reading area jobless rate averaged 5.4 percent in the final three months of 1990, up from 4.7 percent in the preceding quarter but still a half-point below the national average.
Although it has Dana, Exide batteries and some automotive heritage in Charles E. Duryea's turn-of-the-century road trials on Mount Penn, Reading is not essentially a car town. Yet it suffers heavily when the car business goes sour.
Frank Borek, who has a used-car lot in suburban Temple, emphatically rejected a visitor's supposition that in a recession consumers shift from new cars to used ones. "That's a fallacy," Mr. Borek exclaimed. He said he sold 28 cars last month compared with 56 in January 1990, and that his average sale had slumped 40 percent so far this year, to $1,80.
There is little overlap between new- and used-car buyers, Mr. Borek maintained, with both groups tending to trade down within their own categories during hard times.
Yet at least some of the new-car dealers in Reading have eluded the general battering. For example, at Tom Masano Lincoln-Mercury near the armory from which a Marine Corps artillery unit has been called for Persian Gulf duty, salesmen say a late January surge regained ground lost earlier in the month and allowed the dealership to equal the 78 cars sold and leased in January, 1990.
When war broke out, "we were nonexistent" for about a week, said Doug Potts, the sales manager.
 
Cut Costs or Raise Demand
 The general squeeze here has prompted various actions to either cut costs or raise demand so incomes can be maintained in the face of thinner margins:
*Jack Leifer of Bloom Furniture has cut inventories to the near-minimum to deal with what he calls worse conditions than in the recession of 1981-82. Bloom's January sales slumped 30 percent from levels a year earlier. When the rebound comes, he said, "we can accelerate pretty fast."
*The Reading Eagle Company, publisher of the main area newspapers, is working to counter "flat" overall advertising linage and a 10 percent plus drop in lucrative classified linage. It is using cross-promotions involving its WEEU radio station and other affiliates; a new telephone information service in which messages are preceded by commercial plugs, and stepped-up efforts to help local merchants get advertising money from national companies whose products they sell.
*The Burlington Coat Factory Warehouse and Boscov's Department Stores have been driven to two-for-one and "gift with purchase" offers to spur sales. At the same time, the city's famous outlet malls are wooing the local shoppers they have long neglected.
*TCBC of Reading, a computer store, says it is selling personal computers and facsimile machines to many of the newly unemployed who have decided to go into business for themselves. But other business is soft, according to Kevin Bitz, the controller, and "the sales cycle is definitely longer" before a deal is finalized.
*The Carpenter Technology Corporation, a specialty steel company that is the city's second-largest employer after A.T.&T., still finds orders for energy and aircraft equipment largely offsetting poor auto and appliance business. But Paul R. Roedel, its chairman, said Cartech would be "hard-pressed to match" the profits of second-half 1990, which were down 9 percent, because of fierce price pressures. Mr. Roedel said he had just received a letter from General Motors, which it supplies, asking about reductions.
More drastic steps are being taken by managers of the Sonoco Fibre Drum Inc., although they are more the result of industry overcapacity than of general recession. The company announced in early October that the 313,000-square-foot plant would be closed with the loss of 140 jobs.
 
United Way Pledge Worry
 "Now I'm strictly into a cleanup and dismantling mode," said the production manager, Dennis J. Leonard, who said he thought only "a small fraction" of his work force, which had average earnings of $11.50 an hour excluding benefits, had found new jobs.
One factor in the demise of this plant appeared to be modern, "just-in-time" inventory practices that reduce the volume of material that companies need to store in drums on their premises.
The recession has Bob Pollack, owner of a downtown fur store, worried that the apparently successful United Way drive he led last fall will suffer from a high rate of unmet pledges. The recession has already led various companies to delay paying their Chamber of Commerce dues.
But there are some encouraging signs. The Georgia-Pacific paper plant shut down last year has been bought by a New Jersey company that plans to reopen it in 1991 to make recycled paper products. And, not surprisingly, the economy is getting some extra lift from Defense Department orders for such things as underwear, batteries, candy, steel and chemical antidotes related to the Persian Gulf war.
 
Mortgage Applications Rise
 Moreover, while there has been a rise in personal and business bankruptcies, Chris Mills, manager of the Credit Bureau of Reading and Berks County, said loan delinquencies had not climbed much beyond the post-Christmas increases of other years.
In fact, Mr. Mills said, his bureau received 116 mortgage applications in the first week of February, about twice as many as the late 1990 pace.
Albert Boscov, whose family's three department stores in the Reading area ranged from a 3 percent sales decline in January to a 3.6 percent advance, said that major appliances -- traditionally strong in January -- constituted the only notably weak sector.
"Business is pretty flat now," he said, expressing the view of many in this city, "But," he added, "it's not a disaster."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
'German Angst': The Costs of War

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
"GERMANY'S relations with the United States are under strain," said Otto Lambsdorff, the chairman of the Free Democratic Party, a partner in the coalition Government with Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democratic Party, in an interview in New York this week. He had just finished a round of meetings in Washington with top Bush Administration officials and Congressional leaders and with business executives and bankers in New York.
Washington is annoyed, it seems, because it believes Germany has not done enough to support the United States in the Persian Gulf war. Many Americans are angry because the German Government moved slowly to prevent German companies from supplying Iraq with arms and poison gas plants. 
 Lloyd Cutler, a prominent Washington lawyer who has recently spoken at length with German business executives in this country, said in an interview yesterday that unless the rising trend of anti-German sentiment was checked, there was "real concern" in German circles about the danger of a boycott against German products.
Mr. Lambsdorff said American annoyance with Germany was partly related to "misconceptions" but also to "mistakes we have made." It is a misconception, he said, to believe that most Germans are opposed to the war against Iraq. Americans are misled, he said, by the widespread demonstrations in the streets. Most Germans -- at least 75 percent, he said -- support the war.
He did not try to minimize the fury of the German demonstrators: "There is widespread hysteria, a strong rejection of any opposition to the Iraqi dictator, an assessment of the United States as a menacing power."
But he denied that the German protests were a manifestation of anti-Americanism. The demonstrators, he said, were fiercely critical of Germancompanies for shipping arms and poison gas to Iraq. Mr. Lambsdorff was bitter in his denunciation of the small number of companies that had done so. He said he shuddered to hear three words linked together for the first time in decades: "Germans, Jews and gas."
"These companies," he said, "knew what they were doing. They did so in violation of existing German laws." Why? "Greed," he said.
"Such things must not and will not recur," Mr. Lambsdorff told an audience in Washington. "Never again!" he declared, using the slogan of Elie Wiesel, the Nobel laureate and historian of the Holocaust. He said all German parties were supporting aid for Israel, financial and military, and the German Government had supplied Patriot and Hawk missiles to the Israelis.
Mr. Lambsdorff, a former Economics Minister, was also critical of the German Government for being so slow to provide greater financial support for American and coalition actions in the gulf. Germany has pledged nearly $11 billion to the coalition, of which $6.6 billion is pledged to the United States. But the money has been slow to arrive here. As of Feb. 11, only $272 million in cash had been received from Germany by the United States.
Mr. Lambsdorff said there could be no doubt thatthe full German pledge would be paid, adding that the commitment of $6.6 billion to the United States was based on the assumption that the war would last three months. "If it lasts longer," he said, "then we will have to pay more."
He attributed Germany's slowness to several factors: wishful thinking that peace had arrived with the end of the cold war; a fundamental change in German attitudes about war resulting from the nation's terrible experiences in the last two world wars; the German Constitution and its requirement of a two-thirds vote to permit troops to be sent outside the NATO area, and a preoccupation with the problems of German unification.
Overriding all was "German angst," which Mr. Lambsdorff defined as "the fear of losing things hitherto taken for granted." He called it a fear of losing political, social and even ecological stability. He said "German angst" was best expressed in the motto chosen for the German demonstrations: "We won't let our future be destroyed."
But the German anxiety is also rooted in economics, particularly fear of inflation. In addition to its increased pledges to support the gulf war, Mr. Lambsdorff said, the German Government will pay 50 billion marks this year to rebuild East Germany, with the trend rising in coming years; it will pay 13 billion marks to make possible the withdrawal of 400,000 Soviet troops from Germany, and it spend billions more to help the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe "avoid a social catastrophe."
The German budget deficit could rise to 5 percent of gross national product in 1991, a huge ratio for Germany. To hold down the deficit, the Government plans to increase taxes. And to ward off inflation, the German central bank, the Bundesbank, has raised interest rates at a time when the United States, Britain and other European countries are pushing rates down to check recession.
Thus, the war in the gulf is not only straining German relations with the United States but also with its partners in the European Community. The road to European political and monetary union looks rockier and longer than it did before the war in the gulf started. And Germany, the economic powerhouse of Europe, looks politically weaker.

HEADLINE: Big Losses For G.M. And Ford

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 14

 BODY:
Saying that war and recession had shattered consumer confidence, the nation's two biggest auto makers today reported huge fourth-quarter losses. General Motors, with a $1.62 billion deficit, and Ford, with $519 million, said sales had dried up faster than they could cut costs.
Both companies said losses seem likely to continue for several months as they had seen no signs of a rebound in sales yet. Both also said they would intensify efforts to cut costs. 
 When added to the small quarterly profit posted last week by the Chrysler Corporation, the Big Three's collective deficit was the second largest in history, more than doubling the mark set in the last recession. The Big Three racked up an even bigger loss in the third quarter, but that resulted from expenses attributed to a reorganization at General Motors.
The loss at the General Motors Corporation, which came on revenue of $29.88 billion, compared with a profit of $700.2 million, or $1.01 a share, on revenue of $31.36 billion in the period last year. The Ford Motor Company's loss, on revenue of $24.2 billion, compared with a profit of $314 million in the 1989 period, or 68 cents a share, on $24.1 billion in revenue.
 
Auto Stocks Decline
 The stocks of the two companies fell today in trading on the New York Stock Exchange, with G.M. down 62.5 cents, to $36.25, and Ford down 25 cents, to $30.50.
G.M., the industry leader, speaking of overall 1990 performance, said its North American automotive operations had lost money. That loss reflected a drop in the number of vehicles sold in the United States and Canada, a greater proportion of less profitable vehicles sold and intense competition, which reduced prices. But G.M.'s overseas subsidiaries earned $2.4 billion on the strength of GM Europe's record results and despite depressed economic conditions in Brazil. On Wednesday, G.M.'s non-automotive units posted strong profit increases.
Ford's domestic sales volume was also down for the quarter and the year, as was the company's proportion of high-profit vehicles sold. And, like G.M., Ford was forced to pay big rebates, averaging $1,000 a vehicle for 1990, which contributed to making its American auto operations unprofitable. But Ford was also hurt by a huge drop in the profitability of its overseas operations, caused by labor and market disruptions in Britain, and inflation in Brazil and Argentina.
G.M. and Ford said that throughout the second half of 1990 they were selling far fewer pickups, utility vehicles, vans and other trucks, which have provided a disproportionate amount of profit in recent years.
Although G.M. and Ford remain financially strong, each says it is contending with far tougher economic conditions than anticipated early last year when it appeared the economy was headed for a mild recession. Chrysler, while eking out a narrow profit, is financially weak, with fewer liquid assets and less borrowing power than its domestic rivals. At risk for all the Big Three, however, are expensive vehicle development programs meant to help against future Japanese cars and trucks.
"It's not clear what's going to happen," said David McCammon, Ford's vice president for finance, who acknowleged that Ford also expected to post a big loss in the current quarter. "Rarely do we have a downturn and a war at the same time."
Both auto makers, vowing to hold capital spending sacrosanct, say their capital spending will be steady, but analysts and suppliers are reporting that a few programs already are being drawn out over a longer period of time. Since the war, for example, G.M. has told managers working on two new versions of the mid-size Buick Century and Oldsmobile Ciera that their project would be delayed for at least a year, a G.M. spokesman acknowledged.
Harold A. Poling, Ford's chairman, declared in a statement that the automaker would cut costs faster and deeper "without sacrificing its emphasis on a continuing flow of new and improved products."
That means some workers may feel the pinch, starting almost immediately. Mr. McCammon said Ford, the No. 2 auto maker, would try to cut salaried employee costs through attrition, early retirements and other expenses, but he acknowledged that white-collar dismissals would likely occur as well. The pay of hourly workers who are put on layoff is guaranteed by union contract but is usually less than full pay.
 
Ford's Particular Trouble
 The latest results are particularly difficult for Ford, whose top executives have said they reorganized the company in the 1980's so it could be profitable during an industry downturn. Mr. McCammon said a profit for all of 1991 might still be possible.
But Harvey Heinbach, an automotive analyst for Merrill Lynch & Company, said Ford "probably didn't anticipate the loss of market share, the downturn in Europe and the high incentive costs."
Mr. Heinbach said "all the Big Three will have losses in the first quarter and possibly in the second."
Robert C. Stempel, G.M.'s chairman, said, "We expect the U.S. economy will start a gradual recovery at some point in 1991 and G.M.'s North American automotive operations will be in a stronger position."
Mr. Poling said, "Although today's environment is quite negative, we are well poised for the economic recovery that inevitably will happen." Mr. McCammon said orders from dealers had improved slightly in early February from a low level in January.
A G.M. spokesman noted that it planned to reduce white-collar ranks only through attrition. "This puts pressure on the organization to be disciplined," he said.
The results of G.M.'s latest quarter included a one-time charge of $132 million to cover the closing of Saab's plant in Malmo, Sweden; G.M. owns half of Saab. The results also include a $60 million charge to cover the write-down of inventory in Brazil.
For all of 1990 Ford earned $860.1 million, or $1.86 a share, on revenue of $97.65 billion, compared with net income of $3.84 billion, or $8.22 a share, on revenue of $96.15 billion in 1989.
G.M. lost $1.99 billion on revenue of $124.7 billion in 1990, compared with a profit of $4.22 billion, or $6.33 a share, on revenue of $126.93 billion in 1989. G.M.'s 1990 results included a $2.1 billion charge against earnings, announced in November, to close up to nine factories.

HEADLINE: Bloomingdale's Union Asked to Forgo Raise

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
Citing financial hardship, Bloomingdale's has asked the union representing 3,500 full-time employees to rescind an $18-a-week wage increase due to take effect March 1.
But the union said it would not comply and that it would meet with Bloomingdale's management next Thursday to discuss the matter. 
 "This is the first time in 50 years of collective bargaining with Bloomingdale's that they have asked for a wage cancellation," John O'Neill, president of Local 3 of the United Storeworkers, said yesterday.
The scheduled wage rise, the third annual increment in a five-year contract that began in 1989, covers full-time sales and non-sales personnel at Bloomingdale's main store in Manhattan, two warehouses and three office centers. The other 14 Bloomingdale's stores are not unionized.
Bloomingdale's and eight other chains owned by Federated Department Stores Inc. and the Allied Stores Corporation -- units of the Campeau Corporation of Canada -- have been operating under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code since January 1990. Like other New York-based retailers, Bloomingdale's has experienced sluggish sales because of the recession and the Persian Gulf war.
"We have never before asked for rescinding a wage increase, but under the circumstances, with our financial burdens and the recession, we don't think it is unusual," a Bloomingdale's spokeswoman said yesterday.
 
Added Health Benefits
 But Mr. O'Neill of Local 3 said: "It's particularly serious because our contract also calls for the employer to pay 9 percent of payroll for health benefits. So the $18 a week is really $19.75."
In a letter sent to the union last month in which it sought to void the wage increase, Bloomingdale's said that if discussions failed to "produce a mutually satisfactory understanding," it might petition the Federal bankruptcy court to obtain approval for blocking the increase.
Neither Bloomingdale's nor the union would comment on the possibility that a partial wage increase might be acceptable if no other settlement could be reached in the discussions.
Although American retailing is largely non-unionized, it is unusual for a unionized retailer to seek cancellation of a planned wage increase.
"Canceling a contract wage increase is a serious business," a retailing consultant who asked not to be identified said yesterday. "I can't help wondering what other retailers will do when they hear of the Bloomingdale's move,"
R. H. Macy & Company, which is unionized in New York, recently gave a $15-a-week increase to its New York employees. Other large retailers are seeking ways to reduce costs, mostly by reducing staffs through terminations or attrition.
In addition to seeking to erase the union's wage increase, Bloomingdale's is also acting to reduce wages for some 2,000 executives. In a recent letter, it told its executive staff that the effective date of their wage increases this year would be moved from Feb. 1 to May 1.
"What it means is that last year increases were given in May but were made retroactive to Feb. 1. Now, they will not be retroactive," a company spokeswoman said.
Bloomingdale's letters to the union and to its executives regarding wage increases were not released, but copies were obtained by a reporter.
 
A Limited Budget
 In its letter to the executives, sent earlier this month, Bloomingdale's said it would impose "a limited merit increase budget."
"As you all know," the letter said, "Bloomingdale's has just completed one of the most difficult business years in our history. The combination of a recessionary economic climate and the constraints of bankruptcy have forced us to examine our expenses and make some difficult decisions. As we plan for our successful emergence from Chapter 11, we need to capitalize on every opportunity to contain costs and operate more economically."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Pan Am Starts New Fare War

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Pan American World Airways Inc. fired the latest salvo in the air travel industry's fare wars yesterday, and some competitors soon followed.
Pan Am said it would offer round-trip tickets, some to foreign destinations, for prices that are discounted in many cases by more than half.
American Airlines and Northwest Airlines immediately said they were matching the promotion with their own discounts. Others said they were studying the move. 
 Pan Am, which is operating under Federal bankruptcy protection, said it was trying to stimulate business. Airlines have been hit hard by high fuel prices, the recession and a drop in bookings that came as travelers began fearing Iraqi-sponsored terrorism.
Pan Am said its cheap tickets would apply to most cities it serves in the United States and to many overseas destinations, including western Europe. The tickets cost as little as $119 each way for passengers who fly a regular flight of at least $250 by March 1, or as little as $139 each way for passengers who do not fly other flights.
For an extra $100, people can fly to Hawaii, Argentina, Chile, Uruguay and Brazil, Pan Am said. Other fees may apply, the airline said.
American and Northwest matched the Pan Am promotion with deals they said were the same or better. Travel is good from early April through May 20 on the three carriers.

SECTION: Section A; Page 34; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 420 words

HEADLINE: Gov. Weicker Delivers

 BODY:
Lowell Weicker promised to be tough if Connecticut elected him governor -- so tough that he'd be dumped after one term, he quipped. Five weeks in office, he has now delivered in spades, by proposing a personal income tax. Whether his plan succeeds or fails, it took guts and it's years overdue.
There is need for drastic action. Connecticut's deficits this year and next will be among the nation's most severe -- almost one-third of the $7.5 billion budget. Fairness and fiscal sanity recommend what Mr. Weicker has proposed, but governors have banished all thought of it since enactment of an income tax in 1971 met such ferocious protest that it was quickly repealed. 
 Connecticut's main revenue source is the nation's highest state sales tax -- 8 percent. It also levies the highest state tax on corporate profits -- 13.8 percent. Mr. Weicker would chop the sales tax nearly in half and expand its application, cut the profits tax and repeal personal taxes on capital gains, dividends and interest. The sales and corporate tax cuts will boost business, and folding unearned income into the income tax will spread the overall tax burden more equitably.
The strongest argument for converting to income taxation is fairness; a sales tax is disproportionately harsh on the poor. The flat 6 percent rate Mr. Weicker proposes for taxing individual incomes of more than $12,500 and joint incomes of more than $25,000 is less progressive than the graduated rates in New York, New Jersey and other states. But, compared with the current regime, it is a coup for equity -- and stability, too. A sales tax swings sharply with economic ups and down, creating recurrent crises; income taxes are relatively steady.
The strongest counterargument is that an income tax yields a tempting heap of revenue. Republicans who object to the Weicker proposal were quick to demand more control over spending. Governor Weicker's budget for next year cuts $1.2 billion from the budget Gov. William O'Neill left him, and would actually be 2 percent less than this year's -- an extraordinary accomplishment. But the spending cappers want controls written into law, as they are in half the 40 states with income taxes. Statutory strictures are arbitrary, but they can be made workable.
Addressing the General Assembly in person, the Governor said, "Neither you nor I signed on to muck around in the mistakes of the past; we're in the future business." With admirable boldness and Weickerian bluntness, he has defined the debate.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial
