HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
Down the Middle?

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif.

 BODY:
Pete Wilson, California's new Republican Governor, has one picture behind his desk: of Ronald Reagan. In his inaugural speech last month he hailed Mr. Reagan. But among former governors he also praised Democrat Pat Brown and Earl Warren, the great liberal Republican.
Mr. Wilson is coming on as something unusual in American politics: nonpartisan. In a rush of early actions there has been hardly a whiff of ideology. He put a Democrat in his cabinet, and he proposed new programs for prenatal and child care. 
 Is nonpartisanship possible? I asked in an interview the other day. He replied that some party conflict was inevitable, for example on reapportionment. California, gaining seven seats in the House, will soon have to redraw Congressional district lines.
"But I have consciously sought to minimize partisan friction," Mr. Wilson said. Voters, he said, had "an accurate perception" that important issues were not being resolved in part because politicians spent "a great deal of time and energy on partisan gamesmanship."
Two colossal problems confronted him when he left the Senate and took office as Governor on Jan. 7. California was going to be $7 billion short of revenue over the next 18 months. And after four years of drought it faced a critical water shortage.
Governor Wilson proposed some modest tax increases and lots of budget cuts. The cuts hit some sensitive areas. For one, he proposed zero funding of mandatory provisions for cost-of-living increases.
Welfare payments to families would also be trimmed, by $61 a month. The Governor justified that cut by saying California's payments in the program of Aid for Dependent Children had risen 150 percent in the last 15 years, and become a disincentive to employment.
But at the same time he proposed a series of programs for what he called "prevention" instead of "remedial actions with big price tags but uncertain results." Altogether, the new programs would cost $200 million. They focus on children.
One new program would establish a public-private system of medical insurance for poor women, covering prenatal care. Others would establish health and social services in schools, and add money for Head Start.
Mr. Wilson proposed funds for mental health counseling in elementary schools, saying "I want to discover that a child is suffering from depression that prevents learning when she is 6 -- not when she is 16." And he urged a substantial increase for contraceptive services and family planning education, "among the most sensible and humane investments we can make in our strategy of prevention."
When drug-addicted women give birth to damaged children, he said, the women should be counseled and treated. He said, "Rehabilitation is our best assurance against their delivery of a second addicted newborn."
The water problem is daunting. California is in the grip of its worst drought since the 1930's -- when, Mr. Wilson noted, the state "had one-fifth of the population we do now."
The first step, he said, is "to assure the health and safety, the sanitation of all Californians. Then you're in the business of apportioning economic hardship. Nature has already done a considerable amount of that."
What about novel ideas, like water desalination?
"There's no doubt of the ability to desalinize sea water," he said.
"The difference between Santa Barbara and Saudi Arabia is that the Saudis know they need water, and they also know it ain't going to rain there -- not next year or the next hundred. They don't know that in Santa Barbara. You know, it may rain next year! So Santa Barbara has to think: My God, is it worth this investment? Again, it's economics."
Would a desalination plant need a nuclear or oil-fired electric power plant? I asked. Neither is a realistic possibility now, he said, in a state with serious air quality problems. "Maybe natural gas would be feasible."
Governor Wilson won points from environmentalists by calling for a new state environmental protection agency and shifting pesticide control to it from the Agriculture Department. He also appointed a noted conservationist, Douglas Wheeler of the World Wildlife Fund, as director of natural resources.
The Democrats control both houses of the California Legislature. So far they have been friendly to the new Governor. It seems hard to believe that the era of good feeling can last. But perhaps the deliberately unexciting Pete Wilson has found a way to lead the country's largest state through a hard time.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: We'll Pay Dearly for Exporting Jobs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"But Are There Enough Jobs for the Poor" by David R. Riemer (letter, Feb. 5) is too narrow. Yes, getting people into jobs is the preferred solution, not creating another government program, even a Civilian Conservation Corps. A far simpler, less expensive, more effective course would be to stop exporting jobs.
American trade policy has resulted in a massive giveaway of the very jobs most needed to remove people from homelessness, hopelessness and welfare. Apparel is a classic example of the surrender of tens of thousands of jobs to workers in Communist China, Bangladesh and other third-world countries. The reason for this is not productivity, quality or achievement in the workplace, but price.
In our on-again, off-again trade negotiations, the Bush Administration proposes a further liberalization of textile and apparel import policy, which would virtually insure the further reduction of this work force by more than one million jobs in 10 years or less. Apparel, the most labor-intensive part of this complex, will bear the brunt of these further reductions. These are the very jobs the less educated can handle, the entry-level positions in manufacturing.
Our trade policy leadership expresses confidence in high tech as the future of American employment, just as it expressed confidence in service jobs and, more recently, in the "information economy," as if that implied a new kind of workless workplace that will generate a national solution to employment problems. Services and information are developed and used principally by or on behalf of those who generate physical wealth. When that output is surrendered at home and moved abroad, the rest follows. Japanese producers will not long permit themselves to be dependent on United States companies for financing, software or technology.
America's strength lies in a diverse economy that can provide opportunities for all its people, not just those smart or lucky enough to afford college or technical educations, or professional training. Not everyone will be able to master the requirements of labor in a high-tech environment in which most manufacturing and assembly is handled by robots and the jobs involve building and maintaining them. Some must find their role in more basic activities.
We are giving away tens of thousands of those jobs now, even as domestic sweater and other apparel factories close and still more workers are put onto unemployment. These closings are not so easily reversed. Like deregulating the savings and loan associations, this "market" approach to trade may be great for a few for a while, but will be devastating to the country as a whole when the bills come in.
 
SETH M. BODNER
Executive Director, National Knitwear & Sportswear Association
New York, Feb. 5, 1991

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Amax Coal Buys Cannelton Concern

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 14

 BODY:
Amax Coal Industries, the nation's third-largest coal producer, today bought the Cannelton Holding Company and its large, low-sulfur reserves in West Virginia.
Amax Coal, based in Indianapolis, paid $100 million to the Algoma Steel Corporation in Canada, a unit of Dofasco Inc. in Hamilton, Ontario, an Amax spokesman, Kevin Feeney, said. The deal is expected to be closed by next month. 
 The move follows Amax's strategy of increasing its holdings in relatively stable energy concerns to complement its business in the more cyclical aluminum business, analysts said.
The deal also brings Amax more reserves of low-sulfur coal, a commodity that was heavily sought after the clean air amendments were enacted last year. The law requires electric utilities to reduce the sulfur dioxide emissions created when coal is burned. Low-sulfur coal would help utilities meet the new standards.
Amax Coal, a unit of the New York-based Amax Inc., ranks third in the industry, after the Peabody Coal Company and Consolidated Coal. It shipped about 46 million tons of steam coal last year, mostly to electric utilities and industrial companies.
Last year, Cannelton shipped about six million tons of coal, almost 70 percent of which was low-sulfur steam coal. It also supplies metallurgical coal to Algoma. Cannelton holds 138 million tons of economically recoverable reserves, of which 80 percent are low sulfur.
Analysts said an acquisition by Amax Coal was not unexpected. Last year, it was rebuffed in its attempt to buy Peabody. It was outbid by Hanson P.L.C., a British concern that owned 45 percent of the company.
Amax said this week that it had produced 44 million tons of coal last year, of which nearly 31 million came from low-sulfur reserves in Wyoming. It produced 6.2 million tons in Indiana and 5.4 million tons in Illinois from primarily high-sulfur mines.
Last year, Amax mined only 440,769 tons of coal in West Virginia.
On the New York Stock Exchange today, Amax's shares rose 12.5 cents each, to $12.75.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 16, 1991, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article on the Company News page of Business Day yesterday about Amax Inc. misstated the closing price of the company's stock on Thursday. It was $25.25 a share, down 50 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Goodyear Executive To Head Celeron Unit

BYLINE: By Daniel F. Cuff

 BODY:
At a late date in his career, George R. Hargreaves has been handed a challenge by the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company. He has been named as the next president and chief executive of Goodyear's Celeron Corporation subsidiary, generally acknowledged to be the company's white elephant.
Celeron, which runs the All American Pipeline, an oil pipeline stretching from California to Texas, posted a loss of $52.9 million last year and was a heavy contributor to Goodyear's $38.3 million loss for the year. 
 Mr. Hargreaves, 61 years old, is currently vice president and treasurer of Goodyear, which is based in Akron, Ohio. He will take over the Houston-based Celeron on March 1. Robert W. Milk, who currently runs Celeron, will then go on special assignment until April 30, when he retires at age 65.
"Celeron and its All American Pipeline represent a considerable opportunity and challenge for its management team," Tom H. Barrett, Goodyear's chairman, said in a statement.
Celeron has been hurt by low oil prices and domestic production in recent years. An increase in the price of oil, however, could lift the pipeline's prospects.
Goodyear got into the oil business in 1983 as a move to diversify. It bought Celeron and the All American Pipeline Company for about $800 million. The pipeline was folded into Celeron, and Celeron has since sold many of its other assets.
Goodyear spent an additional $1 billon to construct the 1,225-mile pipeline. The pipeline has never run at anywhere near capacity.
"Circumstance changed, economics changed," Mr. Milk, has said of the project.
Mr. Hargreaves was in Houston yesterday, out of the office, and could not be reached for an interview, a Goodyear spokesman said. Mr. Hargreaves, who was born in Akron, joined Goodyear in 1971. He was named vice president and treasurer in 1987 after serving as finance director for Goodyear Great Britain. Mr. Hargreaves is a graduate of Harvard and Case Western Reserve universities.

HEADLINE: Governor of Louisiana Says He May Abandon Democrats

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BATON ROUGE, La., Feb. 14

 BODY:
Faced with poor showings in public opinion polls and a revolt by his fellow Democrats in the State Legislature, Gov. Buddy Roemer of Louisiana says he may abandon the Democratic Party and run for re-election this year as a Republican.
Mr. Roemer says he is disaffected with the ideological drift of his party at the national level; Louisiana politicians say he is motivated not so much by ideology as by a calculated political strategy for survival in the fall election. But whatever the motive, his intentions have drawn no small interest from national figures in both parties, and they are trying to sway his decision. 
 A defection by a Democratic Governor, especially in a year in which only three other Governors are up for re-election, would be an important victory in the Republicans' long-standing effort to boost their hold over local and state offices in the South.
 
Staving Off David Duke
 In addition, Republican officials hope a Roemer candidacy would weaken the strength of State Representative David Duke, a former Ku Klux Klan leader, who is expected to run for governor and whose political successes in Louisiana as a Republican are viewed by many national Republicans as an embarrassment.
Among the Republicans who have called Mr. Roemer to lobby him are Senator Phil Gramm, the Texas Republican who himself was a longtime Democrat and who has been efforts to convert conservative Democrats.
On the Democratic side, national leaders have enlisted the help of one of Mr. Roemer's fellow Southerners, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas. Ronald H. Brown, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, has repeatedly tried to reach Governor Roemer by telephone but to no avail, according to Ginny Terzano, the committee's press secretary.
Billy Nungesser, chairman of the Republican State Committee, said in an interview today that after speaking to the Governor and many others involved in the deliberations, "it is my opinion, my knowledgeable opinion, that Roemer is ready to switch when he is confident that no other major Republican candidate will enter the race."
While in Congress between 1980 and 1987, Governor Roemer frequently voted with Republicans, and he was one of the Southern "boll weevil" Democrats who supported the Reagan Administration's fiscal policies. He campaigned for the governor's mansion four years ago as an outsider who would battle the capital's well-entrenched Democratic establishment.
He has sought to raise taxes, reduce perquisites for legislators and tighten ethical standards. His opponents consider him abrasive and unwilling to keep political promises.
 The fueding has left the Governor with few ties to the Democratic Party. Even as national figures are lobbying to keep him, some local party figures would be just as glad if he left.
"I don't know of any effort, public or private, by the state Democratic leadership to try and dissuade him from leaving the party," said State Senator Allen R. Bares, a Democrat who was unseated as President of the Senate last year by fellow Democrats who accused him of being too closely allied to the Governor.
Though he acknowledges that he is considering shifting parties, Mr. Roemer is somewhat coy about the reasons. "The question I've got to decide," he said last week, "is, Do I do more for my neighbors trying to make the Democratic Party more realistic economically or the Republican Party more sound socially?"
Mr. Roemer denies that he is motivated by efforts to save his own political career. Asserting that he could win regardless of his party, he said: "Quite frankly, this next election works either way. We have checked the numbers."
But local leaders say he is searching for a strategy to survive what promises to be a very difficult re-election campaign. Simply put, they say, he is offering to switch parties if the Republicans will guarantee that he will be their standard-bearer.
The Governor already faces a formidable challenge within the Democratic Party. Edwin Edwards, the Democratic former Governor whom Mr. Roemer defeated in 1987, announced his candidacy last week. Mr. Edwards retains a substantial following, especially among black voters.
As for Mr. Duke, he will be a formidable presence in the race. Though he was disowned by the Republicans for his white-supremacist associations, he captured 44 percent of the vote in his first statewide race when he challenged Sen. J. Bennett Johnston Jr., a Democrat, last fall.
Under Louisiana's open primary law, all candidates regardless of affiliation will face the voters on Oct. 19. If no one wins a majority, a runoff is held among the top two.
Mr. Nungesser said the possibility of Mr. Roemer's switching had not been initiated by the Republicans. "There has been no courtship," he said. "This was initiated by Roemer based on what he and everybody else could see in the polls."
 
The Calculations
 In a poll published last month by The Baton Rouge Sunday Advocate, Mr. Roemer was preferred by a solid plurality of 45 percent of respondents in a three-way race with Mr. Edwards and Mr. Duke. But when mainstream Republicans were added to the list, the Governor dropped to near-even with Mr. Edwards. The margin of sampling error was plus or minus 3.3 percentage points.
Edward Renwick, the political scientist at Loyola University in New Orleans who conducted the poll, said: "Edwards and Duke each have a solid core vote. If a significant Republican candidate enters the race, he and Roemer will be competing against each other for the moderate-conservative white vote. That could very well produce an Edwards-Duke runoff, and that would be a nightmare for the Republicans."
Mr. Nungesser, the state Republican chief, said Governor Roemer asked late last year whether the party would be willing to withhold its support from any candidate so as to avoid the diluting effect of a crowded field.
He said he told the Governor that the party was determined to run a solid candidate. Subsequently, he said, Governor Roemer began negotiations to frame a deal in which he would switch parties and become the endorsed candidate and all other mainstream Republican candidates would agree to stay out of the election. Several other local politicians of both parties confirmed that account.
Chief among those potential candidates is former Gov. David Treen. According to Mr. Nungesser, Mr. Treen recently met with Governor Roemer and is now at a vacation home in Florida considering his options.

HEADLINE: Weicker's Tactic Is to Sell Income Tax to the People

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Feb. 14

 BODY:
Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut, who was elected Governor without the support of either major political party, began a campaign today to leapfrog the legislature and convince the people of his state to accept what they have opposed in the past: an income tax.
On the morning after Mr. Weicker stunned the General Assembly and the state with his plan to resolve Connecticut's fiscal crisis and ease the recession in a single blow by throwing out the state tax system and starting over, the effort at selling the package began. In his shirtsleeves, meeting with reporters and politicians, Mr. Weicker showed that the push was on -- if not to make people like his ideas, then at least to make them understood. 
 In doing this, Mr. Weicker was making clear that he hoped to avoid the fate of the Governor of New Jersey, Jim Florio, who pressed through a major overhaul of state taxes but was reviled for failing, as he admitted later, to explain his program adequately and to rally support for it.
"I don't intend to get into a war of words," Mr. Weicker said. "I intend to get into a presentation of facts."
A sampling of opinion among Connecticut residents, business executives and local officials showed support for the Governor's plan to cut the sales tax but concern over the proposed state income tax. [Page B4.]
 
'A Tremendous Test'
 Mr. Weicker, a former Republican, was elected last year as a third-party candidate, using the same kind of nonparty personal appeal. But many lawmakers and residents say his selling job will be much harder this time around, and much more complicated.
"This will be a tremendous test of his leadership," said the State Senate majority leader, Cornelius O'Leary, a Democrat from Windsor Locks. He said that he gave Mr. Weicker's plan a "less than even" chance of success in becoming law as it now stands but that much would ride on the Governor's powers of persuasion.
"If he truly believes that this is the only option, that this is the best thing for the state, then he's got to convince the people of the state that this is the case," he said. "It will be a very formidable task."
Mr. Weicker's budget plan, with an interlocking series of deep spending reductions and state layoffs, combined with major tax increases and tax cuts -- all crowned by the introduction of a 6 percent income tax and a nearly 50 percent cut in the 8 percent sales tax -- would change most aspects of public finance in Connecticut.
Budget officials say that low-income residents would see a cut in their taxes but that the majority of residents would pay more, in some cases much more. Companies in the state would generally see their taxes cut. Aid to state universities would be cut, forcing increases in tuition of 20 to 30 percent. Some budget items would be eliminated entirely, such as the $20,000-a-year coupon program to help the elderly poor buy fresh produce. About 1,100 state employees would be laid off.
 
'Jumping Up and Down'
 Mr. Weicker, who outlined his budget plan Wednesday night before the General Assembly, conceded in the interview that many people were "jumping up and down" about his plan. But he said details, once made clear to the public, would overcome the partisan political comments that he said were already emanating from the Assembly.
"I don't think the people are going to stand for a political resolution of the fiscal problem," he said.
Mr. Weicker's press secretary, Avice A. Meehan, said the Governor's first major budget whistle stop would be next week -- a two-hour television call-in show devoted entirely to the budget.
One of the main facts of the budget plan is that even Mr. Weicker does not like it. Inaugurated on Jan. 9, he said it was soon clear to him that the old tax system built around sales and corporate profits taxes had reached its limit.
The state faces a projected $2.4 billion shortfall in tax revenue over the next 16 months, with its current biggest tax sources -- the 8 percent sales tax and 13.8 percent corporate profits tax -- already both the highest rates for state taxes in the nation. His plan would cut the sales tax to 4.25 percent and the corporate tax to 11.5 percent.
Mr. Weicker said that while almost everyone would hate some aspect of the package, the idea was to build in things that those same critics might find indispensable enough not to kill the whole thing. "We felt that as long as everybody takes a hit, there is less basis for claiming one group against the other," he said.
For liberals and conservatives alike, the plan offers jolts of pain and gain woven tightly together. The income tax, for example, long abhorred by many lawmakers who argue that it would open the gates of unrestrained spending growth, has been grafted onto an austere budget that actually reduces most state spending in the fiscal year that begins on July 1.
 
An Inordinate Impact
 The sales tax, long criticized as having an inordinate impact on the state's poorer residents, would be cut sharply, but the list of taxable items would be greatly expanded so that people would pay less of the tax each time they made a purchase, but pay it more often. All clothing purchases would be taxed, for instance, as would newspapers, gasoline and international telephone calls.
There were indications today that ambivalence would keep the plan afloat for the moment. The Connecticut Business and Industry Association, for example, said that if its members could be assured that the spending and business tax cuts were real, the income tax would get a fair and open hearing. Some citizens' groups said the spending cuts might be swallowed if a progressive income tax were assured.
"There's a lot of people trying to kill this plan, but we're not among them," said Ethan Rome, legislative and political director for the Connecticut Citizen Action Group, which has advocated an income tax for years as a way to make the tax system fairer for poor people.
 
To Seek Graduated Scale
 Mr. Rome said his 100,000-member group would push to introduce a graduated scale into the income tax that would make the tax bite rise with income levels. Under the current plan, all income over $25,000 a year would be taxed at 6 percent for a couple filing jointly. For a single person, the first $12,500 would be tax free.
Some questions about the Weicker plan remain unanswerable. The state does not know yet, for example, how many of the thousands of residents who commute to jobs in New York or Massachusetts or Rhode Island -- or who commute into Connecticut from those states -- would see their taxes change.
But the acting deputy commissioner at the state's Office of Policy and Management, Lorraine M. Aronson, said that for most people, Connecticut's income tax would be lower than those charged in the other states.
The rule of interstate taxes, she said, is that the state where the money was earned gets first crack at the revenue. If the home state has a higher rate, it can then charge the marginal difference, but not the full tax.
No one, she said, would pay the full tax charged in each state.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. in Hartford yesterday. (Steve Miller for The New York Times)
 
Chart: "Highlights of Weicker's Proposals"
 The budget that Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut presented to the General Assembly on Wednesday includes scores of tax revisions and spending cuts for the fiscal year that begins on July 1. Following are some of the proposals.
 
Taxes and Other Revenue
 
* Establish personal income tax of 6 percent on adjusted gross income over $25,000 for couples and $12,500 for individuals, beginning July 1.
 
* Eliminate the tax on capital gains, dividends and interest income, which would be taxed as personal income beginning July 1.
 
* Reduce sales tax to 4.25 percent, from 8 percent, beginning July 1, and apply it to many goods and services that are now exempt, including clothing, gasoline, newspapers, haircuts and movie tickets.
 
* Eliminate 20 percent corporate tax surcharge, as of Jan. 1, 1991.
 
* Increase motor vehicle registration renewal fee to $90, from $62. Increase driver's license fee to $90 for six years, from $31 for four years.
 
* Increase fee for pretrial alcohol-education program to $600, from $250. Add $20 to the fines for some motor vehicle violations.
 
Spending
 
* Eliminate 1,855 state jobs, including up to 1,100 layoffs. But 1,181 jobs would be added, for a net loss of 674.
 
* Eliminate most cost-of-living increases included in labor contracts covering state employees.
 
* Save $80 million by reducing school aid to wealthy towns.
 
* Close 7 of 19 Department of Motor Vehicles offices.
 
* Close four offtrack betting parlors.
 
The Deficit
 
* Eliminate $707.4 million revenue shortfall in fiscal 1991 by borrowing, to be paid back over three years.
 
(Source: 1991-92 Governor's Budget Summary)

HEADLINE: Peru's Neighbors Halt Food Imports

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 14

 BODY:
Seeking to contain a cholera outbreak in Peru, health authorities across Latin America halted food imports today and tightened controls on people arriving from that country.
 Since the outbreak was publicly identified as cholera 10 days ago, 86 Peruvians have died and 12,669 people have fallen ill, the health authorities reported in Lima today. 
It's the first major outbreak of cholera that we have had in this century in the Western Hemisphere, and it's major," David Brandling-Bennett, an epidemiologist for the Pan American Health Organization, said today in a telephone interview from Washington.
 At the international airport here, in Mexico City and in other capitals, health inspectors checked passengers arriving from Peru for symptoms of the fatal disease -- dehydration, vomiting and diarrhea. Airplane sewage and food garbage was tested for the cholera bacillus.
 
Uncooked Food Banned
 Tightening land exits from Peru, health officials in Ecuador, Bolivia and Chile banned the entry of uncooked food from Peru, largely fish, fruits and vegetables.
 In Bolivia, navy boats patrolled Lake Titicaca with orders to seize and destroy fresh food shipped across the lake from Peru. On Tuesday, Argentina banned the import of Peruvian fish and shellfish, whether fresh, frozen or canned.
 Cholera, a disease that can be fatal if untreated within hours of the first symptoms, is transmitted through water, shellfish or vegetables contaminated by the disease.
 Peru has not suffered from a cholera outbreak since the 1880's. But since Feb. 4, the disease has been reported in cities up and down the nation's Pacific Coast and most recently in the nation's Andean highlands.
 
3 Cases Reported in Ecuador
 According to news reports, there have been three cases in neighboring Ecuador, but these have not been confirmed by Ecuadorean health officials. Ecuador has taken emergency health measures in two southern provinces where 60,000 people a day cross the border with Peru. Ecuador started distributing thousands of pamphlets in the border area today instructing residents on precautions to take, such as boiling drinking water and thoroughly cooking food, to avoid contracting the disease.
 "My advice to tourists is to go ahead with their travel," Dr. Brandling-Bennett said. "It is the indigenous people living under poor conditions, drinking poor water, who are at risk."
 
U.S. Travelers Advisory
 Addressing travelers' concerns about cholera, the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta said in a statement today: "The risk to U.S. travelers of acquiring cholera in endemic areas is low. During the first 20 years of the current pandemic, only 10 cases in U.S. travelers were reported to C.D.C. -- representing a risk of acquiring a reported case of cholera of less than one per 500,000 returning travelers."
 Concerning a spread of the disease, many health experts believe that Peru's neighbors are better prepared to combat a cholera epidemic because they have better health care and better water and sewage treatment facilities. One of Latin America's poorest countries, Peru suffers from widespread unemployment and malnutrition. More than half of the seven million inhabitants of Lima, the capital, live in shantytowns without access to proper sewage disposal facilities.
 To help Peru contain the outbreak, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador have sent aid, largely saline solution that reverses the fatal dehydration caused by cholera. On Tuesday, the European Community pledged $700,000 in emergency medical aid. France has sent epidemiologists and a field hospital capable of treating 10,000 people.
 With the help of the foreign aid -- rehydration salts, saline solution, and antibiotics -- Peru has been able to reduce the mortality rate from five percent of all cases two weeks ago, to less than .7 percent on Wednesday, Peruvian Health Ministry officials said.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 16, 1991, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption yesterday about an outbreak of cholera in Peru misidentified the microbe that causes the disease. It is a bacterium, not a virus.

HEADLINE: Your Money;
I.R.S. Eases Rule On Outplacement

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
For people caught in the wave of layoffs sweeping the nation's businesses, there is one bit of encouraging tax news. The Internal Revenue Service, which ruled in December 1988 that the value of outplacement services should be treated as taxable income to recipients, withdrew that ruling late last year and said it would study whether employer-provided outplacement services could be treated as an excludable fringe benefit.
"It's a very hot topic," said Avery E. Neumark, a partner in Weber, Lipshie & Company in New York, and director of employee benefits and executive compensation for the firm. "With the coming of recession and sudden cutbacks implemented by all types of employers, a ruling like this just didn't sit well." 
 Industry and trade groups, bar associations and others lobbied with the I.R.S. last year to change its position. The American Electronics Association, for example, wrote, "By requiring outplacement counseling to be treated as taxable income, the I.R.S. is kicking terminated employees while they are down."
The basic legal test of whether a benefit can be excluded from taxable income as a "working condition fringe benefit" is whether an employee who paid for the same benefit personally could deduct it as an unreimbursed business expense, said Mr. Neumark, who is chairman of the American Bar Association's subcommittee on fringe benefits. Examples include subscriptions to business and professional journals, professional dues and the use of a car for business purposes.
Outplacement services provide dismissed employees -- executives and managers generally -- with temporary office space and telephone service. They prepare people to look for another job, teaching them to how to make contacts and to handle themselves in interviews, sometimes videotaping practice sessions. They give advice on preparing resumes and writing letters, for example, but do not handle actual job placement. That is generally done by an executive search firm.
Outplacement fees are high, Mr. Neumark noted. They are usually either fixed or a percentage of an employee's annual salary. Either way $10,000 to $20,000 would not be uncommon. Thus, if the services are deemed taxable to employees, they could be liable for thousands of dollars in taxes without having received the cash needed to pay those taxes, and that may discourage people from accepting the services, outplacement experts say.
The cost of providing the services is deductible to employers in any event, Mr. Neumark said, but business groups have lobbied to have them treated as a nontaxable working condition fringe because providing the services is beneficial to employersand they want people to accept them.
"Outplacement services benefit the employer by mending fences with the terminated employee -- averting possible lawsuits charging wrongful dismissal and avoiding revelations of confidential information," he said, "and at the same time creating good will among remaining employees."
The I.R.S. position that the services were taxable income came in a private letter ruling. Although such rulings are technically binding only on the person addressed, their directives are generally widely followed by other taxpayers who do not want to run afoul of the I.R.S. The agency withdrew the ruling and agreed to study the matter in the light of new regulations on fringe benefits last year. That leaves the issue unresolved, but signals to many employers that they need not report the value of the services on terminated employees' W-2 forms.
"Individuals need to be aware that this is under study," Mr. Neumark said. "Certain field agents are focusing on this benefit, usually when the audit an employer." If that happens and the service decides at some future date that the benefits are taxable income, it could affect the recipients. In that case, he continued, a recipient could then deduct the value of the services as an unreimbursed business expense, but that is a miscellaneous itemized deduction that can be taken only to the extent that it exceeds 2 percent of adjusted gross income.
Any job-hunting expenses incurred are deductible if they are in the same line of work, Mr. Neumark noted, so it is important to keep records of everything -- postage for mailing letters, lunches with business acquaintances, telephone costs -- because they add up.
But job-search expenses are not deductible for people who change careers. "And if there is a substantial break between the old job and the new job," the deduction may be denied, he said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
A Credit Review By First Chicago

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Feb. 15

 BODY:
The First Chicago Corporation reviewed the credit backgrounds of its New England credit card holders in August to find customers who have been delinquent on other loans. Once identified, the bank either reduced the card holder's line of credit or revoked the card altogether. A spokeswoman for the bank said it was the only time the bank had selected credit histories in a particular region as a target.
The spokeswoman, Lisa Petrison, said, "Any further action of the sort will be done on a national basis." Another spokeswoman, Lisabeth Weiner, said the bank focused on New England, which accounts for a very small portion of First Chicago's 6.6 million credit card accounts, because the recession is more severe in that region. United States Representative Joseph Kennedy 2d, Democrat of Massachusetts, called the review discriminatory.

HEADLINE: U.S. Securities Mixed in Volatile Day

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, with bills and notes slightly lower and the longer maturities showing small gains. But dealers said the price movements masked a day of sharp swings, mostly caused by short-lived hopes of peace in the Persian Gulf.
Early reports that Iraq had agreed to leave Kuwait caused prices to spurt upward, but President Bush's description of Iraq's terms as a "cruel hoax" ended the rally. The bond market then turned to the day's flow of economic statistics and found then essentially neutral. 
 "The slight decline in January's Producer Price Index was disappointing, but this was offset by the sharper drop in industrial output," said Robert H. Chandross, chief economist at Lloyds Bank. "The big improvement in our trade balance in December was expected. Over all, the prospect of a long weekend at a time of uncertainty over developments in the gulf war inhibited most market participants from taking any significant positions."
 
 Weekend Preparations
 Late in the session, as market participants squared their books for the three-day weekend, the Treasury's benchmark new long bonds, the 7 7/8 percent issue due February 2021, were offered at 98 27/32, up 4/32 on the day, which shaved its yield to 7.97 percent, from 7.98 percent the day before and a week earlier.
Among other representative Treasury issues traded in the secondary market, the new 6 7/8 percent percent notes of 1994 fell 4/32, to 99 21/32, for a yield of 7.00 percent; the new 7.75 percent long notes of 2001 rose 2/32, to 99 26/32, to yield 7.77 percent.
Meanwhile, the $12 billion of new two-year notes that the Treasury plans to auction on Wednesday traded on a when-issued basis to yield 6.81 percent, up 6 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, on the day. The $9 billion of new five-year notes scheduled for sale the next day traded on the same basis to yield 7.40 percent, up a basis point.
 
 Fed Adds Reserves
 The Fed added $2 billion of reserves to the banking system a day after the central bank injected a much larger amount of funds. Both moves were aimed mainly at avoiding a shortage of credit yesterday when purchases in last week's $34.5 billion of refunding issues had to be completed. If so, the Fed's actions served their purpose as the funds rate that banks charge each other dropped from 6 7/16 percent early in the day to 5 percent at the close. The Fed's perceived target for the fund rate is 6.25 percent.
In any event, dealers said the Fed's operations did not influence the discount rates on Treasury bills, which are normally most sensitive to any central bank maneuvers. The 90-day bills rose 6 basis points, to 5.83 percent; six-month bills climbed 7 basis points, to 5.91 percent, and the one-year bills advanced 5 basis points, to 5.89 percent. Some dealers attributed the rise in rates to the shifting of funds from bills to the stock market.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Iraqi Statement;
Baghdad's Offer and Conditions for Ending War Over Kuwait

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15

 BODY:
Following is a transcript of the Baghdad radio address today on a withdrawal from Kuwait, as provided by the State Department via the Foreign Broadcast Information Service:
Honorable Arabs, true Muslim believers, freedom-loving people around the world. Ever since the United States, Zionism, and the United States' imperialist Western allies came to realize that an Arab Muslim country, Iraq, was developing a force of its own, capable of being a counterweight to the imperialist-backed Zionism -- a free, honorable force, resolved selflessly to tackle Zionist aggression and greed, and to reject imperialist hegemony over the region -- the United States, Zionism, and all colonial powers who entertained hatred against Arabs and Muslims set about taking measures, making decisions, and waging campaigns of falsehoods and incitement against Iraq, with the object of thwarting the creation and development of this force, and isolating and punishing Iraq, because it has faithfully, determinedly, and efficiently gone beyond the limits set by the United States, imperialism, and imperialist forces for the states of the region. 
 The years 1988 and 1989 saw sustained campaigns in the press and other media and by officials in the United States and other imperialist nations to pave the way for the fulfillment of vicious aims.
The year 1990 saw these campaigns escalate feverishly and mount day by day. The aim was clear to us and to all conscious Arabs and true Muslims, as well as to all the free people who believe in freedom and justice in the world. The aim was to pave the way for destroying this nascent force and to tip the regional balance back in favor of the United States, Zionism, and the imperialists -- the balance that has been in place for many decades and that has prevented the Arabs from regaining their rights and the usurped and occupied lands in Palestine, the Golan Heights, and Lebanon.
It has also stood in the way of the Arab nation realizing its aspirations for revival, progress, and justice in the interest of occupying its deserved place in the world by virtue of its glorious history and its great contribution to human civilization.
In the early months of 1990, these campaigns intensified, expanded, and assumed a hysterical dimension, with daily incitements to hit Iraq, liquidate its leadership, and deprive it of the means to achieve a revival and progress. Along with other imperialist nations, the United States took a string of measures and made unfair decisions banning the export of whatever might contribute to Iraq's development and its scientific and industrial revival.
 
Economic Blockade
 These decisions called for an effective economic blockade, including the cancellation of food contracts in March 1990. It was also clear that, in concert with the Zionist entity, the United States was preparing to hit Iraq's scientific and industrial facilities and liquidate its patriotic, believing leadership.
When the United States discovered that its plan, which largely rests on the Zionist military capability, fell short of achieving its evil aims, it brought into the conspiracy its hirelings, corrupt agents, and conspiratorial rulers in the region -- the enemies of God.
Their role was to undermine Iraq's economy and then push Iraq to the brink of economic collapse.
In the meantime, the United States set about tightening up the network of the imperialist alliance in the interests of forging a political and military U.S.-Atlantic alliance with the aim of dealing a blow to Iraq and controlling the region, when the opportunity to achieve this aim presented itself with the lopsided balance represented in the Soviet Union becoming preoccupied with internal developments.
O Iraqis, O Arabs, O Muslims, O free men of the world. The events of Aug. 2, 1990, in substance and goals, were not as portrayed by the U.S. and colonialist propaganda, or as were described by the traitorous rulers, followers of America. These events were a national, pan-Arab, and Islamic uprising against the conspiracy and conspirators -- an uprising against injustice, immorality, corruption, and imperialist-Zionist-colonialist hegemony of the region, and against the plotters whose role in the U.S.-Zionist conspiracy became exposed.
Thus, the imperialistic-Zionist-Atlantic alliance revealed its true goals and intentions from the very first hours of those events. The alliance massed armies and forces, and organized the biggest and most malicious campaigns of misinformation, lies, and deception witnessed by the world in the modern age.
 
U.N. Actions
 This oppressive and sly imperialist-Zionist-Atlantic alliance manipulated the United Nations to issue in unparalleled swiftness a series of unjust and unprecedented resolutions, although this body failed throughout several decades to fulfill the simplest demands of the Arab nation and preserve the simplest rights of the Arabs in Palestine, despite the clarity of the Arab right and the severity of the tragedy of the struggling Palestinian people, from which other Arabs, including the oppressed Lebanese people, have suffered.
This tyrannical alliance has forced its will on the world. It has pursued terrorist and extortionist tactics, as well as bribery, not to mention the malicious means of lying and deception found in the bag of tricks of imperialism, Zionism, and the colonial powers to pave the way for the aggression against Iraq.
O glorious Iraqis, O dear Arabs, O faithful Muslims, O free men and honorable persons throughout the world. The aggression that has been launched on Iraq, the courageous, proud, holy warrior, faithful, and patient country, is unprecedented in history. The entire history of mankind never records such an alliance in which the United States as well as two big powers participated -- not to mention several other countries, 30 in number -- against the holy warrior, courageous, and patient Iraq, whose population does not exceed 18 million people. It is an evil rancorous, malicious, and atheistic alliance against the bastion of faith and principles, against the center of freedom where the call for justice and fairness is made.
Over the past month, the United States and its allies, along with the Zionist entity, which has taken part in the aggression from the beginning, launched savage and destructive raids on the Iraqi people, on their economic, scientific, cultural and service property, and also on their religious centers and the sites of ancient civilizations in Iraq.
These raids are unprecedented in history in terms of the enormous firepower used and in terms of the means of killing and destruction used in a manner that contravenes the United Nations Charter, the false international legitimacy, and the new world order, which they wanted to use as an order for U.S.-Atlantic hegemony over the world.
The United States and the partners in the evil alliance, the planes that fire their missiles from a distance, and the long-range missiles, have dropped huge quantities of bombs and explosives on women, children, and old people in all Iraq's cities and villages, and even on the nomad bedouins in the desert.
 
Allied Assaults
 They struck in a premeditated manner mosques, churches, schools, hospitals, civilian factories, bridges, main roads, telephone, electricity, and water centers, irrigation dams, cultural centers and sites in the country. They hit targets that have no connection any way whatsoever with the military effort or the military confrontation arena of which they have spoken.
Their latest crime was the ugly and dirty crime of the premeditated bombardment of a civilian shelter. They killed and burned hundreds of women, children, and old people. The aim of this unjust aggression was very clear, namely to proceed with the process of destruction that they desire and to punish the proud, free, and struggling Iraqi people, because they have chosen the road of freedom, independence, and glory, and have rejected humiliation, disgrace, and submission to the will of imperialism and Zionism.
The United States and its allies have waged a dirty and cowardly war against a courageous and faithful people. The history of peoples and nations and their fate are not decided by the material possessions of states and ruling regimes. How many strong and rich empires throughout history have fallen because they pursued the road of evil, cowardice, injustice, and decadence. This is the fate of tyrannical America and its decayed systems. It is the fate of Zionism and all the imperialist forces by the will of God.
Iraq has triumphed in this duel. It has triumphed because it has remained steadfast, courageous, faithful, proud, and strong willed. It has triumphed because it has maintained principles and the spiritual values inspired by the true religion of Islam and its noble heritage. Its material losses in this battle, despite their enormity, are small compared to its spirit of determination, its firm belief in principles, and strong determination to continue the course of renaissance and progress.
O dear Iraqis, O honest Arabs, O Muslims who truly believe in Islam, O honest and free men of the world. Proceeding from this firm and right feeling and this assessment of the nature of the showdown, and in order to rob the evil U.S.-Zionist-Atlantic alliance of the opportunity to achieve their premeditated goals, and in appreciation of the Soviet initiative conveyed by the envoy of the Soviet leadership, and in compliance with the principles outlined in leader President Saddam Hussein's initiative on Aug. 12, 1990, the Revolutionary Command Council has decided to declare the following:
 
Iraqi Demands
 First, Iraq's readiness to deal with Security Council resolution No. 660 of 1990, with the aim of reaching an honorable and acceptable political solution, including withdrawal. The first step that is required to be implemented as a pledge by Iraq regarding withdrawal will be linked to the following:
A. A total and comprehensive cease-fire on land, air, and sea.
B. For the Security Council to decide to abolish from the outset Resolutions 661, 662, 664, 665, 666, 667, 669, 670, 674, 677, and 678 and all the effects resulting from all of them, and to abolish all resolutions and measures of boycott and embargo, as well as the other negative resolutions and measures that were adopted by certain countries against Iraq unilaterally or collectively before Aug. 2, 1990, which were the real reasons for the gulf crisis, so that things may return to normal as if nothing had happened. Iraq should not receive any negative effects for any reasons.
C. For the United States and the other countries participating in the aggression, and all the countries that sent their forces from the region to withdraw all the forces, weapons and equipment which they have brought to the Middle East region before and after Aug. 2, 1990, whether in land, seas, oceans, or the gulfs, including the weapons and equipment that certain countries provided to Israel under the pretext of the crisis in the gulf, provided that these forces, weapons, and equipment are withdrawn during a period not exceeding one month from the date of cease-fire.
D. Israel must withdraw from Palestine and the Arab territories it is occupying in the Golan and southern Lebanon in implementation of the U.N. Security Council and the U.N. General Assembly resolutions. In case Israel fails to do this, the U.N. Security Council should then enforce against Israel the same resolutions it passed against Iraq.
E. Iraq's historical rights on land and at sea should be guaranteed in full in any peaceful solution.
F. The political arrangement to be agreed upon should proceed from the people's will and in accordance with a genuine democratic practice and not on the basis of the rights acquired by the Sabah family. Accordingly, the nationalist and Islamic forces should primarily participate in the political arrangement to be agreed upon.
 
Reparations to Baghdad
 Second, the countries that have participated in the aggression and in financing the aggression undertake to reconstruct what the aggression has destroyed in Iraq in accordance with the best specifications regarding all the enterprises and installations that were targeted by the aggression and at their expense. Iraq should not incur any financial expenses in this regard.
Third, all the debts of Iraq and countries of the region -- which were harmed by the aggression and which did not take part in the aggression, either directly or indirectly -- to the gulf countries and to the foreign countries that took part in the aggression should be written off.
Besides, relations between the rich nations and poor nations in the region and the world should be based on justice and fairness in such a way that puts the rich nations before clear commitments regarding the realization of development in poor nations, and thus removes their economic sufferings.
This should be based on the saying that the poor have a share to claim in the wealth of the rich. Moreover, the duplicitous approach pursued in handling the issues of peoples and nations should be halted, whether this approach is being pursued by the United Nations Security Council or by this or that country.
Fourth, the gulf states, including Iran, should be given the task of freely drawing up security arrangements in the region and of organizing relations among them without any foreign interference.
Fifth, to declare the Arabian Gulf region a zone free of foreign military bases and from any form of foreign military presence.
Everybody must undertake to observe this.
This is our argument, which we declare before the world, clear and shining against the traitors and their imperialist masters.
Our basic source of confidence, in addition to our reliance on the one and only God, will remain to be our great Iraqi people, our valiant and struggling armed forces, and those who believe in the path that we have chosen in fighting oppression and the oppressors.
Victory will certainly be realized against the oppressors in the coming days, as it had been certain in past times. God is with us. May the despicable be damned.
The Revolutionary Command Council. 29 Rajab 1411 Hegira, corresponding to Feb. 15, 1991.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Baghdad's Position;
Iraq Deals for First Time With U.N.'s Pullout Call

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15

 BODY:
The proposal presented today by Iraq marks the first time that Baghdad has mentioned a "readiness to deal" with Security Council Resolution 660 of Aug. 3, which condemned the invasion of Kuwait and demanded the immediate and unconditional withdrawal of Iraqi troops.
The statement also contains the first Iraqi use of the word "withdrawal" in connection with that resolution, though nowhere does the statement mention Kuwait. That omission leaves open the possibility that the Iraqis might be considering a partial withdrawal. 
 President Saddan Hussein has in the past drawn a distinction between what he calls the 19th province of Iraq, which encompasses most of Kuwaiti territory, and a part of the Rumaila oil field and two strategic islands that Baghdad has moved to incorporate into the province of Basra.
The proposal does not explicitly say Iraq will withdraw even if its long list of conditions are met. Rather, it expresses Iraq's "readiness to deal with" the resolution demanding withdrawal, according to the Arabic text of the transcript, which uses the verb "tamul," meaning "to consider seriously."
 
Issued by Command Council
 In explicitly using the word "withdrawal" and linking it to Resolution 660, today's proposal in one sense went further than a proposal by Mr. Hussein on Aug. 12, which offered his Government's most extensive statement of conditions that could lead to a resolution of the crisis. The August proposal had referred only to "the formulation of arrangments for the situation of Kuwait."
Unlike the Aug. 12 proposal, which was issued in the name of Mr. Hussein and read for him on television, the statement today was attributed only to the Revolutionary Command Council, which Mr. Hussein heads.
In dozens of interviews and public statements, both Mr. Hussein and his top aides have rejected the notion of any Iraqi withdrawal. At one point before the war began, Mr. Hussein said that for Iraq to leave Kuwait would be the same as having the United States relinquish Hawaii.
Today's proposal both includes and excludes demands made on Aug. 12. For example, it repeats the demand that Israel withdraw from "Palestine and the Arab territories it is occupying in the Golan and southern Lebanon." On the other hand, it omits a suggestion in the Aug. 12 declaration that the coalition forces be replaced with an inter-Arab force under the auspices of the United Nations.
 
New Condition Added
 The proposal also adds a number of conditions not included in the August declaration. Iraq is now specifically saying its withdrawal depends on the abrogation of Security Council resolutions against Iraq approved since its invasion of Kuwait, including those imposing a global embargo and holding Iraq liable for war damages and economic losses because of the crisis.
In its newest position, Iraq is also demanding a comprehensive withdrawal of the 28-nation coalition aligned against it, including the troops, weapons and equipment they brought to the region, presumably including American-made Patriot missiles that have largely neutralized Iraqi Scud missile attacks on Israeli targets.
Iraq, Iran and the Persian Gulf nations would be responsible for determining future security arrangments for the region, which would be declared a zone free of foreign military bases, the proposal said.
In a speech a year ago, Mr. Hussein first demanded the withdrawal of American vessels from the gulf, and the withdrawal of foreign forces from the region has been one of his favorite themes since the current crisis began. Today's proposal adds a new element: The forces and weapons would have to leave the region within a month of a cease-fire.
 
No Schedule for Pullout
 The proposal does not, however, give a deadline or schedule for the removal of Iraqi troops and equipment from Kuwait.
In addition to rejecting the Security Council resolution that holds Iraq responsible for war damages, the Iraqi proposal for the first time states that the allies should write off the foreign debts of Iraq and its allies in the region, presumably Jordan and Yemen.
The proposal repeats Iraq's demand that Kuwait's political future be determined by democratic process, and that the Sabah family should not automatically return to power. But it is sufficiently vague that it does not rule out the possibility that the Emir and his family could return.
On the negative side, since the proposal does not include the word Kuwait, it might also reflect Mr. Hussein's hope that the people of Kuwait would choose to merge with Iraq.

HEADLINE: NEW DATA SUGGEST NATION'S RECESSION COULD BE SLOWING

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15

 BODY:
In a report hinting that the economy's decline may be bottoming out, the Government said today that industrial output fell much less in January than in the two months before.
Output was down four-tenths of 1 percent last month after declines averaging three times that much in November and December. 
 At the same time, prices received by producers edged down one-tenth of 1 percent over all, but rose five-tenths of 1 percent when energy and food were excluded, a rise that was more than twice the increase in that category in December. The overall change in the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods was also firmer than the month before, and the prices report was taken by economists as a further indication that the worst of the recession might have passed. [Page 35.]
 
Interpreting the Signals
 "There is now embryonic evidence that the rate of decline in economic activity has slowed," declared Gordon Richards, economist for the National Association of Manufacturers. "The continuing fall in industrial production is clearly serious," he added, but is markedly less worrisome than in preceding months.
In December, production dropped a revised 1.1 percent, nearly double the decline of six-tenths of 1 percent initially estimated by the Federal Reserve Board. The November decline now stands at 1.6 percent, a slight change from earlier estimates of 1.7 percent and 1.8 percent. With the January drop, industrial production has fallen for four straight months.
An upturn in car and truck assembly was the main factor limiting the January slide in the index that measures the output of factories, mines and utilities, the Federal Reserve stated.
 
More Autos Being Made
 Output climbed to a still-depressed seasonally adjusted annual pace of 5.4 million cars last month, but this was significantly above December's total of 5 million, analysts noted. It was also below recent selling rates, which implies that in the months ahead the automotive sector will be a positive force in the economy rather than a drag.
"The question this raises is whether the worst is behind us," said Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber Inc., referring to the overall output report. He said the recession, though likely to continue for another few months, would become increasingly less severe with the help of the recent decline in interest rates, oil prices that have dropped from their highs after the August invasion of Kuwait by Iraq, and a weak dollar that helps make American goods more internationally competitive in price.
The Federal Reserve also reported that utilization of industrial capacity fell five-tenths of a percentage point last month, to 79.9 percent, the lowest level since January 1987. Still, the latest decline was about half the 1.1 percentage point drop in December, providing another tenuous sign that the downturn in the economy might be starting to lose momentum. The rate for factories alone also fell five-tenths of a point in January, to 78.8 percent, the lowest since September 1986 and 2.5 percentage points below its 1967-1990 average.
 
 Concern About Interest Rates
 Some analysts thought the hefty rise reported today in the so-called core inflation rate of producer prices might jeopardize further monetary easing by the Federal Reserve, but others said the central bank would continue to push interest rates down. The core rate is calculated excluding food and energy. The optimists pointed to two price increases last month that were unlikely to be sustained -- 2 percent for cars and 5.9 percent for alcoholic beverages.
The price rise in alcoholic beverages, a record, was thought by some analysts to reflect increases imposed at the first of the year under cover of a rise in taxes. Taxes themselves are not included in the index.
Analysts also found encouragement in another part of the prices report, the decline of five-tenths of 1 percent in the price of goods at the intermediate stage of production, generally two steps short of retail shelves.
 
 Broad-Based Decline
 The production data showed that when motor vehicles and parts were excluded, output fell six-tenths of 1 percent, slightly less than in the preceding three months. All major market and industry groups fell last month -- except for mining, which was unchanged -- but in most cases the declines were markedly less severe than in December.
Output of consumer goods eased one-tenth of 1 percent, business equipment eased two-tenths and materials fell five-tenths while construction supplies tumbled 1.8 percent, twice the December decline.
Factory output fell four-tenths of 1 percent last month after a 1.4 percent drop in December, with durables and nondurables both falling by four-tenths. Utilities, which are heavily affected by extremes in weather, had a decline of seven-tenths of 1 percent after a 1 percent increase in December that had initially been estimated at 1.9 percent.
Since October, output of consumer goods other than motor vehicles has fallen about 1.25 percent reflecting declines in clothing, energy products, appliances and furniture, the Federal Reserve stated.
 
 Computer Production Drops
 Business equipment other than vehicles fell five-tenths of 1 percent, mainly reflecting a big drop in computers and other information-processing equipment, a decline that unnerved some analysts. Mr. Richards noted that capital spending on office automation had been holding up relatively well and he said he hoped this decline was temporary.
While production firmed for motor vehicle components, the output of basic metals, especially steel, fell again and the output of chemicals eased. Textiles, however, rose somewhat and energy materials were virtually unchanged for the second straight month. Output of construction supplies has now fallen more than 7 percent since summer.
The Index of Industrial Production, which covers roughly one-third of the economy, now stands at 106.5 percent, nine-tenths of a percentage point below the level of January 1990.

GRAPHIC: Graphs: "Industrial Production" shows index of total industrial production from Aug. 1989 to Jan. 1991. (Source: Commerce Department); "Capacity Utilization" shows total output as percentage of capacity from Aug. 1989 to Jan. 1991. (Source: Federal Reserve Board)

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Fell 0.1% in January

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15

 BODY:
Prices at the wholesale level edged down one-tenth of 1 percent in January, the Labor Department reported today, as a big drop in energy costs helped provide a bright spot for an economy troubled by war and recession.
The department said the decline in the Producer Price Index last month occurred in spite of a record jump in the cost of alcoholic beverages as producers raised prices to coincide with higher Federal taxes. 
 Increases in the index normally show up with only a short lag in the Consumer Price Index, which measures price changes at the retail level.
 
Heavily Influenced by Oil
 The January decline followed a drop of six-tenths of 1 percent in December. The results in both months were heavily influenced by falling gasoline prices. Oil costs, which had jumped sharply after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, have been coming down in recent months.
Wholesale prices, discounting changes in food and energy, were up five-tenths of 1 percent in January, compared with a rise of two-tenths of 1 percent in December.
Analysts said much of the January rise reflected a record 5.9 percent increase in the cost of alcoholic beverages.
The drop of one-tenth of 1 percent in wholesale prices translated into an annual rate of decline of 1 percent, the Labor Department said. That compares with a 5.6 percent increase in wholesale prices in 1990, the biggest rise in nine years.
 
 Big Drop in Gasoline

The January decline in wholesale prices was led by a 10 percent drop in gasoline costs, which followed an 8.6 percent drop in December. The price survey was taken before the war with Iraq began on Jan. 17. Since then, oil traders have pushed world energy prices down even further, reflecting an opinion that the Iraqis no longer have the ability to damage oilfields in Saudi Arabia.
Because of the price declines since the war started, analysts said energy prices should fall even further in February.
The overall energy index was down 2.5 percent after a drop of 4.7 percent in December. Also holding down prices was a surprising drop of three-tenths of 1 percent in food costs.
Prices of home heating oil fell 6.2 percent in January. But an index that measures the costs of electric power rose 2.5 percent, and natural gas prices were up three-tenths of 1 percent.
Many economists had been expecting food prices to rise in January because of a freeze that damaged fruit and vegetable crops in California. Fruit prices did jump 12.7 percent, but vegetable prices fell by 17.6 percent as ample supplies in Florida offset the effects of the California freeze.
 
Effect of Liquor Tax
 While Federal taxes on beer, wine and liquor went up in January, this increase is not measured in the Producer Price Index because it is paid to the Government and not to producers. But manufacturers used the opportunity of the tax increase to raise their own prices, the Labor Department said.
The various changes left the index, before adjusting for seasonal variations, at 121.9 in January, meaning that a selected group of goods cost $121.90 in January, compared with $117.60 a year ago.
While wholesale prices rose at their fastest pace in nine years in 1990, analysts are looking for a significant easing of inflationary pressures this year.
In addition to falling energy costs, analysts cited the recession as a factor that would hold down inflation because sluggish consumer demand would keep a lid on price increases.
"With demand as weak as it is, companies, even if they wanted to, could not pass price increases along," said Bruce Steinberg, an economist with Merrill Lynch. "We don't have to worry about inflation in 1991 at all, and we probably won't have to worry about it in early 1992."
Donald Ratajczak, head of economic forecasting at Georgia State University, said he expected wholesale prices to increase only about 1 percent this year.

HEADLINE: Syndication Gain Is Seen For Networks

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15

 BODY:
In a setback for Hollywood studios and producers, the White House today signaled its support for proposals to end restrictions that prohibit television networks from syndicating the programs they broadcast.
In a letter responding to questions from a member of Congress, the White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu, clarified the Administration's position and strongly backed the idea that the 20-year-old rules should be repealed. 
 In a month, the Federal Communications Commission plans to decide whether to repeal the rules, and it could significantly change the political balance in what has been an intense lobbying battle between Hollywood and the networks. Although the issue has little or no direct impact on viewers, it will ultimately determine who will control the $3 billion market for television reruns.
 
 Limits on Network Power
 At issue are what are known as the Financial Interest and Syndication Rules, imposed in 1970, which prevent broadcast networks from owning rerun rights to the prime-time shows they acquire. The rules were imposed after an antitrust case that had been brought against the networks, and they were intended to prevent the networks from abusing their control over the prime-time audience.
Preserving the rules has been a priority of Hollywood studios, which argue that the networks could use their access to the prime-time viewers to exert a stranglehold over producers. In the early 1980's, the F.C.C. proposed repealing the rules, but the Reagan Administration blocked the effort.
The networks, along with a growing number of economists and government officials, contend, however, that the rules are out of date and no longer serve any public purpose.
The White House and leading members of Congress have tried to keep out of the recent debate, although the Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission both submitted briefs to the F.C.C. urging repeal of the rules.
But that appeared to change earlier this week, when President Bush's top economic adviser, Michael J. Boskin, issued the Economic Report of the President. The report included a paragraph immediately cited by those supporting repeal of the syndication restrictions. The report said that Government limits on ownership and syndication of programming "are generally an ineffective means of addressing any problems of market power" and added that the Government should stay out of decisions that determine which companies can provide services within an industry.
 
 A Heated Response
 Short as it was, the paragraph prompted a heated response from Jack Valenti, head of the Motion Picture Association of America. After a flurry of meetings, the White House press office issued a statement on Thursday saying that the matter was before the F.C.C. and that the White House had no comment.
But the White House stance was reversed again today, with the letter by Mr. Sununu. In the letter, to Representative Michael G. Oxley, Republican of Ohio, who wanted to know where the Administration stood, Mr. Sununu wrote that President Bush "has made equally clear his opposition to picking winners and losers -- to regulatory or other policies that favor or protect particular competitors at the expense of competition." He added that he hoped the F.C.C. would decide the matter "with full recognition of the high costs to consumers" of government interference.
 
 A Strong Statement

Network officials declined to comment on the record, but they made it clear they viewed the letter as a strong statement in their favor.
Barbara Dixon, a spokeswoman for Mr. Valenti, said the Motion Picture Association of America would not comment.
Proponents of repeal have long hoped that the White House would take a stand because doing so would strengthen the hands of those at the F.C.C. who favor repeal. The five commissioners have not indicated their views, but their statements suggest they are divided. Two members, Alfred C. Sikes and James Quello, clearly favor significant relaxation. Two, Sherrie Marshall and Ervin Duggan, appear to want to preserve the rules in large measure. The fifth member, Andrew C. Barrett, has given no indication of his position.
