HEADLINE: Subway Ridership Drops 4.3%; Fare Rise Could Come in Spring

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
Subway and bus ridership dropped so sharply in the last 13 months that transit officials say they may be forced to seek a fare increase as early as this spring.
The officials, who released ridership figures yesterday, said they had expected some bad news mirroring the weakened economy. Ridership is considered an excellent barometer of economic conditions. 
 But they said the 4.3 percent ridership drop on both the subways and buses in 1990 proved far steeper than anticipated. It was the first decline since ridership began a steady climb in 1983, a particularly disturbing development because billions of dollars were spent to rebuild mass transit in the 1980's with the main purpose of attracting riders.
The ridership figures reverted to approximate 1985 levels -- an average weekday level of 3,329,000 on the subways and 1,283,000 on the buses.
The preliminary figures for January, the officials said, were almost as gloomy: a 3.9 percent drop in the subways and a similar loss in bus riders. The Transit Authority had anticipated only a 1.4 percent drop in subway riders for last month.
The decline in the city mirrors the situation on the region's commuter railroads. With fewer people working and shopping, fewer people are taking mass transit, officials said. And because the transit agencies have already made significant cutbacks, it will be even more difficult to decide what to cut next to make up for the unexpected loss of revenue, they said.
"We are in a much more serious situation than we expected to be in just two months ago," said David A. Winfield, executive vice president of the Transit Authority, which operates the subways and buses. "We are in a position where we are required to provide certain levels of service in existing schedules and commitments to service and reliability, and our ability to change these levels is limited."
Mortimer L. Downey, executive director of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said the Transit Authority could be left with a deficit of $130 million to $140 million in its $2.9 billion budget for 1991. Fare collection was $61.4 million below budget in 1990.
Contributing to the deficit is a drop in city subsidies, also a result of the weakened economy. The Transit Authority's share of taxes on certain real-estate transactions in the city dropped 27.6 percent, or $32.9 million, last year. The authority anticipated $90 million in revenues from the tax in 1991, but receipts to date are running 40 percent behind projections, or $35 million to $40 million for the year.
Mr. Downey said even a 10-cent fare rise to $1.25, which would raise about $10 million a month, would fail to close the deficit. "A year isn't, unfortunately, 14 months long," he said.
Any fare increase would need approval of the M.T.A. board, to which the Mayor and the Governor make appointments. Peter E. Stangl, who is expected to take over as M.T.A. chairman soon, has said an increase is likely.
The Transit Authority uses a formula that indicates subway ridership drops by 1 percent for every 10-cent fare increase. Bus ridership typically drops by twice as much, transit officials said, because bus trips are more discretionary.
Mr. Winfield said a 10-cent increase might not be enough.
"Now that the issue is more pressing, whereas a 10-cent increase might have been adequate under the assumptions made two months ago, under what we're looking at now, things are more severe," he said.
Joseph G. Rappaport, a spokesman for the Straphangers's Campaign, an advocacy group for subway riders, said the Transit Authority was shirking its responsibility by linking declining ridership to unemployment.
"It just ain't so," he said. "They're just not doing a good enough job to retain their riders."
Mr. Rappaport said more innovative programs, like monthly passes, and basic improvements, like better signs in stations, are needed.
"What the Transit Authority doesn't need is another increase in the fare coupled with Draconian service cuts," he said.
Transit officials said fare evasion, which grew sharply last year, played only a minor role in the lower ridership figures, officials said. Last year the percentage of fare evaders to paying riders rose steadily to a high of 7.4 in August. By December, the rate dropped to 5.5 percent.
Transit officials say there is a strong correlation between the job market and ridership figures. "In many ways, the transportation indicator is almost a leading indication of the economic data because we can get the figures more quickly than the Labor Department," said Eugene Spruck, an economist with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which operates the PATH system between the two states.
For instance, employment in finance, insurance and real estate in New York City declined by 2.1 percent in 1990, for a total decline of 5.5 percent since the market crashed in 1987.
Reflecting that decrease, the number of passengers taking PATH trains to the World Trade Center station declined by 2.9 percent through last November, Mr. Spruck said.
In its latest figures, New Jersey Transit, which operates buses and trains, reported that passenger revenue from July to November of last year was 1.3 percent less than had been expected and that PATH ridership declined .6 percent system-wide from January through November.
A recent survey by the Long Island Rail Road indicated that many of its regular riders were among those hit by cuts in the real estate and financial services industries, said Susan McGowan, spokeswoman for the commuter rail line. The number of passenger trips on L.I.R.R. trains dropped 4 percent to 72.4 million in 1990 after a slight increase in 1989 that brought ridership to 75.4 million.
"Those people are losing their jobs and therefore not taking our train to work anymore," she said.
In the middle of last year, the L.I.R.R. made internal budget cuts of 3 percent, has imposed a wage and hiring freeze and in March will reduce some train service for a savings of $2 million.
Metro-North, the commuter railroad serving Connecticut and several New York counties north of the city, actually increased ridership by 1.1 percent last year, said Howard R. Permut, vice president for planning and development at Metro-North.
But in January ridership declined by 1.5 percent over January 1990. Mr. Permut said the railroad had projected a 1 percent increase in ridership for 1991 and that every 1 percent drop in riders translates into roughly $2.5 million lost revenues.
"With the economy being so bad, people aren't coming in to the city as much," he said. "They aren't coming in to go shopping or go to the theater or have dinner, and if they've lost their job, they aren't coming in to work."

HEADLINE: Wielding New Studies, Landlords Ask Albany to Undo Rent Laws

BYLINE: By IVER C. PETERSON

 BODY:
With rents slipping and vacancies on the rise, a loose coalition of landlords and university housing experts is preparing a challenge to New York's 43-year-old system of rent regulations, which is facing renewal this spring in Albany.
Studies and papers challenging the underlying justification for the law have been prepared over the last few years, arguing that the rules, which control everything from rent increases to the frequency of paint jobs, benefit well-to-do renters most, let housing deteriorate, and cost the city taxes. 
 Every three years, when the rent rules come up for renewal, landlords appear in Albany fighting to have them repealed. But this time, they are hoping that their academic backers and the current housing slump will give new force to their argument.
And even if they are not able to kill the system -- which they admit they are unlikely to do -- they hope that an unusual circumstance this year will give them a chance to weaken the rules.
"I don't think we have ever had a more opportune time to structure major changes in the rent regulation system," said John J. Gilbert 3d, head of the Rent Stabilization Association, the city's biggest landlord group.
 
Survey Not Performed
 The unusual circumstance is that a crucial housing survey was not performed. For the rules to be renewed, the state must find, every three years, that the city is still in the grip of the housing availability crisis first declared in 1947 when the law was passed -- that is, that there is a rental vacancy rate below 5 percent.
But last year the Census Bureau was too busy with the national head count to do its three-year vacancy survey for the city, which is due on April 1. The most recent survey, covering a sampling of 19,000 apartments, was done in 1987. It found a vacancy rate of 2.46 percent.
Since then, real-estate brokers have been reporting what many pleasantly surprised newcomers to the city have found -- that renting an apartment is no longer a frenzied competition among would-be tenants in which owners offer "take it or leave it" terms. More vacant apartments has meant that many tenants now are able to choose among vacancies or bargain lower rents.
The city and the state, without proof of a continuing emergency, favor extending the law for only one year. Landlords hope they can use that interim to weaken it.
Defenders of the law maintain that, while it may not perfectly fit today's market, there is still no reason to attack its underlying purpose -- limiting rent increases and regulating relations between landlord and tenant.
 
Armed With Studies
 "There are imperfections in the system, and inequities," conceded Alexander B. Grannis, chairman of the State Assembly's housing committee. "But the flaws are not of a magnitude that mandates dismantling the whole system to get at them."
To strengthen their case, landlords have gone to Albany armed with studies. Among them are the following:
*A study by the Joint Center for Housing Studies at Harvard University found that the rent rules may benefit rich New Yorkers more than poor ones. In poor neighborhoods, some landlords are already charging less than they are legally entitled to, while in Manhattan's wealthiest neighborhoods, rent regulations save affluent tenants hundreds of dollars a month over what they would pay for similar apartments at market rates, the study found.
*A study by the chairman of the Hunter College Planning and Urban Studies Department comparing New York rental housing with that of other cities found that the rent rules reduced incentives to maintain housing so much that New York buildings had, on average, more broken boilers, outmoded wiring, cracked walls and other problems than other cities' buildings did.
*A study by the accounting firm of Peat, Marwick concluded that the city would collect $370 million more a year in real estate taxes by dropping protections for tenants earning over $40,000 a year, since the taxable value of the buildings these renters live in would rise with higher rents.
 
Defenders Dismiss Studies
 The Harvard and Peat, Marwick studies were paid for by Mr. Gilbert's group, and defenders of the rent laws dismissed them.
"I would not expect the landlords to commission a report that didn't support their position," Assemblyman Grannis said. "It's like the cigarette company research that spent years telling us tobacco wasn't responsible for sickness."
Mr. Gilbert and other landlord representatives acknowledge that the chances that the system would be allowed to die are extremely slim.
Rent controls are an emotional issue with a huge constituency, and for many politicians, the issue is simply taboo. Nearly three million people -- about 40 percent of the city's population and a huge voting bloc -- live in the city's roughly one million rent-regulated apartments. Buildings with fewer than six rental units are exempt from the law, as are thousands of unsold co-op and condominium apartments that have been turned into rentals in the current market slump.
The Dinkins administration, with its political ties to neighborhood groups that most strongly defend rent protections, had asked for the law's renewal, without amendments, said Valerie Jo Bradley, assistant housing commissioner for public affairs.
 
Deregulations Sought
 Some members of the Republican-controlled Senate, which refused to grant the one-year extension last year, are thinking of voting to agree to it this year in return for changes in the vacancy-rate survey that would test whether rent controls help the rich.
Landlords' groups, aware that opposition is strong, are determined to use this bending of the rules to seek some changes.
They would like the most expensive apartments, once vacant, permanently deregulated. Alternately, they would like means tests used to reserve vacant lower-rent apartments for tenants with lower incomes.
They are not seeking, the landlords insist, that any of these changes be applied to apartments now occupied.
 
Rules Favor Long Tenancies
 There are about 840,000 rent-stabilized apartments in the city, whose maximum rent increases are set annually by the Rent Guidelines Board. Another 155,000 rent controlled apartments, whose tenants must have been in residence since 1971, have increases figured on a one-by-one basis using a system which takes operating costs into account. These units become rent-stabilized when they are vacated.
In the Harvard study of rent stabilized apartments, Henry O. Pollakowski, a researcher at the Joint Center for Housing Studies and editor of The Journal of Housing Economics, used figures from the 1987 vacancy survey to conclude that, outside Manhattan's richest neighborhoods, stabilized rents and market rents are about the same, so rent rules produce very little benefit.
His study shows that the difference in rents between similar regulated and market-rate apartments in Brooklyn, the Bronx and Queens amounted to less than $40 or $50 a month. But in the wealthiest parts of Manhattan, the Upper East and West Sides, he found that stabilized rents were consistently far lower than rents for similar apartments offered at market rates.
Rent regulations favor long tenancies, so that the longer a renter stays, the more slowly the rents will rise. Poor and working class people tend to move more often, while the middle class generally enjoys more stability in employment and stays put.
In the South Bronx, where Mr. Pollakowski found an average family income of $26,200, 59 percent of the apartments were stablized. Their rents were only $39 a month different from comparable market rate housing.
 
'Rather Large Subsidies'
 But on the Upper East Side -- Mr. Grannis's district -- the average income was over $40,000 and 83 percent of the apartments are stabilized. There, rent-stabilized tenants paid, on average, $337 a month less than they would have for comparable market-rate apartments, the study found.
"What I found is that there are these rather large subsidies in the affluent Manhattan locations and in the rest of the city rent stabilization is pretty much a wash," he said.
Meanwhile, Peter Salins, head of the Hunter College Urban Affairs Department, used Federal housing studies to show that New York rental units are in much worse shape than in other cities, even old ones. He blames rent regulations for discouraging owners from maintaining their properties.
"On every index of housing quality -- all of which are related to maintenance -- New York fares badly," he wrote in a recent article. "Twice as many apartments in New York have cracked walls, broken plaster, holes in the floor and exposed wiring than other American cities. A quarter of New York apartments have broken heating systems, compared with less than 10 percent in other American cities." He found that in Chicago, for example, housing was better maintained than in New York.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Industrial output fell much less in January than in the two previous months, the Government reported. Output was down 0.4 percent last month after declines averaging three times that much in November and December. The report provides a hint that the economy's decline may be bottoming out. [Page 1.]
Prices at the wholesale level edged down 0.1 percent in January, the Labor Department reported, as a big drop in energy costs helped provide a bright spot. The department said the decline in the Producer Price Index occurred in spite of a record jump in the cost of alcoholic beverages. [35.]
The nation's trade deficit fell in December to a six-month low of $6.25 billion, the Commerce Department said. The improvement came from a decline in imports, reflecting a weak economy. [33.]
New software allows blind and nearly blind people to operate computers for the first time by choosing from on-screen pictures, icons and menus that represent instructions. It does so by basically acting as an interpreter that reads the images aloud. [33.]
Anyone shopping for a personal computer for home use faces a daunting array of options. Consumer's World. [52.]
 
Companies
Citibank will join the Cirrus network of automated teller machines. For years it refused to allow other banks' customers to use its machines in the New York area. [33.]
In a setback for Hollywood studios and producers, the White House threw its weight behind proposals to end restrictions that bar TV networks from syndicating programs they broadcast. [33.]
U S West will pay a $10 million fine for several violations, one of which was termed unfair competition against A.T.&T. It was the largest antitrust fine ever levied by the Justice Department. [33.]
The airlines' widening trans-Atlantic fare war has failed to generate the initial surge in bookings produced by earlier domestic fare cuts, a number of travel agents said. [34.]
The sale to Northwest of 67 of Eastern's takeoff and landing slots and 5 gates at Washington National was approved by a Federal bankruptcy court. United wanted the slots, but the Justice Department objected, citing antitrust concerns. [34.]
Chrysler said it might have to eliminate 3,000 of its 27,000 white-collar jobs, or about 11 percent. [35.]
Workers striking Alliant Techsystems, a military contractor, are facing a chilly response from townspeople. [10.]
Senior Daily News and Tribune Company executives met with union leaders in talks that could determine the paper's fate. [29.]
 
 International
Talks on liberalizing global trade may resume soon among low-level negotiators, a GATT spokesman said. [37.]
 
 Markets
Stocks advanced sharply in the wake of Iraq's surprise offer to leave Kuwait. Registering its third new high for the year in the last five days, the Dow jumped 2 percent, to 2,934.65, ahead 57.42 for the day and 103.96 for the week. [33.]
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed, with bills and notes slightly lower and the longer maturities showing small gains. [36.]
Oil prices plunged on news that Iraq said it would consider pulling out of Kuwait. Crude fell $1.44, to $20.88. [42.]
The dollar rose against leading currencies after Iraq's offer and a Government report that raised concerns about inflation. Gold prices fell. [42.]
 
 Today's Columns
For people caught in the wave of layoffs sweeping the nation's businesses, there is one bit of encouraging news from the I.R.S. Your Money. [34.]
A new form of chess that uses a flat board with 28 rows arranged in the shape of a vortex has been patented. Patents. [34.]

HEADLINE: Governor Urges New Water Cuts By Californians

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 15

 BODY:
In his first, rather cautious response to the drought gripping California, the state's new Governor today called on all communities to cut their water use by half, created a "water bank" to transfer water to the neediest areas and asked the Legislature to establish a $100 million drought fund.
But the Governor, Pete Wilson, stopped short of invoking emergency powers to take sterner measures, saying he preferred to allow the local authorities to act first. 
 "I will not kid you," Mr. Wilson, a Republican, said at a news conference at the Capitol. "A drought of this magnitude will change the way we live. It will cause inconvenience for certain. It will cause anxiety, and it will cause some very real pain and some very real economic hardship."
 
'Pray It Rains'
 His specific response to the politically charged issue was a measured political one. It was praised as judicious by the local water districts that had lobbied against the state's taking control of drought actions, but was criticized as timid by others.
"His plan is to hope everybody saves water, spend some money and pray it rains," said State Assemblyman Phillip Isenberg, a Democrat from Sacramento who is a legislative expert on water. "There is not much new here."
In Los Angeles, Bob Gomperz, spokesman for the Metropolitan Water District of Southern California, the wholesaler that supplies half the water used by 15 million Californians, said the agency supported the Governor's "judicious" action in leaving it up to local bodies to respond to the drought. The water district, Mr. Gomperz said, was preparing for even steeper cutbacks than the 31 percent reduction that is to go into effect on March 1.
Mayor Karen Humphrey of Fresno, in the hard-hit agricultural Central Valley, called the Governor's package too little. "His response is not an emergency-type response," she said, "but we clearly have a crisis."
Among the proposals Mr. Wilson rejected was one from some water experts for a statewide limit of 300 gallons a day per household. Enforcement would have been extremely difficult since many urban areas, including Sacramento, lack water meters.
Instead of setting a specific limit, the Governor asked local water districts to restrict use, leaving it to them to impose their own standards on customers.
 
Water Meters Lacking
 The steps came against a backdrop of growing desperation over the drought, now in its fifth year, which is putting farmers out of business, threatening major industries and raising fears of devastating fires this summer.
The Governor acted at the end of another week of bad news for California's farms and cities. On Thursday, the state's largest supplier of water, the Federal Central Valley Project, announced it was cutting deliveries to farmers by 75 percent.
State officials reported today that water conditions were worse than at this date in 1977, the driest year in modern California history. Precipitation is about one-fourth of average, the snowpack is 15 percent to 20 percent of normal and the crucial spring runoff from the Sierra Nevada is expected to run at only 35 percent of normal.
Mr. Wilson, in office only about a month, acted on the recommendation of a "drought action team" he created two weeks ago. He said the "likely scenario" was that most localities would have to reduce water use by half.
The full extent of possible cutbacks will not be known until the rainy season ends in the first half of April; it remains possible that heavy rains and snows could still relieve some of the pressures.
But Mr. Wilson, a former Mayor of San Diego, made plain that he was prepared to act "if local agencies are not coping." Under the state's Emergency Services Act, the Governor can declare a state of emergency in case of flood, fire, riot or other disaster, giving him power to suspend state regulations and laws, commandeer private property and take other extraordinary steps.
"I will not hesitate to assume emergency powers if such powers become necessary to protect Californians from the worst effects of the drought," he said.
 
Voluntary Transfers Are Urged
 For the moment, he offered plans to encourage voluntary transfers of water from where it is abundant. The new water bank would buy water from "willing sellers," pool it in reservoirs, largely through the state's vast system of aqueducts and canals, and resell to areas most in need.
The most obvious source of such water is farmers, particularly rice farmers in Northern California, who enjoy historic legal rights to cheap water and whose supplies cannot be arbitarily reduced. The state is negotiating with the farmers to pay them more for their water than they would make on their crops.
The Metropolitan Water District, a powerful independent agency whose 51-member board is appointed by the 27 agencies that feed off it, had previously disclosed plans to set up a water bank of its own to buy water for Southern California. But the district said today that while it had the right to buy such water it would abandon its plan and would not compete with the Governor's state water bank. The district acknowledged that the Governor, under his emergency powers, could have blocked independent water buying.
Mr. Wilson also asked the Legislature, which is in special session to deal with an equally grave fiscal crisis, to create a $100 million drought fund. The money would be used to offer loans and expertise to localities to find and conserve water, to increase fire-fighting ability and protect wildlife against the severe effects of the drought.
The Governor directed the state Department of Fish and Game to do "everything human possible" to maintain fish and wildlife populations. This was expected to include drilling wells in wetland areas and transporting fish to deeper waters downstream.
The threat of fire is of special concern, particularly since many of the military forces and equipment normally used to fight fires, which are chronic in the arid West, have been deployed to Saudi Arabia.
 
Seizing an Opportunity
 Karen Garrison, a scientist with the Natural Resources Defense Council in San Francisco, called Mr. Wilson's plan an "opportunity to make a major overhaul of a system that got us here in the first place, a system that rewards waste and discourages conservation."
"The current crisis is the result of bad management in the past," she said, "and we're still relying on short-term decisions that basically drain our reservoirs to meet demand."
Steve Stroud, director of public works for Merced, a city of 56,000 in the Central Valley, said his city was one of many that would have problems instituting rationing.
"In areas where you rely on surface water, you have a clear sense of how much you have," Mr. Stroud said. "Cities that rely on ground water, like Merced, never really know the exact volume of water on hand."
Another problem, he said, is that roughly two-thirds of the Merced Water District customers are billed on a flat rate because they do not have water meters.

GRAPHIC: Photo: As California enters its fifth year of drought, a buoy, which normally floats about 25 feet off the lake bed, lies on dry ground at Lake Oroville, a reservoir of the California State Water Project near Sacramento. (Associated Press)(pg. 10)
 
Map/Chart: "Drought Update"
Most of California is supplied by these water systems. Their status led to the drought plan announced by Gov. Pete Wilson.
State Water Project -- Cut water to farmers Feb. 4. Continues to supply reduced levels to to urban users. Expects to meet only 35 percent of urban and industrial requests this year.
Central Valley Project -- Cut back supplies to farmers 75 percent on Thursday. On Jan. 31, had on hand 51 percent of normal water supply.
Colorado River Project -- Expects normal deliveries this year; Federal court order may reduce deliveries by up to 25 percent in future years.

HEADLINE: White House Rebukes Israeli Envoy

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15

 BODY:
In an unusually blunt statement, the White House criticized the Israeli Ambassador today for making public complaints about United States economic aid that it characterized as "outrageous and outside the bounds of acceptable behavior by the ambassador of any friendly country."
On Thursday, in an interview with Reuters, the Ambassador, Zalman Shoval, expressed disapproval of Washington's delay in granting $400 million in housing loan guarantees for resettling Soviet Jewish immigrants in Israel. He also complained that his country "has not received one cent in aid" from the allied coalition to compensate it for losses from Iraqi Scud missile attacks. 
 Mr. Shoval's comments and the Administration's reaction brought to the surface strains in the United States-Israeli relationship that had been submerged by the Persian Gulf crisis. By not retaliating against Iraq despite repeated attacks, Israel had won Administration praise for its restraint. The stationing of Patriot missile batteries in Israel manned by the United States personnel appeared to rebuild strong political and emotional ties between the two countries.
 
Maintaining Good Relations
 The Administration seemed to want to rebuke the Israeli Ambassador personally without fundamentally harming its relationship with a nation it considers critical to the war effort. The White House statement said President Bush had sent Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir a message expressing his unhappiness with Mr. Shoval's statements. Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d protested to Mr. Shoval personally on Thursday.
Referring to the housing-loan guarantees, Mr. Shoval, who arrived in Washington late last fall, was quoted as saying, "We sometimes feel we are being given the runaround."
The Administration agreed in principle to the loan guarantees in October, but delays have arisen because of concern that the money may be used to settle Soviet Jews in the Gaza Strip and the West Bank despite Israeli insistence that this will not happen.
The White House statement today rebuking the Israeli envoy said: "Public statements made yesterday by Israeli Ambassador Zalman Shoval criticizing the United States are outrageous and outside the bounds of acceptable behavior by the ambassador of any friendly country. The Secretary of State made this clear to the Ambassador yesterday, and the President protested to Prime Minister Shamir by cable this morning. We deserve better from Israel's ambassador."
Mr. Shoval said he had no comment about the White House statement. "About the Reuters interview, I'm not going to say I wasn't quoted correctly," he said. "But I will say that if everything I said was seen, you would have seen that most of my comments were praising the state of Israeli-U.S. relations."

HEADLINE: Brooklyn Mother Is Charged With Abandoning a Newborn

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
A newborn boy was found on a trash bin at a convenience store in Brooklyn yesterday, and his 28-year-old mother was arrested, authorities said.
The single, unemployed mother was identified by the police as Paula Winker of the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn. Ms. Winker, of 1516 67th Street, was charged with abandonment and endangering the welfare of a child, said Officer Fred Weiner, a police spokesman.
The five-hour-old boy was discovered yesterday morning by a store employee, wrapped in several blankets. The store is a few blocks from Ms. Winker's home.
A spokesman for Maimonides Medical Center, Michael Heller, said the baby was in "fine condition" yesterday.

HEADLINE: Grammys: Not a One-Night Stand

BYLINE: By ELEANOR BLAU

 BODY:
This is Grammy Week in New York, and although the 33d annual Grammy Awards ceremony doesn't take place until Wednesday night at Radio City Music Hall, festivities ranging from a charity benefit at the Waldorf-Astoria to free concerts in the subway stations have been under way since last Tuesday.
On Monday, Grammy-inspired shows will be offered in nightclubs around town and on Wednesday, the invited audience at Radio City will celebrate at the New York Hilton before going off to nightclub parties. 
 Sinead O'Connor announced last week that she was boycotting the show because she thought it too commercial, but many of the top names in pop music are expected to be in town: Bonnie Raitt, Sting, Phil Collins, Harry Connick Jr., Gloria Estefan, Quincy Jones and M. C. Hammer to name just a few.
This will be only the fifth time that the Grammy show has been in New York, the last time in 1988; most of the shows have been in Los Angeles, the headquarters of the 8,000-member National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, which gives the awards.
In these times of budget angst, the city is hoping the star-studded show and its trappings will be a boon. As Edwin M. Cooperman, who heads the city's Grammy host committee, put it in welcoming academy members the other day:
"Your talent enriches our lives every day. Your presence here this week invigorates city life. You're also going to pick up a few checks in restaurants, hotels, nightspots and stores -- and that'll mean a lot to the city's economy."
 
Wide Range of Estimates
 Just how much is hard to judge. Mayor David N. Dinkins, who proclaimed Feb. 12 to 20 Grammy Week, suggested it would bring in $30 million, the amount said to have been raised by the 1988 Grammy event. Ken Sunshine, his special executive assistant, called the guess conservative. And Mr. Cooperman, who is chairman and co-chief executive of American Express, estimated Grammy-related spending at $60 million, noting that this year's events go on for nine days, while those in 1988 lasted only three.
Hearing of the $60 million estimate, Michael Greene, the president of the academy, said, "It makes us wonder why exactly it is we're coming here and losing all this money when New York is making out like a bandit."
Mr. Greene said bringing the show to New York cost the academy and the production company an extra $1.2 million to $1.8 million, in part because of moving its staff from the West Coast and keeping it here for more than two weeks. He declined to give the total cost of the event or even to say how many members of the academy live on which coast.
Despite the costs, however, Mr. Greene didn't sound unhappy to be here. "New York City is a music center for performers and record companies," he said. He spoke of the vibrancy of New York's "jazz, classical and Latin music communities, not to mention rap, pop and rock," and said: "Bringing a show to New York is revitalizing. Los Angeles is a little bit more laid back than New York. There's a little different buzz, spirit."
 
6,000 Visitors
 Publicity people for the event report that some 6,000 visitors, mostly music-industry members of the recording academy, are staying at the New York Hilton Hotel, which plans to roll out a red carpet all the way to Radio City, three blocks down the Avenue of the Americas, for the post-Grammy party.
More than 1,000 performing artists were said to be staying in hotels around town, their bills paid by various recording companies. That does not include the performers in the show, a glittering array that will include Bette Midler, Diana Ross, Billy Idol, Tommy Tune, Tony Bennett, David Crosby, the Judds and some classical celebrities, like Placido Domingo and Kathleen Battle. Garry Shandling will be the host of the extravaganza, which will present 77 awards. The producer is Pierre Cossette.
Support for Grammy Week was enlisted by Mr. Cooperman and other business and civic leaders, who arranged perquisites for Grammy visitors -- free tickets to some Broadway shows, for example, discounts in restaurants and 20 cars and vans with drivers.
The benefit at the Waldorf-Astoria on Tuesday raised $600,000 for Musicares, a foundation created by the academy to provide drug and alcohol rehabilitation and other services to its members.
Later in the week several artists, including Melba Moore, took part in talks, workshops and performances at La Guardia High School in Manhattan, where opportunities in music and recording were discussed. And Wadleigh Junior High School in West Harlem was chosen for a program to help disadvantaged, inner-city students. Among other things, the school is receiving musical instruments donated by the Warner Music Group so students can start their own band.
 
Subway Concerts
 On Monday night, various clubs plan Grammy Week programs with support from record companies and other sponsors. For instance, an RCA Country Night is scheduled at the Lone Star Roadhouse, featuring Matraca Berg and Bernie Leddin, and a Rhythm-and-Blues Night with Gerald Albright, Bobby Lyle and Paul Jackson Jr. at the Village Gate is to be presented by Atlantic Records and Gilbey's gin for the benefit of the Harlem Boys Choir.
Free concerts have been scheduled at subway sites including Grand Central Terminal, Times Square and Penn Station and also in Bloomingdale's. Starting at 9 A.M. today, for instance, performers in the main concourse of Grand Central will be Caleb Arruda, guitarist, followed by Joel Dallow, cellist, then the Irish dancers Half Moon Sword and Freelance Folk, a vocal group.
The host committee's logo, an apple enclosing a G-clef, has been popping up in store windows, newspaper advertisements and even under ice; a 30-foot version along with a 30-foot Grammy logo (depicting a gramophone) were painted and iced over at the rink at Rockefeller Plaza. It was there that Mayor Dinkins proclaimed Grammy Week.
"The Grammy Awards will focus the attention of music lovers throughout the world on New York, as some of the brightest stars of the music industry converge on our city," he said. Then, noting the economic impact, he added, "Now, that's music to all our ears."

HEADLINE: Vacationers Sticking Closer to Home

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
Travel agents and tour companies are forecasting sharp increases in vacation and leisure travel within the United States and to Canada this spring and summer as Americans cut back on bookings to Europe and other destinations they would normally reach by air. In many cases, they will substitute trips by car, bus, train and ship for airplane travel.
The shift became apparent after the start of the Persian Gulf war on Jan. 17. It follows the earlier twin shocks of a recession and higher oil prices that began to affect travel plans, as well as other consumer planning, late last year. Steven Alesio, a senior vice president of the American Express Company , said, "There is clearly a major shift from Europe to the Caribbean and the United States destinations of Hawaii, California and Alaska." 
 George C. Guenther, immediate past president of the National Tour Association, a group of packaged tour operators, and the president of Talmage Tours in Philadelphia, said: "We have never in recent years had such an expression of interest in U.S. and Canadian travel as we are seeing at this very early point in the year. I believe that trend will continue."
 
Honeymoon Plans Change
 For example, Peter Rusnak, a commercial real estate developer in Washington, is planning to go to Hawaii on his honeymoon in April instead of France and England as originally planned. "It's primarily because of the situation in the gulf," he said.
Within the continental 48 states, motor-coach tour operators expect significantly bigger advance bookings for March and April. Amtrak said reservations were much higher than they were last year. Mississippi River steamboat bookings are expected to be the best ever.
"The consensus for the spring and summer is pretty good," said Preston Robert Tisch, former chairman of the Government Affairs Council of the Travel Industry Association of America and the president of the Loews Corporation. "There is more competition and more choices."
The prime element behind the rush to domestic travel by land and sea, rather than air is the fear of terrorism or other violence stemming from the Persian Gulf war. "It's basically the war," Mr. Tisch said, adding that spring and summer bookings at the Loews Hotels in the United States are up 10 percent over 1990.
 
Many Are Afraid to Fly
 Many Americans are afraid to leave the country or even fly within it, experts in the travel industry say. A trans-Atlantic fare war broke out this week among some international airlines, stemming largely from the declining bookings for spring and summer European flights by Americans.
Adding to the uncertainty over foreign travel is the large number of State Department advisories telling Americans of danger. Currently, 73 countries including Cyprus, Romania, Colombia and Thailand, are on the list.
"People feel safer closer to home," said Lorraine Schechet, the president of Equinox Travel in Manhasset, L.I. "The cancellations that have come in are mostly European cancellations."
Cynthia Newman, the president of Waters Travel Service in Washington, said: "We're getting many calls about the national parks. A lot of people are waiting to see what happens."
Many of those planning to stay in the United States do not want to fly. Last week, most of the major domestic airlines held a half-fare promotion for tickets that are good for travel for as much as almost a year ahead.
Patrick Murphy, the vice president for operations of Mayflower Tours in Downers Grove, Ill., said: "We are looking at 1991 to be a good, strong North American travel year. We have over 2,100 confirmed passengers for April 1991, which is 51 percent over April last year."
Similar opinions are being voiced by representatives of some of the nation's major tourist destinations. "It looks good and we're pretty optimistic," said Mark Northington, research director of the Louisiana Office of Tourism.
Long-distance buses are not the only form of surface transportation luring domestic travelers. Advance train bookings for April and May are showing big increases.
"Calls to our reservation sales offices are substantially up over last year," a spokesman for Amtrak, Clifford Black, said. As people started making plans for spring and summer vacations, inquiries to the national passenger railroad rose last month to 3.1 million from 2.7 million in January 1990, an increase of 13.6 percent.
And the Delta Queen Steamboat Company, which runs the Delta Queen and Mississippi riverboats on the Mississippi River, has the highest advance reservations in its history, Patrick Fahey, the president, said. Its bookings in the last three weeks have jumped 30 percent over the 1990 level to $3.5 million.
"There's a security that people feel in sailing in their own waters," Mr. Fahey said. "We're hearing it over the phones."

HEADLINE: Gas Savers That Belie Their Name

 BODY:
When the price of gasoline increases, as it did in the weeks before the Persian Gulf war, motorists often look for ways to reduce their fuel consumption. Not surprisingly, companies that sell bogus gas-saving devices try to take advantage of that situation.
The Federal Trade Commission has recently warned consumers to be particularly skeptical about three advertising claims: 
 *That a device can improve fuel economy by 12 to 25 percent. The Environmental Protection Agency has tested more than 100 so-called gas-saving devices, the trade commission said, and found only a few that improve mileage and none that do so significantly. Some devices attach to a car's ignition system, others to the engine. Still others contain a liquid similar to antifreeze.
*That a device can result in savings of three to four miles per gallon. So many variables affect fuel consumption, the trade commission said, that the average driver has no way of accurately measuring the savings attributable to the device itself.
*That a gas-saving device is approved by the Federal Government. In fact, the commission said, no Government agency approves such devices for cars.
If a consumer is not satisfied with a product, the F.T.C. suggests asking the manufacturer for a refund. If the company's refuses, call a local or state consumer-protection agency or the Better Business Bureau.
The commission also accepts complaints, and although it does not handle individual cases, a pattern of possible violations could warrant further action. The commission's main office in Washington can be reached by calling (202) 326-2222. It also has 10 regional offices.

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
Creating Illiteracy in New York

BYLINE: By BRENT STAPLES

 BODY:
Illiteracy already threatens to turn much of New York City's population into refugees, wandering jobless through the information age. Mayor David Dinkins's administration now plans to cut about $7.5 million from the New York Public Library and a few million each from the Queens and Brooklyn systems. That's small change in the world of high finance, but for the libraries it could mean death.
Services for children are already taking casualties. Next on the chopping block are the programs that taught reading to nearly 5,000 adult illiterates last year. All city programs must bear the burden of fiscal austerity; but the amounts needed for the library system are so small -- and the consequences of reductions so grim -- that philanthropy could make a decisive difference. 
 The New York Public Library, which covers Manhattan, Staten Island and the Bronx, is the best known. It gets private money, but chiefly for its research libraries; the branch libraries are about 1 percent privately funded. The Queens Borough Public Library and the Brooklyn Public Library receive similarly slight private support.
The libraries still suffer the effects of the 1970's fiscal crisis. With the new cuts, their staffs, already lean, would shrink further. New book purchases have been put off. Hours have been cut; many young people have no quiet place to study.
A visit to the branch in Flushing, Queens, demonstrates the value of what may soon be lost. This branch is the busiest building in the Queens system, which in turn is the busiest system in the nation. One in three visitors is a new American, thirsting to learn more about his adopted country. The neighborhood outside is a riotous collection of shop signs in other languages; inside, the pageant of new Americans stirs the soul.
Chinese, Korean and Spanish voices color the air as patrons wait to check out their precious cargo of books, some in their native tongues. Their children pore eagerly through open books, following the voice of an adult reader. Adults, poised prayerfully over workbooks, sit with instructors in the basement literacy center.
This library and others like it have become settlement houses. Workers who have hidden illiteracy for decades are losing their jobs to the recession and coming in to retool, to learn how to read a newspaper, how to get a driver's license, how to study for college entrance examinations. Neighborhood businessmen come for free seminars on how to run their operations, teenagers for information about AIDS.
Even in these difficult times, the city would do well to restore what money it can. Corporations and individuals could help support the small but vital branch libraries. Libraries are being cut back nationwide. But this city of immigrants bears a special responsibility. This is also a center of wealth, with the means to save this precious asset.

HEADLINE: If Iraq Really Wants Peace

 BODY:
Is Iraq's sudden offer to withdraw from Kuwait a desperate grab for peace, or is it, in President Bush's words, a "cruel hoax," a ploy to throw the impending ground war off schedule? In the end, it doesn't make any difference. If Saddam Hussein is finally serious about wanting to end the Persian Gulf war, he knows how to say so clearly -- starting tomorrow when the Iraqi Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, goes to Moscow.
The terms of Friday's Iraqi proposal are, if anything, worse than before. About the only new element in the proposal is the suggestion that Saddam Hussein is now willing to negotiate, on his terms; it offers not the slightest reason for the allies to budge. 
 The Soviets greeted Baghdad's offer with "satisfaction and hope," and President Mikhail Gorbachev urged Western leaders to delay the ground war until the new Moscow talks conclude. Most other allies were quick to dismiss Baghdad's offer.
Still, Iraq's words inevitably look different to different members of the allied coalition opposing Saddam Hussein. Mr. Bush is concerned that Iraqi diplomatic maneuvering not hold up achievement of his goals. Allies in the gulf and in Europe fear unsettling consequences of an intensifying war and expanding aims on their home fronts.
By saying for the first time that he's prepared to leave Kuwait, but linking that to a series of unacceptable conditions, Saddam Hussein could be trying to arouse false and divisive hope. By moving now, he could also be trying to capitalize on widespread sympathy over civilian casualties. And his offer comes just as the allies are intensifying air, artillery and battleship bombardment in preparation for ground assault. This would seem an opportune moment for him to seek a settlement.
Baghdad's offer does nothing to promote genuine negotiation. In return for an ambiguous promise to withdraw, Iraq wants not only an immediate cease-fire but also cessation of U.N. economic sanctions and withdrawal of U.S. and other forces. For the allies to accept that would be to acquiesce in Iraq remaining a threat to Mideast peace.
Iraq also tries to link its withdrawal to an Israeli pullout from the occupied territories, the Golan Heights and southern Lebanon. That linkage is as unacceptable to Arabs in the coalition as it is to Israel. And Baghdad wants the establishment of an "authentic democracy" in Kuwait. What an added arrogance: Saddam Hussein, after sacking and savaging Kuwait, still wishes to dictate who takes over when he leaves.
In the end, these points may be intended as a list of Iraq's desires and not as conditions for withdrawal, in which case Iraq can raise them later. If Saddam Hussein wants peace, there are two things to do now: First, make clear that there are no conditions attached to his commitment to get out of Kuwait. Second, start getting out.

HEADLINE: Iraq's Ploy: End Game or Dead End?

BYLINE: By Winston Lord; Winston Lord has been Ambassador to China and director of the State Department's policy planning staff.

 BODY:
The announcement yesterday of Iraq's willingness to withdraw from Kuwait coupled with conditions yet to be sorted out is a classic case of good news, bad news.
The good news is that Saddam Hussein is clearly hurting. For the first, time, he has specifically cited a U.N. resolution and concretely agreed to vacate Kuwait. His earlier formulations were adamant that Kuwait was his 19th province and that he would never give it up. After months of aborting all efforts to implant even the principle of withdrawal, he is pregnant for the first time. He has also granted us the favor of relegating the thorny issue of civilian bombing casualties to the inside pages. 
 This reversal can only be explained by a calculation that his military machine and his national infrastructure are crumbling -- and, along with them, the morale of his troops and the stamina of his people. Thus, he has vividly confirmed the accuracy of this week's Pentagon estimates of the destruction of his military assets.
The bad news is that the Iraqi statement as it stands is a ploy, if not a hoax. It is designed not for peace but for venting the pressures on him and dividing the international coalition. He has piled on extra conditions for withdrawal. He has not formally renounced his annexation. He has avoided the other stipulations of U.N. resolutions.
He is working in concert with a Soviet Union that is fast sliding back to its cold war opportunism, and an Iran that provides parking space for his planes and considers Washington a mightier Satan than Baghdad. So far, the rest of the coalition seems to be holding fast. But pressures on our Moslem partners will mount. The Chinese will be unhelpful. The French will be mischievous.
The Bush Administration's immediate response has been right on target. It has moved swiftly and energetically to punch holes in the statement while continuing to pummel Iraqi forces. If, as is likely, the Hussein move is strictly another cynical maneuver, we have avoided the slippery slope of a premature cease-fire. No doubt Washington is busy firming up our friends and serving notice to the vexatious intermediaries (while correctly, if insincerely, "welcoming" their efforts).
This is also the best approach to determine if Saddam Hussein is looking for a way out. Now is the time for third parties to strip away all conditionality from the Iraqi withdrawal, obtain agreement on the remaining parts of the U.N. resolutions and consign other issues to a delinked aftermath. While this process unfolds, we can -- and should -- hold off any ground offensive while unflinchingly prosecuting our air attacks. And only if the diplomatic minuet succeeds should we consider a cease-fire for the sole purpose of returning Iraqi forces home.
The tough issue for the Administration is what to do if, in fact, these remote contingencies prove real. Do we settle for the implementation of the U.N. resolutions while leaving Mr. Hussein in power with much of his arsenal intact? The correct answer is a reluctant yes. "Reluctant" because the Middle East, and the world, would be much more secure without a heavily armed Saddam Hussein. "Yes" because we really have no other choice. Besides, the outcome would constitute a significant victory.
Neither the American people nor the international alliance would tolerate a rejection of our own and the U.N.'s stated aims. To topple Mr. Hussein and completely eradicate his military power would require a ground war with all its certain horrors and horrendous uncertainties. Such a campaign would be supportable if he maintained his manifestly obstinate stance.
But if he is prepared to meet the world community's objectives, the only possible advocates of continued fighting (in addition to the Israelis) would be the Kuwaitis, Saudis and British -- and even those governments would find it extremely difficult to stay the course. Americans would not be willing to purchase a larger victory, however desirable, at the cost of much heavier casualties and international opposition.
Furthermore, the result, while leaving significant residual dangers, would be a singular triumph. Since Jan. 16, the U. S. has been pursuing one official objective, implementation of the U.N. resolutions, and two unofficial ones, the destruction of Iraq's offensive capabilities and the removal of Mr. Hussein. We would have achieved the first goal with minimal casualties. Any follow-on actions, such as diplomacy on Arab-Israeli questions, would be consistent with our prewar policies and in the interests of lasting security.
As for our two unstated goals, we have not done badly. The beauty of the aerial campaign is that it simultaneously weakens Mr. Hussein and his strengths under the legitimate cover of evicting his forces from Kuwait. U.S. officials state that we have severely crippled his weapons of mass destruction and eliminated much of his conventional armaments.
In the war's wake, we should work with others to embargo arms shipments to Iraq and all Middle Eastern trade, including components, in missiles, nuclear, chemical and biological weapons. And we should seek Israeli agreement to negotiate toward a nuclear-free zone in the region.
As for Mr. Hussein, it is not self-evident that he would survive a unilateral withdrawal. How popular or secure can a leader be who brings down upon his country international ostracism, embargoes, devastation of his nation and military defeat on top of giving up all gains from a previous bloody eight-year war? Will the ordinary Iraqi citizen, surveying the desolate landscape, or the average Iraqi general, surveying the wreckage of weapons, find solace in some vague hopes for Palestinian justice? And whatever the official rhetoric of interested nations, their leaders will know who won and who lost, and will draw the appropriate conclusions.
If nevertheless Mr. Hussein does weather yet another appalling miscalculation and defeat, he will surely be a much weaker threat than he was on Aug. 1. We can work with others to contain him and construct a more stable region. To be sure, as alliances shift and opportunism breaks out, our challenges will be daunting.
How do we promote lasting security in the gulf? What are the trade-offs between the reassurances and the resentments fueled by a continuing U.S. presence? How do we contend with the specters of terrorism and weapons of mass destruction? What is a fair distribution of financial burdens? How do we lessen the regional rage harbored by the deprived against the affluent? What constitutes genuine domestic stability for moderate Arab regimes? How do we tackle the virulent Arab-Israeli enmity that exacerbates the area's manifold tensions? What are the implications for American defense and economic policies?
We will confront such an agenda from a position of great prestige and power. The U.S. would have created and led an unprecedented international coalition and, with modest casualties, forced an aggressor to yield his spoils. Having thus won the war, we could feel confident about winning the peace.
A ton of dust has yet to settle from yesterday's Iraqi announcement. The odds remain that we are watching much ado about nothing, that we will not face the policy choice outlined here. But if we do, let us consider it good news, not some "nightmare scenario." Let us not allow the best to be the enemy of the good.

HEADLINE: Don't Use Export-Import Bank for Arms Sales

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As a senior staff employee of the United States Export-Import Bank from 1964 until 1987, where my duties included liaison with other Federal agencies, I am deeply disturbed by reports that the Administration is considering requiring the bank to revert to financing exports of United States military equipment and services. My concern stems from the bank's experience in fiscal years 1966 through 1968, when it was made a major participant in the export of weapons, in part because of budget constraints caused by the Vietnam War, and in part because of the balance-of-payments problem then. 
 In fiscal year 1966, the bank authorized loans of $134 million to finance military sales to Australia, $110 million for such sales to Britain and $237.7 million for weapons sales to "miscellaneous countries," not otherwise specified. During the following 12 months the comparable figures were $159.7 million, $435 million and $353.1 million. The amounts for fiscal year 1968 were $50 million, $100 million and nil.
The drop to zero in fiscal year 1968 resulted from a series of articles in The New York Times derived from interviews with Department of Defense officials who were elated that they had been able to tap into the bank's resources to finance these exports, limiting their department's role to a repayment guarantee of the bank's loans.
The articles provoked extended Congressional hearings, where the technique was referred to as "backdoor financing" and an evasion of the appropriations process. The result of these hearings was legislation in March 1968 (Public Law 90-267), which imposed a limit on the amount of weapons sales to developing countries, followed that October by Public Law 90-269, which imposed an outright ban on Export-Import Bank financing of military equipment sales to developing countries.
Much has changed since 1968, including the development of a more serious Federal budget crisis. In the mid-1960's the bank's authorizations were equal to about 12 percent of United States exports; last year they were equal to less than 2 percent.
With United States exporters of commercial goods desperate for export credit support, the Administration should conserve its severely limited resources to support exports that contribute to development of markets abroad for United States goods and services. If exports of military equipment are deemed to be in the national interest, clearly the responsibility for such transactions should rest with the Department of Defense. After all, that agency is supposed to know about strategy and the legitimate needs for weapons of other countries.
Also, retaining the responsibility for such transactions in the Department of Defense will make the information on amounts, types of weapons and buyers available to Congress and the public through the authorization and appropriation process.
The Export-Import Bank should not now, when commercial goods exports are perhaps the only bright spot in our bleak economy, be used to assume the risks of financing nonproductive military exports, with the associated risks of subsequent political backlash. Debt relating to military procurement is the easiest kind not to pay, particularly when the buyer is asked to join the supplier country in military action, for example, Egypt and the United States, and earlier, Egypt and the Soviet Union.
Since leaving the bank I have been with a consulting organization that analyzes the export credit agencies of other countries -- counterparts to the Export-Import Bank. This has enabled me to see how many of these agencies have gotten into serious political and financial difficulties by supporting exports of military equipment. For example, the British export credit agency some years ago was heavily involved in supporting military sales to the Kwame Nkrumah Government in Ghana. When that Government changed, its successor sought to repudiate the arms-related debt, with resulting financial losses and claims payments.
Arms sales, by their nature, are highly political and noncommercial. Military equipment doesn't generate cash flow for debt service, a serious problem in most developing countries. The financing of such exports cannot be based on the commercial considerations that govern export credit agencies, including the Export-Import Bank.
The Export-Import Bank deserves to be supported in its commercial export finance functions; financing military exports is an inappropriate, unprofitable and unpromising role for it.
 
ALBERT H. HAMILTON
Senior Associate, First Washington Associates Ltd.
Arlington, Va., Jan. 25, 1991

HEADLINE: Why Ban Alcohol Ads on the Cable Car?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
San Francisco's action to ban alcohol advertising on buses, cable cars and streetcars (Advertising column, Jan. 24) is a triumph of emotion over reason, since no connection has been established between alcohol advertising and consumption, let alone alcohol abuse. That has been the consistent finding of the Federal Trade Commission, the Department of Health and Human Services and independent researchers. We believe the action is not a trend, contrary to your portrayal, since we know of very few local governments that have taken such action. 
 In our view, the action does show concerns about alcohol abuse, which we share, and which we are helping fight by spending tens of millions of dollars on research and on programs to encourage responsible drinking and prevent underage drinking.
Banning ads is not only misdirected but also raises concerns about free speech and ignores the benefits of advertising. Ads provide information, foster competition and allow the introduction of new brands. They also provide badly needed revenue. We believe the San Francisco Municipal Railway will be hard pressed in the current economic climate to make up the $760,000 in revenue it loses.
We think society would be better served through the hard work of education and strict law enforcement, which we support, to continue favorable trends of reductions in alcohol abuse.
 
STEPHEN K. LAMBRIGHT
Vice President, Anheuser-Busch Companies
St. Louis, Jan. 30, 1991

HEADLINE: CUNY's High School Plan Looks Backward

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The proposal by the City University of New York to put pressure on city high school students to take a set of traditional academic courses specific to a particular multiple-choice Regents examination is backward looking (news article, Jan. 24). The proposal ignores the efforts of the most innovative and thoughtful high schools in the city to de-emphasize rote learning and promote independent inquiry and study. These schools have learned that Regents exams and standardized tests do not adequately measure an effective school or student learning. 
 The proposal renews emphasis on standardized tests and traditional curriculums that have been discredited by city, state and national educators looking for more effective ways to educate young people. Worse, it is another put-down of minority students. It reinforces the view that they are deficient and can't meet the university's standard. We can only ask CUNY officials and the Board of Education: Stop before you do this.
Ask yourself: why do so many African-American and Latino children not take the Regents? Even a cursory study will show that these children from their first day in kindergarten are informed that intellectual pursuits are not for them. Look at their schools, their teachers, their homes, and instead of asking how to keep them from higher education, ask how to make it possible for them to attend college and to graduate.
Don't be satisfied with the view that you must protect the institution and what may be outdated standards of scholarship and knowledge, by erecting more barriers against the victims of racism and economic injustice. Look at the schools where kids pass the Regents and ask if it's a coincidence that they are populated by mostly white, middle-class children. We must be more creative than this proposal suggests, or we will inherit a world even more divided by race and class.
 
HEATHER LEWIS
Executive Director, Center for Collaborative Education
New York, Jan. 25, 1991

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises on Iraq's Offer And U.S. Economic Reports

BYLINE: By Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose against leading currencies yesterday after Iraq's conditional offer to withdraw from Kuwait and a Government report that raised concerns about inflation.
Gold prices fell. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $364.40 an ounce, down $3.80 from Thursday. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for gold of $363.50, down $4.15. 
 Iraq's offer sought to link an Iraqi withdrawal with an Israeli pullout from Arab territories, a democracy to replace the rule of emirs in Kuwait and forgiveness of Iraqi debts.
Jack Adkins, analyst for Refco Group Ltd. in Chicago, said traders were buoyed by the peace proposal, even though it carried weighty political baggage for the United States.
"The sentiment is that maybe there would be a peace settlement soon," Mr. Adkins said.
 
 Effect of Economic Reports
 The dollar also rallied following release of Government reports showing wholesale prices edged down one-tenth of 1 percent in January, while the country's trade deficit fell to its lowest level in seven years in 1990.
Mr. Adkins said another report saying consumer prices rose 6.1 percent in 1990 -- the fastest pace since 1981 -- indicated the threat of inflation had not disappeared. He added that some traders believed this report might cause the Federal Reserve to postpone further easing of interest rates to bring the economy out of a recession. Lower interest rates push down the dollar by making dollar-denominated securities less valuable.
Stephen Flanagan, vice president of Mitsubishi Bank Ltd., said the low trade deficit figure released by the Commerce Department "reinforced a bullish sentiment that developed in the New York market" following active foreign trading.
In Tokyo, where trading had ended before the Iraqi report, the dollar fell to 129.66 yen, down 0.09 yen from Thursday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted higher, at 130.40 yen. In New York, it settled at 130.50 yen, up from 129.67 yen on Thursday.
 
 Decline for the Pound
 In London, the British pound fell to $1.9680, from $1.9805 late Thursday. In New York it cost $1.9670 to buy 1, less than Thursday's $1.9795.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.4777 German marks, up from 1.4665; 1.2692 Swiss francs, up from 1.2570; 1.1528 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1523; 5.0320 French francs, up from 4.9950, and 1,110.50 Italian lire, up from 1,103.25.
Gold fell in London to a late bid of $365.25 an ounce, from $368 late Thursday. In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $364.85, from $367.75 late Thursday. The gold market in Hong Kong was closed for the New Year holiday.
Silver bullion rose in London to a late bid of $3.84 an ounce, from $3.81 late Thursday. On the New York Commodity Exchange, silver was at $3.780, down from Thursday's $3.826.

HEADLINE: America, Heal Thyself

BYLINE: By Bill Bradley; Bill Bradley is the senior Senator from New Jersey.

 BODY:

THE NEXT CENTURY
By David Halberstam.
126 pp. New York:
William Morrow & Company.
$16.95. 
 Americans are living at a moment of serious introspection about our purpose as a nation. The cold war Communism against which many of us defined ourselves for 45 years is dead. Environmental crises lie on the horizon. Economic competition comes from nations increasingly confident in their abilities and strengths. A decade of profligate debt has endangered our future. The wall between successful and struggling Americans has grown higher. Conditions in many families, schools and cities deny millions of young people the chance to reach their full potential. This new set of circumstances creates doubt about government's ability to meet human needs adequately, and it challenges Americans to develop a positive vision for the nation based on today's reality.
In short, we need a new way of thinking about where the nation can go in the future. The earnest search for a new national ambition, though, is too easily diverted by bitter nostalgia for the postwar days when, as David Halberstam puts it in "The Next Century," "We were rich and confident in a world that was poor and pessimistic." In a world that we can no longer dominate by size or power, the fate of the United States is inextricably bound up with the destinies of the rich nations of Western Europe and the Pacific Rim and with the poor nations of Africa, Latin America, Eastern Europe and what is still, for the time being, called the Soviet Union.
Mr. Halberstam would appear to have spent his whole career in preparation for thinking about this emergent world. Reporting from Eastern Europe in the 1950's, covering the crisis of American aspirations in Vietnam in the 1960's and dissecting the Japanese confrontation with the American automobile industry in the 1980's, he has been on the scene at each stop along the road to the world we see before us. In "The Next Century," he weaves memories, ideas and insights from his life's work into a concise warning about the bad habits we have introduced into American life, and he offers fresh hope for our ability to overcome them.
Mr. Halberstam's is not the only book published recently to scour the past for hints about the future, but it is the shortest and the best. It refreshingly avoids the familiar litany of cold statistics -- trade and budget deficits, S.A.T. scores, foreign ownership -- that supposedly demonstrate America's declining competitiveness. Mr. Halberstam's book is instead about people, and he introduces us to individuals from his various journeys who remind us that the answers to our questions will come not only through conversation with one another but also through exchanges with those in other nations who face similar questions.
In Poland, for example, the journalist Andrzej Wroblewski describes to Mr. Halberstam the new world confronting his country: "The question is how well, how democratically, we will use that time in which we try to catch up. Do we use it to scapegoat others -- do we feel sorry for ourselves and blame our conditions on the Communists and the Jews -- or do we accept responsibility for it ourselves . . . and accept the fact that it will take a great deal of very hard work to catch up?"
In Japan, Mr. Halberstam finds, the successful pursuit of prosperity brings problems similar to the ones the cold war victory has posed for Americans. As a retired Japanese Government official explains: "For forty years we were single-minded in our purpose. We were the greyhound chasing the hare. Now the hare that we chased has disappeared. So who are we and what are we next after the hunt? . . . We put aside almost all our political and social issues because we were dealing with things that seemed much more pressing. Now that we have attained economic success we need these other values, and we lack them, and we are not sure how to find them."
Poland, Japan and the United States traveled very different paths from the end of World War II to the present moment, but those paths now converge. Poland shook off the last great military empire. Japan sublimated its misguided imperial dreams into economic ambition. As for the United States, Mr. Halberstam traces its evolution from the 1954 decision by President Dwight D. Eisenhower and Gen. Matthew Ridgway not to risk hundreds of thousands of troops by intervening in Vietnam at Dien Bien Phu. "This was a nation still in touch with its limits, a democracy, not yet an empire," Mr. Halberstam writes. But a decade later, he continues, as our involvement in Vietnam deepened and we failed to pay for it, we appeared to lose some of the "shared truths" on which a democracy functions. Now we face our successes and our limits all at once, and along with Poland, Japan and other nations we search for a positive purpose in the world, a way to make the most of our potential on our own terms, without defining ourselves in opposition to enemies at home or abroad.
Mr. Halberstam's is one of the few books to recognize that the challenge facing the United States is not finding a scapegoat for our economic blunders but making the most of our physical and mental capabilities, improving our productivity in an open, democratic structure. He pinpoints our failures in education, sees we are practicing "the politics of anxiety and uncertainty rather than the politics of confidence" and urges us to judge ourselves by our own norms of what "a harmonious and decent society" should be.
He seems to be saying that we have a choice. We can follow the path set in the 1980's and continue to fight over the diminishing supply of money and power, dividing ourselves, in the larger world, along national borders and, at home, along lines of class and race. Or, if we take Mr. Halberstam's insights to heart, we can recognize that there is no substitute for quality and no replacement for unity at home and cooperation abroad.
