HEADLINE: Playing the Japanese Market

BYLINE: By James Sterngold; James Sterngold, a correspondent in the Tokyo bureau of The New York Times, is the author of "Burning Down the House," about the collapse of E. F. Hutton.

 BODY:

UNEQUAL EQUITIES
Power and Risk in Japan's Stock Market.
By Robert Zielinski and Nigel Holloway.
246 pp. New York:
Kodansha International. $21.95. 
 A popular school of thought holds that many distinctly Japanese corporate traits -- the rarity of takeovers, the payment of low stock dividends, the bonding of companies into keiretsu, industrial groupings linked together by cross-shareholdings -- are a product of cultural forces peculiar to Japan. The market is seen not as a forum where Adam Smith's invisible hand can work its sometimes rough magic, but something akin to a financial tea ceremony, a cultural institution that reflects the harmonious soul of "Japan Inc."
With careful research and a clear-eyed view of what motivates businessmen, Robert Zielinski and Nigel Holloway, in "Unequal Equities," go a long way toward shattering that myth. In the process, their refreshing look at the ways of corporate Japan demonstrates how the hard rules of finance, rather than the fuzzy virtues of company songs, lifetime employment (available to only a fraction of Japanese workers) or many other famous management techniques, have been key to its competitive prowess.
As Mr. Zielinski, an American stock analyst in Tokyo, and Mr. Holloway, an English business journalist, make clear, Japanese managers have long regarded finance -- obtaining capital in abundance and as cheaply as possible -- as critically important. The main difference between them and their American competitors is that they succeeded in shaping their stock market to satisfy their needs while imposing few demands, such as the payment of high dividends. Indeed Mr. Zielinski and Mr. Holloway present a relatively simple thesis: Big corporations have rigged the Japanese stock market.
The book's most provocative pages describe how Japanese managers achieved this. The story, as Mr. Zielinski and Mr. Holloway tell it, really begins with the American occupation of Japan after World War II. One of the key aims was to break up the zaibatsu, the family-controlled holding companies that dominated Japanese industry and had cooperated with the militarists. The occupation authorities dissolved the holding companies of groups like Mitsubishi and distributed their shares to the public.
As a consequence, when the Tokyo Stock Exchange reopened in 1949 individuals owned almost 70 percent of the shares. Companies were forced to pay high dividends, and they were vulnerable to takeover attempts.
Japanese corporations, according to Mr. Zielinski and Mr. Holloway, responded shrewdly. They began a campaign to buy themselves up slowly, displacing the individual shareholders. The companies, moreover, knit themselves into networks by acquiring one another's shares. Today Japanese corporations own 70 percent of the shares listed on the exchange, and Japanese executives demand of one another not a quick buck but what managers most want: growth. (On Wall Street, by comparison, individuals or their proxies, mutual funds and pension funds, still own more than half of the publicly traded shares.)
The result? Japanese listed companies pay approximately half the level of dividends that their American competitors pay, retaining capital for new investments. Shareholders in Japan who want higher payouts simply do not have the power to demand them. And, as Mr. Zielinski and Mr. Holloway point out, major Japanese companies are almost immune from unwanted takeovers because friendly shareholders in the form of other companies would never sell to an interloper.
In addition, it is much easier for Japanese companies to raise capital by selling new securities within these corporate circles. American companies slashed their equity by a half trillion dollars in the past decade as they resorted to leveraged buyouts and other such schemes to enrich shareholders. Japanese companies strengthened themselves by issuing new shares during this period, raising 70 trillion yen, or about $530 billion at current exchange rates.
A company like Sony, for instance, was able to capture CBS Records and Columbia Pictures, as well as develop its high-tech gadgets, because of its financial position. According to Mr. Zielinski and Mr. Holloway, Sony pays one of the lowest dividends of any company in Japan. Nonetheless it has raised more capital over the past few years than all but one other Japanese company.
Alternatively, Mr. Zielinski and Mr. Holloway show what might happen to an American company like I.B.M. if it were Japanese and did not face shareholder demands for quick returns. The computer company could save $2.5 billion a year by paying a Japanese-sized dividend and could plow the cash into research and new equipment. Instead of using its capital to buy back its shares, as it does now to keep the price up, I.B.M. would be raising another $2 billion every year by selling new securities.
These illustrations can be repetitive, but they make this insightful book readable. Still, what "Unequal Equities" lacks are the voices of Japan's top executives. As any journalist in the country knows, getting them on record can be devilishly difficult. But it would have added to the book's authority had the authors got some Japanese managers to verify the book's conclusions, or at least discuss them.
Another shortcoming of "Unequal Equities" is that it was published before last year's stock crash in Japan had run its course. The system the authors describe depends on constantly rising share prices. So far, however, Japan Inc. does not seem to have missed a beat. In some ways this fact even strengthens the arguments in the book, suggesting that the stock market is a tool, not a reflection, of Japan's corporate health.
Ultimately, "Unequal Equities" will perform an important service if it enlarges the stunted debate over how industrial policy might revive American competitiveness. Too often this discussion starts and stops with the idea of the Federal Government selecting, and then aiding, particular industries. A better understanding of how corporate Japan takes advantage of its financial markets would inject a note of realism into this debate, while raising serious questions about how the United States economy is served by Wall Street.

HEADLINE: Last-Minute Bargains

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE

 BODY:
IT used to be that people who usually took a winter vacation in the Caribbean made their reservations before Thanksgiving. But this year, when the Caribbean Hoteliers Association met in Bermuda two days before the Persian Gulf war began, they saw a clear impact of the recession in the United States. The hoteliers were quick to say that tourists were still coming, but that they were not putting cash on the line until just a couple of weeks before departure.
"The state of mind is 'I don't want to lock myself into anything,' " said James Camissa, a travel industry consultant in Miami. He said this reluctance existed before the gulf war and the recession, though both have intensified it. 
 Despite the hoteliers' protestations that travelers were arriving, even if booking late, many places are hurting for business. Richard A. Ellis, senior director of Caribbean marketing for Liberty Travel-GoGo Tours, pointed out that February and the first three weeks of March were "the sacred cows" of Caribbean travel -- "the equivalent of Christmas week to retailers" -- and that airlines and hotels did not normally discount their prices for these weeks. Not so this year.
Rick Mazza, president of the Travelsavers chain of 1,900 travel agencies, said he estimated that business was off 30 percent from last winter, which "wasn't that great" either. He said that normally difficult air space could be found, as were "prices that are real bargains."
 The discounts take many guises: Some provide free dinners with a hotel room; some say a day or two extra is thrown in. The prices of some air-hotel packages dropped the week after Christmas and now they sound like the price for either the room or the air trip, but not both. "We won't see prices like these again for four or five years," said Steven Heydt, a senior vice president of GoGo Tours.
Not all the islands are wide open; smaller islands that get a steady European trade, for instance, say things are normal or nearly so, and the Virgin Islands, having made big investments since Hurricane Hugo devastated St. Croix in 1989, are pretty well booked. A spokesman for Pan American, John Ruzich, reports few empty seats to the Virgin Islands in February and March.
American Express offices report that they are getting word of new discounts daily. If any advance-purchase requirements have remained, they are eliminated for packagers or travel agencies that are important to the airlines; if there is an empty seat or room, it is for sale.
The steepest discounts may be yet to come. Cruise lines, with their aggressive last-minute discounting, have succeeded in taking away business from island hotels, according to agents and industry analysts. Some hotels still say they are adhering to their high-season rates, hoping to get the best profit they can while the north is still cold. Travel industry experts say that after next month, discounts could get very deep indeed.
Here are some last-minute deals in the Caribbean and the Bahamas:
Aruba . GoGo has two types of programs for the Caribbean. One gives a 20 percent discount on the combined cost of room and air fare. At the newly opened Hyatt Regency on Aruba, for example, GoGo offers a price of about$1,062 a person for seven nights in a standard double room and round-trip air from New York on American Airlines with midweek flights. The full price would be $1,274 a person, the company says. The other programs, "fly free" packages, also include hotel and air but the traveler pays only the cost of the room at standard rates. At the same Hyatt Regency, that deal applies to rooms classified as deluxe, which are $315 a night, or $1,102.50 a person for seven nights. The lowest published midweek round-trip air fare, on American, is $434 a person, GoGo says, so on any program to Aruba, the saving is that much. Hyatt said its new hotel was 80 percent occupied in mid-February, and that there had been a rise in reservations at the start of the month, at the time special prices began to appear in the area. In the Northeast states, Liberty Travel sells GoGo packages; elsewhere they are widely available from travel agents.
Bahamas. The 31 hotels in the Nassau-Cable Beach-Paradise Island complex in the Bahamas reported a busy January. Bob Volk, executive vice president of the Bahamas tourist group, said a survey showed people wanted places they could get to quickly. However, he said that 10 to 20 percent of the rooms were available for February, particularly in midweek. Weekends are filling up by Thursday, he said.
The Merv Griffin Paradise Island hotels have so many deals going it is hard to sort them out. A package of three nights, with two in a room, including air fare from New York, is offered by three hotels: the Paradise Paradise Beach Resort, where the lowest per-person price is $379; the Ocean Club Golf and Tennis Resort, where the starting price is $559, and the Paradise Island Resort and Casino, where it is $429. Resorts International offers these packages, which are available through travel agents.
The Club Paradise, an all-inclusive program where the guests stay at the Resort and Casino, has a three-night package that includes round-trip air fare from New York. This starts at $859 a person with two in a room, and includes three meals, a $100 credit toward drinks, golf and tennis. Three nights at this time of year, without air fare, is listed at $799 a person in the winter edition of 1990-91 Hotel & Travel Index, a travel agent's reference book.
Until April 6, Liberty-GoGo is offering a "dine free" package of three days and four nights in the Britannia Tower section of the Paradise Island Resort and Casino. The guest gets dinner each of the three nights, selecting from the nine restaurants in the hotel. With air fare included, two in a room, this is $559 a person. Extra days are $95.
Barbados The Heywoods Resort on the west coast, is offering a package of three nights for $549 to $649 a person, depending on the location of the room, or seven nights for $774 to $999, including round-trip air fare from Kennedy International Airport. The hotel's regular room rate alone starts at $480 a person for three nights and $1,120 for seven.
At the Regency Cove Hotel, in Hastings on the south coast, a package that includes air fare from New York starts at $485 a person for three nights and $623 for seven nights. The 15 percent charge for tax and service is also included. The standard room rate, with the 15 percent, is $120 a person for three nights and $281 for seven.
 Guadeloupe and Martinique. These French islands are usually full at this time of year, and indeed this is the case with the Novotel, a place that is popular with Europeans. But other hotels reported on Jan. 31 that 10 percent to 30 percent of their rooms were available for the end of February. The islands' tourist authorities are offering special air fare-hotel packages using seats on Sunday charter flights from New York. Round-trip fare and seven nights in an economy hotel cost $819 a person with two in a room; a standard room is $959; a first-class room is $1,055 and a deluxe room $1,265. Comparisons are tricky, but one of the hotels offering the air-fare-room package at the $1,265 rate usually offers double rooms at $251 to $380 a night for two people with breakfast, which is also included in the package. Information: (212) 661-4546 or (800) 765-6065.
Jamaica. Sunburst Holidays offers a number of three- and seven-night packages to Jamaica, air fare included. On the lower end, at Doctors Cave Beach Hotel, three nights are $484 a person from New York and seven nights are $724. The regular room rate is or $270 a person for three nights and $630 for seven. At the high end is the Half Moon Golf, Tennis and Beach Club outside Montego Bay where the package is $736 a person for three nights and $1,322 for seven. The least expensive rooms are room $445 a person for three nights and $1,075 for seven. Sandals Ocho Rio, one of the island's popular all-inclusive resorts, is $1,434 a person for seven nights. The lowest regular seven-night rate there is $1,175, not including air fare. Sunburst Holidays, (800) 666-8346 .
Puerto Rico. This island, a traditional last-minute choice, provides examples of good package prices. A round trip on American Airlines from New York and other East Coast cities, and three nights at the El San Juan Hotel and Casino, which is on the beach, costs $599 a person with two in a room. The same deal, at La Concha, also on the beach in San Juan but less fancy, is $349 a person. For those who want to squeeze the full four days out of the three hotel nights, flights leave as early as 7:30 A.M. and the return can be close to midnight, on a two-and-a-half-hour flight from New York. Both are GoGo packages.
St. Barthelemy. About half of the hotels at small, expensive St. Barthelemy report having no space, but there is only 50 percent occupancy at other places: the Tropical, the Manypany, La Presqu'ile and Baie de Flamands. The Manypany was offering a "late impuse buyer" price for the rest of February that was 15 percent off the regular rates: $1,295 a person for seven nights in a deluxe ocean-view room with daily American breakfast and one dinner included, based on two in a room. In the first two weeks of March, this would be $1,120 a person. More information: (800) 847-4249.
St. Kitts-Nevis. Island Resort Tours in New York has three programs for St. Kitts that include air fare. One, for three nights at the Fairview Inn, on the west coast north of Basseterre, is $649 a person for three nights and $883 for seven nights, with a free eighth night if desired. The room portion represents a 25 percent discount off the regular rates, the company says, and includes an air fare that only travel companies offer. At the Frigate Bay Beach, a three-night package is $639 and seven nights $844, representing a 29 percent discount on the rooms, Island Resort Tours says. And at the Bird Rock Beach Resort, on a hillside near Frigate Bay, three nights is $659 and seven nights is $891, a 20 percent reduction off the regular room rate. These prices include a 7 percent hotel tax and 10 percent service charge. Island Resort Tours, (800) 527-5982, or (212) 545-8475.
St. Martin. In French St. Martin, a building boom has raised the number of hotel rooms to 3,000, and a spokesman said that meant there will be space for the second half of February. Hotel owners there said they were interested in filling those rooms and might offer concessions if people called to inquire. One hotel, L'Habitation, said it had a special offer available for the rest of February and March. The package, called a Winter Quick Escape, provides for room and breakfasts for three nights, one dinner, a car rental for two days and a $25-a-day allowance toward food and beverages in the hotel's restaurants. The price for this, with two people to a room, is $509 a person. The rate listed in Hotel & Travel Index for the type of room in this package for this season is $300 a night. This package is available from Mondotels in New York, (800) 847-4249. Both Pan Am and Continental said they expected to have seats to St. Martin.
U.S. Virgin Islands At St. Thomas in the United States Virgin Islands, Stouffer's Grand Beach Resort has a seven-night package, including air fare, for $895 a person on the basis of two in a room. Mr. Heydt of Liberty Travel said that normally this GoGo package would cost $1,250 a person.
On St. John, the GoGo "fly free" package can be used at the Virgin Grand Hyatt in rooms of any category. The rooms run from $275 to $450 a night with two in a room, Mr. Heydt said, and the lowest air fare would be $488 a person.

HEADLINE: ANTIQUES;
The Boys of Summer Play Ball Forever, for Collectors

BYLINE: By RITA REIF

 BODY:
Baseball memorabilia became a major-league collectible in the 1980's when the prices paid for bats, balls, uniforms, locker keys, rings, pendants, press pins and the ubiquitous palm-sized cards soared. Now, fans of artifacts relating to the boys of summer -- especially Honus Wagner, Babe Ruth, Mickey Mantle and Jackie Robinson -- expect even higher prices at the sale next month of one of the most important baseball collections ever formed.
Assembled over the last five years by James C. Copeland, a California sporting-goods retailer, the collection of 873 items or groups of items is to be auctioned on March 22 and 23 at Sotheby's in Manhattan; the sale is estimated to bring from $5 million to $7 million. 
 Dominated by baseball cards, Sotheby's auction -- its first sale in the United States devoted to sports memorabilia -- includes photographs, programs, game tickets, autographed baseballs and bats, and World Series press pins -- emblematic credentials, specially designed for games dating from 1911 to 1989. The catalogue evokes more than a century of games, mostly through photographs on baseball cards that depict players poised to swing, equipment in hand, looking into the sun.
"Seventy percent of the lots in the collection are baseball cards," says Dana Hawkes, who heads Sotheby's collectibles sales in New York. The cards, issued at first by tobacco companies and today mostly by Topps, the bubble-gum producer, were packaged with candy, cereal, soft drinks, sausages, milk, ice cream, cookies and Red Heart dog food.
 The boom began slowly in 1969 when the first conventions for baseball collectors were held in New York and California.
"This was a closet-collecting type of hobby," said William Mastro, a Chicago collector-dealer who is a consultant to Sotheby's on the Copeland sale. "Until the mid-1970's, most adult collectors did not talk about what they were doing -- baseball cards were what kids collected. The popularity of other baseball collectibles runs in cycles. At one time it was press pins. Then came World Series programs. Right now, there is a real fervor for jerseys -- baseball players' uniforms."
Alan Rosen, a dealer in Montvale, N.J., recalled recently how the field expanded dramatically in the late 1970's. "In 1975, there weren't 50 dealers in the country," Mr. Rosen said. "Today, there are 25,000 to 35,000."
Prices rose -- and then declined. "The 1952 Topps Mickey Mantle card went from $3,000 in 1979 to $500 in 1981 when the recession hit," Mr. Mastro said. "Prices began to rise again in 1984, and now that card is worth over $10,000."
Mr. Copeland began to collect the way many people do. According to Mr. Mastro, "He walked into a baseball convention five years ago with his son Rick and saw all those cards he knew from his youth. Most people who collect today are not interested in the sport itself, because it focuses so much on money. The game was more personal back in the 1950's and earlier. Ball players were accessible. They walked over to the edge of the stands and signed autographs."
Collecting intensified again in the late 1980's, spurring some record prices at New York auctions. Babe Ruth's brass locker tag from Yankee Stadium, engraved with his name and the number 3, brought $7,150 at Phillips in 1987. Last December, Sotheby's sold a bat autographed by Lou Gehrig, possibly in 1935, for $27,500. At Christie's on Jan. 26, an 1866 Currier & Ives print, "The American National Game of Baseball," was sold for $44,000.
The costliest items are multicolor portraits of Honus Wagner, the legendary Pittsburgh Pirates shortstop. Issued by tobacco producers in 1909 and 1910, the cards are scarce because Wagner opposed smoking and objected to his name being linked to cigarettes, which were advertised on the back of the cards. Only 40 of these cards remain.
Mr. Mastro said he has handled a dozen Honus Wagner cards. The finest examples, which are in near-mint condition and have crisp corners and no discoloration, had been packaged with Piedmont cigarettes; only two are known to exist. Mr. Mastro said he bought the card for $25,000 in 1986 and sold it a year later to Mr. Copeland for $110,000. Sotheby's estimates that it will bring as much as $150,000.
A less rare version of the Wagner card, advertising Sweet Caporal cigarettes, was sold to Mr. Mastro in a 1989 auction for $115,000, the highest price paid to date for any baseball item. The sale was organized by Lelands, a Manhattan auction house specializing in sports memorabilia.
The most valuable item in Mr. Copeland's collection is the group of 160 World Series press pins. It is expected to bring $250,000 to $300,000.
For millions of collectors, nostalgia continues to fuel the pursuit of baseball memorabilia. One lifelong fan, trying to explain this fascination, asks: "Why baseball? Why not marbles? Why not tennis? Why not football? It's the only game I know of where the object is to get home -- safely."

SECTION: Section 6; Page 10; Column 3; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 168 words

HEADLINE: SECESSION OF THE SUCCESSFUL

 BODY:
I believe America's class problems are real; however, Reich's article describes the symptoms, not the problems. The separation of classes is a result of the inability of current systems to cope with the complexities of the 1990's. Take education. Why are public schools so poorly managed and structured?
Or safety, another big issue. Why is crime, which often establishes the boundaries separating the elite from the rest of the world, so rampant? Could it be a function of a justice system that paroles criminals too early, or that our country has no substantial gun-control laws? What about the decline of productivity, which steals real wage growth from the middle class?
These are the problems we face. Their causes have little to do with the proliferation of health clubs and home fax machines. We must solve the structural flaws in our system. In doing so, we will give the bottom four-fifths of our society hope for pulling themselves up toward the top.
 
MARK HOSBEIN
Baltimore

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: 712 Fifth Avenue;
High Hopes, and Vacancy, for a 4-Building Complex

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
"BATTERED" is a word used by architects to mean sloping walls. The 712 Fifth Avenue project, at 56th Street, has been battered in more ways than one.
No. 712 was begun in the heat of the mid-80's and has opened in a market that is becalmed. There have been two major designs: a sloping version and the current straight-sided tower. There have been three development teams: David S. and Jean W. Solomon, G. Ware Travelstead and the Taubman Company. There have been at least four plans: apartment house, hotel, combination apartment-hotel and, finally, office building. 
 Now the 53-story skyscraper is again in the public eye as the new Henri Bendel store is readied for its opening there in a few weeks. Bendel will occupy much of the tower's base, as well as two restored landmarks and a companion structure on Fifth Avenue. The interiors of all four buildings are woven together behind their different facades.
Most of the rest of the 545,000-square-foot building is empty. Six office tenants, including the Taubman Company's New York operation, have taken space on seven floors. Leases are pending on four other floors. Some 386,000 square feet are vacant.
The developer has high hopes, however.
"We fully believe that this is a unique, superb building in a location that is arguably second to none," said Christopher Tennyson, vice president for corporate affairs at the Taubman Company of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., which took over the project last year from Solomon Equities of Manhattan.
"We recognize the difficulties of the market at this time," Mr. Tennyson said, "but we are very confident that this landmark building will have a distinguished future."
An "intense level of security" is one of the features, said Jeffrey A. Lichtenberg, executive vice president of Peter R. Friedman Ltd. of Manhattan, the leasing agent. Asking rents range from $50 to $65 a square foot.
Taubman's optimism is shared by the Solomons, who were involved with the project from its outset in 1983.
"Through this period of re-evaluation by many tenants," Mr. Solomon said, "the smaller ones or the ones who want to have a particular presence are looking for a high-quality location and consolidation, rather than big floors in lesser locations." At No. 712, most floors are 9,800 square feet.
Mrs. Solomon said the "ideal tenants" had always been seen as "companies looking for a Fifth Avenue presence: financial companies, investment banks, New York headquarters for international companies." The roster already includes Christian Dior and Grand Metropolitan, the British conglomerate.
Just what role the Solomons now play seems to be a matter of interpretation. They maintain that they own part of the project. The Taubman Company emphasizes that it has "responsibility for the ownership," which does not directly contradict the Solomons' assertion. Both sides say that Taubman is running the development.
In a Sept. 27 memorandum, Robert C. Larson, vice chairman of the Taubman Company, said, "David and Jean Solomon have withdrawn as partners in 712 Fifth Avenue" and "neither the Solomons nor their associates will have any ongoing involvement."
Asked to elaborate last week, Mr. Tennyson furnished a statement signed by Mr. Solomon on Sept. 19 saying Taubman "now has full authority for the ownership, management and operation."
And Mr. Lichtenberg, the leasing agent, said, "The Solomons have zero to do with it."
In an interview Feb. 1, Mr. Solomon said: "In a reworking of all of our deals -- but, in specific, this one -- we have sold an interest back to the Taubmans and still have an ownership interest in the venture. The relationship is very clear. They will become the operating partner of the project. We're very proud of what we accomplished. We still have a significant economic stake in the venture."
Controversy is nothing new at 712 Fifth Avenue. Two elegant, five-story buildings on the site -- the former Rizzoli Building at No. 712 and the former Coty Building at No. 714 -- had attracted preservationists' attention but were not landmarks. The original plan was to replace them with a new structure of similar scale to serve as the tower's base.
"The battered wall came out of that," said A. Eugene Kohn, of Kohn Pedersen Fox Associates, the Manhattan architectural firm that designed the skyscraper. "The tower sloped back as part of a gesture to Fifth Avenue."
But a year after the Solomons and Mr. Travelstead had begun the complicated and costly process of assembling the site, trouble emerged in the most unlikely form.
In December 1984, Andrew S. Dolkart, an architectural historian, announced his finding that the windows at No. 714 had been designed by Rene Lalique, a French master of glass design, for the Coty perfumery that long ago occupied the building.
Within two months, both the Coty and Rizzoli buildings had been given landmark status, leaving the developers feeling ambushed. Not only were they prohibited from demolishing the two five-story buildings, they also were obliged to get approval from the Landmarks Preservation Commission for their tower, on the ground of its appropriateness in relation to the landmarks.
In May 1985, the commission approved the battered-wall design, which also preserved the front 50 feet of both landmarks, meaning that the tower was squeezed farther back off Fifth Avenue than originally planned.
"ONCE you had a deep base, the sloped tower didn't make sense," Mr. Kohn said. "It would have made the upper floors so small that they wouldn't have worked. Plus, with an office building, the idea of maintaining the same floor size all the way made sense."
The Solomons returned to the landmarks commission in 1987 with revised plans, showing a straight, slender shaft.
Then the office market dropped dizzyingly, leaving the Solomons with not just 712 Fifth Avenue to worry about, but also 1585 Broadway and 750 Seventh Avenue.
Last year, when Solomon Equities announced the deal with Taubman, its chief financial officer, Warren A. Schad, said: "This transaction allows us to free up our financial resources in order to devote them to our projects on the West Side of Manhattan."
The Solomons' interest in both projects is "close to 100 percent," Mr. Solomon said. "Some institutional partners," about whom he would not be more specific, have a stake between 5 and 10 percent, he said.
The 36-story Seventh Avenue tower, at 49th Street, has 570,000 square feet. At the moment, the only tenant is the law firm of Olwine, Connelly, Chase, O'Donnell & Wehyer, with 150,000 square feet. "We have three leases out for about 140,000 square feet," Mr. Solomon said. He identified the prospective tenants as a textile, computer and entertainment company.
No. 1585, a 42-story tower between 47th and 48th Streets, has 1.3 million square feet of space. For now, the sole tenant is the law firm of Proskauer, Rose, Goetz & Mendelsohn, which has 426,000 square feet, with an option for an additional 180,000.
"We have another major law firm, with a lease out for final review, for 120,000 square feet," Mr. Solomon said. "With the next deal, we'll be over 50 percent leased, which we like to believe is pretty positive in this market."
He said a 450,000-square-foot lease with an insurance company was "in the formative stages" and that almost all of the retail space on Broadway was in negotiation. Tenants would include a restaurant, a book store and a "high-quality" record store.
"These are very difficult times," he said, "but the quality of what we've got is sending people to look, talk and negotiate."

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Concorde Cuts

 BODY:
Concorde service is being cut because of the war in the Persian Gulf and the economic recession. British Airways has reduced the number of flights by the supersonic airliner between New York and London and Washington and London. In addition, Air France has postponed a plan for additional flights on the Concorde on its New York-Paris route. The British Concorde's daily runs between New York and London were reduced Feb. 7 to one from two and the three weekly Washington flights were suspended. Air France had intended to add a second Concorde flight between New York and Paris four days a week from March to June and from September to December. The airline now hopes to add these flights in September. Air France does not fly the Concorde to Washington.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Inflation In Yugoslavia

BYLINE: By RUTH E. GRUBER

DATELINE: BELGRADE

 BODY:
Despite a big currency devaluation two months ago, prices in Yugoslavia remain considerably higher than they have been in past years.
Indeed, prices of food, clothing and other goods have gone up so much that residents of the Slovenia republic, which borders Italy and Austria, routinely go across the border to shop. 
 While Yugoslavia has been suffering from runaway inflation for several years, it was not apparent to visitors because the currency, the dinar, was constantly being devalued.
Tough economic reform measures instituted a year ago, pegging the dinar to the German mark, have pushed prices up to American and Western European levels. The government tried to counter the inflation two months ago by devaluing the dinar by 28 percent.
While inflation has been slowed, most prices still seem to have at least doubled or tripled, particularly prices paid by tourists. The handknit sweater that cost $50 to $80 a couple of years ago is now more than $200. A simple lunch can easily cost over $10 -- and it costs nearly $5 a minute to direct dial the United States. (Yugoslavia is one of the few countries in Europe that are not plugged into the A.T.&T. or other direct-dial United States phone systems.)
Even more confusing for visitors is the fact that, along with stabilizing the exchange rate, last year's economic reforms also revalued the dinar, slashing four zeroes from the former rate to create new dinars, making 10,000 old dinars worth 1 new dinar.
Today one dollar equals about 13 new dinars, or 130,000 old dinars. And bills in both denominations are still in circulation.

HEADLINE: Shoppers Find Loans With Lettuce

BYLINE: By CAROLYN BATTISTA

 BODY:
MILDRED LAWRENCE had just pushed her shopping cart past the bananas when Jim Beaulieu approached her. "Did you know that we have a bank here?" he asked. "It's open seven days a week."
Mr. Beaulieu is assistant manager at the new branch of Burritt Bank in the Finast supermarket at the Tri-City Plaza in Vernon. The 420-square-foot branch is open daily from 11 A.M. to 7 P.M., and its staff members go out into the supermarket aisles to suggest to shoppers that while they are picking up potatoes, they might also open a checking account. 
 Mrs. Lawrence, who lives in South Windsor, told Mr. Beaulieu, "I might stop for a C.D."
 
Plans for More Branches
 Other banks in Connecticut have provided some services in stores, said David Tedeschi, communications officer for the State Department of Banking, "but Burritt is going about it a little differently" by hiring an outside company to guide it and by offering a wide range of services. .
Burritt, based in New Britain, established the Vernon branch by working with International Banking Technologies, a company from Georgia that has set up such small but aggressive operations in supermarkets around the country. The Vernon branch is the first project in New England for International Banking Technologies, but Burritt already plans to open three other such branches in Connecticut.
Burritt officials said that bank branches in supermarkets are becoming increasingly popular, because they are economical for banks and convenient for customers. But they said such branches must offer more than the limited services, like check cashing, that banks began offering in supermarkets in the 1970's, and they must be promoted, operated and staffed differently from traditional branches.
"When we started," in 1983, "there were fewer than 100 supermarket banks in the country," said John W. Garnett, executive vice president of International Banking Technologies. "Today there are more than 850."
Mr. Garnett said his company set out to "build a better mousetrap," and has now established about 350 bank branches in supermarkets. The concern works with banks and retailers, designs banks to fit the stores and helps banks with marketing, promotion and staff training.
People are used to seeing a bank building, Mr. Garnett said. "When they see such a small facility, you have to talk to them about it. Supermarket bank staffs are small and versatile. Each employee does all the functions. They spend time in the aisles soliciting new business.
"In traditional banks, 95 percent of the people who walk in are customers. In a supermarket, the large majority of people bank somewhere else."
 
A Loan on Sunday?
 A supermarket branch is "a sales platform" for a bank, he said.
Ross C. Fritschler, Burritt's vice president for sales and marketing, said: "If I were opening a free-standing bank in Vernon, I'd market it to the people of Vernon through direct mail, newspapers and radio. But I'm marketing this branch to the customers that Finast already has."
With the aid of International Banking Technologies, Burritt trained its Vernon staff to talk with shoppers, Mr. Fritschler said. "People ask questions like, 'Can I really get a loan on a Sunday?' The answer is, 'Yes, you can,' "
Shoppers are visiting the branch, which is tucked between Finast's pharmacy and customer-service desk.
"People wheel their carts right in," said the branch manager, Linda Michaud. "Last night, we had a cart jam."
Mr. Beaulieu said: "The first week, we opened 29 accounts. And by the second week, I'd say our business doubled."
A few shoppers have arrived confused. One came to complain about the fat content of some meat and another to collect a lottery prize.
"We walked them over to customer service," said Ms. Michaud.
 
'A Great Idea'
 Several people in the aisles said the bank branch will be helpful.
"I shop here a lot," said Mrs. Lawrence. "It's a great idea."
And the store's manager, William Haberern, said he was going to buy a certificate of deposit. "It's very hard for a person like myself to get to a bank," he said.
But Delta Dubuc of Vernon said she did not think she would start banking at the supermarket. "I think a lot of people will go for it," she said. "But my bank is right down the street, and I've gone there for years."
Nor did Arthur Supernor of Tolland expect to bank among the canned goods. "I run a business," he said. "I do a lot of banking, and I wouldn't come down here and fight the parking lot."
Mr. Garnett said International Banking Technologies' research shows that 46 percent of the customers approached by bank personnel in a chain of Virginia supermarkets did sign up for a banking service.
Burritt, which has 12 offices in Connecticut, is scheduled to open a branch in March in the Edwards supermarket in Southington. The bank also plans to put branches in Finast stores that are expected to open next year in West Hartford and Bloomfield. Both Edwards and Finast stores are part of First National Supermarkets, which is based in Windsor Locks and has 64 food stores in New England and New York.

GRAPHIC: Photo: People can wheel their shopping carts right in the Burritt Bank in the Finast supermarket at the Tri-City Plaza in Vernon. The bank branch is open daily from 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. (Steve Miller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Bryn Mawr;
Study of City Problems Has Become Hot Major

DATELINE: BRYN MAWR, Pa.

 BODY:
The Thomas Auditorium is filled on Tuesday and Thursday mornings when the introductory-level course meets for Bryn Mawr College's Growth and Structure of Cities major. Any of the 95 students who arrive late for the class, called "The Form of the City," miss their chance for one of the 90 seats available and must sit in the aisles or on the floor in front.
"This subject is seeing a very strong surge in popularity," said James Wright, the acting head of the cities department. "The number of majors has doubled in the last four years." 
 "The Form of the City" is the second-largest introductory course taught at Bryn Mawr. The introductory biology course has the largest enrollment.
"Most urban programs have experienced rapid increases in recent years," Professor Wright added. "Their directors all ascribe these increases to new concerns among the students that lead them into commitments to careers in social service."
Students and faculty members alike speculate on the reason for the 20-year-old department's recent vogue.
 
 'Cities Have Not Been Repaired'
 "Urban problems really must be solved," said Sophie Lillie, a junior cities major from Austria. Michael Lewis, the lecturer for the introductory course, agrees. "Despite the dearth of jobs and urban renewal, cities have not been repaired," Mr. Lewis said. "In fact, they are worse off than ever if the last census can be believed."
Natasha Seaman, a senior cities major from Elkins, W.Va., who plans to enter the field of social work after graduation, nodded in assent. "It satisfies my social consciousness, and fulfills my desire to understand the more symbolic nature of the physical environment of cities," Ms. Seaman said.
The program is interdisciplinary, but does have a second required course -- "Survey of Western Architecture." Majors must then choose two of four urban-studies courses and must specialize in two of three tracks -- urban history, architecture and planning or social science analyses of the city. Electives come from the departments of anthropology, art history, economics, geology, history, political science and sociology.
"I think it's fine to have a lot of traditional majors, as Bryn Mawr does, but it's vital to have an interdisciplinary option too," said Elizabeth Scott, a senior geology major from Durham, N.C., who has taken many cities courses. "Life is interdisplinary. The more I learn about geology, the more specialized it is. But the more I learn about cities, the more the world opens up."
 
'Important to Be Marketable'
 Ingrid Johnson, a cities minor from Livingston, N.J., noted, too, that "with the tightening job market, it's important to be marketable in many different areas, and being a cities major or minor certainly achieves that aim."
She added, "I want to go into politics, and cities will help me so much in understanding the infrastructure."
"Our majors go all over," Professor Wright said. "Law, historic-preservation, architecture, landscape architecture, business, teaching, architectural history, urban planning and regional science, to name some of the more popular fields. And they come from all over too -- we have more Haverford majors than any other department." Bryn Mawr has an academic exchange program with nearby Haverford College.
The program has also become the focus for students who wish to go on to architecture school, especially because Bryn Mawr's classes in architectural drafting are run under its auspices. "Students now see architecture as the most socially conscious among the professions," Professor Wright said.
But the most compelling reason for the department's success seems to be its vitality.
"Philadelphia is our laboratory," Mr. Lewis said. "The first week, to shake up our students, we send them in and have them walk 30 blocks of the city. Then we send them in to look at open spaces, like the Italian market. This major is all about life."

LENGTH: 924 words

HEADLINE: 2 Grants for Disadvantaged Students

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

 BODY:
TWO Westchester school districts are the first beneficiaries of a $10 million fund from the estate of DeWitt Wallace, the founder of the Reader's Digest in Chappaqua who died 10 years ago.
Over the next three years, more than $600,000 will be available from the new DeWitt Wallace-Reader's Digest Westchester Fund of the Westchester Community Foundation. The money will benefit disadvantaged students in the Peekskill and Mount Vernon school districts. 
 The grants follow an extensive study of county school districts by the White Plains-based Westchester Community Foundation, an affiliate of the New York Community Trust in Manhattan that serves the Westchester community and its donors.
Initial grants from the fund, the largest of its kind in Westchester, will let a Mount Vernon elementary school extend its black cultural heritage program and will permit fourth-, fifth- and sixth-grade students in Peekskill to participate in a wide-ranging cooperative program between a school and the community.
 
Roots and Pride
 In Mount Vernon, children drawn from all six grades at the predominantly black Cecil H. Parker Elementary School participate in a special curriculum that teaches them about their black ancesters and seeks to raise their cultural awareness and pride.
The program, now in its sixth year, has helped students improve their academic performance and their self-image, said the school's principal, Mary D. Spells.
"We had to be a very strong people to survive the institution of slavery," Janette L. Wilson, a first-grade teacher participating in the program, said she has told her classes. "Our people had to have faith and belief in themselves. Today, we need to dig back to those strengths."
As part of that process, students are taught history and learn stories, many of which, Mrs. Wilson said, derive from an oral tradition. "I tell them of the "griot," the official storyteller of the tribe," Mrs. Wilson said. "I tell them, 'Yes, perhaps Africans didn't write books, but they carried on a rich oral tradition.' The fact is there were universities in Timbuktu and an empire in Mali, and even little children can understand that."
 
Principles to Abide By
 Mount Vernon students in the program abide by seven Swahili principles, or nguzosaba, which promote umoja or unity; kujichagulia, or self-determination; ujima, or collective work and responsibility; ujamma, or cooperative economics; nia, or purpose; kuumba, or creativity, and imani, or faith.
Among other benefits, children in the program have begun to "see their future in a sound way," Mrs. Wilson said, and learn to share "without the natural competitiveness you expect.
With the help of the Wallace grant, which provides $125,000 for each of three years, the program, now focussed on 150 students considered to be "at risk," is being expanded to reach more of the school's 623 students.
 
Adopting a Peekskill Class
 In Peekskill, a districtwide program to enhance school and community relations has a variety of components, from an "Adopt-a-Class" plan for local businesses, to an "Adopt-a-Spot" unit in which students elect to adopt a street, a building or an area of the city to care for.
"The community wanted to be more involved in the schools, and the schools wanted to be more involved in the community," said Peekskill's Superintendent of Schools, Salvatore J. Corda. "It's a collaborative effort, and it's neat." The Wallace fund has provided $78,000 to the school district for each of three years.
One group of fifth graders is conducting research on a historic cannon in the city and running the city's maintenance program for it, including planting flowers.
"History often takes place in a vacuum," Mr. Corda said. "Here, kids are learning about a local cannon that two men, one black, one white, lugged across the hills to the Hudson." The cannon, Mr. Corda said, "prevented a British warship from picking up Major Andre -- so West Point was saved, Andre was captured and Benedict Arnold was picked up."
 
How a Business Works
 In another project, the Paramount Theater in Peekskill has adopted one sixth-grade class, involving the students in producing shows. Students act as ushers, count receipts and assist actors and staff members.
"They are seeing how a business really works," Mr. Corda said. "To tell kids to stay in school so they can get a better job is remote. This way, we are showing them that to run a business, you must know how to count money, and you must watch your receipts."
The DeWitt Wallace-Reader's Digest Westchester Fund identified the two districts with the help of the Westchester Community Foundation, which studied the needs of school districts in the county. Once a group of districts had been selected, each was asked to submit a proposal and two were selected.
 
Grants to Teachers Set
 The fund will also award $500 grants to individual teachers in the two districts to underwrite classroom or schoolwide projects of their own design.
An award of $25,000 has been granted to the Westchester Education Coaltion to enhance collaboration between cooperating public schools and local college faculty members, with a particular emphasis on providing better learning experiences for student teachers.
The designation of a special fund for Westchester, said Christine DeVita, president of the Dewitt Wallace-Reader's Digest Fund, reflects her organization's determination to earmark a certain amount of money for the local area as national priorities are developed.

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

BYLINE: By Eleanor Charles

 BODY:

 
COLLECTING FLIES
 A new entry in the world of collectibles is the fishing fly. Compleat anglers as well as people who never go near the water are indulging a passion for acquiring these sprightly little objects, says to Alan Liu, author of "The American Sporting Collector's Handbook," published in 1976 by Winchester Press and revised in 1981. He will give a free talk on the subject Tuesday at 7:30 P.M. at the Fox Lane Middle School, on Route 172 in Mount Kisco.
 "There was no market for this three or four years ago," said Mr. Liu, who suggested one reason for the surge in popularity was that fishing flies were relatively cheap. Prices range from $25 to $250 at the entry level to collecting; as one approaches connoisseurship, prices reach $750 to $1,000.
 For the last few years there have been sufficient devotees to inspire an annual dinner and show at the Rye Town Hilton each March, sponsored by the Theodore Gordon Fly Fishers, a nonprofit environmental organization based in Manhattan. Mr. Liu regards Theodore Gordon as the father of American fly-fishing. "When he died 50 years ago, his flies were saved by friends -- keepers of the flame," Mr. Liu said. "He was a bachelor with no family to carry on the tradition."
 Gordon flies represent the upscale side of collecting, selling for as much as $10,000. While some vintage flies are in the used category, most have never been sullied by a trout's innards.
 Determining the authenticity of a Gordon fly is done by the signature, said Mr. Liu, "like recognizing the brush strokes and colors of a painting." Quality of materials, the angle of the feathers, the hooks -- all identify the maker, many of whom are women attracted to fly-tying as an art.
 Antique flies can be spotted by hooks that are no longer made, or by feathers from rare birds, which are available only on a black market. "Indian crow, toucan, bustard and heron feathers were used during the golden age of fly-tying in Victorian England but they are illegal now," said Mr. Liu.
 His talk will be part of the monthly meeting of the Croton Watershed Chapter of Trout Unlimited, a conservation organization. Call 666-5727 for more information.
 
A STONY POINT ARTIST
 Page Simon, a Stony Point artist whose work goes on display today at the Hopper House Art Center in Nyack, comes from a talented family, but she is its only visual artist. (Her cousins, Carly, Lucy and Joanna Simon, have achieved fame in the music world while her father, Henry Simon, was the book editor of the PM newspaper.)
 The major portion of this exhibition is devoted to Ms. Simon's semi-abstractions of natural and figurative forms. The brightly colored pencil drawings on highly textured paper are sometimes embellished with watercolors. Another group features color studies of the female nude, and a third section is composed of computer-generated images, a field in which Ms. Simon has worked and taught for several years.
 The gallery, at 82 North Broadway, is open weekends from 1 to 5 P.M. A public reception will be held for the artist from 1 to 5 P.M. today. Admission is by donation of $1. Call 358-0774 for more information.
 
CREDIBLE EDIBLES
 Leftover carrot tops, ginger roots and avocado seeds are the components of a "Garbage Gardening" workshop for five- and six-year-olds at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx on Saturday.
 From 10 A.M. to noon the children will learn how to propogate humble kitchen scraps into credible edibles, by planting them in little greenhouses made of cardboard, plastic and florist's wire. The children will take their miniature gardens home to nurture into maturity, along with appropriate instructions.
 A second workshop, for children 7 to 10 years old, will be held on March 9 from 10 A.M. to noon. Children meet in the Greenschool of the Enid A. Haupt Conservatory. The fee for either session is $12, and reservations must be made by calling 212-220-8982.
 
A NEW AGENDA
 Richard N. Gardner, a former United States Ambassador to Italy, professor of international law at Columbia University and co-chairman of the Aspen Institute project on "The U.S. and the World Economy," will be the speaker at a meeting of the Forum for World Affairs on Tuesday. His topic is "A New Agenda for Soviet-American Cooperation: Political and Economic Dimensions."
The event is being held at the Texaco offices in White Plains, at 2000 Westchester Avenue. A reception begins at 6:15 P.M., with the speech and open discussion at 7 P.M. A $10 admission fee includes snacks and dessert. Call 203-356-0340 for reservations.
 
HALL'S TRIO AT CAFE
 John Hall, a singer, songwriter and guitarist who was recently elected to the Ulster County Legislature, will appear with his trio at the Towne Crier Cafe in Pawling on Friday at 9 P.M.
 In the last 15 fifteen years, Mr. Hall has recorded 11 albums featuring his own songs with lyrics written by his wife, Joanna. He has toured the country with a variety of artists, including Jackson Browne, Bonnie Raitt, the Silver Bullet Band and Taj Mahal.
 Accompanying his performance on accoustic guitar, keyboard and synthesizer will be Rob Leon on bass and Peter O'Brien on drums. The cafe is located at on Route 22 and admission is $15. Call 855-1300 for reservations or more information.
 
A GREBU RETROSPECTIVE
 Once seen, the paintings of Devis Grebu are not easily forgotten. The Romanian native, who is now a county resident, has perfected his formula of scattering comic, folksy images across a surreal world, while making a rational statement about a particular issue affecting the planet. The viewer looks, then looks again with expanding curiosity into the context, the technique and the impishness of the artist.
In 1989, Rizzoli published an elegant collection of his cartoons, paintings and illustrations, "Devis Grebu: Through an Artist's Eye" ($37.50). Now a retrospective exhibition of Mr. Grebu's output can be seen at the White Plains Library Gallery, at 100 Martine Avenue, through March 3. Gallery hours are Monday through Thursday from 9 A.M. to 9 P.M.; Friday from 9 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Saturday from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. and Sunday from 1 to 5 P.M.
 
SEE THE WOODPECKERS
 A tour of the "Woodpeckers of Westchester" exhibition, plus a walk along the Greenburgh Nature Center trails to view woodpeckers in the wild, begins at 10 A.M. on Saturday. The center is located on Dromore Road off Central Avenue.
 The exhibition consists of dioramas, charts, maps, graphics and live birds and will remain on display through April 21. It focuses on the woodpecker's unique abilities as a carpenter and its diet of insects, which serves as a protection for trees, houses and the occasional picnic. A number of sub-species are highlighted: the flickers, pileateds, sap-suckers, downy, red-headed and red-bellied, for example.
 An exhibition of related paintings, prints and photographs is also on view. Admission is $2. Call 723-3470 for more information.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIARY/February 10-15

 BODY:

 
THE ECONOMY

 
Washington and London, at Odds in the Air
 
All's fair in love, war and international airline negotiations. Disputes over airline rights can divide even friends as close as Britain and the United States. Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner rejected British Airways' proposed fare cuts to the United States last Tuesday. Britain had blocked the sale by Pan Am and Trans World Airlines, both desperate for cash, of several London routes to Heathrow airport that United and American Airlines want to buy. Sir Colin Marshall, chief executive of British Airways, flew into New York himself last week to display solicitude for the ailing airlines. The dispute is "not about knocking Pan Am or T.W.A. out of business altogether," he said. He also urged timid Americans to resume traveling abroad; those who don't risk losing business, he said. What British Airways actually seeks are broader operating rights in the United States, said American analysts. Problem is, that sort of deal might normally take a year to work out; T.W.A. and Pan Am need agreements within a few months.

Oddball Salary Inequities
 
When Babe Ruth was asked, about 60 years ago, why he deserved $80,000 when President Hoover only made $75,000, Ruth's legendary response was, "I had a better year than he did." A week ago, Roger Clemens signed a four-year contract giving him a record average of $5.4 million a year; President Bush draws $200,000. Clemens won 21 games, holding opponents to an average of less than two runs a game. George Bush showed quick reflexes in the Persian Gulf but bobbled the tax issue. So Clemens did have the better year. But 27 times better? Enough so that the cost of a single Clemens victory more than covers Bush's salary for an entire season? And the President certainly outplayed, say, Jeff Parrett, the Atlanta Braves pitcher, who recently settled for $855,000 after winning five, losing 10. Memo to team owners wanting to economize: draft George, the former Yale baseball captain, when his Washington contract is up.
 
Alcohol-Fed Inflation
 
Economists have found another fuel to blame for increasing wholesale inflation. A record 5.9 percent jump in alcohol prices raised the core inflation rate in January by five-tenths of 1 percent. Higher alcohol taxes do not figure into producer prices, but many manufacturers took the chance to raise their own prices. Some economists said that, even after accounting for liquor costs, the rising core rate would keep the Federal Reserve from easing further. "The Fed will rest on its oars for at least a couple more weeks," said Irwin L. Kellner of Manufacturers Hanover Trust. The broader inflation rate, including food and energy, fell one-tenth of 1 percent, as oil prices declined.
 
Golden Arch of Catfish?
 
McDonald's believes it has found a recipe for Southern success: The Crispy Catfish Sandwich, a 2.3-ounce patty with lettuce and tangy sauce on a bun. McDonald's plans to sell it at 214 outlets in Alabama, Arkansas, Mississippi, Kentucky and Tennessee. Restaurants that specialize in catfish are hardly trembling. Don Buckner, general manager of Hall's on the River in Winchester, Ky., described McDonald's seafood sandwiches as "block pieces of fish" -- suitable for someone who would otherwise have a quarter-pounder. His $9.95 all-you-can-eat catfish dinner includes vegetables and hush puppies, he added. No hush puppies at McDonald's, said a spokeswoman, convinced that Southern customers will accept french fries.
 
Competition for Cellular Lines
 
All that static on the cellular phone lines is coming from aggrieved duopolists. The Federal Communications Commission decided on Wednesday to allow a new form of mobile service in six cities, including New York. Radio dispatch companies for taxis and delivery services will be able to squeeze thousands of other customers into their narrow slices of the radio spectrum. Cellular services that have flourished under rules allowing only two in each city could find competition heating up. Analysts doubt the new service, to be offered initially by Fleet Call Inc. of Bloomfield, N.J., will match cellular's flexibility and features. But the cellular industry called the decision unfair and threatened a fight.
 
Production Declines Ease
 
The slump in industrial output continued for a fourth month in January, but the decline was a moderate four-tenths of 1 percent after much steeper drops in the two previous months. Some economists said the report hints that the worst of the recession is past. But industries used only 79.9 percent of their capacity, the least in four years.
 
In Brief
 
A seven-tenths of 1 percent decline in already lean business inventories in December gave economists hope that any increase in demand would result in higher production.
 
Citibank, long aloof and superior, has decided to join the automated teller machine masses. Its machines will become part of the Cirrus network, sharing access with machines from 7,200 other banks and financial institutions.
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
George Ball Steps Down
 
When the big boys on Wall Street are suffering, a guy who tried to play with them but failed is truly in trouble. George L. Ball resigned as chairman and chief executive of Prudential-Bach Securities last Wednesday, felled by his loss of $308 million in less than nine years as the firm's chairman and chief executive. Mr. Ball tried to transform a humdrum brokerage firm into a glamorous, global investment bank, throwing around millions to hire star financiers. When the Prudential Insurance Company of America lost patience with his prodigal ways, he responded with what he called a "light cruiser" strategy, fighting only those competitive battles that he believed the firm could win. The losses continued, however, and Mr. Ball finally gave up his command.
 
Carter Hawley Hale Goes Under
 
The real markdowns at Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. last week were on "junk bonds" and common stock; the largest department store chain on the West Coast, parent of the Broadway, Weinstocks and Emporium names, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The Carter Hawley Hale story was another 1980's tale of efficient wealth transfer from bondholders, long-term investors and employees -- whose 45 percent stake in the company is now nearly worthless -- to lawyers, investment bankers and the usual short-term profiteers. In its efforts to fight off a takeover attempt led by the Limited Inc. chain in 1987, Carter Hawley Hale had taken on hundreds of millions of dollars in debt. Little was left, therefore, to improve the stores. Competition and a slack American economy did the rest.
 
Auto Makers in Decline
 
The Ford Motor Company has cut back, streamlined production and improved efficiency enough to almost rival the Japanese. But its fourth-quarter loss of $519 million confounded its mission to keep profits flowing even when a recession strikes. The General Motors Corporation lost $1.62 billion, giving the industry its second-worst quarter ever. Analysts were understanding, saying that auto companies can face no worse combination than a recession and higher energy prices. As James P. Womack, an auto industry authority at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said, "You can't take a 25 percent hit on volume and make much money in any business."
 
In Brief
 
A Federal bankruptcy judge approved the sale of 67 Eastern Airlines takeoff and landing slots and five gates at Washington National Airport to Northwest Airlines for $35.5 million. The Justice Department blocked a bid by United Airlines for antitrust reasons.
 
U S West Inc. agreed to pay $10 million, the largest antitrust fine ever, for violating the agreement that broke up the Bell System.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Germany's High-Cost East
 
One weekend last fall, a carnival on East Berlin's Alexanderplatz was so dreary that visitors had to ask to make sure it was taking place. On the Kurfurstendamm in West Berlin, meanwhile, every evening brought out raucous crowds lingering well past midnight. German officials said last Tuesday that giving eastern Germany much to celebrate will prove far more costly than they had thought. With a turnaround nowhere in sight, the Government approved $3 billion in emergency aid for cities and states. Economists say that rebuilding the eastern regions will cost the Government nearly $100 billion this year, more than $1 trillion over the decade. Traditional Eastern European export markets have evaporated, factories are closing and residents are leaving for the West. Germany's bind might well pinch relations with the United States. The cost of aiding the easterners makes Germans more reluctant to lower interest rates in support of the dollar or finance the war in the Middle East.
 
Trouble With the Trade Deficit
 
The trade deficit is heading in the right direction for the wrong reasons. The gap shrank to $6.3 billion in December, better than most economists had expected. Imports fell 7.9 percent, as the recession curbed America's appetite for foreign goods. But exports slipped also, by 2.1 percent, auguring ill for one of the economy's few healthy areas. "We can't count on that sector as much in the months ahead," said David M. Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company. As foreign economies slow, not even a weaker dollar is sufficient to stoke overseas demand.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
America's Recovery Takes the Lead

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
Markets around the world rallied last week, but the roar was loudest in the United States. The Standard & Poor's 500 index hit a record high and the Dow Jones industrial average finally recouped all that it lost after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in August.
Though the European, Japanese and other markets in the Far East rose, most of them are still lagging far behind America's recovery. One explanation is simple. Wall Street did not fall nearly as far as other markets after the invasion of Kuwait. 
 More important, however, in the opinion of many analysts, this divergence reflects the different individual economic cycles that now mark the global economy. The big recoveries have been in countries that are in the midst of recessions, like the United States, Great Britain and Canada. In these countries, the onset of recession brought down interest rates and fostered hopes of further rate declines and a quick economic recovery. This has made their markets very attractive.
On Wall Street, for example, the S.&P. 500 is now 14.54 points, or 3.8 percent, above its pre-crisis Aug. 1 level. The Dow is 1.2 percent over Aug. 1. In London, the Financial Times Stock Exchange Index is up 7.2 percent for the year and is just 1.8 percent below its Aug. 1 level of 2,339. In Toronto, the stock exchange's composite index has jumped 7.7 percent in 1991, most of that rise coming this month. The index is now just 1.8 percent below its Aug. 1 level of 3,569.15.
The markets where the Persian Gulf losses have not been regained are in Continental Europe and Japan. In Germany, the DAX Index of 30 shares is up 9.5 for the year. It jumped 3 percent Friday after the Iraqi announcement of a willingness to withdraw from Kuwait based on conditions that the United States rejected a few hours later. But the stock market index is still 19.1 percent below its Aug. 1 level of 1892.89.
In France, the CAC-40 index of blue-chip stocks is still 14.8 percent from its pre-crisis level. Spain's market is down 12.9 percent. In Italy, the Banca Commerciale index is still 23.3 percent under Aug. 1. And the Nikkei 225 index in Tokyo is still 17.8 percent from its pre-crisis level.
Although optimistic analysts are now talking about the coming economic recoveries in the United States, Britain and Canada, in Continental Europe, excluding Germany, they speak of being at the beginning of the downward side of the economic cycle. This could eventually mean recession, a situation that usually is a drag on their markets.
While the European slowdowns are accelerating -- France could be on the brink of a recession right now -- recessions have not yet taken hold. This means interest rates are not falling quickly. And the recent hike in interest rates by Germany has made it harder for France and other countries to lower rates to stimulate their economies and perhaps extend the market rallies.
Germany, however, is a special case.
Although German business confidence has held steady and the German economy is the strongest by far in Europe, its high interest rates make its equity market less attractive. The uncertainty about the rising cost of the unification of Germany is also adding risk to investment there.
In Japan, interest rates remain high, keeping some investors on the sidelines. But there are signs that the economy is slowing, and analysts expect that interest rates will begin to decline soon, boosting the market.
In Europe, the earnings of many of the companies that dominate the stock markets are very sensitive to the level of interest rates and the health of the economy. About 60 percent of the capitalization in Continental markets is in manufacturing companies. Of this, about two-thirds is in highly cyclical areas like automobiles, according to Michael Howell of Salomon Brothers in London.
The long fall of the dollar has devastated business for European exporters and crunched the earnings of companies with operations in the United States. "The United States," said Mr. Howell "is exporting its recession to Europe."
"I think there is more bad news to come," said Paul Feldman of Goldman Sachs & Company in London. He said he expects a round of "awful" earnings reports.
Such views are helping to hold down the European markets.
Another difference in the two rallies is the performance of cyclical stocks, like construction companies. In the American and the British markets, these stocks have matched or outperformed the market as a whole in several instances in the last two weeks. This buying reflects the feeling that interest rates are coming down and that the recession will end soon, making the companies' stocks a good buy.
But in Germany and France, the cyclical stocks have not performed as well during the same rally, according to the Financial Times index of world markets. Automobile stocks have underperformed the market significantly in Germany, France, Italy and Spain. Construction and machinery stocks have also lagged in Germany.
Then there's France. Cyclical stocks there outperformed the market over the last two weeks. This could reflect a belief that French interest rates will come down soon and that the French cyclical stocks are becoming a good buy, just like in the United States.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Foreshadowing A Short Recession

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
The stock market's reputation as an economic seer looks like it is about to get another boost. The American recession, which seemed so fierce only a couple of months ago, now seems to have eased as the new year began.
It now appears likely that the last few months of 1990 were the worst of the downturn, and that the economy could start growing as soon as the second quarter of this year. 
 Last week, hopes for both peace and prosperity propelled the Standard & Poor's 500 to a record high. The Dow Jones industrial average moved up 103.96 points, to 2,934.65, and is 65.10 points from its own record, set on July 16.
For the world economy, an American upturn would be a very welcome thing. The outlook for the British recession is not nearly so rosy, in part because British policy makers are caught in a bind between trying to protect the pound and pulling out all the stops to revive their economy. And there are signs of economic softness in Japan and Germany, the other big engines of world growth. By letting the dollar fall, the Fed has exported some of the American weakness.
If this recession is to end in short order, it will be a tribute to the power of a unified expansionary policy in Washington. The war is serving as an economic stimulus, and that will be especially true if most of the costs wind up being paid by others, as the Bush Administration has promised. The Federal Reserve, and bank regulators, are also doing all they can to ease credit and get business moving again.
The retail sales figures last week provided the first solid evidence that things did start to pick up a bit in January. Over all, they were down 0.9 percent. But they were flat without autos, and up a bit if both autos and gasoline were excluded.
The auto makers, almost drowning in red ink, have responded to their problems by cutting production more than prices, hoping to make decent profits on the cars they can sell. That strategy may be more widespread than previously appreciated, and could help to explain the report that producer prices, excluding food and energy, rose a surprising 0.5 percent in January. It also could slow any increase in consumer spending.
While there now are good reasons to think the recession is nearing an end, there is another case to be made. The best that can be said for January's industrial production figures, for example, is that the decline was smaller than in previous months.
And, even accepting that the recession is nearing an end, it is possible to fear that stock prices have risen too far on hopes for peace, just as they fell too far on fears of war before mid-January. Since Jan. 16, the Dow is up 17 percent, and it is rare for runs like that to continue unless they start with the market sharply undervalued.
This run did not, and while falling interest rates have improved valuations, Richard Bernstein of Merrill Lynch estimates that Treasury bond rates would have to fall to about 7.4 percent, from close to 8 percent now, to justify these prices.
