HEADLINE: Managing;
A Matter of Supplier-Customer Trust

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
Sherwin-Williams Inc., the big paint company, recently let executives from Sears, Roebuck Inc. help select the people who would service the Sears account. "We and Sears already had joint sales and product-turnover goals, so it made sense to jointly select the people who can make those goals happen," said T. Scott King, a vice president of sales for Sherwin-Williams.
The Digital Equipment Corporation often helps its smaller customers put together corporate image programs in their communities. "They are buying our product, so anything we do to help them be successful makes sense," said Joseph D. Codispoti, Digital's media relations manager. 
 The Xerox Corporation and the General Electric Company, which buy from each other all the time, now send people to each other's in-house training sessions, too. "To really focus on customers' needs, you must understand more about them than how they use your product," said Wayland R. Hicks, Xerox's executive vice president for marketing and customer operations.
Throughout the 1980's, customer partnerships were defined solely in terms of products. But by working together on technologies and processes, many suppliers and customers came to trust each other enough to share schematics for products, sales forecasts and other information once considered proprietary. And many discovered that discrepancies in the ways they handled invoicing and deliveries -- far more than product constraints -- prevented them from doing even more joint business, such as dealing with each other overseas.
As a result, companies are now broadening their definitions of customer partnerships to include office procedures, training, even hiring. "If you assume the goal of staffing, training or any other internal process is to better respond to customer needs, then it makes sense to help the customer participate in those processes," said David Ulrich, professor of executive education at the University of Michigan's School of Business, who has written extensively on the subject.
That may be so, but corporate executives have been slow to act on the concept. "Only lately have we shifted our emphasis from transactions to relationships," said James P. Baughman, G.E.'s manager of corporate management development. "That means feeling that we and the customer are part of one system, not two."
G.E. is striving hard to reach that utopia. Over the last six months, several G.E. divisions have invited customer teams to join sessions of Workout, a training program that G.E. developed to decrease internal red tape. Those sessions enabled one G.E. division to shave more than a week off delivery times by letting major customers enter their own orders into G.E.'s data system. Another division eliminated about six monthly reports to a customer when, in Workout sessions, the customer admitted to throwing them away. Yet another is now working with customers to find the point at which their need for quick access to spare parts intersects with G.E.'s need to reduce inventory costs.
Xerox, too, has been using a team approach -- albeit a less formal one -- to smooth its interactions with major customers. For example, its executives have been meeting with executives from the Bechtel Corporation with an eye toward better understanding Bechtel's ordering and accounting systems. One result: Xerox has stopped sending Bechtel paper invoices for each order, conforming to Bechtel's preferred method of being billed electronically, once a month. "Sometimes, going after small irritants in systems is as important to meeting a customer's needs as major design changes in products," said Mr. Hicks.
Of course, no supplier gives customers a guarantee that every "small irritant" will be abolished. But customers report that being asked for their input has value in itself.
R. Gene Richter, executive director of corporate procurement for the Hewlett-Packard Company, says his suppliers often ask him to recommend people whom they might hire to manage the Hewlett-Packard account. None has let him participate in the hiring decision and only about 25 percent of the people he recommended got hired. But the suppliers invariably explain why talks with the other three-quarters did not work out. "I realize my advice is taken seriously," Mr. Richter said. "And that alone makes me feel warmer to the person they do hire."
 
 
BUILDING PARTNERSHIPS, STEP BY STEP
 Collaborations between customers and suppliers are not always directly tied to business systems. Sometimes, they just involve sharing expertise.
Xerox, which won the Malcolm Baldrige corporate quality award in 1989, has sent its people to help several customers install quality assurance processes. The question of Xerox products rarely comes up.
"A corporate president who invites you to talk to his management team will continue to think of you as a partner, not just another vendor," explained Wayland R. Hicks, Xerox's executive vice president for marketing and customer operations. "And not only that -- our customers might provide us with a way to reach their customers."
Similarly, Frank M. J. LaFasto, the Baxter Healthcare Corporation's vice president of human resource planning and development, holds team-building sessions for some hospitals that buy Baxter's products.
"Hospitals are dealing with all kinds of cost constraints and economic challenges," said Mr. LaFasto, co-author of a book on teamwork. "Helping them manage their businesses more effectively gives us a better sense of security about our own business."

HEADLINE: Last Thing Democrats Need Is to Change Nominating Process

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As we head into the 1992 Presidential campaign, the Democratic Party is facing an uphill fight. If George Bush's war in the Persian Gulf goes smoothly, he will have lots of the momentum he calls "big mo." 
 In this situation, the last thing the Democratic Party needs is to get bogged down in reforming the nominating process, as Tom Wicker proposes in "Why Democrats Lose" (column, Feb. 6). While that process is certainly convoluted, it is not haphazard. In the end, the candidate who has emerged from the primaries as the Democratic nominee has been the strongest, most representative and electable candidate in the field -- with two exceptions, neither of which was under our control.
In 1968 Robert F. Kennedy won the California primary and was on his way to the nomination -- when he was murdered. In 1972, Edmund Muskie appeared to have the nomination in hand -- until he was destroyed by Richard Nixon's "dirty tricks."
We can't prevent assassinations or crimes. All we can do is put our would-be candidates through the test of a national primary campaign. This test weeds out candidates who are too narrow in their geographical (or ideological) appeal or who have fatal character flaws. Given the intense personal scrutiny associated with recent campaigns, this test of character is essential.
Of course, the primary test has become a marathon, as Michael S. Dukakis properly called it. And there may be a few outstanding candidates who are deterred by the excessive agonies of this marathon. But looking ahead to 1992, no one is going to beat George Bush by making televised speeches from a Senate office or a governor's mansion.
Our candidate will have to campaign in all 50 states, making the case that Mr. Bush is neglecting America's deep economic and social problems while he dreams about a new world order abroad.
In 1992 -- perhaps more than ever before -- a successful spring primary campaign will be essential to a successful fall general election.
The open primary system produced Ronald Reagan and George Bush on the Republican side. There is no reason to believe it cannot produce a strong Democratic candidate, now and in the future. Let's concentrate on the candidates and on the issues, not on the distraction of nomination reform.
 
ROBERT FERTIK
White Plains, Feb. 7, 1991

HEADLINE: Social Security Tax Policy: A Democratic Issue for '92?

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16

 BODY:
Democratic Congressional leaders are considering a new political offensive based on a proposal to cut the Social Security taxes of most workers by a small amount while increasing the payroll taxes of high-salaried workers.
The proposal is not likely to become law, since it faces an almost certain Presidential veto and is even opposed by some influential Democrats. But it could be the focus of the political debate over domestic policy in the next two years, allowing the Democrats to revive what party leaders see as the most effective weapon in their political arsenal: the argument that they are the benefactors of ordinary Americans, while President Bush, with his support of a cut in the capital gains tax, is the patron of the wealthy. 
 One Democratic strategist said: "The President wants to reduce taxes on investment income by wealthy people, and Democrats want to reduce taxes on earned income by working people. How's that for a slogan going into 1992?"
The proponents of the Social Security plan, a reworked version of the one offered late in 1989 by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, said it would make the tax system fairer and cost the Government no revenue. Opponents said it would turn the Social Security system more into a welfare program rather than the retirement insurance program it was meant to be.
 
Opposition From Chairmen
 Despite the interest of the Democratic leaders in Congress, the tactic faces a large and possibly insurmountable obstacle: opposition from the Democratic chairmen of the tax-writing committees, Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas and Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois. Unless these chairmen can be brought around, the issue may never get a full airing.
Democratic leaders also maintain that the Robin Hood approach of taking money from the well-to-do and giving a tax break to the less affluent would be good for the economy during a recession. Lower-income workers would be more likely to spend the money and give the economy a lift, proponents maintain.
But Mr. Bentsen, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, and Mr. Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, could squelch the party leaders' plans. Social Security legislation must pass through their committees, and they have the ability to block consideration of measures they oppose.
Senator Bentsen said he thought the proposals being worked on by the leaders "would endanger the Social Security system." They would further stretch the relationship between the amount of taxes workers paid and the size of benefits they received on retirement, and thus "make it more into a welfare system," he said.
 
A 'Six Pack' Tax Cut
 A spokesman for Mr. Rostenkowski said the Congressman was wary of "tinkering" with Social Security, fearing that once the matter was raised steps might be taken that were politically attractive but bad policy. "He thinks it's not worth it just to give people a tax cut that's worth what, a six pack a week?" the assistant said.
With Congress in recess and most lawmakers out of town this week, top staff members worked on a variety of Social Security options.
Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, said in a telephone interview that he intended to press the idea of reducing Social Security taxes for most workers but had not settled on a specific plan. "I definitely favor the concept," he said.
Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, is said to be pushing the idea behind the scenes. And the Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley of Washington, has indicated that he could support a plan if it did not cost the Government money.
The Bush Administration adamantly opposes what the President has repeatedly called "messing with Social Security." Many Republicans in Congress favor lowering the Social Security tax rate, but few if any support raising the amount that high-income workers pay.
 
The Tax This Year
 This year, workers and their employers will each pay a Social Security tax of 6.2 percent of their wages up to $53,400. They will also pay a Medicare tax of 1.45 percent on wages up to $125,000. No payroll tax will be paid on wages above the cutoffs.
One plan being considered would abolish the wage ceilings altogether and use the revenue from the additional taxes to lower the Social Security tax rate by about three-fourths of a percentage point. The effect would be to cut the taxes of about 95 percent of all workers, those with wages below $53,400 a year, by about $7.50 for each $1,000 earned. A person with a salary of $40,000 would get a tax cut of $300.
But workers with higher wages, and their employers, would each pay an additional $62 in taxes for every $1,000 earned above $53,400 a year and $76.50 for each $1,000 earned above $125,000. Someone with an annual salary of $200,000 would pay $10,176 more in payroll taxes than under the current law.
Another plan under consideration would raise the Social Security wage cap to the same level as the Medicare tax, $125,000. The money raised would allow the payroll tax rate to be reduced by about half a percentage point and would save the worker with a $40,000 salary about $200 a year in taxes.
 
Support for Moynihan Plan
 The groundwork for the strategy of pursuing a lower Social Security tax for most workers was prepared last year. The Democratic leaders felt they gained substantial advantage during the budget talks by attacking proposals for a capital gains tax and placing Mr. Bush on the side of the wealthy.
At the same time, a plan to lower the Social Security tax rate offered by Senator Moynihan gained surprising support. The Moynihan plan, which would not have raised the wage ceiling to compensate for the reduced tax rate, was opposed by leaders of both parties in the Senate, mainly on the ground that it would have cost the Government as much as $50 billion in lost revenue. But under a procedure requiring 60 votes for passage, the plan fell only 6 votes short, losing by 54 to 44.
Senator Moynihan said he hoped to join forces with the Democratic leaders this year. "This is our issue, and we're going to take it to '92," he said in an interview.

HEADLINE: In Crowded Japan, a Bonus For Babies Angers Women

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 16

 BODY:
With its crowded roads, overstuffed commuter trains and cramped housing, Japan would hardly seem to be in need of more people. So when the Government recently started telling the Japanese to bear more children, many people, especially women, became incensed.
The focus of their irritation was a soon-to-be-offered "reward" of 5,000 yen, or $38, a month for each child of pre-school age, and twice as much for a third child, the centerpiece of a spreading campaign to combat a birth rate that has plummeted to its lowest level in history.
 
'Trying to Be Equal'
 The baby bonuses were inspired by officials concerned that at the current rate, Japan's population will decline after the turn of the century, causing labor shortages, sluggish economic growth and higher tax burdens to support social services for the elderly. 
 Countering their view are feminists and family-planning experts who find it absurd to be concerned about underpopulation. "I don't understand why the Government is worried," said Shizue Kato, the 93-year-old head of the Japan Family Planning Association.
She added: "In my view, we should tell the women of Japan they are wonderful women, they have reduced the birth rate so rapidly. After all, they are only trying to be equal with the men of this country."
Indeed, women generally see the Government's population drive as a test of their freedom. Typical is Rie Fujinishi, a 29-year-old homemaker who struggles full time with housework and the care of a 3-year-old son, and is envious of her friends who work, go out to lunch or vacation in Hawaii.
"I really have to laugh," Mrs. Fujinishi said of the new baby bonuses. "The Government's thinking is so simplistic. They figure if they pay a little money, the mother will have another baby, just like a machine. I won't be influenced by it. My freedom is more important than 5,000 yen."
 
The Long Work Day
 Many experts are troubled by the reasons cited by Japanese women who decide to postpone marriage or have only one or two children, if they have any at all. Many Japanese women say they are in effect revolting against a system stacked against them.
They complain about the high cost of education, the lack of day care, the scarcity of decent or affordable housing and the physical and emotional burdens of raising children when their husbands work from early morning until they stagger home on the last subway train toward midnight.
"It's not a militant thing, but we're seeing a kind of 'women's revenge' in this country," said Shigemi Kono, director general of the Institute of Population Problems at the Health and Welfare Ministry. "Women are showing their disenchantment with what marriage in Japan has become."
Declining birth rates are a feature of all modern industrial societies, including other rapidly developing nations in Asia where work opportunities are opening up for women and social security systems are taking the place of children caring for their aging parents.
But no other country in the world has experienced the steady and rapid drop in birth rates that Japan has seen over the last two decades. In 1989, the fertility rate, or the average number of children a woman is expected to bear, fell to 1.57, and Mr. Kono said it is expected to drop still further.
 
Late Marriages
 The causes of the drop in the birth rate, not to mention the debate and concerns it has provoked, offer a lesson in how increasing wealth has not brought increasing happiness among the Japanese.
Today two-thirds of the men and a third of the women do not marry until their 30's. Only in Sweden do people marry later, but unlike Sweden and other places, Japan is a country where unmarried couples almost never live together.
Women say they are more interested in careers, education and the attractions of a single life style. They complain about living in tiny apartments, about the drudgery of marriage to demanding husbands who do not help at home, and about the near impossibility of mixing work and motherhood.
"Sometimes I admit I'm very lonely," said Kay Suzuki, a 32-year-old unmarried office worker. "But I just can't imagine quitting my job. My boyfriend finally gave up trying to get me to marry him. He was a typical Japanese man. He didn't want a partner, he wanted me to be his mother."
Every expert has an opinion, it seems, about why the trend is occurring. One scholar recently suggested that sports, video games and other diversions were robbing men of their libido. Others bemoan the absence of places for men and women to meet and go off together.
 
A Throne Goes Begging?
 Humorists note that even so eligible a bachelor as Crown Prince Naruhito, the 31-year-old son of the Emperor of Japan, is having trouble finding a bride -- and future empress -- because few women of high social standing are willing to surrender their freedom to the imperial family.
The plummeting birth rate is cited darkly by ultranationalists, who speak of sapping Japan's "ethnic vitality." One publication warned in all seriousness last year that at the current rate, Japan's population would decline to 45,000 by the year 3000. The population now is more than 123 million.
The Government warns more persuasively of a shrinking tax base and skyrocketing demands for government services, especially for the elderly. But officials fear that promoting births would remind people of the coercive 1930's campaign to "breed and multiply" for the good of the Japanese empire.
"It's a difficult problem that threatens the future of our social welfare system," said Saburo Toida, chairman of a Parliamentary committee on the low birth rate last year. "Of course, we can't tell people to 'breed and multiply,' but we can make a better environment for people to have children."
 
Extension of Day Care
 Accordingly, the Government will soon start its program of family subsidies for each pre-school child and also increase subsidies for day-care programs. The Government also plans longer hours for 23,000 Government-supported day-care centers, with some to stay open until 10 P.M.
Local governments are going further, offering their own subsidies and campaigns. Yamaguchi Prefecture in rural western Japan recently launched "Operation Stork," with television commmercials and postcards bearing slogans like, "Get a brother (or sister) for your child."
Most public surveys show that Japanese are unmoved by such steps. The Government has responded by showing some appreciation of the complex nature of the problem, and it has suggested steps to improve housing, encourage maternity leaves and permit men to come home earlier from work.
But few think these ideas will materialize soon. Not the least of the problems is the view that husbands in Japan work long hours and weekends, not simply because of job pressures but because they enjoy the companionship of male colleagues more than what many now commonly call "home service."
 
'Silent Resistance'
 Feminists say men's attitudes are improving but that deep-rooted cultural traditions die hard.
"The problem is that our entire social system fails to accommodate mothers with babies," said Yuriko Marumoto, a physician, working mother and feminist, who sees the low birth rate as reflecting a "silent resistance by women" to the male-dominated system.
Dr. Marumoto is also one of a small band of women who have spoken out against the Government's bonuses as a repressive response devised by males.
"Our politicians and business leaders only go home late at night," she said, taking time out from her work at a maternity hospital. "They don't know how kids are raised, or what family life is like. Our political system is controlled by men who know nothing about the kitchen or the home."

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 42; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 2288 words

HEADLINE: Wallet of Ideas: New Yorkers Suggest Ways to Save the Budget

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY

 BODY:
New Yorkers are not known for their reticence. Ask them for their views on how local government could do a better job of reducing its budget deficit and they respond vehemently, cynically, and sometimes, with solutions.
The New York Times asked 30 citizens, some prominent, others not, to reflect on the imminent prospect of service cuts and tax increases. 
 None relished the idea of paying more for less. But many also spoke of a sense of civic despair that went beyond current fiscal straits, a collective fear that the stark measures ahead do not cut to the heart of problems they see every day, situations that often defy common sense.
If there was one theme, it was that the city's faltering economy requires more than mere tinkering with the status quo. Robert Hayes, an advocate for the homeless, called for a local public works project mirroring the social programs of the Great Depression.
Housing, or the lack of it, was a widely shared concern. So was education. But like Americans everywhere, New Yorkers consider government part of the problem, not of the solution. Few disagreed with Deidre Sullivan, a writer whose word associations with state and city government were "annoyance, bloat, waste and sluggishness."
Or with Edward W. Hayes, the former Bronx assistant district attorney who was the inspiration for a character in Tom Wolfe's "Bonfire of the Vanities." He suggested, "You could shoot every tenth bureacrat as a warning to the others."
Former officials, understandably, offered less radical proposals. Ralph J. Lamberti, the former Staten Island Borough President, favored introducing sports betting in O.T.B. parlors to raise revenues and avoid another tax increase. "We constantly read that millions and millions of dollars are bet on the Super Bowl," Mr. Lamberti said. "Instead of having the local bookies get all the money, we could have the revenue."
And Susan Brownmiller, the author, voiced a view shared by just about all but the happy few: "Tax the filthy rich."
These are some of the comments:
 
David R. Jones
President of the Community Service Society

A large part of the city's crisis can be attributed to failure at the state level. The Governor's proposed budget would slash aid to urban localities. Losses to New York City would add $600 million to the city's deficit, already approaching $2 billion. This is an abdication of responsibility by state leadership at a time when the city cannot be forced to take any further measures in budget cutting.
I favor cutting expenditures but also increasing revenue, including taxes. We need to revisit taxation possibilities, such as a surcharge on incomes over $100,000. I'm supportive of a New York City Council suggestion that we revisit a possible commuter surcharge.
We need to revisit areas of waste we all know about. Costs of school custodial services are notorious, and so is the use of vehicles by city employees. We should also look at some giveaways, such as tax credits and real-estate tax abatements over the last decade aimed at attracting business, which paid no dividends as promised to city taxpayers.
 
Paul Gorman
Vice president at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine

What government should do is stop treating people like passive recipients and start offering support for courage and creativity.New York is an urban wilderness that has to be settled. Instead of throwing homesteaders out of abandoned buildings and maybe squeezing them into a shelter, the city ought to give them an award for their initiative and the resources to finish the job.
 
Barbara Ann Teer
Founder and head of the National Black Theater
 The economy of New York City is based on culture and the arts. The arts have to be subsidized. They can do this through a government agency, or entrepreneurly or by expanding corporate funding. Long range, we're talking about educating children so they will grow up to be supportive of the arts and buy tickets.
 
Gordon J. Davis
Former New York City Parks Commissioner

Immediate needs on budget and tax strategy should be coordinated at the highest levels of the state and city to avoid working at cross purposes. A long-term suggestion is the creation of a regional development bank, on the model of the World Bank, that would take up the slack in jobs by rebuilding airports, highways, bridges, parks in New York.
 
Beth Anderson
Life-sciences teacher

I hear a lot of things about hiring a lot of police. If you do that, more money has to go to them. Then you will be arresting more people and putting more people in jail, and it doesn't seem to me that that is an investment New York City or New York State should be making. We need to teach kids not to get involved in things that police will later have to stop.
We need to look at finding ways to have people help each other more, for example putting homeless people into the available empty apartments that exist in the city. We need to find ways to lower rents so people can afford to live in the newer empty buildings.
 
Julia Rivera
Executive director of ASPIRA of New York, which promotes education and leadership for Hispanic youth

Times of crisis are an opportunity to rethink the tax component. The Hispanic community cannot afford these heavy blows. We'll be suffering another generation of students whose lives will be lost.
 
Herbert P. Rickman
President of New York Pride, a nonprofit group, and former special assistant to Mayor Edward I. Koch

Slash the overburdened bureaucracy. Encourage volunteerism. Engage seriously in the battle against the underground economy. Street vending is estimated to cost the city $3 billion in taxes every year. Do more to promote the arts, particularly the motion picture industry. Start selling the city as a tourist mecca. Tourism is the one industry that could help turn around the economy, but basic amenities are lacking: facilities to cash foreign exchange, information in foreign languages, necessities like public toilets.
 
 Marlene Swartz
Artistic director, SoHo Repertory Theater

We should set priorities having to do with quality of life. When I see cops wasting time busting a street musician or a peddler and yet I can't feel safe on the subway, it makes me furious.
One way to help might be ask artists or athletes who have risen up from New York City to donate a certain percent of proceeds to a specific cause, the way Paul Simon helped provide medical care for kids in welfare hotels. The money would have to be for a particular need. If you gave it to the city, it would just go into some bureaucratic hole.
 
Sam Rhee
 Director of the Korean Banking Center at Citibank's branch in Flushing, Queens

Real-estate taxes are too high. You penalize the mom-and-pop stores that stay open 24 hours. In the long run we must bring in some investment firms from overseas -- Japan and Korea and Taiwan and Hong Kong. If we have tax abatements or some kind of incentive, we can bring more business in.
 
 Mac Wellman
Playwright

Lots of people are making lots of money in New York and we all know it and it's not being taxed. Tax the rich. A novel idea. What's been going on for 15 years is soaking the poor to make the rich richer.
 
Ralph J. Lamberti
Former Staten Island Borough President and now senior vice president of behavioral sciences at Staten Island University Hospital

The four East River bridges should be transferred to the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority. The authority then can float bonds, with the revenue coming from a toll on these bridges. That way you can have a reduction in the city's budget for the maintenance and operation of the bridges, but still get the work done.
We should have sports betting in New York City, in the O.T.B. parlors. Instead of having the local bookies get all these millions and millions of dollars, we could.
You already have every tax imaginable, and raising them can get you to a point of diminishing returns. Lowering taxes in some cases will actually generate more revenue.
 
William Tucker
Author of "The Excluded Americans: Homelessness and Housing Policies."

The quickest thing the city could do to deal with the budget crisis would be to abolish rent control. That would allow the city to jettison the Department of Housing Preservation and Development and eventually save more than $1 billion a year. Rent control has caused landlords to abandon buildings and stopped builders from making investments in housing. If the city abolished rent control, people would buy these abandoned buildings and there would be an avalanche of private investment from builders.
 
Richard I. Beattie Jr.
Lawyer and former Board of Education member
I think we're shortchanging the future with the Governor and the Mayor taking too much out of education. There are a couple of different ways to address the problem. You can raise taxes, cut expenditures, or use deficit financing. And there's the fourth, which is a combination of cuts and taxes.
 
Sister Barbara Lenniger
Executive director of a transitional housing program for homeless women and children in the Bronx

 I would put money into affordable low- and moderate-income housing with preventive services to prevent addiction, to build up families. If I could cut, it would be in the Federal defense budget. I would rather build houses to shelter people than build bombs to kill people.
 
Ira M. Millstein
Lawyer and a member of Governor Cuomo's Council on Fiscal and Economic Priorities
 I'm in favor of higher state personal income taxes. I know it's not a popular thing to do. But I'm not in favor of raising corporate taxes and chasing businesses out. And I am in favor of maintaining a level of services that will keep businesses here. And there shuld also be a gas tax increase.
 
John Wang
Consultant in Asian-American marketing and former head of the Chinese-American Local Development Corporation

The government and private sectors have never seriously assessed or tried to channel the contributions of immigrants as an economic development resource. The development of immigrant communities as markets would stimulate business expansion and create additional employment and new tax resources. There's also new opportunity in the 1990 Immigration Act. The law provides 10,000 immigration visas yearly to individuals who invest $1 million or more in new businesses, employing 10 or more workers. If New York took steps to attract only 10 percent of such investors, it would mean $1 billion more for the economy.
 
Robert Hayes
Chairman of the Coalition for the Homeless
If I had one wish, it would be the creation of a mass public-works program. If New York is being crushed by the need to provide general services like sanitation and infrastructure repair, that could really work. At the same time it is being strangled by an increased welfare burden. You could strike at both of those problems by getting people into jobs.
 
Deidre Sullivan
Writer

When I think of city and state government, I think of annoyance, bloat, waste, sluggishness. Dealing with most local government offices is a real pain in the neck. Business is not a golden child, but the private sector can serve as a role model for instilling competitiveness and verve in government.
 
Angelo Falcon
President of the Institute for Puerto Rican Policy
 What I don't see happening at all is a critical evaluation of how the city does its business. Part of this critical re-examination has got to be a strengthening of institutions in poor neighborhoods. This is an opportunity to raise the issue of redistributing the city's wealth, because some can manage cutbacks better than others. There is a connection between poverty and racial tensions and an unfair distribution of services and city resources that fall along racial lines.
 
Susan Brownmiller
Writer

I'm horrified at all the proposed cuts in services. What we've got to do is tax the filthy rich. I think we should go with a one-year emergency surcharge added to the city taxes: one percent if your annual income is above $200,000 but below $300,000; two percent if it's above $300,000 but below $400,000, and so on, up to $1 million. I'm convinced that this would wipe out the deficit. But it would have to be on the gross income, and extended to the people who live outside New York City but work here.
 
Edward W. Hayes
Lawyer and former assistant district attorney in the Bronx
 Cuomo's budget is good because he relied on cutting costs and raising taxes. He pushed back on localities the idea that they also have to cut costs, particularly in the school system, where it is possible.
I would favor a limitation on the terms of legislators. If congressmen and state legislators did not look to get a lifetime job, they would have a whole different attitude to managing the business. Or, you could shoot every tenth bureaucrat as a warning to the others.
 
Roy Friberg
Recovering heroin addict with AIDS who tries to get addicts into drug treatment
 There's a lot of exorbitant waste as far as welfare is concerned. When I see putting people in welfare hotels instead of putting them in an apartment where the rent is a lot less, I see the waste.
You're going to need to start funding more drug programs. Unless you deal with that problem, New York City is not going to get any better. You've got professional "boosters" who will shoplift to pay for drugs. You've got drug-related murders, neighborhoods taken over by drugs. Your drug money is not going back to the city. It's affecting every segment of society.

PUB-DATE: February 17, 1991

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 1; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 3930 words

HEADLINE: Bank Losses Worst in 50 Years, But No Danger to System Is Seen

SERIES: Banks Under Stress/First of five articles: The Legacy of Excess

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT with JOHN C. FREED

 BODY:
As Congress begins debate on one of the most extensive series of changes ever proposed for the nation's banking system, there are clear signs of serious illness at many banks -- large as well as small. But experts say the system itself does not appear in danger of collapse.
The banks are suffering more from losses on bad loans than at any time in the last 50 years -- the amount sharply accelerating in the first nine months of last year. Federal regulators expect 180 banks to fail this year -- banks whose average size is much larger than those that failed in recent years. Nevertheless, the problems do not approach those of the early years of the Depression, when the collapse of 7,000 banks before the national bank holiday was declared in March 1933 helped shatter the economy. 
 By contrast to the savings and loan industry, which is essentially broke, the banking industry earned a profit of $14.7 billion in the first nine months of 1990, despite the increase in loan losses. And to absorb future losses, the banks have a record $218.2 billion of capital and $52.3 billion of other reserves. Capital, in this sense, means stockholders' equity or, more simply, the difference between what a bank owns and what it owes.
 
A Large Bank's Fall
 The state of the banking system is now a matter of heightened public interest following the collapse in early January of the Bank of New England and several reports of losses and dividend cuts at other banks. The problems are typified by the troubled history of a little bank in White River Junction, Vt., for example, where the 1980's temptation to seek ever higher profits from real estate helped bring the institution to its knees -- or by a similar story in New Hampshire at a bank that had been in business since 1830.
Attention is also being drawn to the system by the Administration's attempt to broaden it, by giving banks the powers to do business nationwide and to make it easier for them to enter the insurance and securities businesses. The proposals would not help solve a bank's immediate problems with bad loans, but they could eventually help make the banking industry more profitable, specialists say.
"We certainly don't have a banking crisis in the sense that the country as a whole has a problem," said L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. "But in certain areas of the country there is real stress," he continued, adding that bank problems will worsen if the recession is more severe than he expects or if it lasts beyond midyear.
The troubles among larger banks are clearly shown on the F.D.I.C.'s most recent list of banks that it sees as vulnerable to failure or requiring close supervision. At the end of 1990, that list, which is not publicly available, included 1,046 banks with $408.8 billion of assets, or 12.1 percent of the industry total. A year earlier, at the end of 1989, there were 1,109 banks on the problem list, but their assets were only 7.1 percent of the national total, or $235.5 billion. The list changes every quarter as the condition of some banks improves while other banks deteriorate or fail.
 
 Stocks Down Sharply
 Among the nation's 10 largest banking companies, all continue to be rated as "inherently sound" with ratings of a middle grade or higher, according to Thomson Bankwatch, a bank rating firm based in New York City. But sharp declines in the stocks of those companies -- many are down more than 50 percent in the last 15 months -- are a reminder that investors and analysts see problems that the banking companies may not yet have acknowledged in their financial reports.
Indeed, for 8 of the 10 largest banking companies, industry analysts estimate that losses on loans -- particularly risky loans for commercial real estate and leveraged buyouts -- are well in excess of the reserves set aside by the banks to cover those losses.
Bankers dislike the private estimates of loan losses, because the losses for similar kinds of loans may vary widely from bank to bank.
"We make sure our reserves are consistent with the risk characteristics of our portfolio," said John F. Kooken, vice chairman at the Security Pacific Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest banking company, based in Los Angeles. "There are a lot of checks and balances in the mechanism for setting reserves," he added, noting that the bank's loans are studied by outside auditors as well as banking regulators.
 
Loan Troubles
Large Banks Cut Dividends
 Even if banks deny that loan losses are as severe as analysts estimate, they acknowledge that problems exist. Citicorp, Chase Manhattan, Chemical Banking and Manufacturers Hanover have all cut their dividends in recent months, and others have reported large increases in their delinquent loans.
Thomas Hanley, an analyst at Salomon Brothers, said recent increases in loan problems among larger banks "are especially alarming because they are showing up at the earliest stage of the recession but are already much greater than at the end of the 1981-82 recession."
Financial statements filed with the F.D.I.C. by the banks on Sept. 30, the most recent available, show that through the first nine months of 1990, commercial banks in the United States charged off as a loss 1.36 percent of their outstanding loans, compared with only 56-hundredths of 1 percent in 1982, the last year of the most severe recession since World War II.
Loans that were seriously delinquent equaled 2.65 percent of all bank assets on Sept. 30, up from 1.85 percent in 1982. In loans in this category, no payment has been made for 90 days or more or full payment is no longer expected. In a recession, when more borrowers default, the banking industry normally doubles its write-offs of bad loans; so analysts now expect losses to remain high for many months.
 
Problems Shift to the Northeast
 A New York Times analysis of the Sept. 30 data shows a geographic shifting of banking industry problems away from oil-producing states like Texas, Oklahoma and Louisiana to the Northeastern region, where the troubles are rooted in declining real estate values.
More than one in five Northeastern banks reported a loss, according to the September data, for the first nine months of 1990, compared with one in nine for the rest of the country. Many of the worst problems in that region have occurred at savings banks, including Goldome in Buffalo and several in New Hampshire and Massachusetts, that ventured outside their traditional business of collecting consumer deposits and making low-risk home loans and investments and into commercial real estate.
The Times study of the financial reports filed by the nation's 12,926 banks identified 252 that were in weakened condition, either because of a low level of capital or unusually large amounts of seriously delinquent loans. Inclusion on these lists does not mean that all 252 banks are going to fail, but it is regarded as matter of serious concern.
 
Oil Collapse Jolted Southeast
 Most of the weakly capitalized banks are in Texas, Oklahoma and Louisiana, where many banks are still suffering from losses in the late 80's, following the collapse of oil prices in 1986. Troubled banks in Massachusetts and Connecticut dominate the list of banks with large holdings of seriously delinquent loans.
The F.D.I.C., whose list of "problem" banks has many more names on it than 252, has complete access to bank records and can examine the quality of individual loans. It does not publicly identify problem banks, though depositors may request an annual financial statement from their bank or may write to the F.D.I.C. to obtain a copy of quarterly reports filed by any bank with federally insured deposits.
Measuring the health of banks depends mostly on the value of the loans they have made and how that value is figured. Since there is no stock exchange to determine the value of bank loans, their worth is always open to debate.
If it is assumed that the loans would be sold immediately, their price would be sharply lower than their face amount and banks would realize large losses. An alternative, preferred by bankers, is to assume that the loans will not be sold, and that losses would be recognized only when a default occurred or became likely.
 
Realty Woes
Banks Are Forced To Take Losses
 The steep decline in real estate markets in the last two years has led bank examiners to conclude that many bank loans backing those projects have also declined in value. They have forced banks to write off many loans as a loss and build their reserves to cover future losses.
But in the last few weeks, in response to complaints that strict accounting practices were closing off the supply of new loans to the economy, regulators have shown signs of adopting easier accounting rules. These rules could reduce the losses and reserves required of banks.
"We don't want the environment bankers face to be more difficult than it has to be," said Robert L. Clarke, Comptroller of the Currency.
To measure whether a bank can withstand a siege of bad loans, analysts and regulators pay close attention to the bank's capital to absorb the losses. For many banks, the capital cushion is now thin. But the industry as a whole has more than $6.50 of capital for each $100 of assets, or more than double the minimum standard for financial safety set by regulators.
 
Two Key Ratios Studied

Two important warning signs that analysts look for are the ratio of a bank's capital to assets and the ratio of bad loans to assets. Experience suggests that an average of at least 30 percent of banks with capital of less than 3 percent of assets will fail within two years, and that 60 percent with less than 1.5 percent will fail in that time. Warnings sound, too, when a bank has more than 8 percent of its assets in nonperforming loans.
Texas still has more insolvent and weakly capitalized banks than any other state, but problems are abating there, with fewer banks reporting losses and delinquent loans declining. In the Northeast, despite its problems, relatively few banks have accumulated enough losses to push their capital below 3 percent. But the number of banks reporting losses is growing and their holdings of delinquent loans are rising faster than in any other region of the country.
 
Customer Losses
Leading Concerns Look Elsewhere
 The temptation to plunge into commercial real estate lending was especially strong for many of the country's largest banks. They had been hurt when top-rated corporations, beginning in the 1960's, started to bypass American banks to get funds from foreign banks or the securities markets, where interest rates were lower.
"Twenty years ago we would have had major credit commitments and outstanding loans to companies like Du Pont and TRW," said Edward Brandon, chief executive at the National City Corporation, a Cleveland-based banking company that has been hurt in commercial real estate but remains profitable and well capitalized. Without those top-flight borrowers "banks have been forced to seek other borrowers, which inevitably means making riskier loans."
Still, bankers and analysts alike repeat that for all the unfavorable trends, the great majority of the nation's banks are faring well.
 
A Stress on Growth
 A leading cause of bank problems, said James McCormick, president of the First Manhattan Consulting group, is "a reliance on growth to cover up other failings, whether it is a high level of expenses, a recent acquisition that cost too much, or unprofitable operations."
Because real estate loans carried higher interest rates than other business loans, they seemed attractive. Many banks increased their commitment to these loans by 20 percent or more from 1986 through 1989.
"The most seductive trap in banking is growth," said John G. Medlin Jr., chairman of the First Wachovia Corporation in Winston-Salem, N.C. "It looks so good while it is happening, but the real costs do not become apparent until later."
Mr. Clarke, Comptroller of the Currency, said many leading bank executives ignored warnings issued by his office as long ago as 1985 that standards for real estate loans were slipping.
"There are just too many bankers who forgot or ignored some fundamental precepts of the business," he said. "They put too many of their eggs into the basket of commercial real estate, and now they are paying the price."
 
Insolvencies
Most Are in Texas And the Northeast
 The compilation of the Sept. 30 bank data shows the following:
Twenty-five banks, with assets totaling nearly $13.5 billion, had the weakest capitalization in the country. Their losses had eaten away at capital to the point where they were insolvent and owed more to depositors and other creditors than the value of their "hard" assets, like loans and investments. Fourteen of the 25 have since closed.
Texas accounted for 13 of the insolvent banks, reflecting in large part the economic problems that hit the state and the region after the 1986 fall in oil prices. Five banks in the Northeast are in that category, including three F.D.I.C.-insured savings banks that are the only ones on the list with more than $500 million of assets -- Goldome, with headquarters in Buffalo; the Maine Savings Bank of Portland, and the New Hampshire Savings Bank of Concord.
The largest insolvent bank is Goldome, which has nearly $10.3 billion of assets. Under close scrutiny of regulators it has been steadily shrinking its business. It has sold 24 branches with $2.8 billion of deposits in the New York City area to the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation.
Thomas A. Cooper, chairman of Goldome, said the negative capital position was not necessarily a death knell. "Capital is extremely important, and regulators are right to demand that banks keep their financial condition strong," he said. But he noted that accounting practices show Goldome's weakness but "do not reflect our strength, which is the value of our consumer business."
By allowing Goldome to stay in business despite a lack of capital, Mr. Cooper said, regulators gave the bank time to cut expenses by 40 percent. He noted that the company returned to profitability in the last half of 1990.
 
Insufficient Capital
 Another 166 banks, with assets totaling $55.8 billion, had capital equal to less than 3 percent of their assets, the minimum set by regulators. For 61 banks, capital was less than 1.5 percent of assets.
While Texas, Oklahoma and Louisiana account for 92 of the banks with capital below 3 percent, they are relatively small institutions, with only one having assets above $500 million. Nine of the 10 largest banks in Texas have either failed or been acquired in the last few years, leaving only the smaller banks with lingering problems.
In the Northeast, which to the F.D.I.C. includes the District of Columbia, Maryland and the 10 states to the north, there are fewer undercapitalized banks, but they are much larger than those in Texas. The weakly capitalized banks from the region included 11 with more than $1 billion of assets, including the $13.2 billion Bank of New England, which was taken over last month by the F.D.I.C., and the $5.9 billion American Security Bank, a unit of MNC Financial, a Baltimore company that owns the Maryland National Bank. To raise cash and strengthen its bank units, MNC recently sold its credit card business.
The largest savings banks reporting weak capital were also in the Northeast, and included the Meritor Savings Bank of Philadelphia, now known as the Philadelphia Savings Fund Society, with $5.6 billion of assets, and the Dollar Dry Dock Bank of New York, with $4.6 billion. Both Meritor and Dollar Dry Dock have been selling branches and taking other measures to reduce expenses.
 
Bad Loans
 There were 118 banks, with total assets of $68.8 billion, that had more than 8 percent of their assets in nonperforming loans. The industry average for such loans on Sept. 30 was only 2.65 percent. But earnings reports for the fourth quarter of 1990, not yet compiled by Federal regulators, showed continued rapid increases in nonperforming assets in the Northeast and some evidence that California was beginning to experience the same problem as real estate prices there turned down.
Eight percent is a red flag to regulators and analysts, warning that additional loan losses are likely.
Northeastern states account for 68 of the banks with nonperforming loans above 8 percent. Two of the largest are the $9.3 billion Midlantic Bank in Newark and the $5.2 billion European American Bank in New York. Midlantic has been trying to improve its condition by reducing its size and selling assets, while European American has relied on a fresh capital investment by its European owners, led by ABN AMRO Holding of the Netherlands.
 
A Bank's Fall
Poor Management And Realty Losses
 The brief but troubled history of the Valley Bank in White River Junction, Vt., is an example of how the temptation of high profits from real estate lending and poor management can bring a bank to its knees.
When Valley Bank was established in early 1987, there was still enough spark in the New England real estate market for the founders to expect to match the high profits and rapid growth of many other New England banks.
"There was great pressure to generate earnings, and in that process the principles of lending got put on a back burner," said Joseph J. Greco, who was named Valley Bank's president a month ago. "The supply of credit for real estate deals from banks and savings banks far outstripped the demand. If you were the new bank on the block, like Valley was, you did not get the more sound, reputable businesses. You had to take the second tier."
By Sept. 30, the costs of those policies were clear: heavy loan losses had reduced Valley's capital to only $508,000, or 1.23 percent of assets. With the real estate market still falling, Valley is stuck with 49 percent of its assets consisting of loans backed by commercial real estate projects.
 
Looking for Capital
 As recently as a decade ago, commercial real estate loans accounted for only 5.8 perent of bank assets, and many bankers refused to consider such loans at all. Or they would require personal guarantees from developers as well as a solid business plan, with tenants lined up before construction began. But such lending grew rapidly in the 80's and reached 11.9 percent of assets by last Sept. 30. At 2,836 banks, commercial real estate lending accounted for more than 15 percent of all assets. And at 123 banks, the figure reached 40 percent.
"In retropect, it was probably not the best time for this particular venture to have been started," Mr. Greco said. But now that the mistakes have been made, he added, the bank is trying to recover what it can from the bad loans "and look everywhere for more capital."
The rush to participate in the 80's real estate boom claimed victims far older and better established than Valley National. The New Hampshire Savings Bank in Concord, for example, was founded in 1830 as a mutual-type bank owned by its depositors. But in 1982 it converted to a shareholder-owned company and soon became an aggressive lender on real estate. Losses on bad loans wiped out the $58.6 million of capital the bank had at the end of 1988 and left it insolvent, owing $38.8 million more to depositors and creditors than the estimated value of its assets.
Whatever else is done, most experts agree that the banks must return to sound lending practices, even if growth is sacrificed. In the best of times, the difference between healthy and weak banks is small. Operating on average with only about $6.50 of capital for every $100 of loans and investments, banks are extremely vulnerable to relatively small losses on loans, which can be enough to wipe out much of their capital.
"This is a business where you can be right 95 percent of the time, and still be in serious trouble," said Mr. Seidman of the F.D.I.C.
Next: The bank run
 
 
WHAT THE CHARTS AND LISTS SHOW
 The charts are based on balance sheets and income reports from 12,926 banks as of Sept. 30, 1990, the last period for which such data are available. All the banks are insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.
A computer-assisted search of those records identified banks that were insolvent, or had a small amount of capital relative to their size, or had a high amount of nonperforming loans. Banking experts regard low capital and large holdings of nonperforming loans as two key indicators of a troubled bank.
Banks on the insolvent list were those with negative capital-to-asset ratios, meaning that the amounts they owed depositors and other creditors were greater than the value of their "hard" assets, like loans and investments. Eighteen of the 25 banks on this list have since closed.
The Low Percentage of Capital to Assets list includes banks whose equity capital had shrunk to less than 3 percent of assets. Equity capital represents the amount that a bank's assets exceeds what it owes to depositors and other creditors.
 
Nonperforming Loans

And the banks on the Nonperforming Loans list were those with more than 8 percent of their assets tied up in loans that are delinquent by 90 days or more, or so troubled that the bank does not expect repayment in full.
The appearance of a bank on these lists does not mean it will fail. But bank regulators regard it as a clear sign of serious trouble when a bank's capital-to-assets ratio falls below 3 percent or when bad loans climb to more than 8 percent of assets.
The chart covering the nation's 10 largest banking companies compares the amount of capital and reserves they reported on Sept. 30 with outside analysts' assessments of the losses banks are likely to suffer on their loans. Bankers count on the reserve for loan losses as a way of setting aside money to cover bad loans, but many analysts say those reserves are not enough to cover the losses that banks will actually face.
For 8 of the 10 largest banking companies, the losses based on assumptions used by analysts exceeded the banks' reserves and left the institutions with less capital than their financial statements showed on Sept. 30. Two companies, J. P. Morgan & Company and the Bankers Trust New York Corporation, appeared to have reserves greater than losses assumed for their loan portfolios. Of course, the actual loss on those loans will vary widely from bank to bank, and could disappear for many loans if the economy and real estate markets improve.
 
Estimates of Losses
 Based on past experience, analysts assume the losses average 10 percent for loans to highly indebted companies; 20 percent for all kinds of commercial real estate; 50 percent for delinquent loans to less-developed countries; 25 percent for all other kinds of loans so delinquent that bankers call them nonperforming, and 1.5 percent for all other kinds of loans. Those losses are then subtracted from the company's loan-loss reserves and existing capital.
The bankers counter by saying that the analysts' estimates are exaggerated. Even if all those losses materialized, they would probably occur over a period of time, during which banks could build up reserves from profits, the bankers say. Citibank officials add that the analysts' estimates are wrong because they do not recognize the full extent to which the bank company has already written off troubled loans.

HEADLINE: Colorado Journal;
Meant for the Stomach, Really Taken to Heart

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DENVER, Feb. 16

 BODY:
Back when the West was wilder, it was deadly dangerous to insult another man's horse. An unkind remark could start a gunfight.
These days, disputes are settled by lawyers, who are better paid than the old gunslingers, if not as quick to get results. And Westerners are no longer so defensive about their horses.
But watch what you say about their vegetables. 
 Under a bill pending in the Colorado Legislature, those who unfairly "disparage" food products could be sued. In short, if you have something bad to say about peas or carrots or for that matter T-bones, you had better have a good explanation.
Do people have a beef with beef? Why the need for protection for food? Is "anti-veggieism" on the rise? If so, was it set off by President Bush's intemperate remarks about broccoli?
The sponsor of the bill, State Representative Steve Acquafresca, says there was no specific incident that called for urgency on this matter. Rather, he said, he detected "a general trend in this country to unfairly and inaccurately disparage perishable food products."
Around the state, some people are wondering about the scope of such a law. Kelly Myers, a grocer in Palisade, acknowledged that he had sometimes complained to producers about small bananas and overripe tomatoes.
"Am I safe?" he asked. "Could they come after me for saying these things?" The bill has caused a lot of snickering. But Mr. Acquafresca, who is an apple grower, said, "I don't think there is anything funny about producers' being victimized by these unfair, disparaging statements."
As one example, Mr. Acquafresca cited the Alar scare two years ago, which raised concerns that apples were unsafe to eat because of the preservative sprayed on them. The fears proved exaggerated, but not before apple prices plummeted.
The measure, which would give agricultural producers the right to sue those who make "reckless and unfounded claims" about food, passed the State House of Representatives and now goes to the Senate.
Under the legislation, "any producer of perishable agricultural food products who suffers damages as a result of another's disparagement" of those products "may bring an action for damages."
Colorado's agriculture industry, which ranks second only to tourism in economic importance to the state, has strongly supported the bill.
Brad Anderson, vice president of the Colorado Cattle Feeders Association, said the bill would also provide a remedy for some of the unkind things being said about beef.
The average person now eats 71 pounds of beef a year, he said, down from 100 pounds per person 15 years ago. He said inaccurate claims about red meat were largely responsible for the decline.
"With this bill, if someone claims that beef is unhealthy, which isn't true," he said, "then we have a mechanism to file a lawsuit."
As an example of a possible suit, Mr. Anderson noted that a health food store in Boulder had recently advertised that beef "should be sold in drug stores," because it contains residue from the antibiotics given to cattle.
Jerry Kopel, a State Representative from Denver, voted against the measure. "This is very silly," he said. "It's not going to help the food industry. And it could discourage people from doing legitimate research on products."
Other opponents say it violates the First Amendment. Representative Jeanne Adkins, a former publisher, warned that newspapers could be sued for carrying the views of those who disagree with food producers.
David Miller, the legal director of the American Civil Liberties Union in Colorado, said his group would be studying the bill.
"My immediate reaction," he said, "is that you can't stop a Legislature from enacting silly legislation."
But Kevin Simpson, a columnist for The Denver Post, concluded that fruits and vegetables had simply "had it up to here" with disparaging remarks.
"It's bad enough they get cored, mashed, ground and pitted," he wrote. "You think they appreciate being defamed?"

HEADLINE: Daily News Strikers Hopeful Over a New Round of Talks

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES

 BODY:
On the second day of new do-or-die talks between striking Daily News unions and senior executives of the newspaper, strike-weary workers expressed hope yesterday that a negotiated settlement in the four-month-old strike would finally be reached.
But most workers interviewed said that while they would welcome a settlement, they were also relieved that the paper's fate would be decided soon, no matter the outcome. 
 "I think everybody thinks it will be settled soon," said Nancy Stedman, an assistant features editor and member of the Newspaper Guild. "It would be the happiest moment of my life. This whole thing has been like watching somebody die of cancer."
The new signs of life were detected on Friday, when the leaders of the paper's nine striking unions met in a joint session with senior executives of The News and its corporate parent, the Tribune Company of Chicago. It was the first time that the publisher of The News, James Hoge, and the chief executive of the Tribune Company, Charles T. Brumback, had met face-to-face with all the union leaders.
 
More Than 2,000 Employees
 William J. Usery, Secretary of Labor in the Ford Administration, who was invited by both sides to mediate the dispute, began holding talks yesterday at noon with the pressmen's union. He met separately with union and management representatives and also held several joint sessions with them that lasted for a total of more than two and a half hours. The Newspaper Guild president, Barry F. Lipton, whose union was scheduled to take up negotiations after the pressmen, said he thought the talks were likely to last all night.
Mr. Usery said on Friday that the paper's fate could be decided in days.
Both sides agree that there has been little negotiation amid the bitter accusations that have been exchanged during the strike, which involves more than 2,000 employees.
News officials have contended that they have tried to negotiate with the unions, while the union leaders have maintained that The News has refused to bargain in good faith.
But yesterday James Willse, the executive editor, struck a conciliatory note, "I think everybody is encouraged that there is at least some movement," he said.
 
'If I Had My Friends Around Me'
 Some workers said the strike was demoralizing for their colleagues, themselves and their families. Some live on unemployment checks, borrow from relatives or pay rent with money from union strike funds. While some have found permanent jobs, others have picked up part-time work, unwilling to surrender the hope that they will return to their jobs.
For some, the hardest part has been marching in front of the newspaper's East 42d Street headquarters -- and watching colleagues cross the picket lines or replacement workers assume their jobs. "A lot of people in my department crossed," Ms. Stedman said. "It would have been a lot easier to picket if I had my friends around me."
At the Newspaper Guild headquarters on West 44th Street, where strikers often gather, the mood was decidedly wait-and-see yesterday.
"I think everyone thinks this is good," said Pat Wallace, an editorial clerk. "We got Brumback to come. I've never seen him around any union talks."
 
Somewhat Skeptical
 But Tom Pennacchio, the secretary and treasurer of the Guild, refused to comment on the negotiations at the Waldorf-Astoria. "The pressmen are meeting," he said. "In the parlance of negotiations, they're up first."
A striking feature writer, Monte Williams, said management tactics -- like the hiring of permanent replacement workers -- had fundamentally undermined the collective bargaining process. She said she was hopeful but somewhat skeptical that the negotiations taking place would be fruitful.
"It could be a management ploy, or it could be a genuine attempt to negotiate," she said. "If it's the latter, great. But taking into account the company's abhorrent actions in the past, I wouldn't be surprised if it was just a ruse so that the company could say -- in court -- that it negotiated in good faith."
If the talks fail, the unions and management would probably meet again in court, with the outcome over issues like severance pay and other closing costs likely to hinge on whether unions and management had tried -- in good faith -- to save the newspaper.
Jim Farber, a pop music critic for the newspaper, said, "We'd love there to be a settlement. Sometimes, I think, it's got to close. But I do have a sense that newspapers are kind of like Jason in 'Friday the 13th' movies. You can stab them, bleed them to death, they just keep coming back."

HEADLINE: Town's Good Reputation Has Become Its Problem

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WILLIAMSPORT, Pa.

 BODY:
Every day Lynn I. Miller looks through his office window at the Loyal Order of Moose and watches buses from big cities pull up across the street and disgorge drug addicts, alcoholics, people with AIDS and welfare families who need everything.
"You see them getting off the buses and they don't know where to go," said Mr. Miller, administrator of the Moose lodge here, a chapter of the national fraternity. 
 For several years, the word has been out on inner city streets and in rehabilitation clinics in places like Philadelphia and New York that Williamsport is a good place to try to pull one's life together. Sixty people a week sign up for social services, and the recovering newcomers now represent about 10 percent of Williamsport's 33,000 residents. Longtime residents call them "the influx people," "the recovery people" and, when fear looms largest, "walking time bombs."
 
Town Ahead of Others Its Size
 While thousands of rural communities around the nation have also begun to grapple with homelessness, violent drug crimes and the AIDS epidemic, this town tucked in the foothills of the Allegheny Mountains in north central Pennsylvania has been battling these typically urban problems for years.
Williamsport first became a recovery center in the early 1970's, when alcoholics and addicts, almost all of them white, moved into the city as part of the final phase of a treatment program conducted by a private organization in nearby Allenwood. The concept was that recovering people living in squeaky clean Williamsport, the birthplace of Little League baseball, would find it easier to stay away from the people, places and activities that they associated with their addictions.
Inevitably, some settled here and established a growing support network, which, in turn, attracted more people who were trying to recover from addictions. Gradually, the population of newcomers began to include many blacks, adding a racial aspect to the growing tension felt by longtime residents.
 
10 Recovery Meetings a Night
 At last count, more than 80 single-family homes had been converted into rooming houses, and every night there are at least 10 meetings of Alcoholics Anonymous or Narcotics Anonymous groups in crowded church basements and other rooms.
The population of recovering people grows as quickly as the names on a chain letter. "It all started with my cousin, a crack addict, who came here in 1987 after he did a rehab program," said Eugene Way, a 40-year-old recovering crack addict who is black and used drugs for 24 years. He comes from West Philadelphia and has nine children by five women.
"Back then we were looking for him to die any day, but he came here and it worked for him," Mr. Way said of his cousin. "It worked for my brother in 1988, it worked for my two nephews in 1989, and that's when I came. Now about 15 of my friends are here, and more are coming and some bring families."
Mr. Way said the people of Williamsport "have good reason to be afraid," but he added that the newcomers "have a good track record; we don't do crime no more and it's part of our N.A. therapy to be totally self-supporting, to do volunteer work and be productive."
Mr. Way said he has organized three neighborhood crime watch programs to help improve community relations. But the former car salesman added that he planned to return to Philadelphia this month, primarily because he had failed to find a well-paying job here. He partly blames the poor economy, but says hostility to newcomers is also a cause.
 
Financial Aid and Cool Greeting
 The extraordinary influx of downtrodden people in Williamsport, near Interstate 80 and about 90 miles north of Harrisburg, follows what by now is an established pattern. The newcomers often arrive fresh from drug and alcohol treatment programs, with little money, ill health and criminal records, according to a Bucknell University study made public last year.
The first thing many do is sign up for general assistance, a state program that provides up to $100 a month for a year to a recovering addict. The Federal Government provides an additional $90 a month worth of food stamps. Mothers with children sign up for Federal Aid to Families with Dependent Children.
The newcomers get a decidedly cool greeting in this tidy city, whose skyline is dominated by church steeples and whose residents live and breathe Little League baseball and revel each August in the Little League World Series. Nestled at the foot of Bald Eagle Mountain at a bend in the west branch of the Susquehanna River, Williamsport grew in the 1880's through the efforts of logging magnates who spared no gingerbread in building a town filled with Victorian-style architecture.
It is now a struggling city, however, where the largest employers are two hospitals and an aircraft engine factory. The once-fanciful homes appear drawn and gray and the commercial buildings downtown have not been spruced up since the 1950's and 1960's. Yellow ribbons and miniature American flags, festooning trees and store windows, provide the most noticeable splashes of color on a winter day.
Blacks bear the brunt of the city's hostility toward the newcomers, in part because they stand out, Mr. Way said. Williamsport was 99 percent white until about 1985; now the black population is estimated at 5 to 10 percent.
But there is also a racist component, best exemplified by fliers, periodically posted on telephone poles, that advertise meetings of the Ku Klux Klan.
 
Heckling and a Court Fight
 While people are reluctant to speak openly about any hostility in the community, there have been some conflicts.
"I've been heckled by a lot of people at Burough Council meetings and I've gotten threatening mail that they're going to burn us down," said Craig Snyder, director of Stepping Stones Recovery Center in Montoursville, a town adjacent to Williamsport.
In late 1989, Mr. Snyder successfully fought in court to block the city's efforts to zone his seven-year-old halfway house out of business. He said a third of residents of Stepping Stones, where recovering men live while they make a transition back into normal living, are from the Williamsport area.
Public officials and scholars have studied the phenomenon of Williamsport's newcomers but because records for the past decade rarely hold information about how long a person has lived here, these experts have not reached any positive conclusions about the effect of newcomers on social services and crime.
Social services are indeed stretched to the breaking point, said Jenny S. Thorsen, associate director of Lycoming County United Way in Williamsport, but she noted that among the beneficiaries are many native Williamsport people who have lost jobs or homes or need medical assistance.
Residents are worried about crime more than ever, but the crime rate was actually higher in 1979 -- before the greatest wave of newcomers -- than it was last year, said Police Chief William F. Miller. "There is a lot of fear in this community," he said. "Every crime that's committed, everybody wants to blame it on the influx people, but it's not true."
Medical services have undergone the greatest strain. Officials at the 300-bed Williamsport Hospital and Medical Center calculate that the state reimburses the hospital only 18 percent of the cost of caring for indigent patients.
As a result, last year the hospital closed its infectious diseases clinic because it was overwhelmed with 27 new AIDS cases. Three of the patients were local residents and the rest were from places like New York, Newark, Pittsburgh, Philadelphia and even San Francisco. For similar reasons, the hospital also closed its family practice clinic and is now considering closing its entire outpatient clinic to new patients.
"We're struggling to survive," said Robert E. Mr. Kane, administrative director of ambulatory care services.
 
One Hospital Takes All
 Because the state's aid does not cover the cost of services, all private doctors in Williamsport have also stopped taking medical assistance patients.
Only one hospital in Williamsport, the 272-bed Divine Providence Hospital, continues to serve anyone, regardless of their ability to pay.
All the local elected officials have said they want to reduce the tide of needy people, but there are sharp divisions on how to do it.
"We've got to crack down on housing codes and zoning to control these people," said Steven M. Confair, a Republican member of Borough Council. "You would evict them, and as far as I'm concerned, they can go back to Philadelphia or New Jersey."
Others, including Mayor Jessie L. Bloom, a Democrat, want to improve social services for local people and others who are serious about recovering and, at the same time, deal firmly and swiftly with anyone who causes trouble. "It's a problem we have to address," she said. "We can't send these people away."
