HEADLINE: Saddam's Signal;
Underneath The Theatrics, A First Hint Of Concession

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
STRIP away the conditions, the flowery language and the hoopla surrounding the latest Iraqi peace overture and what you are left with is a core fact: Saddam Hussein flinched.
More than six months after invading Kuwait, and after a month of pounding by an international army, the Iraqi President finally uttered the word "withdrawal." To be sure, he surrounded that concession with a forest of conditions designed as much to disguise his weakness as to probe what sort of payoff he might be able to get for giving back that which he never should have taken. But a concession it was. Nevertheless, it is far too early to pronounce this the beginning of the end of the crisis. It is a new phase, though, in which Saddam Hussein's steely gaze has given way to a certain groping for the exit. 
 It is instructive, at this turning point, to reflect on the reasons for the Iraqi overture, because President Hussein's offer punctured many myths about this conflict and spoke many unintended truths.
The first myth is the one peddled by various Middle East experts that President Hussein believes he can win by losing -- that even if he is driven out of Kuwait in a ground war all he has to do is inflict thousands of casualties on the coalition forces and he will be hailed as a hero at home and in the Arab world for having defied the West.
No one seems to appreciate what nonsense that is more than Mr. Hussein. He knows you don't get to be a hero by elegantly losing. You get to be Gen. George C. Custer or, at best, Gamal Abdel Nasser after the 1967 war, when his stature was radically diminished.
Mr. Hussein seemed to be telling the world last week that he understands that having ruined his country's economy, put its armed forces through a meat grinder and isolated Iraq as an outlaw state, he more than ever needs something to show for it. No one needs to explain to him that one doesn't retire gracefully as the leader of Iraq: there is no Santa Barbara on the Euphrates. The law of the land is rule or die, and unless he brings something back from this war he will indeed be in peril.
The image of Iraq as a battle-hardened warrior state is also largely a myth. For the most part, its eight-year war with Iran took place on battlefields far from Baghdad and other cities. Thanks to Iraqi oil money and Arab gulf aid, life went on normally in Iraq throughout its war with Iran and a new and relatively pampered middle class was even born. Iraq was never an austere North Vietnam, and it has never been asked to withstand the levels of deprivation now being meted out.
This is one way to explain the wish list President Hussein attached to his peace overture -- including a demand that an Iraqi pullout be linked to an Israeli pullout from the occupied territories and a demand that the countries participating in the war against Iraq must "undertake to rebuild what the aggression has destroyed." President Bush dismissed that list as a "cruel hoax," and added for good measure that the Iraqi people should now try to oust Saddam Hussein from power.
Another thing that the Iraqi leader's overture highlights is that the course of battle, and not anything that happens around a negotiating table, will define both this conflict and its aftermath. He clearly made this offer because he is losing the battle on the ground.
The bombing last week of a hardened shelter in Baghdad, in which several hundred Iraqi civilians were hiding unbeknown to the American command, was a tragic event, and one the Iraqis tried to exploit in order to generate sympathy. But it is important to distinguish between how the Iraqi leadership wants the West to think about that tragic bombing and how they themselves probably thought about it. It had to have been a sobering event, or, as one senior Administration official put it: "Don't forget, that was only one of several command bunkers we hit that night. The message to the Iraqi leadership was that 10 feet of concrete didn't protect anyone."
In other words, it probably was not a coincidence that the Iraqi overture, signed by the entire Revolutionary Command Council, came less than 48 hours after that bombing. Just as it was not an accident that the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, Yasir Arafat, finally agreed to withdraw from Beirut in August 1982 only after a wild day of Israeli bombing demonstrated to him that the Israelis were prepared to be as ruthless as he was.
Wars take their grisly toll, and after men finish denouncing their enemies as cruel and cowardly, after they vow revenge before the television cameras, they quietly add up their losses and reconcile themselves with certain realities. It has always been thus. There is not likely to be any charity here, or time-outs. From the start of this conflict the choices for President Hussein were clear: war or the bazaar. President Hussein chose the battlefield and now he wants to go back to the bazaar. But he missed the turn.
That is why the prize for ironic quote of the week goes to the unidentified Iraqi official who said to the Associated Press in Baghdad: "Why is the United States attacking again when we have offered them a way out?" Mr. Bush is not looking for a way out. He is looking for a military victory, because American officials are convinced that only on the basis of a total victory in which Saddam Hussein emerges a clear-cut loser in the eyes of his own people and the region at large will any of their postwar political goals be achievable.
Even the Soviets, who apparently helped elicit the latest Iraqi offer through the visit to Baghdad last week by their envoy Yevgeny M. Primakov, were initially enthusiastic, but after a closer reading, noticeably cooled toward the initiative. That seemed to suggest that until Mr. Hussein comes up with something more concrete -- say a partial withdrawal from Kuwait and then an appeal for some compensation -- he is unlikely to fracture the coalition. The Soviets want to demonstrate some independence, but they won't isolate themselves from their Western financial backers to save Saddam Hussein if he isn't ready to save himself.
It was no accident that the pro-American Arab states, such as Egypt and Saudi Arabia, were also quick to denounce the Iraqi offer as a sham. They understand that if Mr. Hussein were let off the hook now, he would emerge from this war with part of his army still intact, and seething with revenge. The Arabs still standing with America do so not as some favor to Mr. Bush, but because they know the rules of their world: You take a ride with the tiger, you gamble and bid for power, and there is no mercy for the loser.
Their steadfastness, interestingly, comes after a week in which many analysts were predicting that the tide of Arab public opinion was now turning decisively in favor of Mr. Hussein. Actually, there seemed to be a general bewilderment in the faces of the pro-Iraqi Arabs interviewed on the streets of Amman, or firing their guns in celebration in Baghdad, after the Iraqi peace offer. Was this a triumph they were celebrating, or the familiar ride with a pretender who tempted the fates and was now telling them to dismount?
The image of the Arab world is of a land of romantic hazy dreams, where men don't know how to calculate their own interests and where politics defies the laws of gravity. It is anything but. What Saddam Hussein reminded everyone of last week is that the laws of gravity also apply to him. That is not at all to say that the battle up to now has been easy or that America and its allies will be able to rest easy when it is over, or that power alone can redefine the Middle East. Many troubles lie ahead. It simply means that for everything there is a season and this is the season of war and it will be defined by the logic of war.

HEADLINE: The Region;
Should Suburbia Help Foot the Bill For Connecticut's Urban Poor?

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

DATELINE: HARTFORD

 BODY:
THE thousands of commuters who drive in from the suburbs to the offices of the big banks and insurance companies here don't linger in the desperately poor neighborhoods they must cross to get to work. The thousands of poor people who live here -- more than 22 percent of the city's population is now on welfare -- depend on the property taxes paid by those companies, where few of them are able to find jobs.
While suburban residents and their political representatives have managed to insulate themselves from the problems of the cities, a recession and a statewide budget crisis here and elsewhere in Connecticut are causing some to say that the old relationships may have to be redefined, with the suburbs playing a more supportive role. Last week's proposal by Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of a sweeping reorganization of the way Connecticut raises and disperses state funds has local officials bringing new calculations to the dispute. 
 The central argument, articulated by a new generation of aggressive city officials including Raymond Eugene Shipman, the City Manager of Hartford, and Douglas Rae, the Chief Administrative Officer of New Haven, is that such cities can sink into bankruptcy and in turn pull the suburbs down with them.
 
Homelessness and AIDS
 Officials here say that between 100 and 150 people a month, uprooted by layoffs and needing economic assistance, are drifting from across the region into a city already stretched to care for its own and facing a projected shortfall of $50 million in a $440 million budget. Over just the last year, the number of people receiving welfare benefits has grown by an estimated 14 percent.
New Haven, similarly overwhelmed by rising homelessness and the AIDS epidemic, is considering selling bonds to meet day-to-day operating expenses. Bridgeport, the state's largest city, has flirted with bankruptcy. Stamford, whose downtown prospered in the 1980's office construction boom, has found itself overbuilt with real estate prices and property tax collections falling.
Mr. Shipman, who became Hartford's City Manager last September, argues that the suburbs should have to help support the increasing numbers of the poor, and he has proposed a series of changes that have not been well received outside the city line, to say the least.
Mr. Shipman believes, for example, that commuters -- but not residents -- should pay a 1 percent wage tax to City Hall. He has also suggested razing three of the city's oldest public housing projects, which he calls "inhumane warehouses," and relocating the 1,000 families affected into housing scattered around the region.
<> <> The proposal last week by Mr. Weicker to overhaul the state's entire system of raising and spending money adds new elements to the disputes between city and suburb. The plan, which would be based around the creation of a 6 percent income tax on wages and a nearly 50 percent reduction in the 8 percent sales tax, seemed almost designed to drive a further wedge into already uneasy urban-suburban dynamics.
Mr. Weicker, facing a $2.4 billion shortfall in tax revenue, proposed resolving problems with a 16 percent increase in taxes, or about $836 million, and about $1.1 billion in spending cuts; the balance would be raised through borrowing. Some programs affecting local government would be eliminated, while in other areas, existing funds would be distributed differently.
<> <> Some of the biggest cuts, if enacted by the state legislature, would be felt in the cities, including a $50 million reduction in the amount of money available for subsidized housing construction. A program that helps financially strapped families with rent payments would be halved. A $580,000 fund that helps nonprofit housing developers meet expenses would be eliminated.
But the new distribution formulas would hit the suburban towns hardest. New methods of dividing up state education money, for instance, would cut state aid by more than a third in some wealthier towns, and the money would instead go to the cities. For example, Hartford's biggest suburb, West Hartford, would see state aid fall to $7.5 million next year, compared with nearly $11 million this year. Hartford's share would rise to $149 million from $138 million.
 
Pleasing No One
 The proposals appear to please no one. Suburban officials say the cuts in state aid would be devastating, and city officials say the new money will still not be enough.
"We would drown closer to the surface of the water, but we'd still drown," said Mr. Rae in New Haven, which would get a nearly 10 percent increase in state money next year.
Officials in many smaller communities say that while they may not have the scale of problems faced by the cities, their budgets have been just as strained. They need all the resources they can marshal to try and retain local services.
The debate over the Governor's income tax proposal could prove the most divisive factor of all. State lawmakers say that the state's poorer urban areas, all of which have predominantly Democratic delegations to the state legislature, would have the most to gain from an income tax, or the least the lose.
The suburban communities, which are far wealthier and in many areas of the state heavily Republican, are more likely to question whether getting more state money is worth the price of an income tax.
"The wagons are being circled," said Richard D. Pomp, a professor at the University of Connecticut law school who specializes in state and local tax issues. "I'm afraid it's going to touch off the usual suburb-city, beggar-thy-neighbor policy."
Mr. Pomp agrees with officials like Mr. Shipman and Mr. Rae that the only long-term answer to Connecticut's periodic border wars is some form of regional authority similar to the county governments Connecticut abolished in the 1960's. He said he has little hope that such changes would actually occur.
What has changed, he said, is that Mr. Weicker, in proposing a budget that would increase taxes on the wealthiest residents, has introduced the question of fairness into the debate over the fate of the cities. Even if nobody much likes the short-term results, he said, the basis of the arguments could well shift.
"Maybe Weicker will have the ability to break with the past on this," Mr. Pomp said. "That's a reason for hope."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 14; Column 1; Week In Review Desk

HEADLINE: The Region;
A New Source of Money for the City, but at What Price?

 BODY:
BALANCING the budget, on time and under sound accounting principles, has been an article of faith in New York City since 1975, when it nearly went bankrupt from borrowing billions to pay for operating expenses.
Now Felix G. Rohatyn, one of the architects of the plan that rescued the city, has suggested that New York may be better off borrowing than making draconian cuts to balance its budget next year. 
 Mr. Rohatyn, a senior partner at the Lazard Freres investment firm, is chairman of the state's Municipal Assistance Corporation, known as M.A.C. and set up in 1975 to borrow money for the city when it was shut out of the credit markets. He estimates that M.A.C. could realize as much as $400 million a year for the next three years for the city by refinancing bonds and postponing the payment of principal for up to 18 years.
City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman and other critics view Mr. Rohatyn's offer as an invitation to the sort of deficit financing that caused the fiscal crisis in 1975. She said it was "too seductive" and could discourage city officials from making tough fiscal choices.
Following are excerpts from interviews by Josh Barbanel with Mr. Rohatyn and Miss Holtzman.
 
'Just Too Seductive'
Bond Ratings Would be Lowered
 Q. Any homeowner knows that if you borrow against your house to pay today's bills, you could get in trouble in the future. Is the city heading for trouble under your plan?
FELIX ROHATYN: No. When a homeowner gets into difficulties because either he's being laid off or his income is being cut back, he can go to the bank and stretch out his mortgage, stretch out the principal payments. That is a perfectly classical way to finance and has nothing to do with the suggestion of open-ended deficit borrowing for operating expenses.
I don't believe that this is deficit financing, and no business person I know would define this as deficit financing. I also believe that it is consistent with generally accepted accounting principals. It is a method of dealing with a temporary downturn by deferring the pay down of debt that might be too rapid at this point.
Q. Is it possible for Mayor Dinkins to solve the city's problems without any special help or deficit financing?
A. Well, until additional cuts were imposed by the state, I thought they were capable of doing it. But if this economy continues to be weak, then it's questionable whether the city can close its budget gap next year solely with taxes and layoffs without inflicting really dramatic long-term damage to the economic and social structure of the city.
Q. So will the corporation be able to step in and solve the city's problems?
The reason I raised the question of M.A.C. possibly helping would be to deal with what I hope to be a temporary cyclical deficit that will occur over and above the structural deficit as a result of the, hopefully, temporary depression. Even that we couldn't do alone; it would have to be part of an overall city plan.
M.A.C. refundings would benefit the city over a period of two or three years. There could be other temporary measures, wage deferrals by municipal unions, surcharge or other methods of reducing costs or increasing revenues.
But as I said earlier, I don't think any of this is meant to suggest by any way, shape or form that I would in any way support open-ended deficit financing. M.A.C could be an important part of alleviating the cyclical deficit, but cannot in any way play a major, or any kind of a role in dealing with a permanent deficit.
Q. So how much could M.A.C. provide?
A. With the city facing a deficit of perhaps $3 billion to $3.5 billion next year, M.A.C. could do no more than help with 10 or 15 percent of that.
Q. You are an adviser to Governor Cuomo, who recently asked you to stay on as corporation chairman. If your plan gives the city more money, wouldn't that make it easier for the Governor to cut aid to the city?
A. I know people find it hard to believe that there aren't conspiracies, but it isn't the case here. In 15 years as chairman of M.A.C., I have tried to help the city and the state, and if that is defined as conspiring with the Governor or trying to influence the city, I plead guilty.
 
Money From M.A.C.
Just Like Streching A Mortgage
 Q. Mr. Rohatyn has likened the city to a homeowner in deep financial straits who goes to a bank and seeks to stretch out the payment of his mortgage. Do you agree?
ELIZABETH HOLTZMAN: If a homeowner did this, and he wanted to borrow for other things, like keeping a business going or paying for his kids' college education or doctor bills, the banks wouldn't lend him more money. The proposal is premised on a catastrophic scenario for New York City. We are not there yet. I'm not going to say that there are not severe problems. They are severe and they are serious. But that doesn't mean that the budget can't be balanced without resorting to deficit financing.
We have to examine how this could be done without decimating the city. We would have to take greater advantage of attrition, and find more budget relief through productivity improvements. Only 5 percent of the budget closing measures are productivity improvements. We estimate that between $150 million and $200 million could be found through a much tougher attrition program, not replacing people who resign or retire, or leave city employment.
Q. Mr. Rohatyn said that he remains opposed to deficit financing, but is prepared to pump hundreds of millions of dollars into the city's operating budget by stretching out the terms of M.A.C. bonds.
A. That is precisely what deficit financing is. Rolling over the deficits from year to year will simply impose additional burdens on New Yorkers for years to come. Let me give you an example. In the fiscal crisis, the city accumulated an operation deficit of $4 billion that was rolled over. Here we are in 1991 still paying roughly $250 million to $300 million a year of interest to pay off the accumulated deficits of 1975 and prior years.
That could, more or less, offset the entire state cut for education, and allow us to avoid layoffs and serious school cuts next year. We are talking about serious adverse consequences to New Yorkers.
Q. Wouldn't the Rohatyn plan be worth it, to avoid severe disruptions in city services?
A. While it may provide some temporary relief, it could have some very serious consequences.
For one thing, it will cause a downgrade of the city's bonds. We have been told and the public has been told that any deficit financing will cause a downgrade of the city's bonds. That will mean that many people, particularly institutional investors, who now buy city bonds will not be able to do so. That will be extremely disruptive, to say the least.
Q. Could the city have trouble selling its bonds?
A. We may have difficulty selling the bonds we need. That could have a drastic impact under the capital budget, on the city's ability to repair schools, bridges and roads. Interest rates will become much higher and the spending on debt service will compete with spending on social programs.
I want to give you an example of how interest on the city's debt aversely affects the city's ability to pay for other necessary services. The interest on the debt is going to increase from $1.8 billion to $2.7 billion in 1992. That means almost half of the budget gap the city has identified in 1992 is due to the increase in debt service. We have been piling more interest on more interest on more interest. Right now, we are having to cut back on other services because of these interest payments.
Q. Would the M.A.C. plan take the pressure off Mayor Dinkins to balance his budget?
A. It just becomes too seductive. I would hope the answer is no, because the adverse consequences of deficit financing are just far too serious. I don't think that we should give up hope that the city administration will balance its budget in a responsible manner.
 There is no reason not to demand of the city that it come up with a credibly balanced budget. We are still five months away from the final adoption of a budget for 1992. There will be plenty of time.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Fallback for the Jobless Has Little to Fall Back On

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
BY providing income to jobless people for a temporary period, the unemployment insurance program is designed to be the first line of defense when jobs are cut in a business downturn.
But while the present recession deepens and joblessness rises, there is mounting concern that the unemployment insurance program may not be up to the task. 
 The program is so starved for administrative funds that it cannot be run properly; less than half of those out of work are receiving jobless benefits compared to 75 per cent of those who became unemployed in the mid-1970's; few of those unemployed longer than six months get any benefits and severe cuts have been taken in programs that have shown some success in removing from the unemployment rolls those people who remained jobless for long periods.
"In its totality, unemployment insurance is the weakest it's ever been going into a recession," says Isaac Shapiro, a senior research analyst at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a Washington research group.
Under the program, the Federal Government levies a special tax to cover administrative costs, and states set eligibility requirements for workers, determine the level of benefits to be paid and collect taxes to pay for those benefits.
In the week ending Jan. 26, the latest period for which figures are available, more than 3.9 million people received unemployment checks nationwide in a 36 percent jump over the same period in 1990.
The most visible signs of the system's problems are the long lines of impatient people waiting to be served in offices that dispense jobless benefits across the country and the long waiting periods -- in some states as long as seven weeks -- that applicants endure before receiving their first unemployment checks.
The delays are the result of a failure by Congress to allocate enough money to maintain an adequate staff to process claims, even though a Federal trust fund created to run the program is overflowing with money. Instead, the trust has been used to reduce the Federal budget deficit. Last month the Bush Administration announced it was seeking an additional $100 million from Congress for administrative costs. But governors and other critics of the Federal effort say this is only about half the amount that is needed.
Discussing the sharp reduction in the number of people receiving benefits, analysts account for the change in a variety of ways.
During the 1982 recession, a number of states ran out of money to pay unemployment benefits and, faced with borrowing from the Federal Government, many tightened eligibility requirements for the program. As the power of unions has waned, workers have lost an agent that often insured they were aware of unemployment benefits and applied for them. With the population shifting to the West and South, where states provide lower levels of such benefits, more unemployed workers do not even bother to apply.
It is not surprising, some analysts say, that benefits are paid to two-thirds of those people who are out of work in Massachusetts, where payments can run as high as $423 a week, while such benefits are paid to only 17 per cent of the jobless in Virginia, where the maximum is $198 a week.
The biggest cause for the decline appears to be changes made in 1981 in the formula that causes the payment of benefits to extend beyond the 26-week period.
As a result of these changes, these extended benefits are currently available in only two states, Alaska and Rhode Island.
In contrast, these benefits were available in all 50 states during the 1975 recession.
The Department of Labor predicts that another eight states will be paying extended benefits before the recession ends.
In addition to scaling back the unemployment insurance system during the 1980's, the Administration and the Congress sharply cut back its companion, the employment service program, which is intended to help laid-off workers find jobs.
Because of cutbacks in Federal financing, the employment service staff has been reduced from 30,000 in 1981 to about 17,000 today.
Yet, a recent study by the W. E. Upjohn Institute for Employment Reasearch, a private research foundation, found that those out of work for more than 20 weeks and who used the employment service found jobs an average of six weeks faster than a similar group that did not use the agency.
"These days when you want activities that are budget-neutral, our evidence suggests that if you give more money to the employment service, you could save so much in employment insurance benefits that the program would pay for itself," said Louis Jacobson, a senior economist at Upjohn who conducted the study.
 
A Legacy of Anti-Tax Mood
 But if the tax-cutting mood of the 1980's prompted a scaling back ofboth the employment service and the unemployment insurance program, that same anti-tax sentiment is also preventing a consensus on how to fix some of the system's problems.
For example, many governors feel the lack of extended benefits, whose costs are shared by the Federal and state governments, produces hardships for many of those who remain unemployed for a long period.
But a concern over the fiscal and political repercussions of seeking tax increases to help pay for these benefits has kept many governors from pushing for them.
"If we make it so that extended benefits trigger on easier, there are some states that will have to raise taxes," said Raymod C. Scheppach, executive director of that National Governors' Association.
"Politically that's very difficult."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 4; Column 1; Week In Review Desk

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
Why America Still Hates the Words 'Energy Policy'

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
SINCE the election of Ronald Reagan, the nation has approached energy policy in the same ambivalent way it has approached sex education: some people think it is indispensable; others think it is none of the government's business. A silent majority appears to grudgingly agree that something is needed. But in Washington the attitude often seems to be, Do we really have to talk about it in public?
One of the most surprising things about the war in the Persian Gulf, and the third oil crisis in less than 20 years, is how little it has done to shake this complacency. As Brooks B. Yeager, a lobbyist for the National Audubon Society, put it, oil policy and the oilfield war are "eerily disengaged from each other." 
 Last week the Bush Administration's draft energy strategy leaked out, perhaps as a trial balloon, and experts in the field found it more remarkable for what it does not say than for what it does.
The plan could still change before it goes to Congress, which will probably happen this week. But in its preliminary form the draft evokes the Reagan years. The emphasis is not on conservation but on the supply side, with calls for pumping oil in areas previously off limits for environmental reasons and for deregulating pipeline operators and electricity producers.
Electricity, in fact, is heavily stressed, with a continued Federal commitment to nuclear power. But electric companies do not use much oil, and besides, said Mary Kenkel, a spokeswoman for the Edison Electric Institute, the trade association of investor-owned utilities, they use the thick, heavy stuff that no one else wants. "That oil, even if it's displaced, is not going to power your automobile," she said.
Mr. Bush's plan would make it easier to build natural gas pipelines, but at present, gas is in surplus. He would open the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge for drilling, but that, say the experts, would only delay the decline of American oil production, not stop it.
 
Playing the Market
 Energy policy, to the extent that it exists at all, is still driven by what Peter C. Beutel, an oil analyst at Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J., calls a Republican mantra: "The Market Is Our Policy."
But Adam Smith's invisible hand has increased dependence on imports by choking domestic production. In the late 1980's domestic production declined sharply as an OPEC price war made Texas and Oklahoma wells uneconomical. At the same time, demand kept rising. Imports made up 31 percent of demand in 1985; now they make up nearly half.
A year ago the Department of Energy seemed poised to propose steps to modernize everything in America that uses energy, to do the same work with less. Adm. James D. Watkins, the Energy Secretary, said last summer that the one area in which consensus existed was for higher efficiency. But the draft of the Bush plan includes very few of those options.
In a way, Mr. Bush has replaced energy policy with foreign policy; the problem of expensive oil went away when the bombers went in. Some people favor a more direct approach to oil, however. Senator John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio, complained that an energy policy should not have to rely on "fragile coalitions and the prosecution of a war."
 The war could conceivably push Congress into demanding more from the Administration. Congress has 80 energy bills waiting, some paralleling Mr. Bush's plan. Congress may also try a new windfall-profits tax, although it seems unlikely any oil company would earn enough to pay it in 1991. Higher on Congress' agenda is raising the efficiency standards for automobiles, which were introduced after the first oil shock in 1973 but are now at a plateau of 27.5 miles per gallon. A proposal by Senator Richard H. Bryan, a Nevada Democrat, which passed the Senate last year but not the House, would raise the standard to about 40 miles per gallon in the coming decade. Congress seems inclined to approve some sort of increase.
But paradoxically enough, the war with Iraq, having insured at least for now a steady supply of oil, might contribute to the national complacency. Since the bombing started, the price of gasoline, the barometer of public mood, is back down. The American Automobile Association said on Feb. 12 that the nationwide average price of a gallon of regular gasoline at a self-serve pump was $1.164, down 1.9 cents for the week and 20.7 cents since the peak on Dec. 18. Subtracting for inflation and recent tax increases, the price is near a record low.
Crude oil users may also feel lulled again. At this time last year, West Texas intermediate crude was selling for more than $22 a barrel; on Friday it closed at $20.88.
With an allied success in the gulf, the complacency could become even more ingrained. But the United States would still be confronted with the impediments it has always faced in energy policy.
Perhaps chief among these is the schizoid role of oil in this country. Around the world a power struggle rages between consumers and producers, but as J. Robinson West, of the Petroleum Finance Company, a Washington-based consulting firm, pointed out, this country has both consumers and producers. A tax that a consuming nation might impose on itself to hold down demand would be opposed here by producers because it would damage their market. A tax to stimulate production would be opposed by consumers, who can buy oil more cheaply from abroad.
<> <> Joseph Stanislaw, an energy expert who works in Paris for Cambridge Energy Research Associates, said that France had an easier time developing an energy policy, cutting its oil dependence sharply along with its ratio of energy use to economic production, because there is not much in the way of an energy production industry to complicate the argument. "They have no natural resources with which they can deceive themselves," he said. Furthermore, the American system of government is federal, not central. The French, said Mr. Stanislaw, are "used to more authoritarian control and centralized government."
 
A Thousand Axes
 In the United States, "energy policy" is sometimes a rubric for a thousand axes to grind and oxen to gore. "It is hard to differentiate what is being done because it makes sense and what is being done because the policy helps someone," said Michael C. Lynch, senior research associate at the Washington International Energy Group, a consulting firm. For example, many people think ethanol is the ideal substitute for foreign oil, he said, but most of them make the corn from which the ethanol would be produced.
And many of the tools that would be needed for a policy "have either been specifically rejected or are unavailable," said James R. Schlesinger, who served as Secretary of Energy from 1977 to 1979. Further tax subsidies to drillers are nearly impossible at a time of huge deficits, he said, and taxes to dampen consumption are out of the question "partly because of the budget stalemate, and partly because of the President's renewed pledge with regard to no more taxes."
Internal squabbling does not help, either. Oil companies bad-mouth natural gas, a potential competitor, saying that it has a history of shortages and price volatility. Natural gas producers complain about coal, which is too dirty, they say. Coal producers, with supplies so abundant and technology so advanced that big price swings are difficult to imagine, speak derisively of price and supply volatility in both oil and gas. And the nuclear industry is off in its own corner, haughty and despised.
In the midst of all this, Americans may not know how to get it, but they know what they want. "Americans see cheap, abundant, reliable energy as a biblical and constitutional entitlement," said Paul Hilliard, chairman of the Independent Petroleum Association of America. "If you're born in America and you don't have cheap energy available at any time, day or night, then somebody is beating up on you, and the government ought to fix it."

1960 -- U.S. car population tops 62 million, or .29 per person. Gasoline averages 29.3 cents a gallon (leaded regular, in Houston).
1967 -- Oil is discovered in Prudhoe Bay, Alaska.
1970 -- U.S. oil production hits peak of 9.64 million barrels a day.
1971 -- Price controls are imposed on oil as part of anti-inflation program, creating a disincentive to drill.
1972 -- Average annual gasoline consumption per car reaches a peak of 785 gallons.
1973 -- Following Yom Kippur War, Arab oil embargo pushes prices from less than $6 a barrel in October to over $16 by December. Car population exceeds 100 million, or .49 per person. President Nixon abolishes 14-year-old import quota system, because domestic production cannot keep up with demand.
1975 -- U.S. establishes fuel economy standards for cars.
1977 -- Alaska pipeline completed.
1978 -- Gasoline demand in United States peaks at 7.4 million barrels per day; unleaded sells for 61.3 cents a gallon (Houston).
1979 -- World production peaks at 62.68 million barrels a day. Shah of Iran is overthrown and exports fall precipitously; in December, spot price of oil exceeds $40 a barrel and some states impose gasoline rationing.
1980 -- President Carter declares that "an attempt by any outside force to gain control of the Persian Gulf region will be regarded as an assault on the vital interests of the United States of America."
1981 -- Unleaded gasoline reaches $1.313 a gallon (Houston).
1986 -- An oil price war pushes some crudes down to $7 a barrel and Vice President George Bush, in Riyadh, asks Saudis to help maintain "price stability."
1988 -- With better fuel economy, average annual gasoline consumption declines to 507 gallons per car.
1989 -- Exxon Valdez spill temporarily shuts Port of Valdez, contributing to a spike in gasoline prices. Car population exceeds 143 million, or .58 per person.
1990 -- Domestic oil production declines to 7.28 million barrels a day at year-end. Iraq invades Kuwait, sending oil prices from low $20's to over $40.
January 1991 -- U.S. begins bombing Iraq; oil prices fall by one-third overnight.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
War and Recession Speed Up the Airlines' Flights to Oblivion

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
FOR America's airlines, the friendly skies are a distant memory. Since Iraq invaded Kuwait last August, the jump in jet fuel prices, economic recession and fears of terrorism have added to the industry's angst. United States carriers lost $2 billion in the last quarter of 1990, and analysts expect them to lose another $1.5 billion or so in the first three months of this year. More than 25,000 airline workers have lost their jobs. Eastern Airlines finally folded last month, and others are clearly on the endangered list.
"The airline industry isn't in a recession," said John Meyer, an economics professor at Harvard's John F. Kennedy School of Government. "It's a depression." 
 The industry's current problems are accelerating the Darwinian process of sorting out winners from losers in a deregulated environment. At stake is the future shape of the airline industry in the United States and the level of competition that will remain to benefit travelers by maintaining service and restraining prices.
Clearly, the winnowing process is already well advanced. Many of the newcomers spawned by the Carter Administration's deregulation, like People Express and Air Florida, are long gone, and several established carriers are in dire straits. Among them are Pan Am and Continental, both temporarily shielded by the bankruptcy code.
But today, the industry and the Government are confronting a series of critical issues: How much further, how rapidly and under what conditions should the industry's consolidation continue? Should foreign airlines be allowed to buy control of weaker American carriers to keep them flying and thus foster domestic competition? How can competition be increased at airports where single carriers are dominant?
To address these matters, the House aviation subcommittee held hearings in early February. Last week, Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner huddled with about a dozen airline experts, mainly consultants and academics, to discuss the industry's problems and its future.
The worry is that the number of big national airlines in the United States could be reduced to as few as three -- United, American and Delta -- surrounded by a handful of regional carriers like Southwest and Alaska Airlines. And the airlines in the middle -- like Pan Am, T.W.A., Continental and USAir -- could be squeezed out, threatening the benefits of competition that deregulation was intended to encourage.
The latest signs of industry consolidation and the Government's concerns about the loss of competition came last week. USAir announced Monday that it was laying off 3,585 workers as a means of reducing costs to try to survive the current slump. And on Friday, the Justice Department succeeded in blocking the purchase by United of Eastern's takeoff and landing slots at Washington's National Airport. The Justice Department contended that the purchase by United would violate antitrust laws because it would give United too dominant a presence in the Washington area. Instead, a Federal bankruptcy judge approved the sale of the Eastern assets to Northwest.
The policy debate under way, for the most part, is not about re-regulating the airlines. There have been drawbacks to deregulation, including the sharp climb in fares on less-traveled routes, especially flights of less than 500 miles, and the end of service to some rural communities. But analysts agree the drawbacks are far outweighed by the benefits of increased service and lower fares (one study said they were down 17 percent, adjusted for inflation, nationwide).
So the current debate centers on how to maintain and expand competition. In today's market there are considerable advantages for the biggest airlines.United and American have computerized reservation systems in travel agencies that feed them travelers; they have globe-girdling frequent-flyer programs, and they control a huge number of takeoff and landing slots.
Yet the possibility of reducing the number of national carriers to three or four is a matter of concern even for the champions of deregulation. "Some further consolidation is inevitable and healthy," said Dan Kasper, a consultant at Harbridge House, a consulting firm in Boston. "Having three carriers compete in one market is fine. But if you have the same three in all markets around the country, there is a risk they will not compete as vigorously as they should and that you lose the benefits of deregulation."
One answer is to allow foreigners to buy America's struggling middle-sized airlines. Under current law, foreigners cannot control more than 25 percent of the voting stock of an American airline. (In January, Mr. Skinner ruled that KLM Royal Dutch Airlines could buy a stake of up to 49 percent in Northwest, but only 25 percent of the voting shares.)
Many airline experts contend that it is time to change the law to permit up to 100 percent ownership of United States airlines by foreign buyers. The proposal has some support in Congress, but it will be controversial. Proponents of allowing foreign control say that two conditions should be attached: the buyer should not be state-owned, and the foreign airline's home market should be as open to American airlines as the American air travel market is to them. The most likely overseas buyers: British Airways, Japan Air Lines and All Nippon Airways.
"We'd surely wind up with more, stronger airlines in America if we opened up to foreign investment," said Thomas Gale Moore, a senior fellow at the Hoover Institution.
The big American carriers are just as eager to break into lucrative air travel markets abroad as the foreigners are to buy into the United States market. Indeed, the Transportation Department's rejection last week of a plan by British Airways to slice fares by one-third on some trans-Atlantic routes was an effort to pressure the British Government into approving the sale of routes to London's Heathrow airport by Pan Am and T.W.A. to United and American, respectively.
Another method of encouraging competition is to deal with the aspects of air travel that are untouched by the deregulation of fares and routes -- airlines' access to airports. Because no airports have been built since 1976, the established carriers have been able to negotiate long-term leases at airports. And when an airline is the dominant carrier at an airport, it can keep rivals out. One study found that airlines charge higher fares and take in 27 percent more revenue at airports where they dominate traffic than where there is effective competition.
It is an airport-by-airport issue, and it is not only the big three carriers that hold dominant status: in Minneapolis, Northwest is the big airline; in St. Louis, it is T.W.A. To increase access to airports, experts recommend privatizing airports and auctioning landing slots.
"We should deregulate the airline industry entirely to insure the benefits of competition, not leave some anti-competitive protections in place," said Joel Bleeke, a director of McKinsey & Company, a consulting firm. "The danger lies in partially deregulating an industry. That was the real lesson we learned from the savings and loan debacle."

HEADLINE: Horse Racing;
Tracks Working To Lure Crowds

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DURSO

 BODY:
You can get more than a $2 bet if you go to the race track these days. You can get a concert, a picnic, a short "horse course," a long lecture, an umbrella, a T-shirt, a chance to pet a pony, a chance to meet a jockey, breakfast at Belmont, breakfast at Santa Anita, free admission sometimes at Gulfstream Park, a family fair, a playground for the kids and a briefing on how to place the bet you might not have placed if you had stayed home.
At Aqueduct this holiday weekend, you can even get a chance to pick the jockey who will win the most money and, in a manner of speaking, to take home a piece of his purse. 
 Horse racing is unveiling all these capers because it is beset by new threats. Its grip on the public fancy and fortune is being pierced by offtrack betting, television betting, satellite betting, commingling betting, casino betting, state lotteries and many other forms of betting that do not require anybody to drive to the race track and watch a horse.
So the push is on: bring the people back to the horse.
 
Fighting to Survive?
 "It's do-or-die," said Alan Balch, whose company directs all marketing and promoting for Santa Anita in California. "We have to keep developing fans, or there won't be any. We have to develop their interest in coming to the race track, or we'll lose them to betting away from the track. And we can't count on people stumbling in."
"We've got to get people back to the track," said Joe Tanenbaum, the director of communications at Gulfstream Park in Florida. "We're trying to establish a racing presence."
"There aren't enough heroes in the sport," said Richard P. Brown, the vice president for marketing of the New York Racing Association. "Racing has to introduce more people to the sport, and to educate them. Racing has no choice. It's got to face the competition."
Brown personifies the urgency of the problem. He was signed by New York's race tracks June 29 after a career in advertising, and he is now their main strategist in the struggle to find and keep racing fans.
 
Betting on Jockeys
 One of New York's lures is the Aqueduct Jockey Jackpot Challenge, which appeals directly to people's purses. They more or less bet on the jockey, not the horse.
"We started it a couple of weeks ago," Brown said. "Seven weekend days, ending on this holiday weekend. You get a ballot with 10 jockeys listed, and you vote for one or write in somebody. Every time he wins a race, that's 10 points; second place, 5 points, and so on. At the end of the day, all the people who picked the leading jockey share in his earnings.
"Well, let's say his horses win $60,000. The jockey's share is usually 10 percent of the purse. So, he earns $6,000 that day. But we set a minimum of $7,000, so all the people who picked that jockey share in the $7,000.
"The first weekend we tried it, attendance was up by 1,600 over the year before. The next weekend, 1,800. And remember, attendance has been down by about 13 percent this winter because of the recession and the war in the Middle East."
Brown acknowledged that spot promotions might be only tactical, and said:
"Racing has to introduce more people to the sport, but it also has to educate them to know the sport. That's why we have the newcomers' guide and the horse course and things like that. But we have to research this and find out what the public really wants."
In New Jersey, the public wanted Sunday afternoon racing and approved it in a referendum in November. When the Meadowlands held its first Sunday program two weeks ago, with long-sleeved T-shirts as gifts and strolling musicians, children with parents were admitted free and the attendance nearly doubled to 20,103.
"The main thing," said Balch of Santa Anita, "is to show people the racing environment isn't threatening. Attendance reached a peak of 33,000 a day in 1984. Now, it's down to 22,000. That's a steady decline, and it started when the state lottery began in '85. The next blow, we delivered ourselves: satellite wagering. Now, you can get nonstop action without ever coming to the track."
To counterattack, Santa Anita began serving breakfast at the finish line (as Belmont and Saratoga and other tracks have also done). It gave gifts. It staged jockeys' volleyball matches. It set up a playground in the infield for children, and theme parties for their families.
"We've had 5,000 people in the infield for the Family Fair," Balch said. "Pony rides, clowns, theme parties for St. Patrick's Day and Halloween and other holidays. And the kids' playground goes back 50 years. Very elaborate. Kids tend to grow up here. We're starting clubs, and field trips for schools."
 
Coaxing the Cautious
 He paused, and said: "But the first time you say 'race track' to a school administrator, he says, 'Now, wait a minute.' It takes time."
Gulfstream Park in Florida staged a Family Day last Sunday, and counted 1,800 children. They met a jockey, a trainer and a horse, and cavorted in the petting zoo near the paddock.
"The children may not come back as customers," Tanenbaum said. "But we're establishing a racing presence in the home. We've given caps, tote bags, umbrellas, lots of things. As a result, people came to the track who weren't hard-core."
"Did they come back?" he asked, getting to the bottom line. "We don't know. But that's the idea."

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Massachusetts;
3 Big Companies Quit Career Fair Over War Protest

DATELINE: AMHERST, Mass.

 BODY:
After being notified of possible anti-war protests on campus, two major manufacturers of defense equipment - the Raytheon Corporation and Pratt & Whitney - decided not to attend the annual career fair at the University of Massachusetts last week. And representatives from Exxon, who arrived Tuesday night, left the fair before noon the next day after having learned that demonstrations were taking place.
 A spokesman for Pratt & Whitney, a subsidiary of the United Technologies Corporation, would not say whether the protest influenced the decision but said "many factors," including current economic problems and the tight job market, were considered. 
 Representatives of Raytheon, which manufactures the Patriot antiaircraft missile, could not be reached for comment.
 A spokesman for Exxon, Les Rogers, said, "It wasn't the nature of the demonstration, it was the fact that there was going to be a demonstration and the company didn't want to expose its recruiters to any harm." The protest did not affect the company's efforts, he added, because recruiters began getting in touch with students in September.
 
'An Open Campus'

 Joan M. Stoia, director of the university's Mather Career Center, said she called company representatives last week after learning of plans by anti-war groups on campus to protest their participation in the fair.
 "This is really a new thing and we felt we should let them know," she said. "We have no objection to students protesting. This is an open campus."
 About 15 protestors held placards and distributed anti-war literature outside as the fair continued on Wednesday in the campus center auditorium. Raytheon and Pratt & Whitney were scheduled to interview more than 40 students, Ms. Stoia said.
 Ms. Stoia said she told company representatives about the protest "as a courtesy." She said Pratt & Whitney executives said they would hold their interviews at their offices in East Hartford, Conn., and Raytheon representatives said they would review resumes.
 "We had no intention of stopping recruitment sessions," said the spokesman for the protesting group, Marc Kenen, a graduate student in education from Belchertown, Mass. "We wish they did come. It would've given people a chance to ask them questions about the issues we're raising."
 Representatives from about 50 companies attended the fair to speak with students and accept resumes.
 
'They Overreacted'

 Student reaction was divided over the protests.
 Stephen Robbins, a senior engineering major from Amherst, said he was disappointed that the companies withdrew and he supported the students' right to protest.
 "They overreacted," he said of the companies. "For them it was probably a choice to go with what was easier" by interviewing at home.
 Carla Ranhand, a junior communications major from Rockville, MD, said the protest made sense.
 "I think they had a right to protest, just the way our campus is so divided over the war and how people feel about it," she said.
 But Kimberly Broderick, a graduate student in linguistics from New York City, said the protest was unfair to students seeking jobs with those companies.
 "You should have the right to be recruited by them and to see them on your campus rather than having to travel," she said.

HEADLINE: Why Punish Reservists' Families?

 BODY:
Operation Desert Sword has exposed an embarrassingly outdated support system for families of reservists and National Guard members suddenly called to active duty. There is hardship enough in sending them off to war, perhaps never to return. To add financial distress is inexcusable.
Federal laws do provide substantial protection. (Some state laws provide more.) They guarantee re-employment when the war is over. Pay for enlisted men in a combat zone is tax-exempt, and partially so for officers. Military health benefits cover all dependents. Interest rates on mortgages and credit-card and personal loans are capped at 6 percent for the duration of service. 
 But this safety net has many holes. Reservists' families don't get dental care under the military health plan. Students called to active duty are dunned for repayment of student loans if they don't notify the lender in time. Discharged servicemen are eligible for 13 weeks of unemployment insurance benefits; civilians get 26 weeks. And service families are protected against eviction only if their rent is less than $150 a month. Congress is about to raise it to $1,200, but its failure to act sooner shows gross neglect.
Representative G. V. Montgomery of Mississippi, chairman of the Veterans Affairs Committee, has taken the lead in rectification. His bill would, among other things, upgrade unemployment benefits, defer repayment of student loans when students leave for military duty and generally improve veterans' benefits.
One worthy provision would revise military life insurance, linking benefits to age instead of rank. But, like the unemployment insurance proposal, this one is headed for the budget buzz saw. The budget law puts no ceiling on Persian Gulf war spending, but any new legislation that applies to all servicemen -- not just to those in Operation Desert Sword -- may be counted in the Pentagon's regular budget, and the cost would have to be offset by other cuts. Hopefully, such strictures won't block humane reform.
 Representative Bernard Sanders, the Vermont independent, raises the most difficult question of all: How do families cope when their income is suddenly cut to military pay? He wants the Government to make up the difference, up to $40,000.
That may seem generous, but high-earners, with bigger homes and bills, often have bigger money problems when they are called up. The Sanders plan for reservists sounds fair, and would cost only $11.4 million a month, but it has one glaring flaw. It would shortchange full-timers on regular military pay, and there is no equitable way to even out the difference.
Large companies commonly make up their employees' wage and salary losses, and some provide family counseling too. Smaller firms often can't afford to do anything. Senator Edward Kennedy proposes $50 million for counseling and child care. Meanwhile, private and nonprofit organizations like the Red Cross are offering assistance. In New York City, Consumer Advocates, a fuel cooperative, has arranged with local oil companies to supply heating oil free or at a discount to families who have lost income.
Even so, some reservists' families are forced onto welfare -- a scandalous humiliation for the wives and children of men risking their lives in service. The reserves and National Guard are essential to the gulf war, and their importance will grow in the post-cold-war years. Their personal concerns deserve better than they have gotten so far.

HEADLINE: Sick and Poor

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The Missing Agenda: Poverty and Policy" (front page, Jan. 27-29) highlights the national agenda, but omits the important effort of the community health centers that were started, along with Head Start, in the first poverty program of 1965. 
 Twenty-five years later, 600 community and migrant health centers at 2,000 clinic sites are providing primary health care to six million people. That the poor get sicker and the sick get poorer remains true. This program, which has reduced mortality and morbidity, should be expanded for the more than 30 million uninsured Americans.
The George Bush-Jack Kemp strategy of entrepreneurial capitalism and empowerment will simply not work if a person is disabled by sickness.
 
HARVEY I. SLOANE, M.D.
Louisville, Ky., Feb. 2, 1991
 
The writer, former mayor of Louisville, directed a neighborhood health clinic 1967-72.

HEADLINE: GULF WAR SETS OFF CRISIS FOR GERMANS

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, Feb. 14

 BODY:
War in the Persian Gulf has thrown Germany into a crisis of confidence and direction.
Only a short time ago, buoyed by the euphoria of unification, Germans considered themselves to be, in the words of Mayor Walter Momper of West Berlin, "the happiest people on earth." Today, deeply uncertain of what role they should play in the gulf and in future world conflicts, they find themselves searching for a political identity.
In Washington, London, Paris and other allied capitals, there has been much grumbling in recent weeks over Germany's perceived reluctance to help the anti-Iraq coalition. German leaders have been assailed as self-absorbed, niggardly, and ungrateful for four decades of Western support. 
 When Chancellor Helmut Kohl pledged a $5.5 billion contribution to the allied war effort at the end of January, some coalition leaders felt that the pledge had been given grudgingly and late.
 
Anti-Militarist Lessons

"Whatever you get out of them, you really have to squeeze it out," said a pro-American diplomat based in Bonn.
Since the end of World War II, Germans have had the principles of pacifism relentlessly drilled into them. Schoolteachers and schoolbooks have emphasized the absolute supremacy of the rule of law, the unacceptability of war, and the need for Germany to become a thoroughly anti-militarist nation. Many people here have evidentally learned those lessons well.
Antiwar demonstrations are held every day in German cities. Several leading politicians have urged the United States to call a halt to its campaign against Iraq. And in January alone, more than 7,000 German Army reservists applied for conscientous-objector status to avoid possible service in the Middle East. That is more than applied during all of last year.
Chancellor Kohl has taken pains to point out that the 18 German planes sent to defend Turkey from possible attack do not carry enough fuel to allow them to fly into Iraqi airspace. He has refused to pledge explicitly that the planes would be sent into action if Iraqi jets attack Turkey.
 
Cynicism on War Motivations

The harsh criticism that Germany has received has puzzled many of its political leaders.
"When Germany was united in 1990, there were many fears that we would one day become a militaristic power," President Richard von Weizsacker said in a recent speech. "Now, at the beginning of 1991, Germans are being criticized for not wanting to take part in a war."
Many Germans are instinctively skeptical when they hear that a particular war is being fought for a just cause. They remember that their country was led to catastrophe twice in this century by leaders using that argument. Even some members of the Parliament in Bonn say they are fully persuaded that there can be no such thing as a just war.
Cynicism over the true intentions of governments has been fed here by the ever-widening scandal of Germany's arms exports to Iraq. Hardly a day passes without another appaling revelation about one German company or another.
 
Arms Sales to Iraq
 The current issue of the magazine Stern reports that in 1980 and 1981, a consortium of at least nine German concerns headed by the engineering and construction giant Thyssen Rheinstahl Klauseln built a plant south of Baghdad at which poison gas and biological weapons were developed. Thyssen reportedly won the $1 billion contract after pledging in writing that its corporate policy was to "boycott Israel economically and have no relations with Israel."
Another magazine, Der Spiegel, reported in this week's editions that a Cologne-based construction company called Strabag has sent about 70 shipments of equipment to Iraq since August, when the United Nations declared a trade embargo against the Government of Saddam Hussein. The shipments were said to have included tools, spare parts, chemicals for purifying water and even 500 gas masks.
Revelations like those feed the widespread belief here that all wars, and particularly the one being waged against Iraq, are fought for the benefit of small political and industrial cliques. That sentiment, though far from unanimous, has permeated the political process.
Chancellor Kohl has said that when the gulf war is over, he will seek to amend the German Constitution, which now strictly limits the circumstances under which German troops can be sent into combat. But he has not said what kind of amendment he will propose, and his political adversaries say they will resist all such efforts.
Last week, the Kohl Government issued a new declaration tightening control over arms exports, but it fell far short of what critics have been demanding. Mr. Kohl and his senior advisers have refused to support proposals that would ban German arms exports to countries outside the NATO alliance.
The debate over whether Germany should take a more politically active role in the world, and perhaps even a militarily active one, is muffled for the moment because few politicians want to be seen as bickering while a war is underway.
But commentators forsee a period of reflection and self-criticism here once the conflict is over.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 24, 1991, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about a crisis of confidence in Germany over the Persian Gulf war misidentified a company that reportedly headed a consortium that built an Iraqi plant that developed poison gas and biological weapons. It was Thyssen Rheinstahl Technik G.m.b.H.

HEADLINE: FILM;
Peter Sellars Digs Up 'The Cabinet'

BYLINE: By KARRIE JACOBS; Karrie Jacobs, who writes frequently on design in the arts, is writer-at-large at Metropolis magazine.

 BODY:
What has he done now? The enfant terrible, the precocious one, the spiky-haired iconoclast: What has he done?
Most articles about the director Peter Sellars begin this way. Perhaps those aren't the exact words, but the question is always implied: What has this brat pack of one done? Which of Western civilization's most sacred cultural monuments has he desecrated this time? 
 In a roller-coaster ride of a career that began while he was still a student at Harvard University in the late 70's, in which he was made director of the Boston Shakespeare Company at age 25 and the American National Theater at the Kennedy Center in Washington at 26, Mr. Sellars achieved notoriety for, as Arthur Koestler would put it, intersecting matrixes. His favorite conceit has been to uproot classical operas and transplant them to contemporary settings. He staged "The Marriage of Figaro" in Trump Tower and "Don Giovanni" in Harlem. In doing so, he found a way to attract an audience to Mozart for whom opera previously had begun and ended with "Einstein on the Beach."
"That was my 20's," says Mr. Sellars, who is now 33. He thinks that his last season of Mozart will be this summer at Glyndebourne, in Britain, where he is planning a production of "The Magic Flute" set in 1990's Los Angeles.
So what has he done this time?
Mr. Sellars has written and directed a movie, a silent movie, very loosely based on the 1919 German Expressionist landmark film "The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari." With the backing of an independent producer from Munich, Rainer Mockert (the producer of the television versions of Mr. Sellars's Mozart operas recently broadcast on PBS's Great Performances series), Mr. Sellars has been shooting a low-budget ($3.5 million) production scheduled to be screened this summer at Cannes.
"The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari" is best remembered for how it looks; its set was a painting in three dimensions, at times compressed to seem like two, a vivid depiction of a madman's world view. In it, the arrival of a carnival act consisting of a doctor and his somnambulist is followed by a series of murders.
"The Cabinet of Dr. Ramirez" is not a remake; it isn't faithful to the plot of the original, but rather to its spirit. At the heart of this movie project is one strong, lucid idea: that the ghastly disconcerting setting of the original movie -- a world of fearful contrasts between darkness and light, a world where all the angles are wrong -- is not so different from present-day New York City.
For five weeks in November and December, Mr. Sellars and crew shot on location around lower Manhattan, New Jersey and Westchester County. Mostly the movie was filmed in the vicinity of Wall Street.
The plot concerns Matt (played by Peter Gallagher) and Cathy (Joan Cusack), two young, successful stockbrokers whose personal and professional lives are, along with the economy, crumbling. They have a series of increasingly bizarre encounters with Dr. Ramirez (Ron Vawter) and Cesar the somnambulist (Mikhail Baryshnikov), who, in Mr. Sellars's story, are not a mad carnival sideshow operator and his homicidal performer, but a pair of disheveled street people. Ruth Male czech, best known for her work with the experimental theater group Mabou Mines, plays Cathy's mother, and Michael Kirby, who plays Cathy's father, is one of half a dozen members of the Wooster Group (another innovative troupe) who appear in the film. The score consists of two pieces, "Harmonielehre" and "Harmonium," by John Adams, who composed the music for Mr. Sellars's "Nixon in China" and his new opera, "Kling hoffer." The music is sometimes insistent and rhythmic, at other times melancholy.
As in the original "Caligari," directed by Robert Wiene, madness is the theme of "Dr. Ramirez." "Nothing in New York is more maddening than the way things are," observes George Tsypin, the film's set designer.
 Mr. Tsypin has collaborated with Mr. Sellars regularly since they staged "The Count of Monte Cristo" at the National Theater in 1985. Currently, Mr. Tsypin is designing the set for "Klinghoffer," which Mr. Sellars will bring to the Brooklyn Academy of Music in September and which was inspired by the hijacking of the Achille Lauro. Mr. Tsypin has also created the sets for JoAnne Akalaitis's production of "Henry IV," currently in previews at the Public Theater.
Trained as an architect in Moscow, the designer immigrated to this country 10 years ago. For him, the everyday features of New York City are both visually compelling and possess an almost talismanic quality. The look of "Ramirez" is the product of Mr. Tsypin's fascination with the New York vernacular (also a recurrent theme in Mr. Sellars's screenplay) and a desire to depict a specific variety of urban hell -- that of the white collar. Mr. Sellars wrote his original screenplay two years ago in response to the stock market crash of 1987. "What was so eerie," Mr. Sellars says, "was to get there and find all these empty offices."
When shooting for the movie began in the financial district, desolation was indeed what they found. In one office building they used, Mr. Tsypin recalls, "there were huge empty floors and everything was in place," including office equipment.
 Much of the set design for "Ramirez" was actually "anti-design," according to the designer. It was a matter of using what New York has to offer. The narrow streets of the financial district, as he points out, are full of the weird angles and odd perspectives for which "The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari" was famous. And the contrast between the tidy 9-to-5 environment inside the office buildings and the disorderly world of the homeless, who, after office hours, huddle on the buildings' heating vents, became the film's leitmotif.
The most important thing Mr. Tsypin had to do was come up with a way to reveal the inner world of the characters, which, in another movie, could have been conveyed through dialogue.
"Every place becomes this trap," he says. "Not only are they trapped spatially, they're trapped in color. Every location has its own color which is completely overwhelming." The loft where Cathy lives, for instance, is entirely painted a deep shade of blue. "Like van Gogh colors, really vibrant, but mad and suffocating."
On Beaver Street near Bowling Green, is a loft in which the walls have been painted gold. This is, in fact, the loft where Mr. Sellars once lived, that he subsequently sublet to members of the Squat Theater, and then to a series of Chinese exchange students. It is now Dr. Ramirez's loft. The rich, shimmering shade of gold was Mr. Tsypin's doing. The garbage all over the floor -- root beer cans, crumpled newspaper -- was, it seems, left behind by the exchange students.
It is the final week of shooting. While the cast and crew finish lunch, Mr. Sellars stands amid the wreckage of his former home (he now lives in Southern California), his arms folded tightly across his chest. He is rewriting. In theory, "Ramirez" does have a script. But every day, in response to the qualities of the location, in response to mood, Mr. Sellars changes everything.
"Of course it throws everybody off," Mr. Tsypin allows. "It creates unbelievable tension."
By the time the cast returns, Mr. Sellars knows what he wants. First, he shoots a scene with Mr. Gallagher. Matt, the confused stockbroker, his tie perpetually askew, has a lot in common with the philandering husband the actor played in "Sex, Lies and Videotape." Mr. Sellars, behind the camera, instructs Mr. Gallagher -- who is spying on Ramirez -- about how to creep along a wall: "Don't be so much on the floor of this room," he suggests. "Be thinking about the next room."
 The director moves fast. He shoots maybe two takes. Three at the most. He believes that he will wind up using the first take in most cases because he gets the most genuine reactions from the performers the first time around.
Then Mr. Baryshnikov does a scene. He is made up as a derelict, his face dirty and bruised, his hair dyed dark and matted. He is dressed in a blue sweatsuit and he is barefoot. No one should have to walk barefoot on a floor like this. Especially not Mikhail Baryshnikov.
"Slow. Beautiful." Mr. Sellars alternates instruction and praise as the dancer creeps along the wall. "Slow. Beautiful," he repeats.
"What happened is once we started to work, things took their own course," says Mr. Sellars. "What's interesting is to get something to grow really organically, in film terms, that has nothing to do with the written word."
The script was really a list of visual ideas, ways of illustrating the awfulness that Mr. Sellars sees in Wall Street life. If the script is expendable, and there is no dialogue, is there a plot? And if there is a plot, will anyone be able to follow it?
"I'm not terribly interested in that, by and large," Mr. Sellars says. "I mean, sure, I think there's a plot. What's surprising is that a plot emerged from all this. But, you know, obviously we're frying bigger fish."
Which fish?
"What it's like to live now."
The last day of shooting is clear and cold. The location is the Brooklyn Bridge. One lane is partly blocked to accommodate the camera truck and equipment. The scene being shot is of Cesar carrying Cathy along the narrow catwalk that runs directly beneath the wooden pedestrian walkway in the center of the bridge. The most dramatic event of the day's filming involves throwing several dummies, doubles for Cathy, off the bridge. All of this was in the script. Then Mr. Sellars decided to do a scene that wasn't.
"I just realized when we were on the bridge that the point of the movie had nothing to do with the bridge, and I wanted to get off the bridge very quickly," he says.
In late afternoon, shortly before sunset, the crew sets up at the edge of the East River, on the Manhattan side, just north of the South Street Seaport. The shore is covered with debris including four or five cars, some half-submerged, others upside down as if they had been driven straight off the F.D.R. Drive, which looms overhead.
Mr. Sellars begins to set up a shot in which Cesar finds Cathy's body, and is joined by Matt. The two sit on some rocks, looking strangely companionable and sad.
The sun is disappearing and the sky is every bit as color-saturated as one of Mr. Tsypin's sets, all magenta and orange. While waiting for the lights to be set up, the actors perform a scene that was not in the script and will not be in the movie, either. A little improvisation. Mr. Baryshnikov, in a ratty purple sweater, and Mr. Gallagher, his business suit in disarray, stand on either side of Ms. Cusack. And Mr. Baryshnikov starts to teach Mr. Gallagher to dance. With Brooklyn, beautifully illuminated by the last rays of sunlight, as their backdrop, they do what looks like a soft-shoe, Mr. Baryshnikov making up the steps and Mr. Gallagher following. They are starring in their own silent movie, one the camera has missed.
Finally, the lights are set up, Mr. Sellars directs one more scene, and "The Cabinet of Dr. Ramirez" wraps.
Unlike such movies as "Wall Street" and "Working Girl," which are about speed, power and upward mobility, "The Cabinet of Dr. Ramirez" is about slowing down, perhaps about stasis. It's about how the downward slope of the economic spiral looks and feels.
So what has he done now?
Assuming that the wordless performances, the urban imagery and the music truly articulate his ideas, Peter Sellars has made the first Wall Street epic of the recession.
"I think we spent the 80's rushing around," Mr. Sellars says. "And now we have to live with it. I think this movie is about living with it."
