HEADLINE: Mourners Recall Wagner as Man Of Subtle Grace

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
Friends, loved ones, old political allies and ordinary New Yorkers remembered Robert F. Wagner yesterday as one of the city's most popular and pivotal mayors, a quiet man of conscience and probity who led New York through some of the most sweeping changes in its history.
Under the soaring Gothic vaults of St. Patrick's Cathedral, some 700 mourners -- public officials, dignitaries from yesteryear and scores of people who simply knew and admired him -- gathered for a funeral Mass and a final round of tributes for the city's 102d Mayor, who died of heart failure at his Manhattan apartment on Tuesday at the age of 80. 
 There was no parade of politicians to the pulpit and no extensive review of Mr. Wagner's three terms as Mayor from 1954 to 1966 -- a feat matched only by Fiorello H. LaGuardia and Edward I. Koch -- or of his later service as Ambassador to Spain and emissary to the Vatican.
But William Cardinal Baum, a Vatican official who conducted the Mass and read a message of condolence from Pope John Paul II, spoke of Mr. Wagner's service to the nation and the church. And one of Mr. Wagner's sons, Robert F. Wagner Jr., a former deputy mayor and president of the city's Board of Education, gave a brief, moving eulogy on the warmth, kindness and wit of a man he called remarkable.
 
'With Grace, With Humor'
 "He accomplished things subtly," Mr. Wagner said of his father, "sometimes so subtly that people didn't realize what was happening. He accomplished with grace, with humor, with ability to build consensus. He brought New York City into the modern age. He saw the transformation of New York City, which was a great national city, into the pre-eminent city in the world."
Mr. Wagner said his father had jotted down some thoughts in the last weeks of his life. "It was some advice, I think probably not for the officials here, but probably for his sons," Mr. Wagner said, and he read the jottings: "When in danger, ponder. When in trouble, delegate. And when in doubt, mumble."
Mayor Wagner in fact was known as a man of caution and reticence, who often addressed problems by naming study commissions, and whose deliberate, methodical approach was sometimes derided by critics as a failure to respond forcefully to major economic and social changes.
But as others outside the funeral recalled, Mr. Wagner accomplished a great deal in an era of dramatic upheaval in New York, clearing slums and building public housing, fighting for state and Federal aid to the city, holding down transit fares, granting collective bargaining rights to municipal unions and quietly integrating city government with more black and Hispanic appointees to reflect a changing city population.
Joseph A. Califano, who was President Johnson's domestic affairs adviser, recalled Mr. Wagner as an ardent advocate of programs for the poor and disadvantaged. "He was the mayor who was most willing to try the Great Society programs," Mr. Califano said. "Part of what he did was empower minorities."
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, arriving with his wife, Mathilda, praised Mr. Wagner. "He was a very underrated man in his own time, a superb conciliator and consensus-builder," the Governor said on the cathedral steps. "We've known him a long, long time, and our respect and admiration for him grew over the years."
Mayor David N. Dinkins and former Mayors Koch and John V. Lindsay attended, as did a host of former city commissioners and politicians, including Carmine G. DeSapio, whose Manhattan Democratic organization was crushed in 1961 when Mr. Wagner, a lifelong Democrat, won his third term at City Hall despite its opposition.
Mr. DeSapio offered no comment, but his presence seemed a gesture of civility often lacking in today's rough-and-tumble politics. Indeed, Mr. Wagner's funeral itself appeared to many to represent the passing of an era of simpler, more civil times.
When Mr. Wagner was Mayor, New York was "a safe, secure, happy city that I was proud to live in -- and now I can't wait to leave," said Alan K. Brown, a tax accountant and one of many people who attended because they admired the man.
Herman Badillo, a former Congressman, Deputy Mayor and Borough President of the Bronx, said: "Mayor Wagner cared about the city. He started me out in politics. I was the first Puerto Rican commissioner to be appointed in New York history."
After the funeral, at which John Cardinal O'Connor spoke and Robert Merrill sang "Ave Maria," six police officers carried Mr. Wagner's polished mahogany coffin to a hearse, and a cortege carrying family members -- Mr. Wagner's wife, the former Phyllis Fraser Cerf; his sons Robert Jr. and Duncan, and others -- drove to a cold windswept hillside in Calvary Cemetery in Sunnyside, Queens.
There, under the blowing bare branches of a plane tree, traditional prayers were recited and Mr. Wagner was buried beside the graves of his father, United States Senator Robert F. Wagner, and mother, Margaret, and first wife, Susan Edwards Wagner, and not far from the grave of New York's Governor Al Smith.

HEADLINE: Hachette Is Paying For Its Hubris

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
If high fashion has a soul, it is French. Givenchy, Christian Lacroix, Yves Saint Laurent, Chanel -- the biggest names in couture hail from Paris. And when the French talk fashion, people listen, or so goes the thinking at Hachette S.A., the giant French publisher whose European magazines include Match, Elle and Tele 7 Jours. When it brought Elle magazine to the United States in 1985 -- the first part of what was to be a major push outside Europe -- Hachette dismissed market research.
"In the Bible, Jesus said: 'If you love me, you will follow me," said Regiz Pagniez, the debonair French publications director, who created the Elle look and works in New York at the company's budding American arm, Hachette Magazines Inc. "We have the same thing. Readers can't tell us what is necessary. We have to give them examples." 
 But Elle's following has flagged, and Hachette's entire United States foray has had some costly setbacks. At Elle, newsstand sales have fallen as its formula, critics say, has grown tired. Woman's Day, the biggest of 12 titles picked up by Hachette in its 1988 purchase of Diamandis Communications Inc., has been ransacked by the competition.
Hachette is now scurrying to give both magazines a fresh face, which means shrinking the oversized Elle and trading in a homey tradition at Woman's Day for a more contemporary cover look. With a hint of nostalgia, Daniel Filipacchi, the chairman of Hachette Magazines, which now has 15 titles, says: "There has always been a cake on the cover. One day it is red, one day it is yellow and one day it is blue, but it is always a cake."
Despite deep pockets and its standing as the world's largest magazine publisher, Hachette has had difficulty transporting its success to the United States, an illustration of just how tricky creating a global presence -- that universal ambition of media mavens -- can be. The industrywide advertising slump is not the only problem. Magazine executives and analysts claim that Hachette has been undermined by market miscalculations and by the same arrogant attitude that it demonstrated in the Elle start-up:
* Hachette, critics say, mistakenly assumed it could operate in the United States as it does in France, where it owns not only magazines but also interests in the companies that distribute them. But Hachette broke an unspoken code in America, where publishers have not historically owned wholesalers, when it spent $15 million last year to purchase control of the Imperial News Company, a magazine wholesaler on Long Island. Less than 10 months later, it sold Imperial back to its original owners at a loss, claiming that it was effectively driven out of business, and filed a $100 million lawsuit. "It was a fiasco," admitted Didier Guerin, a long-time Hachette executive who oversees Elle and Elle Decor, two of the 15 magazines.
* Hoping to pay down debt assumed in the Diamandis purchase, Jean-Luc Lagardere, the chairman of Hachette S.A., decided to sell Woman's Day in an auction, a technique he had used successfully in France but that investment bankers and managers discouraged him from using because of weakening magazine prices. When bids came in far shy of the asking price, Hachette was forced to yank the magazine off the block, a blow to its credibility and to its advertising, which dwindled. "All our problems stem from Woman's Day," Mr. Filipacchi said.
* Hachette has been unable to keep some of the highly visible and successful executives who came with the Diamandis purchase, leading some in the industry to conclude that the French did not understand how to manage top-flight talent. Among the recent departures: Peter Diamandis, the chairman of Diamandis, and his longtime associate, Bob Spillane; Elle's publisher, Anne Sutherland Fuchs, who became publisher of Vogue; the editor of Woman's Day, Ellen Levine, who joined Redbook, and the Elle Decor editor, Lou Group, who went to House Beautiful.
Mr. Filipacchi dismisses the criticism. Can a media company realistically go global? "To doubt that is to say that you cannot sell Coca-Cola in Russia," he scoffed.
Despite the distress, Hachette Publications appears to be in decent shape financially. Last year, it had cash flow of $60 million on sales of $550 million -- enough to cover debt payments from its purchase of Diamandis. But problems would have arisen next year if not for a $150 million infusion from its corporate parent last November, which it used to pay down debt.
For Hachette S.A., venturing into the United States was consistent with a currently popular premise that any media company wanting to prosper in the next century must be global and diversified to survive as advertising dollars move from print to other forms of media. A big believer in the vision is Hachette's 63-year-old chairman, Mr. Lagardere, who owns the largest racing stable in France, and with his family, controls a 51 percent interest in Hachette and in Matra S.A., the French munitions manufacturer.
Taking over Diamandis was a delicate proposition. Peter Diamandis had bought 19 magazines from CBS Publishing Inc. in 1988 for $680 million in a leveraged buyout. He had given his top 29 executives shares in the new company, Diamandis Communications Inc., and plenty of room to maneuver.
The sale to the French for just 12 of the original 19 magazines for $712 million six months later, made several executives into millionaires, and at high risk of leaving Hachette once their payouts -- staggered over several years -- were completed. Indeed, after collecting the last 10 percent of their payout in December, two of the top executives left: Ms. Fuchs, who had moved to Elle from Woman's Day, and Ms. Levine of Woman's Day. Several industry executives believe that Ms. Fuchs and Ms. Levine each earned $3 million.
The temptation to leave may have been heightened by the changing nature of the enterprise, which some executives say shifted from freewheeling to somewhat bureaucratic. Certainly that quickened the exit of Mr. Diamandis, who had stayed on as chairman of Diamandis after the acquisition. "The problem was that Peter had a taste of being an entreprenuer," Mr. Filipacchi said. "It would have been different if we had bought his company straight from CBS."
Mr. Diamandis is contractually obligated not to comment on Hachette, but several executives said that he smarted when Hachette insisted he close Memories, a nostalgia magazine he started. The last straw, however, according to one executive, was when Hachette decided to rename Diamandis Communications. The French management had bristled when they realized that the Diamandis name was still being used.
Mr. Diamandis was even madder and left in September, about $30 million richer. The name was changed to Hachette Magazines the next day. David Pecker, the chief financial officer of Hachette, is the sole remaining executive from Diamandis.
Dissatisfaction at some of the other publications escalated when all publishers began reporting to Mr. Guerin after Mr. Diamandis resigned. One executive who left the company believes that Mr. Guerin antagonized some executives by keeping tighter tabs -- asking for memos and reports -- than Mr. Diamandis. Mr. Guerin denies any conflict.
Meanwhile, the tension at Elle, which eventually was incorporated into Hachette Publications, was mounting. Newsstand sales, the impulse buys that are the clearest indicator of reader interest, dropped 16 percent in 1990, while those of Vogue declined by only 7 percent. Several critics feel the magazine has become too predictable, while Vogue, under its new editor, Anna Wintour, has rebounded and stabilized.
Mr. Pagniez, who works closely with the team of five photographers who do virtually all the work for Elle editions worldwide, argues that the magazine's photography and styling are more subtle and less shocking than they once were. He attributes the decline in figures to the recession.
Elle is being downsized slightly this spring. But the new look may be perceived as a sign of trouble. "If they're downsizing, it is probably realistic from Elle's point of view, but among the magazine community, people look upon it as an acknowledgement that Elle has peaked," said Midge Richardson, editor in chief of Seventeen.
Elle, however, is doing well compared with Woman's Day, which was highly vulnerable to a market downturn. Critics say Mr. Diamandis was slow to recognize how competitive the newsstand business would become.
And putting Woman's Day up for auction was no solution. "We would have taken $200 million, but the highest bid was $125 million," Mr. Filipacchi recalled.
Hachette's advertising pages plummeted 21 percent last year to 1,407 pages, while Family Circle's were down only 16.5 percent. The departure of Ms. Levine compounded a morale problem at Woman's Day. One editor at a rival publication says Hachette had trouble replacing Ms. Levine because publishing executives believed Woman's Day was still for sale.
Several editors said they also were concerned that the culture at Hachette was too "foreign" for them to feel comfortable. One was surprised at being asked, "How good is your French?"
Hachette's challenge is to blend comfortably into the American publishing landscape.
 
ONE LESS STAR ON ELLE'S MASTHEAD
 For Anne Sutherland Fuchs, her new job as publisher of Vogue is nirvana. "Vogue is the Metropolitan Museum," said Ms. Fuchs, who until December was the publisher of Hachette's Elle. "It's an institution. Elle was a five-story art gallery. A very pretty gallery, but an art gallery."
No one is saying how much Conde Nast Publications, which puts out Vogue, is paying Ms. Fuchs. But money could hardly have been the only draw. Her stock in Diamandis, which was bought by Hachette, was worth $3 million. And she was making nearly $400,000 a year as Elle's publisher, associates say.
Ms. Fuchs was the first woman to become publisher of a major national magazine when she took that title at Woman's Day in 1985. Hachette moved her to Elle after it bought Woman's Day from Diamandis in 1988. Ad pages have since ballooned.
The 43-year-old executive is a compulsive worker for whom even socializing is serious business. She is out with her husband, Jim Fuchs, a former Olympic shot putter and now an executive recruiter, five nights a week. One associate recalls watching Ms. Fuchs disappear into the dining room at a dinner party to change the place cards so that she could sit next to a prospective advertiser.
And her sales strategies have sometimes been both daring and controversial. When Hachette introduced Elle in the United States, the magazine was only taking upscale advertisers. Ms. Fuchs started taking ads for inexpensive products like drugstore cosmetics to gain market share.
Some advertisers were not happy. Leonard Lauder, the chairman of Estee Lauder Inc., complained to Peter Diamandis, Ms. Fuchs's boss, that Lauder ads were not in sufficiently prestigious company.
"I wrote two numbers on a piece of paper: $1 million and $2 million," Mr. Diamandis recalled. "I told him Estee spent $2 million in Vogue, which takes all those categories. I said that before he complained, he should spend more in Elle."
Then last year, Ms. Fuchs offered new advertisers a 10 percent discount, which some executives thought weakened Elle's leverage. When she left Hachette, Daniel Filipachhi, the head of Hachette, said Elle, which had just raised rates 9.3 percent, would eliminate the discounts. But, as one company executive said, "If Hachette eliminates the 10 percent discount, then new advertisers would be paying a 20 percent increase over last year. It won't work."
And how will Ms. Fuchs keep Vogue's lead over Elle, which has about 900 fewer advertising pages a year? "In a soft economy, people don't want to take risks. They know that Vogue delivers," she said.

HEADLINE: Fears of War And Recession Put Pressure On the Psyche

BYLINE: By ANDI RIERDEN

 BODY:
STEVE ROBERTS said he often feels like a counselor on wheels. "I hear everything," said the driver for Diamond Cab Company in Bloomfield, "from the mundane to the incredible."
Lately, he said, many of his customers were unusually gloomy. One man was depressed because he lost his job at Pratt & Whitney and did not feel that he could give his children what they need. Others shared their anxieties about the war in the Persian Gulf, Mr. Roberts said, and some dreamed about leaving Connecticut and moving to a place less affected by the recession. 
 "It's a down, down time," he said. "And for a lot of people, it really hurts."
The economic problems in Connecticut are real enough. Housing prices have plummeted. Office buildings stand empty. Layoffs have become common. In December, unemployment was 4.7 percent, up from 4.0 percent a year earlier, according to the State Labor Department. Nonbusiness bankruptcies in the state more than doubled in the 12 months ending Sept. 30, compared with the previous year; the number of filings was 4,521, up from 2,973. Consequently, many people have become unusually gloomy, said a variety of watchers of the public mood. Mental health professionals said that financial problems were leading to symptoms like low self-esteem, anger, addictive behavior and lack of concentration. "In the past, people's problems usually had to do with a crisis at home or substance abuse," said Stephen Witty of Bethel, a psychotherapist and business consultant. "More and more, I'm finding that the stress they're feeling stems back to the economy and whether or not they are able to make tuition or mortgage payments."
Under the amber lights of Bennigan's, a bar and restaurant in the center of Stamford's financial district, a bartender, Dave Havey, said he had seen his customers' mood change. Not long ago, "yuppie whiz kids in Armani suits would sit at the bar boasting about deals, promotions or how much money they made," he said. But the atmosphere has become more somber, he said, and people often talk nervously about their employers' plans to reorganize and restructure.
"People are afraid they might be getting sacked," Mr. Harvey said, adding that the bar also seemed quieter since many people were sitting and watching television coverage of the war. "Nobody's in much of a partying mood."
Vicky Spiro Smith, coordinator of the Connecticut Self Help and Mutual Support Network in New Haven, a referral service for support groups, agreed that international events are taking a psychological toll. "It's a very devastating time to begin with," she said. "Then we have this war on top of it." The Connecticut Psychological Association reported that calls for referrals are up 43 percent from a year ago. Requests for help have also increased at the state's Info Line in Waterbury, which runs a 24-hour crisis-intervention and suicide-prevention service for 41 towns. The assistant director, Angelica Medina, said many of the calls are triggered by concerns about jobs and finances "and an overwhelming fear of the unknown."
Connecticut has lost 19,700 jobs since 1989, 12,000 in manufacturing, said the director of communications for the State Labor Department, C. Richard Ficks. The closing of Bloomingdale's in Stamford, Sage-Allen in downtown Hartford and several Ames department stores throughout the state, he said, contributed to the loss of 4,000 retail jobs.
Enid Sherry of Guilford said the declining optimism about the economy and the general uncertainty about the war were the two main reasons she was forced to close her business, Enid Sherry's Fine Linens and Lingerie, in Guilford Center.
Until a few months ago, she said, her store buzzed with customers, including many women executives who bought imported bed and table linens, silk robes and peignoirs. By the fall, she said, business began dropping. Once the war began, she said, "I knew it was all over for me."
Some residents of the state, like Leroy and Margaret White of New Haven, must cope with economic hardships and their concerns for relatives deployed in the Middle East. Mr. White, a builder, said that until last year, he and his small crew had more business than they could handle. Now, he said, requests for the single-family homes that he builds have halted, forcing his family, including five children, to live on the $24,000 that his wife earns as a school administrator.
 
'It Will Pass'
 In addition, the Whites' 30-year-old son, Roy, is an Army lieutenant now stationed in the Middle East. To overcome the hard times, said the couple, the family members are relying on each other for support.
"The kids are scared and keep asking us when everything is going to get back to normal," said Mr. White. "And we keep telling them that it is a storm we all have to weather. It will pass. It will pass."
The ranks of unemployed professionals has also burgeoned in the last few years, as corporations cut away at middle management, and mergers and acquisitions eliminate thousands of jobs in the region.
"The typical profile of an executive is someone who takes charge and makes things happen," said Cynthia Trapani, president of the Connecticut Consultation Services in Stamford. "And to take that away is to take away someone's identity, structure and self-worth."
Ms. Trapani and other employment counselors said that with so many people out of work, the shame of being jobless has been reduced. In the last two years, she said, large numbers of unemployed people have turned to open forums run by local churches and synagogues, to help each another with job searches and with emotional stress. Fairfield County now has 13 executive support groups.
Robert King, a former corporate financial officer and one of the founders of an executive support group in Stamford, said its participants range from 40 to 60 years old and come from a variety of professional backgrounds.
"It's a place to share ideas, relax and realize that you're not alone," he said.
 
'Spinning Out of Control'
 Mental-health professionals said some people affected by the recession have found solace through a statewide network of support groups that address issues like substance abuse and panic disorders.
Others are voicing their worries over the airwaves. On a recent call-in show on radio station WPKN in Bridgeport, one listener from Milford lamented: "We're living in a world where there are so many massive problems, and nobody seems to know what to do about it. Things seem to be spinning out of our control."
But others, like Ms. Sherry of Guilford, seemed to be taking things in stride. She said she was not sure what she would do after she shut the door to her Water Street shop for the last time.
"My customers seem to be more worried about that than I am," said Ms. Sherry, who is also an interior designer. Though initially saddened by having to close, she said she decided that her situation was a sign that other opportunities await her.
"What can I say?" she said, standing next to a wardrobe that once held lace camisoles. "Life is a circle."

HEADLINE: More Debtors Seeking Protection in Bankruptcy

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
THE word bankruptcy comes from banca rotta, or broken bench, a term used in 14th century Italy where merchants conducted their business seated on benches. When a merchant failed to meet his financial obligations, the other merchants broke his bench over his head.
There are a lot of broken benches around today. Bankruptcy filings at the United States Bankruptcy Court in White Plains, which serves Westchester and Rockland Counties, increased to a record 1,364 last year, up from 978 in 1989. If January, when an additional 146 filings were recorded, is a portent, this year could also set a record. 
 "Filings are being made right across the board," said Kenneth Freda, deputy clerk of the Bankruptcy Court. "They range from small businesses to large businesses and to consumers, including professional couples, who are all seeking protection. We have six people in this office and we could use 10 to handle the increased traffic."
 
Locally, Individuals Predominate
 Bankruptcy filings in the court include those under Chapter VII, which covers businesses that want to liquidate; Chapter XI, which allows businesses to keep operating; Chapter XII, for farmers, and Chapter XIII, for individual debtors.
In the White Plains court, the majority of bankruptcy filings come under Chapter XIII, said Eric Charles Kurtzman, a lawyer who specializes in bankruptcy law. "Many cases in this court involve young families who are struggling to get out from under a mountain of debt, brought about by using too many credit cards," he said.
Mr. Kurtzman said the latest bankruptcies frequently involved people who were very well off until recently. "For example, one professional couple living in northern Westchester recently filed for bankruptcy even though the husband, who is a lawyer, earns $120,000 a year," Mr. Kurtzman said. "But their problem was that the wife, who also earned a high salary, lost her job and then they started falling further and further behind making payments on the $350,000 debt they had run up on six credit cards."
He added that bankruptcy petitions were now filed by people from all walks of life: from 22-year-olds unable to pay car loans to elderly citizens burdened with high medical bills.
Mr. Kurtzman, who is 37, is a partner and founder of the law firm of Kurtzman & Haspel. It is one of the few full-service law firms in the local area that has its own department specializing in bankruptcy law and creditors' rights.
"Bankruptcy law was a relatively obscure specialty when I began my law career nine years ago, as a clerk for U.S. Bankruptcy Court Judge Roy Babit," he said. "Then only a few of the largest firms had bankruptcy departments. But I've always been interested in the power of bankruptcy law and the restructuring of debt."
Now the economic downturn has created a boom for bankruptcy lawyers. Mr. Kurtzman's firm, headquartered in Nanuet, has an office in Manhattan and recently opened a third one in Ramsey, N.J.
"Changes in the bankruptcy law in 1979 have made it easier to file for protection," Mr. Kurtzman said. "It doesn't have the stigma it once had. I'm a court-appointed bankruptcy trustee for the Southern District of New York and as such I administer 60 to 80 cases a month and I see everything.
 
'Most People Are Honest'
 "Most people, I've found -- at least 98 percent -- are honest. They file for bankruptcy because they are pushed to the limit. Divorce and matrimonial problems are the root of a lot of trouble, but credit card debt is what sends most people over the edge."
April is the cruelest month for debtors, Mr. Kurtzman said, because of the demands for payments of bills acquired during holiday buying sprees.
"Credit card companies start demanding payment in earnest and our phones start jumping off the hook with people wanting to know how they can stop collection agencies from hounding them," he said.
"I still recommend that they try to contact the financial institution that issued the credit card, to try to reach a settlement on the debt. But unfortunately the credit card companies will usually refuse. They find it cheaper to give the case to a collection agency."
 
Some Debts Still Must Be Paid
 In most cases, he said, the advantage in filing for individual bankruptcy protection is that it automatically stops any foreclosure proceedings on property the debtor owns.
"I'm not saying that everyone with credit card debt should file for bankruptcy protection," he said. "It should only be considered as an alternative. It's not a way to discharge all debt: Taxes have to be paid first and student loans have to be paid. Alimony and child support have to be paid and lawyers are paid up front."
Bankruptcy has a number of disadvantages. "Anyone filing for bankruptcy protection can't file again for another six years." Mr. Kurtzman said. "And bankruptcy remains on credit reports for 10 years, which affects an individual's credit rating."
But credit card debt, Mr. Kurtzman said, will continue to plague consumers unless Congress forces banks and credit card lenders to reduce the 16 percent to 18 percent interest charges. These, he believes, are excessive.
"Consumer debt keeps the credit card companies and the banks afloat," he said. "But personal bankruptcy is a problem that has been created partially by the economy and the consumer, by lending institutions who are more than happy to absorb some bad debt in return for the 18 percent interest they get from consumers who are not in danger of default."
 
No Jump in Bankrupt Businesses
 Business bankruptcies, surprisingly, don't jump during a recession.
"The reason is that in hard times it's tougher to start a new business," Mr. Kurtzman said. "So there are fewer to go broke the way new businesses do in the first one or two years of operation, and you see fewer of them going into bankruptcy."
Mr. Kurtzman was the trustee in the liquidation of the Charles and Lillian Brown Hotel in the Catskills, a business that was liquidated and its assets sold. But he said that in most business bankruptcy proceedings, under Chapter XI, the overextended borrower engages in what is known as restructuring. Creditors are paid a fraction of what is owed them and the business is allowed to keep operating under court protection.
"Bankruptcy has become widely used as an accepted financial tool," he said. "Restructuring of a debt gives a corporation or an individual a fresh start. The concept is as old as the Bible, which decreed that in a jubilee year all debt should be forgiven."

HEADLINE: Corporate Books Move to Retail Shelves

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

DATELINE: ELMSFORD

 BODY:
CORPORATE histories, those glossy tomes once written solely to flatter the chairman of the board, are no longer destined to end up unread on warehouse shelves. Instead, some are selling well in retail bookstores, generating profits for a growing number of companies.
Roy Benjamin is the chairman of the 37-year-old Benjamin Company here, publishers of scores of corporate histories and business anniversary books. One reason for their success, he suggests, is that the editorial quality of the sponsored books is now equal in many cases to that of the best trade books on the market. 
 "Business happens to be a very popular topic today," Mr. Benjamin said. "There's especially a lot of interest in reading about the people who developed successful companies. So a well-written, well-illustrated corporate history has not only tremendous value as a marketing and public-relations tool, the dollars it makes from retail sales is the icing on the cake."
And those dollars can add up.
 
A Nice Profit for Goodyear
 Take the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company book, "The Goodyear Story," which recounts the company's growth from a small provincial concern into the world's largest tire company. It has earned Goodyear a nice profit since it was published by Benjamin in 1983.
"It's a timeless book, illustrated with about 150 color and black-and-white photos from the company archives," Mr. Benjamin said.
Eventually more than 75,000 copies were distributed by Kent State University Press as trade books, with cover prices of $19.95 for hardcover and $12.95 for soft cover. "Who bought them?" Mr. Benjamin said. "Libraries and business students, mainly, who used them as supplementary textbooks."
 
How Companies Use the Books
 Other copies were distributed to employees, retirees and Goodyear dealers, he said, and some were sold to stockholders at discounted prices.
Companies use their books in many ways, Mr. Benjamin said, from recruiting college graduates to promoting the company to customers and stockholders.
Corporate histories take a lot of work, he said, requiring a search of the corporate archives. His company spent 18 months on the anniversary book for McCormick & Company, the spice concern.
John W. Felton, vice president of corporate communications at McCormick in Hunt Valley, Md., said the company wanted more than a corporate history when it decided to celebrate its 100th anniversary with a special book.
"We thought the concept of combining significant company historical references with a tasty recipe for each important time period would create a more appropriate book for a food company such as ours," Mr. Felton said. "So with the Benjamin Company we were able to create a cookable corporate history: '100 Best Recipes for 100 Years From McCormick.' The book's been a great success, both with our employees and our customers."
Other Benjamin clients that have sold their books to a wider market include Kraft Foods, Remington Arms and Parker Pen.
"What those clients have in common is that all their books were good enough to be distributed to a wider audience," Mr. Benjamin said.
Consumers bought more than 600,000 copies of Kraft's anniversary book, "The Kraft Cookbook,"which has an easel-back binding so the cook can read recipes easily, giving Kraft a profit of more than $1 a book, Mr. Benjamin said.
 
25,000 Extra Copies
 When Mr. Benjamin and his brother, Ted, who is the company president, think a sponsored book has enough merit to stand on its own, they print about 25,000 extra copies for trade distribution, Roy Benjamin said. The Benjamin Company offers such books to trade publishers, which means, he said, that the sponsoring company not only earns royalties from the sale but free publicity as well.
One of the most successful Benjamin titles to be handled in such fashion is "Do's and Taboos Around the World," done for Parker Pen. The book, a reference guide on the gift-giving protocol in 96 countries, was originally packaged with a Parker pen-and-pencil set.
"Parker wanted a book they could market with their pens for gift and sales programs," Mr. Benjamin said. "Since about 80 percent of their business is generated abroad and they have numerous offices overseas, they felt a book dealing with manners and mores abroad was very appropriate for them."
Since its first printing, "Do's and Taboos" has sold 100,000 copies. It has been translated into Japanese, German, French and Finnish.
 
Profit and Publicity
 Eugene G. Rohlman, Parker Pen's manager of marketing communications, said the book had earned a handsomeprofit and about $1 million worth of free publicity for Parker Pen. The book was also acquired by John Wiley & Sons, the trade publisher; in addition to a $9.95 paperback, the publisher has also successfully distributed a hardcover version selling at $19.95 in bookstores.
Other books appearing in bookstores, Mr. Benjamin said, include those his company produced for the 150th anniversary of Remington Arms, a DuPont subsidiary, including the "Remington Historical Treasury of American Guns," books on skeet shooting and trap shooting and a wild game cookbook. The books were sold to bookstores by Grosset & Dunlap.
"How to Protect Your Business," originally published for the Better Business Bureau in 1968 and now in its eighth version, is distributed to bookstores by Prentice Hall.
This aspect of the value of sponsored books was virtually unknown, Mr. Benjamin said, when he and his brother formed the company in 1953. "We pioneered the concept of using books to achieve business objectives and meet budget requirements," he said.
"Now anniversary books have become popular with associations," he added, citing the National Football League's "First 50 Years," the major baseball leagues' "This Great Game" for their 100th Anniversary and the National Association of Broadcasters' "Cavalcade of Broadway -- 38 Years." Books like these usually become classics, Mr. Benjamin said. "They have a long life."
Although the corporate history and anniversary books are the fastest-growing segment of the Benjamin Company, reprints are its bread and butter, Mr. Benjamin said.
"Many are cookbooks," he said, "which are the favorite of sponsors in the food industry because they feature recipes that use the products. They have a long shelf life and because they're constantly used, the sponsor's name is never forgotten."
 
Part of a Package
 He cited as an example the cookbook the Benjamins produced for B&B/Benedictine Liquor's anniversary, based on the recipes of great American chefs. "The book, packaged with each B&B product, is being offered as a premium with purchase," Mr. Benjamin said.
Such books cost the sponsoring company from $5 to $15 a book, depending on such factors as research, art work and production. The average order is 60,000 to 70,000 books. The Benjamin Company uses a cadre of freelance writers, designers, home economists and dietitians who, working with 25 staff employees, bring out six to 12 titles a year.

HEADLINE: DINING OUT;
Begin the Meal With Authentic Borscht

BYLINE: By JOANNE STARKEY

 BODY:
FYODOROFF boldly proclaims in neon that it is both a Russian and an American restaurant. But diners would be foolish to choose a sirloin steak or steamed lobster when the likes of pelmeni, vareniki, shashlik Karsky and chicken Tabaka are as rare as rubles on Long Island.
The brand-new Fyodoroff adds an air of elegance to a strip shopping center on Glen Cove Road in Carle Place. Its bold-white exterior highlighted with silhouettes of towers and onion domes, hunter-green and burgundy marquee and valet parking are not the norm in this land of outlets, clearance centers and carpet stores. 
 Inside, Fyodoroff is even more sumptuous. Its Winter Palace-style foyer of mirrored walls, marble floors and luxuriant floral arrangements is a mere preview of the dramatic dining room.
The large room is romantically illuminated by candelabra on every table, tasteful chandeliers and glowing murals of festive folk celebrations. Although Fyodoroff is not decorated in spare Soviet style, it is authentically Russian. Owners, chefs, patrons and many of the waiters hail from the Soviet Union.
On a recent Saturday night, our waiter told us to relax and enjoy what might be a four-hour dinner. His advice was right on target. Although the leisurely pace might irritate Americans planning a movie, another appointment or early bedtime, Russian diners make a night of it.
Dinner at Fyodoroff is more than a meal. Large groups of friends gather for a spirited Russian evening. In the early hours, a trio played laid-back American jazz classics. Later, it was joined by five brass musicians, and diners crowded the dance floor. When the band took a break, a seven-piece gypsy troupe sang, danced and played. There was even a magician to top off the festivities.
As might be expected, food is secondary in this exciting, convivial nightclub atmosphere. Nevertheless, some of it, especially the Russian choices, merit attention.
Begin the meal with borscht. It is not a one-note beet bonanza, but rich with meat, cabbage and other vegetables. But wild-mushroom soup and clear chicken broth were timid.
Yes, there is caviar. Beluga is $33 an ounce, Osetra is $31, and two ounces of salmon's red caviar is $12.50. We enjoyed the red in tandem with thin, yet fluffy, pancakes and sour cream for $15.
More economically priced and equally good starters were the pinwheels of cold, flavorful flank steak stuffed with cheese, garlic, ham and bacon with a zingy horseradish accompaniment, and cold Georgian eggplant topped with a savory mixture of ground pecans, herbs and spices.
A hot appetizer featuring bits of sturgeon mingled with onions and mushrooms in a creamy wine sauce was delectable, if diminutive and overpriced at $11.95. Better buys are the menu's two salads, tossed green at $6.50 and Black Sea at $8.55. Both are large enough for two or more, impeccably fresh and zesty with lemon. The Black Sea has a bonus of feta cheese and six jumbo shrimp.
At entree time, aim at the low end of the price scale. Pelmeni, $7.50, light-as-air dumplings encasing a juicy meat filling, and vareniki, $8.50, gossamer lovelies stuffed with sour cherries and enriched with side offerings of sour cream and tangy cherry sauce, are Soviet satisfiers.
Other Russian bellringers were the shaslik Karsky, a swordful of tender lamb chops and vegetables; beef stroganoff, and chicken Tabaka. A baby chicken is bathed in vermouth, lemon juice and a hefty dose of garlic and is then flattened and fried under a press. The zippy marinade and a bowl of fresh fruit accompany the juicy chicken.
Most of the American offerings sampled were routine, and chicken Kiev spurted herb-colored stringy cheese rather than butter.
There was no liquor license at the time of this writer's visits. When it is granted, alcoholic beverages will include Russian beer and wines.
Fyodoroff gets a good rating for food, but an excellent for fun. So gather a crowd, put on your dancing shoes and enjoy an exciting European evening on Long Island.
 
Fyodoroff

HEADLINE: Stoned in the Streets of Moscow

BYLINE: By Katrina vanden Heuvel; Katrina vanden Heuvel is the author, with Stephen F. Cohen, of "Voices of Glasnost: Interviews With Gorbachev's Reformers" and the editor of the anthology "The Nation: 1865-1990."

 BODY:

SOVIET SOCIAL PROBLEMS
Edited by Anthony Jones, Walter D. Connor
and David E. Powell.
Illustrated. 318 pp. Boulder, Colo.:
Westview Press. Cloth, $52. Paper, $19.95. 
 Soviet scholars and journalists, now freed under Mikhail S. Gorbachev's policy of glasnost to write about subjects that had been taboo or heavily censored for decades, have been publishing detailed exposes about everything from officially committed crimes of the past to the country's large array of present-day social problems. As a result, Western Soviet specialists, who once had to scrounge for data, can barely cope with the new torrent of information. "We are still trying to sort out and understand all that we are hearing," the editors of this accessible collection acknowledge.
Most of the topics analyzed by the 16 contributors to "Soviet Social Problems" -- crime, drug and alcohol abuse, ecological calamities, juvenile delinquency, poverty and failing educational and health systems -- will be familiar to American readers. "If, indeed there is any kind of convergence between the U.S. and the Soviet Union," notes Paul Hollander, a professor of sociology at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst, "it can be found in the realm of social problems." But for Soviet citizens, the shock of learning about their society's ills has been profoundly unsettling and threatening, and many of them tend to associate those social problems with Mr. Gorbachev's reforms -- so much so that in a recent Soviet public opinion poll, the majority of Soviet citizens ranked the reforms considerably below food shortages, crime and environmental abuse in importance. As Louise I. Shelley, a professor at the American University's School of International Service, points out in her thoughtful essay on crime, such public attitudes may cost Mr. Gorbachev "the support he needs for his economic and political reforms."
By putting their contemporary findings in a historical context, the book's contributors show how the Soviet Union is only now beginning to grapple with problems that Western industrial societies have struggled with for decades. Many Soviet policy makers and intellectuals -- but certainly not all of them -- are eager to learn from Western experiences and practices. In his analysis of the growing problem of Soviet drug abuse, for example, John M. Kramer, a professor of political science at Mary Washington College, reveals that in 1988 the United States Drug Enforcement Agency responded to a request from Moscow to train Soviet officers to combat drug trafficking. (American readers may wonder how much Soviet authorities can actually learn from the D.E.A.) And the study of Soviet pollution problems by Marshall I. Goldman, the associate director of Harvard University's Russian Research Center, suggests that the independent environmental movement in the Soviet Union could benefit from Western experience.
Perhaps the gravest question raised by this book is not whether there are policies to solve these problems, but where any Soviet leadership will find the resources to rebuild a failing health care system, clean the despoiled environment or increase pensions that currently leave most retired citizens near or below the poverty level. Thus Anthony Jones, a fellow at Harvard's Russian Research Center, maintains: "The material resources that the schools so desperately need are unlikely to be forthcoming from an economy that worsens year by year." The new policy of encouraging privatization of services may be a partial solution. But as Walter D. Connor, a professor of political science at Boston University, emphasizes in his treatment of the social justice issue, this approach collides with deeply ingrained Soviet attitudes about equality and hostility to privilege.
Even though this book is written by scholars and primarily for scholars, it raises very large and troubling questions of general concern. As much as any other factor, the social problems of Soviet society will determine the kind of political system that eventually prevails in the Soviet Union and whether the country will survive as now constituted. Only five years ago, most of this book's contributors probably would have emphasized political and ideological differences between the Soviet Union and Western democracies. Now, they encourage us to think about common problems and interests. In this respect, the book is a good omen for post-cold war scholarship on the Soviet Union.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 3; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 2172 words

HEADLINE: The Great Frederick

BYLINE: By David Levering Lewis; David Levering Lewis is a Rutgers University historian and author of "King: A Biography." He is writing a biography of W. E .B. DuBois.

 BODY:

FREDERICK DOUGLASS
By William S. McFeely.
Illustrated. 465 pp. New York:
W. W. Norton & Company. $24.95. 
 Frederick Douglass stood well over six feet tall under a mass of wiry hair that, as it gradually whitened, imparted to his broad, powerful features and intense gaze qualities of unforgettable charisma and prophecy. Self-taught, he became one of the 19th century's greatest orators, its fearless combatant for the civil rights of African-Americans and the rights of women, publisher and editor of one of the abolitionist movement's most influential newspapers, The North Star, and author of three autobiographies, the first of which, "Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass" (1845), compared in contemporary impact with "Uncle Tom's Cabin" and "The Communist Manifesto." Black people called him the Great Frederick, the personification of their hopes for citizenship. Republican Party bosses, waving Douglass at election time, fretted lest he finally decide, in a surfeit of rage, to denounce their stealthy accommodation with Southern white supremacy. Douglass ended his remarkable life of public service in 1895 on his estate overlooking Washington, shaken but clinging fast to the conviction he had expressed several months earlier that "race, in the popular sense, is narrow; humanity is broad."
William S. McFeely, the Richard B. Russell Professor of American History at the University of Georgia, winner of a Pulitzer Prize for his biography of Ulysses S. Grant, achieves a detailed, finely written portrait of the imposing 19th-century leader in his biography, "Frederick Douglass." But Mr. McFeely's is ultimately a rather puzzling portrait as well.
Born into slavery in Talbot County on Maryland's Eastern Shore in 1818, Frederick Bailey (a patronymic believed to have derived from a Muslim ancestor named Belali Mohomet) knew little of his mother, Harriet, and nothing about his father except that he was white. He was shipped back and forth between masters in Baltimore and the Eastern Shore, of whom one was kind but most classically feckless, cruel or indifferent, sometimes all three. Somehow, Douglass's strong sense of himself survived. Making good his escape on the second try in September 1838, the 20-year-old (he thought he was 21) came out of slavery literate (thanks to the wife of one former owner), socially adroit, a skilled ship's caulker, and pledged to marry a devoted, dark-skinned woman he had met in Baltimore named Anna Murray -- free-born, illiterate and five years his senior.
With a new name (chosen from Walter Scott's "Lady of the Lake"), having settled in New Bedford, Mass., Frederick Douglass took a sudden, irreversible turn to celebrity on a Monday evening in August 1841. The place was a Quaker barn on Nantucket Island; the occasion, a meeting of the American Anti-Slavery Society, with William Lloyd Garrison and Wendell Phillips, among others, speaking. That single-minded audience might have cheered wildly simply because a black fugitive from bondage was able to speak, whether or not he spoke well. A reasonably articulate fugitive slave was just what the movement had long needed.
Douglass proved from that moment on to be an arresting orator, with a voice capable of marvelous modulation and of such power as to be able to blast into silence proslavery rowdies who often threatened to set upon abolitionist audiences in Ohio and Indiana backwaters. Growing in confidence, Douglass's independence of mind soon troubled white abolitionists, who urged him to stick to slavery anecdotes and leave the thinking to Garrison and Phillips. "Give us the facts," one of them commanded, "we will take care of the philosophizing" -- a racially charged incident Mr. McFeely apparently thinks too well known to comment upon.
The author moves engrossingly through the details of Douglass's early life, offering the fullest explanation to date of why it may be impossible to solve the mystery of Douglass's tangled paternity (although Thomas Auld, a former owner, remains the leading candidate). Other Douglass scholars have underscored the strong formative role of women in his life (until she was sold, Grandmother Betsy, along with the white surrogate mothers Lucretia Auld, the wife of Thomas Auld, and Sophie Auld, Lucretia's Baltimore sister-in-law), but Mr. McFeely has made vivid the connection between their furtive kindness and Douglass's precocious feminism. Douglass seems always to have been much more at ease with intelligent women than with men in the public sphere, perhaps because of his insecurities about paternity, professional standing and racial condescension -- insecurities masked by gracious regality but sometimes betrayed by sudden spleen.
Mr. McFeely clearly believes that psychology is as essential to biography as sex is to a good marriage. He serves up a lot of both sex and psychology, although sometimes with a speculative zest that, in a biographer less certified in his craft, might seem unwarranted. The alleged homosexuality of the infamous Eastern Shore "nigger-breaker" Edward Covey -- into whose clutches the young Frederick fell with fateful consequences -- seems forced. The recurrent speculation about the domestic tensions between Douglass and his wife also has an overwrought quality. In the matter of complexities of color in the marriage, Mr. McFeely may be off the mark in stating flatly that Douglass decided not to settle in England after his celebrated 1846 speaking tour because Anna and "his dark children could never be at home in this foreign country." Surely, other more compelling matters of service to what abolitionists called "the work" dictated Douglass's decision. Douglass's numerous friendships with white women also troubled contemporaries. But as Mr. McFeely wryly observes, "No self-respecting reform movement is complete without a scandal." Mr. McFeely legitimately places the burden on the reader to decide whether or not Julia Griffiths, the indispensable English helpmate on The North Star, and Ottilia Assing, the German social reformer who comforted him in Hoboken, were Douglass's lovers (Assing committed suicide when Douglass remarried).
Mr. McFeely portrays Douglass as cantankerous, excessively solicitous of his dignity and prone to equate the marginalized economic and political interest of the mass of African-Americans with his own vision of racial progress. Personalized in this manner, this biography veers away from the large sense of Douglass's life. "His dream, his fantasy," Mr. McFeely writes, "was that each person should be his or her own Moses and confront Pharaoh on equal terms." But what Mr. McFeely sees as Douglass's fantasy came from a profound belief in an evolving American democracy, one in which he saw his own private and public life to be representative and galvanizing.
To be sure, the principal characters, editorials, speeches, debates, policy decisions and public-service achievements are all there: Douglass at the historic 1843 Buffalo Convention of Colored Citizens, debating the wisdom of the "Call to Rebellion" issued by the fiery Henry Highland Garnet, a direct descendant of Mandingos; Douglass at the epochal 1848 women's rights convention in Seneca Falls, N.Y., applauding the feminist "Declaration of Sentiments," the only male present who endorsed Elizabeth Cady Stanton's female suffrage resolution; Douglass emerging stunned from a secret conference with John Brown in Chatham, Ontario, on the eve of the raid on Harpers Ferry; Douglass lamely explaining away President Ulysses S. Grant's failure to invite him to the White House with the other members of the commission to investigate annexation of the Dominican Republic. And the story of Douglass's beleaguered, yet not wholly ineffective, service as United States Minister to Haiti in 1889-91 -- with powerful New York shipping interests and an insufferable American admiral scheming to provoke an incident to force the cession of a base to the United States Navy -- has not before been as cogently related.
The relative absence, nevertheless, of the highs traditionally associated with this life, the muffling of the active voice of Douglass, is the result of Mr. McFeely's tendency to decouple Douglass from his race (there is little interaction with other African-Americans), to follow his progress through the eyes of white contemporaries and, finally, to measure his shortcomings by late 20th-century standards.
 An example of this may be found in the relating of Douglass's confrontation with the slave-breaker Edward Covey. After six months of regular beatings, the young Douglass finally resisted Covey's attempts to subdue him. "Whence came the daring spirit necessary to grapple with a man who, eight-and-forty hours before, could, with his slightest word have made me tremble like a leaf in a storm, I do not know; at any rate, I was resolved to fight," Douglass later wrote in "My Bondage and My Freedom."
Covey was humiliated. In relating the Homeric barnyard fight with the sadistic overseer from lecture platforms and in his three autobiographies, Douglass clearly intended it to serve as a powerful metaphor for the individual's struggle against tyranny. In the rolling periods of the mid-19th century, Douglass proclaimed that "he is whipped hardest who is whipped oftenest" -- that slavery was more fatal as a state of mind than as a physical predicament. But his moment of epiphany with Covey is not only rendered curiously flat dramatically, but Mr. McFeely reproaches Douglass for diminishing the role of ordinary black folk from the parable's significance. "In isolating himself in order to point the moral," Douglass downgraded the "heart of the story" -- that two other slaves had refused to help Covey (a point, moreover, Douglass did make).
The famous "Open Letter" to his former master Thomas Auld, in which Douglass presents a searing eight-page indictment of his Stygian life as a slave, leaves Mr. McFeely puzzled because of inaccuracies -- Auld's house was not an "elegant dwelling," nor did Auld turn out Grandmother Betsy "like an old horse to die in the woods." "But why," asks Mr. McFeely, "did he misrepresent Auld's actions?" This seems a stunning solecism on the part of Douglass's biographer, given the patent and potent propaganda intent of the "Open Letter."
This angle of vision derives from Mr. McFeely's conclusion that Frederick Douglass was a leader flawed by an unreasonable belief that exceptional ability and public service placed him above the common run of black people. Among the problematic results, then, is an insufficient sense of Douglass's white-hot anger upon discovering that his amiable white traveling companion during his 1846 British speaking tour had been given exclusive charge of their funds. As well, the sufficient cause is rather misplaced for Douglass's adamant opposition to the attempted subordination of the issue of Negro slavery to white working-class emancipation, or, after publicly making the common servitude connection in Britain, Douglass's refusal to pursue it. How Mr. McFeely can suppose that Douglass and most abolitionists could have embraced a labor philosophy at once repugnant to their upper-class supporters and fraudulently propounded by antebellum Southern sociologists is not clear.
By judging Douglass from the perspective of the 20th century, by seeing him as misguided for holding to the success ethic of "The Self-Made Man" (his favorite post-Civil War lecture), for embracing European culture (and a white second wife), for justifying American imperialism in Haiti, for pushing party politics at the expense of the black labor movement, and for dogmatically opposing outmigration of Southern black farmers, Mr. McFeely obscures the truth that Douglass's views were shared by much of the contemporary African-American leadership. Unlike many of them, Douglass spoke out against racial separatism until the end. Mr. McFeely illustrates the troubling incongruences in Douglass's private and public life by writing of a Washington social affair, "Never was . . . incongruence . . . better displayed than when Frederick Douglass went to Kate Chase Sprague's elegant place in the city to play croquet, while his son-in-law was in her employ as a stableman." It is a telling comment, indeed, about the society Douglass refused to lose faith in.
It was not because he was estranged from his people that Douglass behaved as he did. Rather, it was because the racial realities of his times increasingly mocked his statesmanship, ultimately leaving him, as they did other African-American leaders, with little more to fight with than an Enlightenment creed and exemplary personal dignity. The Great Frederick died in 1895, as Mr. McFeely notes, seven months before the Great Accommodator, Booker T. Washington, delivered his Atlanta Compromise address, in which the civil rights of African-Americans were bargained away for the chimerical prospect of economic advancement.

INDUSTRY: NAICS511130 BOOK PUBLISHERS (91%); SIC5192 BOOKS, PERIODICALS, & NEWSPAPERS (91%); SIC2732 BOOK PRINTING (91%); SIC2731 BOOKS: PUBLISHING, OR PUBLISHING & PRINTING (91%);

HEADLINE: How Manufacturers Increased Productivity

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"American Revival in Manufacturing Seen in U.S. Report" (front page, Feb. 5) states that the Commerce Department sees a revival of American manufacturing and attributes it to a "wrenching contraction of payrolls and plants." An important point has been overlooked. There has been an amazing increase in productivity, but it did not stem primarily from job cutbacks. Instead, it reflects aggressive actions by many manufacturers to re-engineer their businesses by:
* Simplifying and streamlining the flow of materials and information across entire enterprises.
* Speeding machine changeovers and setups, running small lots, reducing inventories, slashing product movement and improving quality.
* Breaking down "walls" between departments to foster a teamwork that does things right the first time.
* Integrating equipment, systems and people, so everyone has the right information at the right time to perform better.
* Responding faster to customers, in minutes, not hours, days or weeks.
These techniques have reduced inventories to the point where the customary inventory overhang is not present in this recession, making the United States economy better positioned for fast recovery.
You point out, correctly, that white-collar productivity is a drag on overall productivity. It's now time to apply to the office those business re-engineering principles that were so successfully applied in the factory in the 1980's.
 
WILLIAM G. STODDARD
New York, Feb. 6, 1991
 
The writer is a consultant specializing in manufacturing.

HEADLINE: Revival of Water Sports in New York City Deserves a Boost

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Roger Starr's "Reading History on Harbor Waves" (Editorial Notebook, Feb. 9) is a decorative though fragmented account of the past grandeur and hopeful revival of New York City's historic waterways. By contrast, a glimpse of New York City's waters as they are today shows that the steam towboats and floating grain elevators rotting in awesome maritime graveyards have been replaced by fleets of sleek racing shells, kayaks and canoes.
These water sports represent a growing recreational movement sprouting from the ashes of the last Victorian-era boathouses destroyed by arsonists and the misguided zeal of Robert Moses.
From the late 19th century to the early 20th, New York City was a mecca for water-sports enthusiasts, boasting as many as 31 boathouses in 1905. The hundreds of thousands of regatta spectators along its banks were displaced by the same economic hardships and social changes that forced the demise of the city's maritime-based industries.
Today, to participate in rowing, kayaking or canoeing in New York, you have to do your homework on and off the water. Organizations representing these sports have been lobbying city and state authorities for municipal facilities to serve as a base for providing low-cost access to these sports for city residents, particularly urban youth, and as a requisite for Mayor David N. Dinkins's appeal for an Olympic festival -- and eventually, the Olympic Games.
At the very least, we should be able to break upstate New York's monopoly on the Empire State Games. But with budgets at all-time lows, such visions seem further from reality, without alternative funding, for a city shamefully underusing its waterfront.
 
JAMES SCIALES
Flushing, Queens, Feb. 9, 1991

HEADLINE: Beef Producers Burdened by Growing Criticism

DATELINE: LOST CABIN, Wyo.

 BODY:
While modern cattle ranchers like Rob Hendry use helicopters and computers, much of their work is still done on horseback and by hand. That serves as a harsh reminder in this town where the temperature has hit 40 degrees below zero of how hard it still is to make money in the cattle busines.
But the extreme weather and constant manual labor do not bother Mr. Hendry, who raises about 2,000 cows and 100 bulls on 150,000 acres 70 miles west of Casper. He even shrugs off a decade of financial difficulties like low beef prices, high interest rates and the collapse of land values. 
 What most bothers Mr. Hendry now, as a businessman who is barely keeping his corporation profitable, are the growing attacks by doctors and environmentalists that have led to fundamental changes in his industry. Some of those changes, while wrenching, seem to be paying off, however, with beef prices making a comeback.
 
 Many Negative Attacks

"We've been attacked by any number of organizations," said the 33-year-old rancher, labeling many of them "just a back-door approach to get rid of the cattle industry" by "negative people."
Some of the harshest criticism came from a recent study linking red meat and animal fat to colon cancer.
"If you step back and look at the data," said Dr. Walter Willett, a Boston-based researcher who directed the study, "the optimum amount of red meat you should eat should be zero."
Health experts have also linked the fat and cholesterol in red meat to heart disease. The meat industry says such studies are inconclusive, and that they were done when beef contained more fat than it does today.
Even so, the accusations have hurt. "Per-capita consumption has been dropping for some time," said Bob Budd, executive vice president of the Wyoming Stock Growers Association. Americans ate an average of 68.9 pounds of beef in 1989, down from 94.5 pounds in 1976, American Meat Institute data show.
And while beef prices do not fluctuate wildly with bad news, as oil prices do, the decline in consumption has put pressure on prices, said Tom McDermott, vice president of information for the National Livestock and Meat Board in Chicago.
 
Balancing Supply and Demand
 Forced to respond, the beef industry has firmed up prices by shrinking production to bring supplies in line with demand. It is also raising leaner cattle in response to the health concerns. That is the case at Mr. Hendry's Clear Creek Cattle Company, which now produces leaner beef because it changed the type of bulls that are bred with cows.
Mr. Hendry is the third generation of his family to run the ranch, started by his Scottish immigrant grandfather in 1912. Today, the Hendry ranch consists of what was once nine separate spreads. It is a patchwork that stretches 50 miles by 36 miles at the furthest points, in a section of Wyoming where the outlaw Butch Cassidy once hid.
In addition to aggressively promoting leaner and healthier cuts of beef, producers are also financing industry efforts to promote beef consumption and to dispute health and environmental charges.
Four years ago, the Beef Industry Council started a multimillion-dollar promotional campaign featuring celebrities like Cybill Shepherd and James Garner. It has since been revised to feature inhabitants of towns like Paradise, Tex., and Manhattan, Mont., as illustrations that beef is "real food for real people."
 
Prices on the Rebound
 These efforts seem to be working. The price of a 500-pound calf, like those Mr. Hendry sells, had plunged by $78 between 1980 and 1986. But between 1986 and 1990, prices rose by $171, to $516 each, according to Cattle-Fax, a Denver-based industry research group.
In an average year, Mr. Hendry sells about 1,950 calves to feedlot operators that fatten them for slaughter. Buyers view the cows on videotape transmitted to some 900 sites nationwide via satellite. Winning bidders arrange for truck shipment. The current price is about $1 a pound. If it were to drop by just 10 cents a pound, Clear Creek would be in trouble.
For now, however, the ranch is making money. It operates as a corporation, paying Mr. Hendry just $850 a month for his labor. The corporation also owns and provides the ranch house he lives in rent-free, plus grocery money. If Clear Creek makes a profit, the money goes back into the business.
 
Environmental Pressures

Aside from the economic and medical pressure on beef producers, environmental concerns are beginning to have an influence. The National Wildlife Federation, an environmental group in Washington, has charged that overgrazing is a major cause of deteriorating productivity of Federal lands in 10 Western states. A 1989 report by the federation asserted that more than 68 percent of the 174 million acres held by the Bureau of Land Management were in unsatisfactory condition.
Critics also say ranchers pay too little to the Government to graze their herds on bureau lands. A move to increase grazing fees more than fivefold died in Congress last year.
These moves are especially threatening to Western ranches, like Clear Creek, which are often a patchwork of privately held and leased Federal land. In Clear Creek's case, about 66 percent is leased from the Federal Government.
 
Big Part of the Economy
 Pressure on the beef industry touches a large part of the economy. According to industry and Federal Government data, the nation's 1.3 million cattle operations grossed $36.7 billion in 1989. Meat packing and processing employed more than 225,000 people, and related industries use cattle byproducts to make shoes, candles, insulin, medical sutures, piano keys, glue and yogurt. And 50 percent of the country's corn production is used to fatten beef and other livestock.
In an industry that is perceived by many to embody basic American values, the attacks are especially difficult to stomach. A generation ago, ranchers were not under fire from anyone.
"That's all new," said Jim Hendry, 66, Rob's father. Like many Western businessmen, he sees himself building the West, not tearing it down. "We have no reason to hang our heads over what we have done," he said.

HEADLINE: Troubled Banks and the Role of the Press

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
On Jan. 4, The Boston Globe had a front-page article under the headline, "Damaging Loss Expected for Bank of New England." The newspaper reported that during the day the troubled bank would announce a large loss for the fourth quarter of 1990, which would effectively wipe out the equity of shareholders and make the bank insolvent. The Globe report was correct. The bank announced it would post a $450 million loss. The newspaper report led to a brief run on the bank. The run ended after the Government took over the bank on Sunday, two days later.
The Globe's part in the run on the Bank of New England, most analysts agree, was typical of the role played by the media in recent months in shaping public attitudes toward or confidence in many banks. Newspapers, magazines and television tend, as always, to be messengers of bad news when the news is bad. But the bankers do not seem to be blaming the messenger for their troubles. 
 There have been some cases of misleading and inaccurate reports. One case caused a brief run on the Old Stone Corporation, a banking company in Rhode Island. The run ocurred in late January after Cable News Network did a story on the closings of state-chartered banks and credit unions in Rhode Island, using an Old Stone bank branch as a backdrop. But unlike the 45 credit unions and banks in Rhode Island that were closed, Old Stone, which is federally insured, was not in trouble. CNN broadcast an apology a few days later for using the Old Stone footage.
In another case, a small Massachusetts bank, the Granite Cooperative Bank, experienced a rush of depositor withdrawals after The Boston Herald included the institution in a list of the 10 "worst banks" in the state, which the paper published on Jan. 8, based on a list provided by a bank-rating service in Massachusetts. The bank did not belong on the list, and The Herald printed a correction.
Yet Federal authorities are less concerned by factual mistakes, which they say are comparatively few, than by the interpretation of the news by reporters and editors, which they say can inordinately magnify public worries about the banking system. John LaWare, a governor of the Federal Reserve Board, cites the "temptation" in the press to draw parallels between the banks' problems and the savings and loan crisis. "I think that is dangerous," Mr. LaWare said. "We're far from having a general collapse of the banking system. It's nothing like the S.& L. situation."
Some press critics reply that the real weakness of the media's coverage of the banking crisis is that it has been too cautious and too late in detecting problems. "Reporters and editors have been so sensitized to bend over backward not to fan up a panic that we have paid a price for it," said Ellen Hume, executive director of the Shorenstein Barone Center on the Press, Politics and Public Policy at Harvard.
Ms. Hume and others do find what they consider disturbing journalistic similarities between the problems of the banking industry and the savings and loan debacle. In both cases, the press and Government regulators seem to have been too slow in recognizing the full extent of the problem. And in the banking crisis, as in the savings and loan crisis, a result could eventually be a higher cost to the American taxpayers.
"The press should be aggressively reporting these issues because they have a major impact on taxpayers," said James Barth, a professor at Auburn University and one author of a recent House Banking Committee study on the industry. "It is the Government's role to instill public confidence by demonstrating that they are on top of the problems of the banks and doing something about them."
