HEADLINE: Forecasters Projecting Rosy View

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
A majority of the nation's forecasters are insisting that the current recession will end by August, basing their optimism on the behavior of past recessions. By their own acknowledgment, however, the forecasters are playing down the special troubling features of this recession that could prove them wrong.
The big rise in stock prices in recent weeks has reinforced the forecasters' view that this recession, the ninth since World War II, will be among the shortest, lasting less than a year. Blue Chip Economic Indicators, which polls 50 prominent forecasters each month, shows that their consensus prediction in February is for healthy economic growth beginning in the third quarter -- assuming the Persian Gulf war ends by April 1. 
 "People are behaving as if there is something objective out there making the Dow Jones industrial average go up, but it's just animal spirits," said Paul Samuelson, the Nobel laureate in economic science. "The forecasters are taking the average length of the four mildest recessions since World War II and assigning it to this recession."
 
 A Different Kind of Recession

By sheer chance, the optimists may turn out to be correct. In fact, the consensus forecast has had an uncanny knack for predicting the beginning of past recoveries. But Mr. Samuelson and other economists contend that the outcome of this recession is harder than others to forecast -- and perhaps is unpredictable -- because it departs radically from the postwar norm in three main features: the huge quantities of unpaid bank loans, the resulting crisis for the nation's banks and the cutback in lending.
Economists say they do not know whether the lending cutback stems mainly from the reluctance of banks to lend and risk more problem loans or from the reluctance of consumers and businesses to borrow and spend during hard times. Whatever the dynamics, the economy cannot move from recession to recovery without a revival of lending and the increased spending that loans make possible.
"We know that the credit stringency problem exists, but it is nearly impossible to anticipate whether it is a major obstacle to recovery or a third-order problem," said Stephen McNees, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, who has studied forecasting trends.
 
Blind Spot Acknowledged

The nation's forecasters, acknowledging this blind spot, issue their forecasts anyway, saying in effect that they have no choice. Most are economists employed at brokerage houses, banks and corporations, and their forecasts are churned out for customers and top management. Investment and business decisions are hard to make without an educated guess about the economy's future, and the forecasters provide this service. The problem is that their widely published predictions help to shape not only a customer's view of the economy, but also the public's.
Edward Yardeni, chief economist at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., the investment house, is among the optimists, and his weekly forecasts are mailed to many in the media as well as to investors.
"My ultimate job is to forecast the economy's impact on the stock and bond markets, to help people make money," he said. "So far, I have stressed that the Federal Reserve is committed to getting us out of a recession by lowering interest rates, and that drives up stock prices.
"What I have not discussed is whether the Fed's commitment will work. If the Fed gets the Federal funds rate down to 5 percent and the economy is not only not improving but still deteriorating, then I'll switch my forecast and we'll get out of stocks. But I will have served my customers well."
 
Shifts in Federal Funds Rate

The Federal funds rate, the interest rate at which banks lend money to each other, determines the level of many other short-term rates, including interest rates for auto loans and many mortgages. The Fed has been reducing the funds rate by a quarter of a point at a time since last fall, and on Feb. 1 drove down the rate by half a percentage point, an unusually large amount, to its current level of about 6 percent.
"The thing that really turned the corner in terms of forecasting optimism was that Feb. 1 move by the Fed," said Stephen S. Roach, a senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company.
But some economists argue that even if interest rates get low enough to revive lending, the recession still might not end this summer, or even this year, for that matter. They cite problems like the weak real estate and construction markets, a sharp decline in consumer spending in recent weeks, and the growing budget deficit, which makes the Government unwilling to spend for public works and other projects that stimulate economic activity.
"My feeling is that the recession will be deeper and will last longer than the consensus forecast believes," said Edward S. Hyman Jr., a vice chairman of the investment house of C. J.Lawrence, Morgan Grenfell Inc.
 
 View of Bush Administration

By contrast, the consensus forecast, which is shared by the Bush Administration, draws heavily on past experience. The past teaches that recessions usually end when falling interest rates revive consumer spending and inventories of unsold goods are slim. Low inventories mean that when spending starts to grow again, production can be quickly stepped up and people rehired, without having to wait for stockpiled merchandise to be sold.
Consumer confidence also played a role in most of the eight other recessions since World War II, and the consensus forecast assumes that confidence will rebound once the Persian Gulf war ends. Surveys show that consumer confidence fell sharply after Iraq invaded Kuwait in August, and as confidence declined, so did spending. The consensus forecast also notes that exports have remained strong, helping to keep industrial production from falling too sharply.
Perhaps most important from the optimists' viewpoint, the recession will reach its first birthday in the third quarter, and that is roughly the average length of the eight previous recessions. Only two ran more than one year: the recessions of 1974-75 and 1981-82. Each lasted 16 months.
 
 Historical Argument Challenged
 But that does not mean this recession will parallel the earlier experiences, said Professor Robert Hall, a Stamford University economist. "There is no basis in historical experience for knowing how long or deep a recession will be," he continued. The art of forecasting often involves splitting the difference between expectations of a quick and vigorous upturn and a prolonged and severe recession, Professor Hall added.
Recessions usually require the gross national product, or the total value of newly produced goods and services, to shrink for at least six months. So far, the G.N.P. has contracted at an annual rate of 2.1 percent in the fourth quarter. The optimistic consensus forecast holds that the economy will shrink by a much smaller 1.3 percent in the current quarter and that by the second quarter growth will have risen to zero. In the third quarter, the recession will end as the G.N.P. expands at an annual rate of 2 percent, the optimists predict.
Whatever the guesswork involved, the consensus forecast has accurately pinpointed the beginning of past recoveries, said Robert Eggert, publisher of the Blue Chip survey of forecasters.
 
 Failure to Predict Recessions
 But the consensus view has been much less accurate in predicting the onset of a recession. The majority of the forecasters in the Blue Chip survey, for example, failed to recognize the 1981-82 recession until February of 1982 -- eight months after it had started -- although they accurately predicted that the recession would end in the fourth quarter of 1982. The same majority failed to recognize the current recession until October.
"The reason is that the economy's basic tendency is to expand, not to contract," said Saul Hymans, director of forecasting at the University of Michigan's Research Seminar in Quantitative Economics. "So you have a better reason for saying that a recession will end soon -- for paying attention to the average length of previous recessions -- than you do paying attention to the average length of expansions."

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Israel;
Israel Rules Out Palestinian Talks Until War Ends

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Feb. 17

 BODY:
Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said tonight that Israel would not be willing to discuss any new regional peace initiatives until the war in the Persian Gulf ended and the new order of the Middle East became clear.
In the meantime, he said, Israel needs billions of dollars in new economic assistance for the repair of damage caused by Iraqi missile attacks and for the resettlement of Soviet Jews. That money should be provided with no political strings attached, the Prime Minister added. 
 "I've never heard that the assistance of the United States for the absorption of the Soviet immigrants in Israel is conditioned on political steps we will take or not take," Mr. Shamir said in an address to visiting Jewish leaders. "It was not so in the past, and I hope very much that it will not change in the future."
The latest allotment of American financial aid, $400 million in loan guarantees for immigrant housing, is being held up, apparently because of Israel's policy of expanding Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.
 
U.S. Asks for Details
 Washington asked Israel to provide detailed information on settlement costs and plans before the guarantees would be issued, apparently to insure that no American money would find its way to the West Bank. Recently, the Government did turn over a report.
But last week, two opposition members of Parliament released a report of their own, quoting Housing Ministry figures, showing that the Shamir Government intended to increase the Jewish population in the West Bank and Gaza by 50 percent in the next three years with the construction of 12,000 housing units.
The Government report had not even hinted at such plans, and officials here said they were certain the legislators' report had angered the White House just when deliberations on the loan guarantees seemed to be concluding.
Then, late last week, Israel's Ambassador in Washington, Zalmon Shoval, complained that the United States was holding up the aid. For that he received an extraordinary, angry public rebuke from the State Department.
 
Levy to Visit Washington
 Today, the Foreign Ministry said Foreign Minster David Levy would visit Washington in the near future to try to straighten matters out.
In any case, Mr. Shamir said tonight, Israel needs money -- lots of it and soon. The missile attacks and the added military costs caused by the gulf war are costing Israel at least $3 billion, officials say.
Iraq fired two more missiles at Israel on Saturday night, the 14th attack since the war began Jan. 17. Iraq asserted today that the missiles had hit Israel's nuclear weapons plant at Dimona, in the Negev. The Israeli military said one of the missiles had fallen in the Negev but had caused no casualties or damage. Military censorship regulations prevent publication of the precise point of impact.

HEADLINE: WAR IN THE GULF: Soviet Union;
IRAQI AIDE ARRIVES FOR MOSCOW TALKS

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Monday, Feb. 18

 BODY:
The Iraqi Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, arrived early today for talks with Soviet leaders about Baghdad's highly conditional offer to discuss a withdrawal from Kuwait.
Soviet officials depict the talks as possibly Iraq's last chance to avert a ground war. 
 Mr. Aziz arrived here shortly after midnight and made no comment on the situation in the Persian Gulf. "I will talk to you if possible after our meetings with our Soviet friends," he told reporters after traveling from Baghdad via Iran.
The visit by Mr. Aziz has become the focus of intense interest in the Soviet Union and abroad since Friday, when the Iraqi leadership issued its statement about Kuwait.
Western leaders of the alliance fighting Iraq in the gulf rejected the proposal as a propaganda tactic, while Moscow suggested that it might contain elements that could be shaped into a political settlement.
 
Visit Seen as Last Chance
 All sides agree that whatever elaboration Mr. Aziz brings will probably be Iraq's last chance to avert a ground assault by the United States-led forces. Western leaders have insisted that Iraq can stop the war only by withdrawing unconditionally from Kuwait.
Soviet leaders and spokesmen made no new comments on the gulf today, but the suspense over the Aziz visit was evident in commentaries like one by Georgy Shmelev of Tass, the official press agency, who wrote on Sunday: "The forthcoming negotiations hold a special significance for the world. Some observers even believe that they are 'the last chance,' 'the last effort' to forestall an all-out war in the Persian Gulf."
In their talks with Mr. Aziz today, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Foreign Minister Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh hope to discern whether Iraq's statement on Friday represented an opening bid to end a war that has already inflicted heavy damage on the Iraqi military and economy.
The Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman, Vitaly L. Churkin, said on Saturday that the Iraqi offer as it stood was burdened with conditions that "could render it meaningless." The conditions included demands that all foreign forces withdraw from the gulf, that Israel withdraw from occupied Arab lands and that Iraq be paid compensation for war damage.
But Mr. Churkin said the main point from the Soviet standpoint was that the Iraqi leadership had publicly spoken for the first time of withdrawing from Kuwait. "We hope that this announcement can become the starting point for peace, and will not be fruitless," Mr. Churkin said.
 
Insist Iraq Accept Resolutions
 Since launching their latest mediating effort a week ago, the Soviet Union has steadfastly insisted that Baghdad adhere to the United Nations resolutions demanding an unconditional Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, and Mr. Churkin emphasized that this would be made clear to Mr. Aziz.
That position has prevented estrangement between the Soviet Union and the Western powers. Representatives of the European Community welcomed the Soviet diplomatic initiative after meeting on Saturday with Mr. Gorbachev.
Moscow's effort has also included talks between Soviet leaders and the Foreign Ministers of France, Iran and Kuwait, and Mr. Bessmertnykh has had telephone conversations with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and other members of the anti-Iraq coalition. Reports from Washington said Mr. Gorbachev also had written to President Bush.
The Soviet effort is thought to derive from several motives. Chief among them is a general alarm over the possibility of a massive ground war near the Soviet Union's southern border. On the domestic front, opposition to the war has become a rallying cause for the military and the newly invigorated conservative forces, and Kremlin leaders also fear that a prolonged conflict could fan passions in the large Muslim populations of the Soviet Union.
The Kremlin is also thought to hope that even if the current mediating effort fails, it will help boost Moscow's standing in the Arab world.

HEADLINE: Small Business Adapts to Lean Times

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
When Richard Mecaskey bought the Reliable Auto Paint and Supply Company last April, the former steel company executive figured that his new venture in the Cleveland suburb of Maple Heights was recession-proof. The tougher things get, he was told, the more inclined people would be to take their cars to the repair shops, like those served by Reliable, instead of buying new ones.
It has not worked out that way. Not only are consumers holding back on new purchases, but renovations and repairs are being put off, and those that are being done are frequently paid for more slowly. One result is that the small businesses on the economic frontline are shifting at least some of their woes to companies like Mr. Mecaskey's by falling behind on payments for supplies or services. 
 In response, Reliable is greatly reducing inventories, working overtime to find new customers, hounding its clientele to pay more promptly, and generally, in Mr. Mecaskey's anxious assessment, eking out a "hand to mouth" existence.
Economists have more anecdotes than statistics, but they suspect that experiences like Mr. Mecaskey's might be afflicting many more small businesses than in the recession of the early 1980's. That recession was notable for its effect on big manufacturers, particularly those competing with large European and Japanese companies helped by a strong dollar. This time, collapsing real estate prices and regulatory pressures on the nation's banks make life much more difficult for smaller concerns.
"The small-businessmen's primary financing options -- bank loans based on their business prospects and home mortgages based on the value of their homes -- have been shut down," said Roger Brinner, chief economist at DRI/McGraw Hill Inc. in Lexington, Mass. He said the impact has been clearly measurable in the construction sector, where DRI's computer models attribute a 25 percent drop in housing activity to a lack of financing.
Retailing and other segments of the service economy that have also been small-business bastions appear to be experiencing hard times far more than in the early stages of the previous recession.
"The current recession is having much more effect in areas where small businesses dominate," said Thomas A. Gray, chief economist for the Small Business Administration.
Economists caution that it is difficult to verify such assertions or, if they are true, to make useful projections based on them about the economic outlook. Small businesses are by their very nature tough for researchers to accumulate data on, and few academics study them.
 
 One-Third of the Work Force
 It is estimated that more than a third of the nation's workers are employed by businesses with fewer than 100 employees and that 15 million businesses have five or fewer employees. Small companies supply products and services to every major industry and are often also the primary distribution channel for multinational corporations.
In general, economists say, small companies in those segments of the economy affected by a recession contract more quickly than bigger ones, but small businesses rebound sooner once a recovery begins.
Most experts assume that small businesses are more prone to cash-flow problems in tough times because of the more informal nature of their operations.
"Smaller business people tend to have more personal relationships with their customers," said Tim Andrews, president of CPA Affiliates Inc., a network of accountants in Ohio. "They often have trouble refusing to extend credit because it's hard to take off the personal hat and put on the business one."
That has been the experience of Thomas Green Jr., who runs a consumer electronics sales and repair shop in the small Northern California mountain community of Chester.
As new-equipment sales have slowed and customers have delayed picking up VCR's and other devices left with him for repair, Mr. Green has taken a number of belt-tightening steps. He has pared the number of new televisions he stocks from 15 to 3, has switched his advertising in the local newspaper from displays to small classified notices, and has charged supplies on his Mastercard instead of paying immediately to conserve cash.
Mr. Green said he had even gone to small claims court to deal with a friend who had "developed amnesia" about his bill. But he is reluctant to sell equipment brought in for repairs that has become long overdue on being picked up. "I don't want that kind of reputation," he said.
Even small businesses for which demand remains steady have run into problems in the recession as their customers slow down payments.
J. R. Dietl, owner of Medical Repair Specialists Inc. in Tulsa, Okla., said that he had many customers asking him to repair ambulance equipment, but that many had been unable to stick to his 30-day payment terms. With numerous municipal accounts falling up to 90 days behind, he has begun to demand that private customers pay cash on delivery, slowed down paying some of his bills and laid off one of two office workers.
"The farther away customers are, the slower they are to pay," Mr. Dietl said. "They figure we can't afford to come after them."
Super Millwork Inc., a Long Island window distributor with annual sales of about $20 million that has laid off about 20 percent of its work force, has taken a tough stance in credit negotiations with new customers, said Sanford M. Lavitt, the majority owner and president.
"A big percentage of our customers are 30 days late or more in paying, but we have to pay our window suppliers before they will deliver," Mr. Lavitt said. "We have become bankers, which isn't easy. All of our competitors are in the same boat."
The real estate slump has played a critical role in lenders' reluctance to lend. Small-business owners are far more likely than large corporations to rely on real estate as collateral for bank loans. In areas like the Northeast, where real estate prices have fallen most sharply, banks are reluctant to extend new loans to even healthy small businesses.
 
Surveys on Credit Trends
 So far, the widely followed monthly surveys of the National Federation of Independent Business, a Washington-based group with 500,000 small-business members, show just 12 percent have reported that credit has tightened in the last three months, about a third the number that reported problems in the last recession. But those figures may be deceptive. The survey also shows that fewer than ever are borrowing from banks.
Signs are also apparent that many are seeking financing in other ways. The National Association of Purchasing Management in McLean, Va., for instance, found that some members were getting requests from their smaller suppliers for advance payments or other financial support.
Some small-business executives say that one of their problems in a recession is that they lack the influence to drive hard bargains with big suppliers or customers.
But such a claim is hard to prove. Melchior, Armstrong, Dessau Inc., a wholesaler of heating, ventilating, and refrigeration equipment in Ridgefield, N.J., says it has sought to stretch out payments to small suppliers because larger companies would cut it off if payments were missed.
But for every company like Melchior, Armstrong, there are those like Mr. Mecaskey's that have found big businesses to be supportive.
"We have been candid and they have been cooperative," Mr. Mecaskey said of paint and solvent suppliers like Du Pont and PPG Industries.
 
 Dealing With Big Accounts

"A lot of companies are actually more likely to pay off small businesses," said Robert Bretz, a purchasing manager for Pitney Bowes Inc. who oversees the monthly survey of business conditions for the purchaers' group. "If you have a cash-flow problem, you would prefer to handle it by dealing with one or two big accounts than hundreds of little ones. Who wants all those phone calls?"
Surveys in November and December by the National Federation of Independent Business, the small-business advocacy group, found that its members' optimism had fallen to its lowest point since 1980.
In another survey, by the Small Business Service Bureau, an organization in Worcester, Mass., whose 35,000 members all have 10 or fewer employees, one in three small businesses expect sales to fall this year, up from one in eight five years ago.

AtMr. Mecaskey's Reliable Auto Paint and Supply Company in a suburb of Cleveland, John Wrona, left, mixed special paint orders for customers. (Barney Taxel for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Deadly Fire in Connecticut Is Attributed to Heater Cord

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW BRITAIN, Conn., Feb. 17

 BODY:
Luis Soto shook his head in dismay this morning as he gazed up at the charred skeleton of a three-story, three-family house where 10 people, including five young children, perished in a fast-burning fire early Saturday.
"It was so quick -- it was unbelievable," said Mr. Soto, who lives across the street from the gutted brick-and-wood home, which is in a low-income neighborhood near downtown in this central Connecticut city, about 10 miles southwest of Hartford. "I've never seen a house go up that fast." 
 Fire officials said today that an overheated extension cord on an electric space heater caused the blaze, the most deadly in Connecticut since 14 people were killed in two Waterbury apartment buildings in 1982.
Fire Chief Thomas D. Keough also said that because of a "considerable delay" in calling in the alarm, firefighters faced a building entirely engulfed in flames when they arrived at the fire at 6 Erwin Place. "It was more than a couple of minutes," he said.
 
New in the Neighborhood
 Hector Ortiz, the executive director of Communidad En Accion, a local housing development agency, said the victims belonged to two families, and that five of them were children under the age of 5.
The Office of the Chief Medical Examiner in Farmington has not released the identities of the victims, pending notification of next of kin. A spokesman for the office said autopsies showed that all 10 had died from smoke inhalation.
Santos Ayala, who lives next door to the apartment building, said two Hispanic families had moved in during the last few months but little was known about them. "They were considered new people here," he said.
The fire was reported about 2:45 A.M. Firefighters arrived about one minute later, but did not have the blaze under control until about 5 A.M.
The victims were found on the second and third floors. Seven people who lived on the first floor and one person who lived on the second floor escaped.
"Fire was coming out all the windows," Mr. Soto said. "People were screaming. One guy came running out, yelling, 'Help me! My family is in there!' "
Firefighters, working in near-zero temperatures, were initially blocked from entering the building by extreme heat and flames, Chief Keough said. Several firefighters suffered minor injuries.
 
A Portable Heater
 The Chief said the fire started on the first floor, spread up the front and rear stairwells and caused the roof to collapse. He said an extension cord connected to a portable electric heater on the first floor overheated, causing its insulation to melt and ignite a chair.
The Chief said it did not appear that the cord was defective, but that it was too small to carry the heater's charge. He warned that extension cords should not be used with many portable room heaters.
Tenants and the landlord both told firefighters that the house was equipped with smoke alarms. Chief Keough said the building used a gas-stove heating system, which is legal. He added, though, that no such system appeared to exist on the first floor.
He said no decision had been made about citing possible fire-code or housing-code violations.
 
Collecting Donations
 Communidad En Accion, the development agency, held prayer services outside the home today. The group also established a fund to help pay for the victims' funerals. About $1,100 had been collected by this afternoon.
Mr. Ortiz, the agency's director, said: "They may not have been well known, but for the Puerto Rican community this is very sad. This is our first major tragedy. We are very moved by it."
New Britain, a city with about 73,000 residents, has a fast-growing Hispanic community. Census figures place the number of Hispanic residents at about 12,000; local Hispanic leaders said the number is closer to 15,000.
The city has also received some national recognition because it is featured in advertisements for Stanley Works, a local tool maker, reflecting what the company sees as New Britain's reputation as a charming, hard-working New England town.
But Alderman Peter M. Rosa said such an all-American image is largely illusory in light of the city's growing urban problems and the declining role of manufacturing. He said the fire may help to highlight inadequate housing and other social and economic ills in the city's Hispanic community. "This is a tragedy and a shock to everyone," he said.

HEADLINE: Georgia, Powerhouse for Two Decades, Winds Down

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Feb. 17

 BODY:
In the 1970's and 1980's, Georgia was a centerpiece of the South's economic boom. Today it is mired in recession.
Nowhere is the trouble more evident than in Atlanta, the engine that drives the state's economy. As Georgia and the South grew into economic powerhouses, Atlanta became the region's capital, a center for airlines, telecommunications, distribution and insurance. But this year, economic forecasters say, the metropolitan area will lose jobs for the first time since 1974: 5,800 jobs this year, two-thirds of the total loss for the entire state. 
 "The Atlanta area is struggling," said Donald Ratajczak, director of the Economic Forecasting Center of Georgia State University here, "and there is no way we can avoid the word recesssion for the state and the city." But he predicted that the state and city would begin to recover late in 1991.
Until last month Mr. Ratajczak and other forecasters had generally been more optimistic about the region's prospects. He said he believed that Atlanta, with its economy based on the service industry and with the second-largest proportion of white-collar jobs in the nation after Washington, could have avoided a recession.
 
The Effect of Eastern
 Then, in the middle of January, came the demise of Eastern Airlines, one of two carriers that used Hartsfield International Airport here as a regional center of operations. (The other is Delta Air Lines.)
Eastern's closure meant the initial loss of 10,000 jobs, said John Braden, a spokesman for the airport, when one takes into consideration concessions, suppliers and commuter airlines that fed passengers into Eastern's base here. But not all those jobs will be lost permanently.
"All of the indicators from construction activity to retail sales were weak," Mr. Ratajczak said, "but we could have avoided a recession had it not been for the closing of Eastern Airlines. The loss of a second airline hub at Hartsfield has tilted the Atlanta economy into recession."
Concourse C at Hartsfield, with its lights dim, looks like a ghost town. When the concourse was a bustling crossroad for travelers, the airport logged 2,200 takeoffs and landings a day. With the loss of Eastern and the end of many commuter flights feeding the Eastern network, the number is down to 1,172.
 
Advantages Disappear
 Georgia's problems partly reflect those of the entire Southeast. In a recent analysis, the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta said the region is tending to lose the advantages, like inexpensive labor and growing population, that it enjoyed in the last two decades.
Sheila Tschinkel, senior vice president of research for the bank, said the Southeast had matured economically and become more urban. Many parts of it may not actually be declining now, she said, but they are not growing as much as they used to.
In the past, she said, the region grew sharply as people moved in. But now, as job opportunities decline, fewer people are coming and the bill for the increased public services required by the past growth is coming due.
 
Bad News Abounds
 The figures on job growth come on the heels of bad news on other fronts like real estate and automobile sales.
Ron Harris, general sales manager of Banner Ford here, said that while his business was decent it was a constant battle to stay positive amid the torrent of bad economic news.
"Employees have to get their heads right every day," said Mr. Harris as he stood nearly alone in his showroom on a rainy Sunday afternoon. "We can't control much else when it comes to the economy, but we can control our attitudes, and no one who comes in that door is going to buy a car from a guy who acts like he's beaten down by the economic news."
His dealership had cut back on advertising, Mr. Harris said, but had trimmed inventories only slightly, because "you can't sell from an empty wagon."
 
Home Buyers Hold Back
 Jim Thibadeau, a real estate broker and developer whose family-owned business builds houses here, said customer visits to some of the company's developments had been up in recent weeks, but "buyers are still holding back."
Mr. Thibadeau said he, like many other developers, was laying off workers and taking steps to reduce overhead. But he said he had found a tenant to sublet some of its office space.
In the Southeast, as in other regions, nearly all the states are seeing a decline in retail sales and sales tax receipts. Some states are cutting spending to avoid raising taxes; others are finding new taxes impossible to avoid. In Tennessee last week Gov. Ned McWherter, a Democrat, announced he would seek imposition of the state's first income tax to finance long-planned improvements in education.
 
Promises Are Delayed
 Such "important social commitments" are on the agendas of many states in the region, said Ms. Tschinkel of the Federal Reserve Bank, but most had planned to finance them out of normal growth or through methods like state lotteries.
Fulfillment of campaign promises has also been put off. Georgia's new Governor, Zell Miller, a Democrat, had promised to eliminate the sales tax on groceries, but Dr. Henry Thomassen, the state's chief economist, said last week it had become clear that the move would have to be delayed and phased in over time. The tax brings in about $340 million a year.
Most Southern states are not experiencing the same level of job losses in manufacturing and the service industry as is Georgia, or the same recession in real estate. Arkansas, for example, projects that its economy will grow by nearly 3 percent, thanks largely to a growing food-processing industry and several other manufacturing areas that are benefiting from increased exports.
"We've felt the recession mostly in the form of lower retail sales," said Joe LaFace, chief economist for the Arkansas Department of Finance and Administration. "But generally we are doing well."
Georgia and Atlanta's drift into recession comes, paradoxically, at a time when the city is looking forward to a boom from the 1996 Summer Olympics and the accompanying development.
"Being designated at an Oympics city was expected to enhance Atlanta's stature," Mr. Ratajczak said. "Now it may restore it."

HEADLINE: Some Reservists' Families Face a Financial Siege

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME

 BODY:
While some reservists called to active duty worry about sun, sand, bullets and bombs, many of the families back home are fighting battles of their own.
"I'm embarrassed to be around my in-laws because of all the money I've borrowed," said Isabel Cranston, a 30-year-old mother of three in Charlotte, N.C., whose husband, Gary, left his $2,500-a-month job with USAir when he was called to active duty in the Air Force Reserves. 
Mr. Cranston's monthly paycheck as an enlisted man is $1,800. Since he was called up, Mrs. Cranston has seen two credit cards canceled and has had to borrow from relatives. "Right now," she said, "I've got six diapers left. I'm hoping they'll last until payday."
While not unsympathetic to such problems, military officials say that all reservists are aware when they sign up that they can be called to active duty, and that Government programs cushion the impact for military families.
 
'Like Becoming Unemployed'
 Many families report no financial difficulty from the call to active duty, and military officials point out that all benefited from the extra income their part-time reserve duty provided before their call to active duty. Income from part-time reserve duty varies widely, depending on rank, but can easily total several thousand dollars a year.
But many of the 215,000 reservists called to active duty face financial strains that are a concern not just for them but for the military, which has made the reserves an integral part of the all-volunteer armed services.
"For many of these people, being called up is like becoming unemployed," said Luther R. Gatling, president of Budget and Credit Counseling Services, a nationwide organization.
 
'On Prayers and Hope'
 For some families, the impact has been traumatic.
Neal Satterwhite, a 44-year-old nurse in Chapel Hill, N.C., was called up for Army reserve duty in December and is now in the Persian Gulf. Administrative problems in getting any of his checks sent home and health problems at home have left his wife, Daisy, and three children reeling.
"We didn't make a lot of money, but we were comfortable," Mrs. Satterwhite said. "I had never been in a position before where I had to ask for money. We were down to nothing, just living on prayers and hope. My aunt brought me some food, and a woman at my church brought over some chicken. It's been a lot to deal with."
Some corporations either continue or supplement lost wages. But those who are self-employed or own their own businesses have no such relief.
 
A Dentist Adjusts
 Mr. Gatling, the credit counselor, said reservists tended to be older, better educated, and with more financial responsiblities than those on full-time military duty. Many are professionals with offices and businesses to maintain and major debts to pay off.
A year ago, after nine years in a partnership, George Priest, an Atlanta dentist, set up his own practice. Since his call-up, he still has to pay the $3,000 monthly rent on his office and other expenses. A salaried associate has been taken on to see patients. Dr. Priest, who was recently transferred to Fort Benning in Columbus, Ga., is now able to see patients on Saturdays.
But the income is less than half the $27,000 a month the practice generated. "The money coming in isn't enough to pay the bills," said Dr. Priest's wife, Sharon, mother of a 22-month-old son. "I've thought of getting a job, but especially with child care, what I could bring in would be insignificant compared to the bills we have to pay."
 
Cutting Back on Everything
 Most families are saving where they can. For Jo Beadling of Carver, Mass., and her three children, house rules now include no new clothes, no eating out and no heat on warmer winter days.
"You try to cut back, but with three kids, it's not as easy as it sounds," said Mrs. Beadling, whose husband, Keith, a freelance craftsman, is now a staff sergeant with the Army National Guard's 1058th Transportation Company in Saudi Arabia.
Military officials say they do not believe severe financial distress is widespread. "I hear sporadic reports of financial problems, but I haven't seen anything that indicates many people are really being pummeled," said Maj, Bill Maddox, a spokesman for the Office of the Chief Army Reserves.
Much of the financial impact is blunted by laws like the Soldiers' and Sailors' Relief Act of 1940, which provides for a 6 percent cap on any previously incurred interest payments by reservists and offers protections against hasty evictions or foreclosures. And Congress is considering several bills to provide them protection from creditors and loans.
 
Most Creditors Are Helpful
 Military officials say most creditors have been sympathetic. "Of those creditors that I've talked with, and I've probably talked with a couple of hundred over the last few months, I have not had any that were not very, very willing to cooperate," said Col. Andrew Vanore, the judge advocate for the North Carolina National Guard.
Many military families say support groups, neighbors and local organizations have helped them.
Three weeks after Michael T. St. Amour, a 35-year-old technician from Milton, Vt., was sent to Saudi Arabia as a member of the 131st Engineers Combat Support Company, the family's trailer was gutted in a fire.
Since then, his insurance company has reimbursed him $32,000 for the trailer and $4,800 for living expenses until the family can settle into a new home. The Vermont National Guard took up a $1,000 collection for him, and other groups have raised amounts ranging from $400 to $25.
"Everybody out there is being supportive," said Mr. St. Amour, who got an emergency leave to deal with the problems at home and was scheduled to return to Saudi Arabia this weekend.
For some families, help from support groups and the resolution of administrative difficulties have solved the most pressing problems. Mrs. Satterwhite said she was expecting her husband's check within a week.
For most, however, problems are likely to mount. Beverly Ashby of Charleston, S.C., said that because of days off her husband accumulated over the years she had been getting his old salary since his Air Force Reserve unit was called up. That will last until April. After that, she may have to pull her daughter from her private school.
"I'm looking at a salary being almost cut in half," she said. "We would basically be living by the skin of our teeth."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Families of reservists called to active duty often struggle financially. "You try to cut back, but with three kids, it's not as easy as it sounds," said Jo Beadling, at home in Carver, Mass., with two of her children, Melissa and Adam. Her husband, Keith, is a staff sergeant serving in Saudi Arabia. (Rick Friedman/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: MEDICAID IS DENIED DISCOUNTED DRUGS DESPITE A NEW LAW

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17

 BODY:
Congress recently passed a law requiring drug companies to give Medicaid the same deep discounts they give other big customers. But instead of reducing Medicaid drug prices, many companies are now raising the prices that those other big customers must pay.
For two decades, Medicaid, the Federal-state health program for poor people, has paid more for prescription drugs than other large buyers, like government and private health groups, which have negotiated discounts of 25 percent to 60 percent or more from the usual wholesale prices. 
 Until last year, the Government did not demand such discounts because Federal Medicaid officials did not focus much on the cost of drugs and drug companies argued that their prices were justified by the high costs of research.
 
Industry Opposed Legislation
 Under the law, which was passed over objections from the drug industry and took effect on Jan. 1, drug makers must offer state Medicaid programs the lowest price available to any buyer in the market.
Now drug companies are increasing prices to some of those other buyers, including the Department of Veterans Affairs, prepaid health plans like the giant Kaiser Permanente group, hospitals, family planning clinics and community health centers for migrant workers, homeless people and the indigent. Health care experts say these added costs may soon trickle down to consumers in the form of higher medical costs, and ultimately, insurance premiums.
In October, the Congressional Budget Office estimated that the Medicaid discounts would save $1.9 billion for the Federal Government and $1.4 billion for the states over five years. Assuming that such savings would be achieved, Congress substantially expanded Medicaid benefits for pregnant women, children and frail elderly people.
 
Backers Voice Objections
 Supporters of the 1990 legislation are furious about the drug companies' move. The chief sponsor, Senator David Pryor, Democrat of Arkansas, chairman of the Special Committee on Aging, said the price increases appeared to be "an attempt to circumvent the new Medicaid law," shift costs and nullify the savings envisioned by Congress.
Representative Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, acknowledged that the price increases were legal, but he added: "This is a very foolish move by drug companies. It will be seen as a transparent attempt to get around the intent of Congress."
In opposing the legislation, the drug industry termed it a violation of "free market principles" and warned that it would disrupt the market. Jeffrey C. Warren, vice president of the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, said its 100 member companies "make their own decisions about prices and do not talk among themselves about the effects of the new Medicaid drug law on individual companies because such discussions could raise substantial antitrust issues."
 
Changes Termed 'Logical'
 But a lobbyist for the drug industry, who would speak only on the condition of anonymity, said: "We are surprised that Senator Pryor is surprised. I don't know what else he would have expected. It's logical that companies would re-examine their prices if Congress passes a law saying that Medicaid, which accounts for about 10 percent of our revenues, must get the best price given to any pharmaceutical customer in the country."
More than 16 million people, about two-thirds of all Medicaid recipients, get drugs through the Medicaid program each year. Medicaid spent $3.7 billion on drugs in 1989, or $280 million more than it spent for doctors' services.
Medicaid benefits vary from state to state. All states pay for all or most costs of prescription drugs for Medicaid recipients. Many also pay for a few selected over-the-counter medications when bought on written instructions from a doctor.
In the 1980's, Medicaid's spending for drugs increased faster than its payments for inpatient hospital care, nursing homes, doctors or dentists. Data from the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics show that prescription drug prices rose an average of 9.6 percent a year in the last decade, while the Consumer Price Index for all items rose an average of 4.5 percent a year.
Drug companies say the increase in prices reflects the increased costs of developing new medicines as researchers use more complex technology and focus on chronic diseases requiring long clinical studies.
 
Savings on Several Fronts
 Congress ordered the discounts in an effort to control Medicaid costs after concluding that drug companies had not been forced to make any significant contribution to reducing the Federal budget deficit. Over the last 10 years, lawmakers repeatedly squeezed savings out of Medicaid and Medicare beneficiaries, hospitals and doctors.
The Department of Veterans Affairs, which pays some of the lowest prices in the country for the drugs used at its 172 hospitals, says the latest price increases come on top of the usual inflation.
John E. Ogden, director of pharmacy services for the department, said drug company representatives had told him the price increases were a response to the new Medicaid law.
The veterans agency spends $700 million a year on drugs and in the past has negotiated discounts as big as 90 percent for some items.
The Du Pont Merck Pharmaceutical Company, a joint venture of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company and Merck & Company Inc., recently sent letters to customers announcing that it had discontinued discounts for hospitals on large bottles of five drugs for outpatient use: Coumadin, Ethmozine, Percocet, Percodan and Sinemet. The letters did not give a reason for the action, but said discounts would still be allowed on tablets sold in single-dose packages for hospital patients.
Hospital pharmacists say Du Pont employees told them the requirement for Medicaid discounts was a factor in the new prices.
But Joseph F. Boudreau, director of sales operations for the company, denied that the move away from large-volume discounts was a result of the Medicaid law, saying instead that it reflected the company's new preference for "a one-price policy."
 
Contracts Being Reassessed
 Officials of Kaiser Permanente, the nation's biggest health maintenance organization, with 6.5 million members, say that drug companies are suddenly trying to renegotiate multiyear contracts and raise prices.
Daniel D. Danzig, a spokesman for Kaiser, said the moves were "clearly related to the new law," because drug companies did not want to have to offer Medicaid discounts. Mr. Danzig said Kaiser, which spends $500 million a year on drugs, feared that the increase in drug prices would force higher ipremiums for its members.
Officials of Kaiser and several other health-care organizations said they would resist the drug price increases. If they retained their discounts, Medicaid would be entitled to similar discounts on certain drugs for at least a few months. But as contracts expire or are renegotiated, drug prices would rise for both private buyers and Medicaid programs. Under the law, the best or lowest price for each drug is calculated four times a year.
Health maintenance organizations provide a comprehensive set of medical benefits to their members in return for flat monthly fees. Leslie Rose, chief lobbyist for the Group Health Association of America, which represents the organizations, said: "The reports we hear from H.M.O.'s across the country are really disturbing. They are being told by drug companies that the days of discounts are over, that drug prices will be raised. Clearly, this is an unintended effect of the new law."
 
Action Came Within Weeks
 Jose E. Camacho, executive director of the Texas Association of Community Health Centers, said that within weeks of passage of the Medicaid law 7 to 10 drug companies began trying to renegotiate the discount-price contracts for his organization, which buys drugs for 31 clinics serving 250,000 patients a year.
The clinics care for migrant workers, homeless people and others who have neither Medicaid nor private health insurance. In the past, Mr. Camacho said, such clinics have negotiated discounts averaging 40 percent below the wholesale price for brand name prescription drugs.
Officials of family planning clinics say they have been told by some drug companies that they should expect higher prices for oral contraceptives. Hoping to build brand loyalty as well as encourage family planning, drug companies typically offer such pills to clinics at a fraction of the list price.
Gerald F. Radke, director of the Pennsylvania Medicaid program, said that drug companies, in increasing prices, "may meet the letter of the law, but certainly do not meet the spirit of the legislation."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The run on the Bank of New England was worrisome, but panic eased when the F.D.I.C. took over. The lesson is that a modern-day bank run is containable because of Federal deposit insurance. The situation is far different from Depression-era runs that wiped out the life savings of millions. [Page 1.] The press has played an important role in recent months in shaping public confidence in many banks and attitudes toward the banking industry. [33.]
A majority of forecasters insist that the recession will end by August, basing their optimism on the behavior of past recessions and big recent rises in stock prices. By their own admission, however, they are playing down troubling features of this recession that could prove them wrong. [29.]
A new law requires drug companies to give Medicaid the same deep discounts they give other big customers. But instead of reducing Medicaid drug prices, many companies are raising the prices that other big customers must pay. Health-care experts say these added costs may soon trickle down to consumers in the form of higher medical costs, and ultimately, insurance premiums. [1.]
The problems of domestic auto makers are being aggravated by a decline in the sales of some of its most profitable products: full-size pickup trucks and vans. Sales of light trucks, which include pickup trucks, vans and sports-utility vehicles, declined 7 percent in the fourth quarter, while car sales rose 1 percent. [29.]
Some small companies that thought they were recession-resistant a finding they are not. Not only are consumers holding back on new purchases, but goods and services bought are frequently paid for more slowly. [29.]
A California company is proposing what may be the ultimate wilderness experience for those who think they are roughing it when they peer at mountains and canyons through the windshield of a car: viewing a magnificent film about Zion National Park on a giant wrap-around movie screen, without ever having to set foot in the park. [1.]
The Atlanta metropolitan area is expected to lose jobs this year for the first time since 1974. The demise of Eastern Airlines may have struck the final blow to the optimism of the city, the engine that drives Georgia's economy. [10.]
Cattle ranchers say they face bigger challenges than the extreme weather of places like Wyoming, the constant hard work and even weak beef prices. What bothers some of them the most, they say, are growing attacks on their products from the medical community and environmentalists. [32.]
 
 The Media Business
Young & Rubicam is trying to regain the edge it held in the creative revolution of the 1960's. To that end, the agency has hired an outsider to head its New York creative department, which suffers from an image of making lackluster ads. [29.]
NBC is in the middle of a high-stakes game of programming poker as it tries to extend the lives of aging hit comedies. Even winning the game will cost NBC a potful of money; the producers of "Cheers," for example, are reportedly seeking $4 million an episode. But losing could end NBC's ratings dominance and even send the network into third place. Bill Carter: Television. [34.]
The gulf war is cutting into the publicity that new books receive. Some authors have had book tours curtailed or canceled. Others are finding it increasingly difficult to get television interviews. As a result, sales of some books are likely to fall. And the publication of at least one travel book has been delayed. [34.]
The BBC World Service has expanded its Arabic-language broadcasts to the Middle East. The Arabic Service provides news to 10 million listeners, the BBC estimates. [34.]
 
 International
Several Soviet economists say the Soviet Union's transition to a market economy remains irreversible, even if recent developments have slowed the process, because the old centrally planned system has been too dismantled and discredited to be rebuilt. [29.]

HEADLINE: Slump Not Exclusive, Private Schools Find

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW

 BODY:
New York City's "other" school system -- where families pay $10,000 a year and more for the kind of education that most public schools cannot provide -- has lost whatever immunity it had to hard times.
This year, the city's version of the old boy and girl network -- the nation's largest and oldest alliance of nondenominational schools -- has been stunned by the effects of recent financial and population changes. Teachers are being laid off, class sizes are rising, two sets of schools have decided to merge, two others are selling real estate to survive and another narrowly averted closing. 
 Private school tuitions are soaring, and a growing number of parents are applying for financial aid or have withdrawn their children and moved to suburbs with good public schools.
Part of the problem is a drop in the number of students of high-school age, and part of the problem is money: The same slump that is making it harder for parents to pay tuitions that skyrocketed during the 1980's is battering endowments and fund-raising efforts.
"New York's private-school marketplace is shrinking, which means that schools are more and more in competition with one another," said Augustus Trowbridge, the director and founder of the Manhattan Country School. "And with fewer students, there will be fewer schools."
While some schools with traditionally strong academic programs -- among them Dalton, Horace Mann, Chapin, Trinity and Brearley -- remain healthy in both endowments and prospective applicants, many headmasters and admissions directors acknowledge that many of the city's 65 private nondenominational schools are ever more aggressively marketing themselves in order to fill classrooms -- and bank accounts.About 32,000 students, excluding preschoolers, are enrolled in the city's independent schools -- a slight decrease that was the first in many years, said Frederick Calder, the executive director of the New York State Association of Independent Schools. Letters of acceptance were recently sent out, and headmasters are now nervously waiting to see if the numbers of students accepting offers of admission by the March deadlines will continue to decline slowly, or begin a more precipitous fall.
 
New Attention to Bottom Line
 The troubles have clearly affected some schools much more than others, deepening divisions between the most socially and academically prestigious schools, respected middle-tier schools and those without the reputations to attract enough paying applicants, many educators say. This de facto hierarchy and the new attention to the bottom line are subjects that many in the private school community are reluctant to discuss -- in part because they have always guarded their privacy and that of their stu dents and in part because pride and reputation are keystones in maintaining a place in the independent-school market.
One school recently confronted by these brutal realities has been Walden Lincoln. Three years ago, the Walden and New Lincoln Schools, both early-20th-century Progressive schools, merged after a decade of declining enrollments. New Lincoln's East 77th Street building was sold to the Birch Wathen School for about $7 million, said Richard Marotta, Walden Lincoln's director. In 1987, Walden sold property next to its school on Central Park West and 88th Street to a developer, Sutton East Associates, for $5 million, with another $2 million dependent on condominium sales by Sutton East.
Despite this huge cash infusion, in December Walden Lincoln's board voted the school out of existence after a two-year, $3.6 million loss, and it was taken over by the Day School, an East Side elementary school.
"Walden Lincoln parents initially felt betrayed and tremendous loss," John Dexter, the Day School's headmaster, said of the takeover.
 
Teachers Fear Big Pay Cuts
 Though some parents plan to pull their children from the merged school, and almost half of Walden Lincoln's 50 teachers may be laid off, Mr. Dexter and Mr. Marotta voice confidence that a bigger school will be a better, more financially stable one. But some Walden Lincoln teachers worry that they may take a big pay cut at the Day School, and that Walden Lincoln is trying to avoid more than $200,000 in severance pay to laid-off teachers.
In another effort to avert financial catastrophe, the Birch Wathen and Lenox Schools agreed in November to merge next fall and are trying to sell one of Lenox's two buildings. Just two years before, the merged McBurney, Baldwin and Rhodes Schools folded.
Selling real estate has also been the formula for several other schools to remain solvent. The Fleming School, a 35-year-old elementary school that has emphasized French culture, recently sold its two East 62d Street buildings for $13 million and moved to a more modestly priced $6 million building on West 79th Street this fall. Ray-Eric Correa, the headmaster, described the move as a way of paying off debts and trying to attract more students.
St. Hilda's and St. Hugh's School, on West 114th Street, is trying to sell its air rights to Columbia University for $1 million, and 100 acres that it owns near Brewster, N.Y., for another $1 million, said the headmistress, Lynne Allen, in order "to finance ourselves when enrollment is going down."
After years of tuition increases that roughly paralleled the consumer price index, tuitions soared during the 1980's. The average tuition at a private Manhattan high school jumped by 40 percent in the last five years, partly to bring teacher salaries closer to public-school pay levels, Mr. Calder said. Teacher salaries are about $18,000 to $50,000, still less than in public schools, but low teacher-student ratios -- about 1 to 8 -- keep salary costs per student considerably higher.
 
Economic Diversity in Peril
 While more parents are finding themselves unable to afford that kind of tuition, the hardship is leading not to a large number of students' switching to New York City public schools, but to an increase in parents' leaving the city or requesting financial aid.
"High costs have driven many families out of New York, and the erosion of the city's middle class has been a big problem for private schools," said Brian Wright, the headmaster of Birch Wathen. "We've had a number of parents who've lost jobs and come to us in midyear asking for financial aid or deferring tuition payments."
The financial-aid requests pose another economic conundrum. Even before the recent surge in aid requests, private schools have been trying to broaden their ethnic and socioeconomic profile by admitting and giving scholarships to poorer white, black, Hispanic and other minority students. Consequently, the aid given to private-school students has doubled in the last five years, to $47.4 million in New York State and $267 million nationally.
"If families with kids already in private schools are now requesting financial aid, how can we also attract a new, more diversified student body needing scholarships?" said Randolph Carter, an official of the National Association of Independent Schools.
Many administrators say that the most vulnerable schools include high schools, smaller schools, girls' schools and newer experimental schools.
 
Concern for Girls' Schools
 And while officials of established girls' schools like Spence, Hewitt and Convent of the Sacred Heart say that their applications have held up, there is concern that a national trend toward co-education may cause a drop in girls' schools' enrollments. A 36-member National Coalition of Girls' Schools -- which includes Brearley, Marymount, Chapin, Hewitt and Nightingale-Bamford in New York -- was established two years ago to promote the values of a single-sex education. said Arlene Gibson, the coalition's chairwoman.
The coalition's efforts illustrate a new emphasis among schools to publicize themselves and to appeal to families who have never sent children to private schools.
Glossy new school prospectuses, open houses for prospective students, hiring public relations concerns and even newspaper advertising are signs of this new marketing consciousness, said Cynthia Bing, the head of the Schools Advisory Service, which provides information on New York City private schools.
Others see another kind of change at work. "Even the top-tier schools are taking kids they might not have taken in the past," said William A. Spiegler, an education-marketing consultant.
 
Harder to Raise Money
 Declining enrollments are also forcing schools to look harder for other revenues, but the current recession and 1986 tax-law changes have made it harder for all nonprofit institutions to raise money.
Creative fund raising was key to the unexpected survival of the Elisabeth Irwin High School earlier this month.
"The school was on the brink of closing," said Andrew McLaren, the director of Elisabeth Irwin and the Little Red Schoolhouse, its affiliated elementary school. "A majority of trustees were recommending that we close because, with our falling enrollment, they couldn't see any way out financially."
But the plight of the school "energized our community in an extraordinary way," Mr. McLaren said. In the weekend before the board was to vote on closing the school, one board member raised $250,000, and a $1 million fund-raising campaign was begun.
"I got a letter from a colleague congratulating us for pioneering a good fund-raising concept -- a sort of Phoenix number, closing in order to emerge from the ashes reborn," he said. But, noting that many schools may not be able to tap such last-minute largesse, he added: "I wouldn't recommend it as a long-term financial solution."

HEADLINE: Marla Simpson Has a Wedding

 BODY:
Marla Grace Simpson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leo A. Simpson of Farmington Hills, Mich., and Barry Dinerstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Dinerstein of Elmont, L.I., were married Saturday. Rabbi Michael Ehrlich performed the ceremony at Bridgewater's at the South Street Seaport in New York.
The bride, 36 years old, is keeping her name. She is the director of land use planning in the office of the Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger. Ms. Simpson, formerly a lawyer with the New York Lawyers for the Public Interest, graduated from Michigan State University and received a J.D. degree from the University of Michigan. Her father is the assistant general counsel at the Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Michigan in Detroit. Her mother, Elaine Simpson, is an independent realtor. 
 The bridegroom, 34, is a city planner with the housing and economic planning group at the Department of City Planning in New York. He graduated from the State University of New York at Albany. His mother, Edith Dinerstein, is a freelance artist. His father, who is retired, was the owner of a clothing business in New York.

HEADLINE: SPRING TRAINING;
A Time of New Hopes And New Teammates

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
With all due respect to Aldous Huxley, John Schuerholz said, "It's the new Brave world."
Schuerholz is the new general manager of the Atlanta Braves, and in an effort to abandon last place, which the team has firmly held the last three years, he has spent an active off season adding players he believes can spur the Braves onward and upward. 
 That quest, of course, is No. 1 on the priority lists of 22 teams each winter because they are the ones that did not win division championships the year before. With many other general managers having joined Schuerholz in bids to bolster their clubs' chances, a small army of players will head in new directions this week as they prepare to begin spring training.
Pitchers and catchers from 15 teams are scheduled to ache their way through their first workouts Friday. Their colleagues from the other 11 teams will begin in the ensuing four days. By March 2, a week from Saturday, all 26 teams will be in full-squad workouts, with exhibition games beginning five days after that.
This spring the players will have a full six weeks of workouts and games. Last spring the players were locked out during the negotiations for a new collective bargaining agreement and ended up with less than three full weeks of organized spring training.
Perhaps the player who will have the most difficult task finding his way to his new spring camp is Dwight Evans. After 18 years with the Boston Red Sox, Evans has joined the Baltimore Orioles. Rick Cerone, on the other hand, has become accustomed to traveling to new camps in the spring. In heading for Port St. Lucie, Fla., and the Mets' complex, he will be switching sites for the ninth time in the last 16 springs.
Some teams, like the Braves, have made such wholesale changes that they will have to give their players extra time to introduce themselves to one another. New to the Atlanta camp, for example, will be Terry Pendleton, Sid Bream, Juan Berenguer, Mike Heath, Rafael Belliard, Glenn Wilson and Deion Sanders, all of whom Schuerholz signed as free agents.
 Joe McIlvaine, another new general manager, has been at least as busy as Schuerholz, but he has an advantage in getting the newcomers acclimated. The San Diego Padres train in Yuma, Ariz., and it's so isolated with so little to do that the players will have more than enough time to get to know one another. McIlvaine, who admitted he's not a "stand pat" executive, is counting on the new players to have a positive influence on their new, young teammates.
Ticking off the people he has acquired, McIlvaine noted that Marty Barrett, "a guy who got shunted aside in Boston, is like Ray Knight."
"He doesn't have great physical tools," McIlvaine said of Barrett, "but he's a winning type of player. He's been in the World Series. The Toronto guys" -- Fred McGriff and Tony Fernandez -- "have been in the playoffs. Larry Andersen has been in the playoffs. You try to bring in some people who have had success and hope it rubs off on the younger players."
McIlvaine has also brought in Jim Presley, Wes Gardner, Oscar Azocar and Scott Coolbaugh. The Blue Jays, with whom McIlvaine made a stunning December trade, grew tired of being a preseason pick and an end-of-season flop. Pat Gillick, usually the antonym of McIlvaine, shook up his troops by obtaining Joe Carter, Roberto Alomar, Devon White, Pat Tabler, Ken Dayley and some lesser-known players.
The Los Angeles Dodgers, one of the most active teams in the most active division, spent $30 million to create two-thirds of a new outfield with Darryl Strawberry and Brett Butler. They also added two veteran starting pitchers, Bob Ojeda and Kevin Gross.
"It's a tough division," Schuerholz said. "It seems every move one club made another club answered with a salvo of their own. We made some moves we felt would make us a substantially greater club, but so have other clubs in the division."
The Dodgers also invited another veteran pitcher, John Candelaria, and a veteran catcher, Gary Carter, to spring training, giving them a chance to put in one last year while possibly providing needed bench strength. Carter and Candelaria are two of a group of players, aging and otherwise, issued such invitations.
The group also includes Rich (Goose) Gossage, by Texas; Ernie Whitt, by Baltimore; Rick Dempsey, by Milwaukee; Rich Gedman, by St. Louis; Bob Boone, by St. Louis, and Darnell Coles, by Houston. This could be the final spring for some well-traveled catchers.
 This will be the first spring with teams for other players, who are certain to have a greater impact than the invitees.
Vince Coleman, for example, will be relied upon to serve as the catalyst for a Mets' offense devoid of Strawberry's home runs. Hubie Brooks, returning to his starting place, is expected to replace some of the runs Strawberry produced.
Jack Morris will add stability and leadership to a young Minnesota starting rotation, and Kansas City will look to Kirk Gibson, perhaps no longer the offensive threat he once was, to provide the fiery leadership he has displayed in Detroit and Los Angeles. Mike Boddicker joins an already strong Royals pitching rotation.
After 10 years with the Yankees, Dave Righetti has gone home to San Francisco to lead the Giants' bullpen, leaving his spot in New York open to perhaps Steve Farr. Scott Sanderson also has joined the Yankees' pitching staff.
Tim Raines, the new left fielder for the Chicago White Sox, is in the American League for the first time, eager to show that Rickey Henderson is not in a class by himself. George Bell, on the other hand, has moved to the National League, adding a potent bat to an already strong Chicago Cubs lineup. The Cubs, in an uncharacteristic spending spree, also signed Danny Jackson and Dave Smith as free agents, establishing themselves in the view of many as the team most likely to finish No. 1 in the National League East.
But what about the movement of a collection of players who finished No. 1 in offensive categories in the National League?
Willie McGee, the batting champion, is in San Francisco; Butler, who tied for the lead in hits, is in Los Angeles; Jack Clark, who walked more than anybody, has left the league and gone to Boston; so has Danny Darwin, who had the National League's lowest earned run average. Carter, the leader in games played and times batted, has returned to the American League with Toronto, and Glenn Davis, hit by more pitches than anyone else, is in Baltimore.
Rob Deer and Mickey Tettleton are in Detroit, meaning the Tigers could create a gustier breeze than the Cubs get from Lake Michigan. Deer, Tettleton and Cecil Fielder, teammates now, were among the top seven strikeout artists (they use not a brush but a bat) in the American League last year. They struck out a collective 489 times last year.
Given the escalating economy baseball has created, the Tigers could save a lot of money on baseballs this year. What they can't hit won't leave the field.

HEADLINE: The City and State Are One

 BODY:
If New York City and State hope to surmount their shared fiscal crisis, they will have to cooperate. The counterproductive war now going on ignores the obvious: There is no way to separate the two.
The state is the city's bank, the source of at least a quarter of its money -- and of rigorous rules that tell the city how to spend that money. The city is the state's engine, the place where economic activity generates half the state's tax revenues. There is even a mechanism already in place for state-city cooperation. The only hitch is that it is misunderstood and thus mistrusted. 
 Mayors have resented the Financial Control Board ever since it was created to help the city escape the fiscal crisis of the 1970's. Mayor David Dinkins recoils at the very thought that the Control Board, now functioning in only an advisory capacity, would ever regain its original power to approve and veto the city budget. That, city officials think, would be seen as a sign of failure.
But Mr. Dinkins's reservations are based on a misconception of what the Control Board could mean to a city under budgetary siege, now that the state, too, is in economic trouble. The state is planning a deep cut in aid to the city to help close its own huge budget gap. It also imposes laws, rules and mandates that require costly, often unreasonable, spending.
In this climate, nothing could benefit the city more than a mechanism that encouraged close city and state cooperation, forcing Gov. Mario Cuomo to confront his role in the city's fiscal life. The board, headed by the Governor, can be that mechanism.
"The Control Board is not a hair shirt," says Hugh Carey, the Governor during the last fiscal crisis. "It was designed to bring the city and state together to match wits and figures, to see how they can solve their problems. You're not going to solve the state's problems without the city and you're not going to solve the city's without the state."
The current crisis demands fundamental changes -- in city spending, in state spending and in the relationship between the two. There is no better place to examine such matters than on the Control Board, which in addition to the Governor includes the Mayor, the city and state comptrollers and three gubernatorial appointees from the private sector.
The board would also be the appropriate panel to consider the financier Felix Rohatyn's proposition that it might be preferable for the city to use borrowed money, accompanied by a prudent spending plan, rather than make unthinkably harsh cuts.
Mr. Dinkins and his administration have made grave fiscal mistakes -- especially by negotiating costly labor contracts. They have produced an unrealistic spending plan that will be difficult to carry out and have yet to cut programs enough or to weigh structural changes. But any mayor would have trouble pulling the city through this recession. Tax revenues continue to drop, and if things get bad enough, the Control Board's oversight powers will be triggered by law. That happens if the city's budget is $100 million in deficit on June 30, the end of the fiscal year, or if the city cannot sell its bonds.
Why wait? Mr. Dinkins could show strong leadership, political courage and enlightened self-interest if he invited the participation of the Control Board now. As Hugh Carey says, "When the problem is this severe, you'd better bring the two groups together."
