HEADLINE: Crossroads in Mental Health: Red Ink and Unused Wards

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GOWANDA, N.Y., Feb. 13

 BODY:
Ward 50 at the state-run Gowanda Psychiatric Center in southwestern New York seems a throwback to the age of asylums. Like geriatric wards at mental hospitals across the state, the day room is well scrubbed and cheerfully decorated, but most of the 18 elderly patients are lost in schizophrenic hazes, captives of their wheelchairs.
Ravaged by decades of mental illness and confinement, they mumble incoherently as accordion music seeps from a stereo. Their limbs jerk involuntarily; their faces contort into images from Edvard Munch. One of the few lucid patients, an 82-year-old woman who has lived here for seven years, shows off a Valentine from her daughter, then begins to weep. 
 Last month, when Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's budget proposed closing Gowanda, Ward 50 became a symbolic crossroads for a state mental health system that is struggling with its evolution from institutionalization to community care. Whether the Cuomo administration can persuade the Legislature to close the hospital over the protest of organized labor may provide the clearest sign of that system's future.
 
Millions for Empty Beds
 Since the 1950's, when psychiatry was revolutionized by the introduction of mood-leveling drugs, New York's mental hospitals have been discharging patients into group homes, outpatient programs and, disturbingly, into the streets. But the state still spends nearly three-fourths of its $2 billion mental health budget to maintain 22 underused centers that now are part hospital, part nursing home.
While the state continues to run the largest network of psychiatric hospitals in the country, it is not meeting a dire need to expand community mental health services like group homes, outpatient centers and acute-care units in general hospitals.
Historically, the combined political forces of the local economy and organized labor, whose members staff the centers, have prevented the Office of Mental Health from closing hospitals. But in a year when the state faces a $6 billion budget gap, the fiscal pressure to shut doors may finally rival the political pressure to keep them open.
State officials have announced a campaign to close four hospitals by the end of the decade, beginning with Gowanda in southwestern Erie County. The proposal has generated a heated debate in the Legislature about the wisdom of mothballing hospitals when there is no money for a commensurate expansion of community services.
 
Where Would Patients Go?
 Mr. Cuomo's budget for the 1991-92 fiscal year, which begins on April 1, would cut $110 million in mental health spending, virtually all of it from state hospitals. But while the budget projects a decline of 1,200 hospital patients during the year, from 13,700 to 12,500, it would also cut $5 million in grants to community mental health programs.
That has raised the prospect that deinstitutionalized patients could wind up untreated and homeless.
The leaders of the Legislature's mental health committees, Assemblywoman Elizabeth A. Connelly, Democrat of Staten Island, and Senator Nicholas A. Spano, Republican of Yonkers, worry that closing the hospitals now may make fiscal sense without making good policy.
"Deinstitutionalization without sufficient community programs is a formula for disaster," Ms. Connelly said.
The state's mental health commissioner, Richard C. Surles, said he understands such concerns. But after seeing his department savaged by recent budget cuts, Mr. Surles said he is convinced that there may never be enough money for community services if hospitals remain open.
"This is not something I would have proposed were it not for the economic conditions," Mr. Surles said. "But I don't see anybody telling us that the state is going to put more money into the mental health budget. So if we don't close Gowanda, we're going to have to cut patient care."
New York has long had the largest and most expensive state mental health system in the country. In 1987, it spent almost $99 a citizen on mental health. Its closest rival, Massachussetts, spent almost $62. California spent just under $30.
The cost has been driven largely by the unwillingness to close hospitals, even as the state has locked unused wards and demolished unneeded buildings.
Mr. Surles estimates that 8,000 of the state's 185,000 mentally ill patients truly require hospitalization. But with the state unable to shift enough money from hospitals to community services, the hospitals have also become dumping grounds for elderly patients who could be treated in nursing homes, and clinics of last resort for younger patients who cannot find care elsewhere.
The cost is numbing. The hospital reimbursement rate for Medicaid patients, half of which is paid by the state, averages $473 a day, or $172,645 a year. A bed in an adult community residence costs the state $15,995 a year.
And because hospitals must meet standards of cleanliness and care to qualify for Medicaid reimbursement, and because of strong and entrenched union opposition, the state has not been able to cut staffing at the same rate it has cut patient populations. At Gowanda, for instance, although dozens of employees have been laid off in recent months, 649 workers care for 300 patients. Officials at Gownada and other state hospitals argue that such staff-to-patient ratios are necessary for 24-hour-a-day, year- round care.
 
'A Lot of Money to Squander'
 The cost of maintaining state hospitals during Mr. Cuomo's eight-year tenure grew by $600 million, while the hospital population shrunk by nearly 10,000.
"That's a lot of money to squander on something that isn't state policy," said Evelyn R. Frankford, a mental health policy analyst for the State Communities Aid Association.
Mr. Surles, who has been commissioner since 1987, maintains that the state is heading in the right direction.
The population in state psychiatric hospitals, which peaked at 90,000 in the 1950's, has dropped to less than 14,000, from almost 20,000 in 1987. Ms. Frankford and other lobbyists credit Mr. Surles with starting several innovative programs aimed at shortening hospital stays and expanding community care.
But the Commissioner concedes that the state is meeting only 60 percent of its need for outpatient programs, and only half the need in New York City and on Long Island.
Mr. Surles said he believed he could ultimately save $100 million a year by closing the four hospitals, mostly by eliminating administrative costs and by canceling planned renovation projects.
But John R. Collier, Gowanda's executive director, predicted that the state would save little by closing the hospital, rated among the state's best. Two hundred and twenty-five of its patients are geriatrics, like those in Ward 50, who would have to be transferred to the Buffalo Psychiatric Center.
Other patients -- one hospital official said they "usually come in either a sheriff's car or an ambulance" -- would either have to be admitted to the Buffalo center or find space in community programs in Gowanda's four-county service area.
That region is meeting only a fraction of its need for most mental health services, and would have to expand them greatly to compensate for closing Gowanda, said C. Richard Orndoff, the Office of Mental Health's regional director for western New York.
If closing Gowanda poses a logistical problem, it may pose an even greater political problem. The Public Employees Federation and the Civil Service Employees Association have pledged to defend the hospital's workers, along with thousands of others that Mr. Cuomo plans to lay off, with a $1 million advertising campaign.
Because the psychiatric center has long been the area's largest employer, residents and their legislators have also turned up the heat. Retailers like Stephen L. Cocca, who owns Gowanda's only jewelry store, say they fear that the village of 2,200 would become a ghost town.
Some jobs could be saved if the state followed through on plans to convert the hospital into prison space, but village leaders note that prison jobs would pay far less than the hospital's average annual salary of $33,000.
Three hundred people braved a snowstorm to attend a rally in Gowanda in late January. Yellow signs reading "Keep Gowanda Psychiatric Center Open" are displayed in store windows on Main Street along with American flags.
In normal times, such pressures might quickly kill a proposal to close the hospital. But Cuomo aides hope the state budget crisis will force legislators to accept cuts this year that might otherwise seem unthinkable.
"The only way we'll ever be able to do anything for community mental health in a big way is to downsize the state institutions," said Michael J. Dowling, the Governor's deputy secretary for human services. "If we don't do it now, I don't know that we'll ever have an opportunity to do it again."

HEADLINE: On Baseball;
Maddox Maintains Community Ties

BYLINE: BY CLAIRE SMITH

 BODY:
Ralph Kiner, the Mets' broadcaster, was once moved to say that "two-thirds of the earth is covered by water, the other one-third is covered by Garry Maddox."
As a major leaguer, Maddox, known as the secretary of defense, indeed played his position superbly, More important, he played his role even better in showing what could be accomplished off the field as well as on. 
 Even though he is five years removed from the game, Maddox is still quite the secretary of defense, only now he defends as best he can children who cannot defend themselves.
He has done so for nearly 14 years as an integral part of the Philadelphia Child Guidance Clinic, a place where the most innocent victims of violence in the home can find refuge.
 
Knowing Violence First-Hand
 Maddox knows all about such needs, for he has seen what violence can do to a soul. The night of his most recent fundraiser for the children's clinic, Maddox gave a hint of how thorough his education has been.
The occasion was the 14th annual Garry Maddox Celebrity Bowling Tournament put on to benefit the clinic. This year the tournament happened to fall on Jan. 17, which was also the second day of the United States-led coalition's war against Iraq.
As other celebrities paired off the bowl at a South Philadelphia locale, Maddox met with reporters. He was asked if he felt it was appropriate that the Super Bowl go on as scheduled, considering the events of the day.
Maddox said yes. Such events are important to service men and women who might listen on Armed Forces Radio or watch via satellite, he explained. Maddox knew. He once clutched a radio so he could hear the 1969 World Series while serving as an Army combat infantryman in Vietnam.
 
Apology of Sorts
 Days later, Maddox was almost apologetic about the reference. "I've made it my policy not to speak about the war," he said of the conflict that snatched him from the minor league system of the San Francisco Giants at the age of 19. "I hope you understand."
And rare have been the glimpses the quiet, almost introverted Maddox has given. But there had been enough during his playing days for one to see that life at a forward base near Chu Lai was hell because it was war.
Maddox came out of Vietnam whole if not completely healthy at first (skin rashes caused by allergies made it all but impossible for him to shave, thus resulting in his trademark beard, worn well before facial hair was commonly accepted in baseball).
Most important, Maddox did not return a bitter man. Instead, he immersed himself into society and the game which he played so spectacularly at times, as evidenced by eight Gold Gloves and a championship ring.
 
Feelings of Obligation
 Maddox came to the Child Guidance Clinic shortly after being traded to the Phillies in 1975. He had to, Maddox figured, because he had just become a member of an athletic community that was a veritable hotbed of such activities.
Julius Erving, Mike Schmidt, Bobby Clark, Bill Bergey, superstars all, seemed to be everywhere espousing various causes.
"It was so different in those days," Maddox said. "If you came to play in Philadelphia, you made it your home. And it seemed like everyone wanted to help the community."
In 1977, the bowling tournament was born. In any given year in that era, Maddox and his one-time co-host, Larry Bowa, would draft Erving, Schmidt, Pete Rose, Steve Carlton and ballplayers from around the country to participate.
Today, it's still the draw; fans come to see Charles Barkley, the musician Grover Washington Jr. and the like.
"Those guys are the ones who really make it successful," said Maddox. But it is Maddox who's remained the constant.
Not that Maddox hasn't had a notion to give way.
"The 13th tournament was going to be my last," Maddox admitted. "But there's been a tendency in this country to cut back.
"With fewer grants and the trouble Philadelphia is having with its economy, the funds were getting real short. Being on the clinic's board, it was an easy problem to recognize. I didn't have to be asked to stay."
Maddox is not alone in his fervor, but he sadly says he does see a difference.
'It's not the same," Maddox admitted. "Free agency has brought a lot of good things, but a lot of changes, too. Players have become more dollar-conscious, so there's a lot more movement from team to team. They just don't stay around as long."
Maddox did stay though, through the end of his playing career in 1986, through to this day.
Fourteen years and more than a million dollars in solicited donations later, Maddox said: "It's not only just about giving something back. Whether we like it or not, athletes are role models. The sooner a player realizes that the better off he'll be."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Garry Maddox, the former Phillies' outfielder, is still active in the Philadelphia community, five years after his retirement from baseball. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: When a Big Bank Went Under, U.S. Presence Stemmed the Panic

SERIES: Banks Under Stress - Second of five articles: Anatomy of Bank Runs

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
Jean Driscoll, the manager of the Bank of New England branch in Chestnut Hill, Mass., went to work on the morning of Jan. 4 expecting it to be just another Friday in the affluent Boston suburb. But there was nothing routine about it. By 8:30 A.M., there were long lines of anxious depositors at the tellers' windows and cash machines, withdrawing their money. The phones rang steadily with calls from worried customers. Bank officers tried to calm account holders, assuring them that their savings were federally insured up to $100,000.
 But to little effect. There were similar scenes at many of the Bank of New England's 300 branches. Frantic depositors pulled nearly $1 billion out of the bank in two days; small savers trooped through the lobbies with their money in wallets, bulging envelopes and briefcases, and money managers yanked out multimillion-dollar deposits by remote control with computer and telex orders. 
Some local crooks even tried to get in on the action. The Federal Bureau of Investigation said it foiled a plan by six men who had hoped to rob an armored car they figured would be loaded with cash for all the withdrawals.
 Yet as soon as Washington stepped in, with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation taking over the bank on Sunday, the panic subsided. On Monday morning, the doors of the Chestnut Hill branch were opened, and it was business as usual. "We even started to see some money come back," Ms. Driscoll recalls.
 Certainly, the bank run of today is not something to be taken lightly. The Bank of New England case underscores how rapidly public confidence can evaporate. The real lesson in the view of most banking experts, however, is that the modern-day bank run is containable. The bank run of today is far different from the situation in the days before deposit insurance, far different from the Depression-era runs that wiped out the life savings of millions of people and destroyed the American economy. Runs by individual depositors are extremely rare and are likely to remain so, even in times when a rare combination of harsh economic forces collide, as they are doing now amid high deficits, low growth and the stresses of war. The safety net of Federal insurance and regulation does appear to hold.
 At the Bank of New England, the main concern of small account holders was that they would not have access to their money for days or weeks if the bank closed. Few expressed fears of actually losing their money. And it took an unusual series of events -- recent failures by savings institutions in Rhode Island, steady press coverage of the bank's problems and the Jan. 4 announcement of a big loss -- to precipitate the temporary run that did occur.
 After looking back and surveying the damage, banking regulators and experts came away less concerned about conventional runs by the nation's individual depositors than about "silent" runs by corporations, foreign banks and other large institutions, whose money managers might decide to sell the certificates of deposit or commercial paper of banks that show signs of weakness. Usually, these no-confidence votes are made coolly in dealing rooms around the world. The verdicts may simply be relayed by computer, or telex, and can gather momentum with little warning.
 Big depositors have reason to move quickly when the first danger signs appear. There is no assurance that when a bank gets in trouble the Government will guarantee all accounts, even those of more than $100,000, as it did with the Bank of New England.
 Some flow of money away from American banks, mainly those burdened with bad loans from real estate and takeover deals, is already under way. It is a phenomenon that is difficult to measure precisely or to attribute entirely to eroding confidence in the banks. But in the past year or so, money market funds, foreign investors and American corporate treasurers have all cut back their holdings of certificates of deposit from United States banks.
 "The real issue for American banks," said Robert E. Litan, senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, "is the silent run that seems to be going on right now, and whether that run is gradual or whether it snowballs out of control."
 
The Bank Run

 Confidence Can Erode Quickly
 A bank run occurs when depositors take their money out of a bank, not to use it elsewhere -- to buy a new car or invest in Treasury bonds, say -- but because they are worried about the bank's stability. During a run, a bank must typically sell assets to pay its depositors or temporarily borrow money from the Government. If the run continues, the bank will eventually shrink to the point of collapse, as it loses deposits and sells more and more assets.
 Runs on a small number of banks, causing them to fail, would not be a real blow to the economy. But a more widespread loss could have a collective psychology about it that could deepen the current recession, effectively curb the credit available for growth and increase unemployment and business failures, experts warn.
 "Our whole financial system runs on confidence and not much else when you get down to it," said L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. "What we've learned is that when confidence erodes, it erodes very quickly."
 Some analysts contend that bank runs are not a bad thing, if they represent a "flight to quality," shifting money from weaker banks to stronger ones. This kind of shift can keep the banks sharp. "The runs that involve the movement of funds from one bank to another are a good thing," said George Kaufman, a finance professor at Loyola University of Chicago. "And the threat of a bank run is a powerful source of market discipline."
 The winners in this flight to safe banking havens range from huge foreign institutions to tiny but financially strong rural banks. As qualms about some United States banks have grown, the American arm of Germany's Deutsche Bank has experienced a rise in corporate deposits, says Detlev Staecker, a general manager for Deutsche Bank in New York. In Newman Grove, Neb., a farm town of 750 people, the First National Bank of Newman Grove, an institution with $28 million in assets whose capital cushion far exceeds Federal standards, has pulled in more deposits recently from nearby communities.
 "We're even seeing it out here with small depositors," said Jeffrey Gerhart, the bank's president. "It's not a big stampede. But people want to deal with a bank they feel is going to be around next year and the year after, just as customers feel more comfortable dealing with an airline, a department store or a car dealer that is financially strong instead of one that seems shaky."
 But another group of analysts cautions that viewing bank runs as a market-driven agent of improvement and change may be a dangerous mistake. Their concern is that the scalpel edge of competition that may kill off a sick bank may reach out to pierce the healthy banks as well. "Market discipline and a bank panic can be synonymous," observed Lowell L. Bryan, a director of McKinsey & Company. "Nobody makes a bank deposit choosing to take a risk."
 It was this concern in the Bank of New England case, this fear of runs at other banks in the region, that led Federal regulators to move so quickly and to guarantee that even deposits of more than $100,000 would be fully insured. "When you have a problem with confidence, you have to act decisively to restore calm," Mr. Seidman said.
 
The Safety Net

 
Keeping Panic In Check
 Hugh Rockoff, an economic historian at Rutgers University, points out that when President Franklin D. Roosevelt declared a bank holiday in 1933 in the depths of the Depression, half of the nation's banks had closed, industrial production had fallen by half and unemployment had risen to 25 percent. The United States was still on the gold standard, the Federal Reserve was not able to create money to bolster the financial system and the world was in the grip of a destructive trade war.
 Yet not only in the 1930's, but also in the bank panics of 1890 and 1837, Mr. Rockoff said, a powerful psychology was unleashed that quickly fed on itself and operated independently of the underlying causes that started the bank run. Once it started, he said, some people began losing confidence in the banking system, then no one had confidence, and it became "very difficult to trace the source of the panic."
 It is this contagious spiral of unreason that the modern system of bank regulation is designed to stop, and in recent years the Government has done reasonably well in putting that system to work.
 For the last decade, Alan Whitney, the director of communications for the F.D.I.C., has traveled across the country, helping to shut down failed banks. When the Government seized a failed bank, customers were sometimes confused about the arrangements, but rarely were account holders panicked, or did they force the Government to close a bank quickly by making a run on deposits, he recalled. The Bank of New England was the big exception.
 "People have gotten used to the idea that banks can fail, and that their funds are safe and they have access to their accounts," Mr. Whitney said.
 That the Government stands behind federally insured deposits was also underscored by the savings and loan crisis, which has proved costly for taxpayers but generally not for depositors. Most people are reassured by Federal deposit insurance, said Richard T. Curtin, director of surveys of consumers at the University of Michigan.
 
Continuing Weakness

 
Big Depositors Go Elsewhere
 Ordinarily, large institutional depositors use banks as a place to park their spare cash by putting it in short-term certificates of deposit and the commercial paper of bank holding companies. Typically, their holdings at a bank exceed $100,000.
 For their part, the big money-center banks and large regionals are generally much more dependent on these sources of short-term money than small banks, which tend to rely mainly on the deposits of individual savers.
 Even among big banks, the situation can vary considerably, however. The failure of Continental Illinois Bank and Trust in 1984 was a result of a global run on its deposits. Continental had depended on short-term deposits made by large institutions from around the world. But those depositors fled fast once the Chicago bank's bad loans led to earnings problems. And the Continental case showed that once a silent run begins, it can quickly prove unstoppable.
 But when the Bank of America ran into earnings troubles in 1987, it did not suffer a run. "Bank of America never lost its faithful California depositors," said Christopher Mahoney, a bank analyst for Moody's Investors Service Inc. "Having retail deposits makes a bank much less sensitive to confidence problems."
 Now as the financial position of many banks has weakened, the big customers have pulled back. "The smart money is heading for the exits," observed Charles P. Kindleberger, an emeritus professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
 The American bank holdings of major foreign depositors like Japan and Taiwan have been sharply trimmed. During the first nine months of 1990, Japan cuts its holdings in United States banks by $19.3 billion, to $92.5 billion, according to the Treasury Department. Over the same period, Taiwan reduced its American bank holdings by $7.1 billion, to $12.5 billion.
 Recently, Prudential-Bache Securities surveyed the treasurers of 100 of the nation's large corporations and found most of them reducing their deposits and dealings with banks showing signs of financial weakness. The survey concluded the shift was "equivalent to a long-term slow run on sicker banks."
 Corporate money managers are particularly sensitive to the marks given to banks by credit-rating agencies, like Moody's and Standard & Poor's. Last year, for example, Moody's downgraded the rating on banking companies 92 times, about double the number of such rating drops in the previous year. The major bank companies whose ratings were lowered a notch last year included Citicorp, Chase Manhattan and Security Pacific. Citicorp was downgraded again in January.
 Many institutions have cut back their large bank deposits. John Hackett, vice president of finance at Indiana University, says that of the university's $200 million in operating cash, well under 20 percent is in bank certificate of deposits, compared with 50 percent two years ago. "We're being very, very cautious about banks today," Mr. Hackett said.
 Whether confidence can be restored, thus containing the silent run that is under way, will depend on the basic condition of the nation's banking system. And that, in turn, will depend on whether bankers and bank regulators forcefully address the question of the industry's health.
 Next: Politics of reform
 
The Making And Breaking Of a Bank Run
1. With the economy strong, a big bank becomes overly aggressive, making enormous loans for real estate and other projects that seem to make sense - as long as the good times roll.
2. But when the economy weakens, developers cannot find tenants, and default on loans. Institutions - mutual funds, pension funds, corporations and other banks - see the trouble and silently begin to pull money out.
3. Because of its deposit - gathering troubles, the bank must shrink. It sells assets, like loans and credit-card operations, and reduces its work force.
4. The economy weakens further, more loans go bad and the bank's downturn accelerates.
5. Press coverage of the bank's problems helps alert small depositors to its weakness.
6. Reports of continued losses prompt a wave of withdrawals by small depositors, leaving the bank precariously short of funds.
7. The Federal Government declares the bank inxolvent, closes it, takes it over and reopens it almost immediately. Depositors have their accounts insured up to $100,000 and the F.D.I.C. tries to find a buyer - and business goes on.

HEADLINE: Toyota to Cut U.S. Exports

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 18

 BODY:
The Toyota Motor Corporation will cut exports to the United States by 10,000 vehicles during February and March because of the soft American market, the company's president, Shoichiro Toyoda, said today.
But Mr. Toyoda stressed at a news conference that the auto maker, Japan's largest, would not reduce production at its plants in California and Kentucky, since that could further damage the sagging United States economy.
Toyota's sales in the United States fell an estimated 13 percent in January, compared with January 1990, to 63,568 vehicles, according to Yoshiharu Tateishi, a Toyota spokesman.
In 1990, Toyota's exports to the United States fell by 4 percent from a year earlier, to 703,000 vehicles, but production in the United States rose by 39 percent, to 320,000 vehicles, Mr. Tateishi said.
Toyota exported about 53,000 vehicles to the United States in February and 58,000 in March 1990, he said.
Toyota's planned cut in exports followed similar announcements by other big Japanese auto makers last month.
The Nissan Motor Company plans to trim exports by 4,500 to 5,000 vehicles in March, the Honda Motor Company by 20,000 in February and March, and the Mazda Motor Corporation by 8,000 in February and March. Honda also said it would trim production in Marysville, Ohio, by 5,000 vehicles between January and March.

HEADLINE: In a Tide of Japanese Books on Jews, an Anti-Semitic Current

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 18

 BODY:
The Persian Gulf war has led to a boom in book sales on all aspects of the Middle East. And once again among the best sellers are books about a subject that has long held a fascination for Japanese readers: the influence and power of Jews.
The popular titles include dozens of translated versions of standards in the United States and elsewhere. But also selling well, indeed as best sellers in major Tokyo bookstores, are books depicting a Jewish conspiracy to control the world economy. 
 The popularity of books about Jews in Japan is not new. But according to Masanori Miyazawa, a history professor who has compiled a bibliography on the subject, at least 100 new books related to Jews -- a record number -- were published last year, apparently because of the gulf crisis.
The specific appearance of the new anti-Semitic books, some of them published by mainstream houses, has again drawn the concern of Israeli diplomats and Jewish organizations, giving new impetus to the Jewish groups' campaign to inform publishers that Jews regard such books as repugnant.
 
'Total Ignorance of Judaism'
 "The publication of these books by itself doesn't worry me too much," said Nahum Eshkol, the Israeli Ambassador to Japan. "What worries me is the readiness of Japanese to buy them, maybe to read them, on the backdrop of maybe total ignorance of Judaism and Israel."
Leading American Jewish groups have met quietly with Japanese officials, politicians, opinion leaders and publishers, most recently in December, to discourage distribution of the books, but with little success.
A year and a half ago, the Japan Foreign Ministry responded by urging the Japan Book Publishers Association to be more sensitive, asserting in a memorandum that "the Government of Japan regrets to see that the label of 'Japanese anti-Semitism' has taken root among American Jews."
But the publishers group declined to distribute the ministry memorandum to members, saying it did not want to endorse censorship.
 
'Rebuffed by the Publishers'
 An official of the American Jewish Committee who had lobbied in Japan praised the Foreign Ministry, saying, "They put themselves on the line and were rebuffed by the publishers."
But the official, Neil C. Sandberg, director of the Committee's Pacific Rim Institute, said he found the publishers puzzled by the protests, wondering why Jews were not flattered to be thought so powerful.
"They told us, 'You're a member of a superior race and you come from a successful group and we're surprised this material concerns you,' " he recalled.
 
No Reports of Discrimination
 Books condemning Jews flourish inspite of the fact that the few hundred Jews who live in Japan experience no discrimination or even any evidence that Japanese distinguish them from other foreigners.
The anti-Semitic books continue to sell along with more mainstream works. At present, for instance, bookstores are featuring "The Arab-Israeli Wars," by Chaim Herzog, the President of Israel, along with books telling readers how to make money off stocks that Jews buy, plus others that speak of Jewish rituals and conspiracies.
One new book published in December, "Counterattack of Hitler," is a best seller at many book stores and has sold 30,000 copies. It denies the existence of the Holocaust and asserts that a Jewish conspiracy is being thwarted by Germany, Arabs and other groups.
Another new book, "Confessions of the Jews," by Paul Goldstein and Jeffrey Steinberg, two American followers of the political extremist Lyndon LaRouche, says the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, the American Jewish group, engages in organized crime and drug-trafficking. The book has sold only 5,000 copies but is a best-seller in those bookstores carrying it.
 
Author of Anti-Semitic Books
 The author of the first book and the translator of the second is Masami Uno, an Osaka man whose books denouncing Jews have long sold well and are widely available. His book, "If You Understand Jews, You Can See the Whole World," has sold 540,000 copies since it was published in 1986.
Critics of such books, Jewish groups among them, are troubled less by their direct influence than by their general respectability. The new books are from subsidiaries of prestigious publishers and "Counterattack of Hitler" was recently advertised on the front page of the Asahi Shimbun, the nation's most prestigious newspaper.
"Right now, the Japanese are scared to death that Israel will enter the war, disrupt their oil supplies and start a third world war," said David G. Goodman, a professor of Japanese literature at the University of Illinois. But he added that a "blind spot" exists on Jews.
"In all the book stores, there are legitimate books along side this anti-Semitic garbage," Mr. Goodman said. "The question is why the Japanese don't seem to be able to tell the difference."
 
'A Deposit in People's Minds'
 Mr. Miyazawa, a history professor at Doshisha Women's College in Kyoto, who compiled the Jewish bibliography, said they tend to leave "a deposit in people's minds" that could "trigger anti-Semitism."
Indeed, Tatsuya Shoda, a manager at the main office of Maruzen book stores, a major chain, said Mr. Uno's books were stocked because he was widely respected as "an expert on Jewish issues." Mr. Uno declined to return several telephone calls asking for comment.
It is difficult to document the books' influence, but it is not uncommon for businessmen to express concern over what they see as excessive Jewish influence in American foreign policy.
"In Japan, there is no anti-Semitism," declared Takeshi Muromatsu, a literary critic on the board of the Japanese-Israel Friendship Association. "But many Japanese accept this Nazi-style stereotype that Jews control the world's finances. I would guess more than 80 percent of Japanese believe it."
 
Honor for American Financier
 The paradox, Mr. Muromatsu said, is that Japan and Jews have had good relations for many decades. For instance, Japanese histories continue to honor Jacob Schiff, the early 20th century New York financier, for helping Japan float war bonds to fight its war with Russia in 1904-05.
In the 1920's, "The Protocols of the Elders of Zion," the notorious Russian forgery portraying a Jewish conspiracy to rule the world that became a Nazi propoganda tool, was published in Japan. Other Nazi propaganda circulated during World War II, but the Government protected Jews in Japan, Shanghai and Manchuria.
Today the issue is complicated because many Japanese companies observe the Arab boycott against Israel, and because of widespread sympathy for Palestinians and anxieties about war with Iraq.
But the Israeli Ambassador, Mr. Eshkol, said that although Japan and Israel had had many difficulties over the years, ties have improved recently with stepped-up diplomatic exchanges and an increase in trade.
Mr. Eshkol added, in fact, that the recent attacks on Israel by Iraqi Scud missiles, coupled with Israel's not retaliating, had brought an outpouring of sympathy for Israelis, including offers of donations from schoolchildren.

HEADLINE: New York City's Reliance on Public Hiring Is Facing a Change

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
New York City's economy, in the midst of a slide that shows no sign of abating, now faces the decline of one of its last sources of strength: government hiring and government spending.
Of the 350,000 jobs that the city gained in the 1980's, almost 100,000 were government jobs, many on the city's own payroll. Even in 1988 and 1989, when other sectors of the economy were slowing or shifting into reverse, the city government added 20,000 workers, Federal statistics show. 
 The public sector -- city, state and Federal combined -- now accounts for 607,000 jobs, or about one of every six in New York City. And in 1989, the last year for which statistics are available, the $13.9 billionlocal government payroll -- including teachers, subway workers, hospital employees and others who work in city agencies -- outstripped Wall Street's payroll of $10.8 billion, the manufacturing sector's $10.6 billion and the construction industry's $4.2 billion.
 
From Source of Growth to 'Negative'
 But in its struggle to balance the worst budget deficits since the city's fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's, the Dinkins administration is contemplating layoffs and attrition that could alter the city's heavy reliance on public-sector spending. The cuts would also turn a source of growth into what Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, called "a negative part of the economy."
Under the law, New York City must havea balanced budget. But the consequences of removing large numbers of workers from its payroll has stirred talk about the extent to which a local government can soften or even reverse an economic decline through continued spending.
In any case, it is far from clear how many city jobs will be trimmed since the administration plans to add police officers and social workers even as it cuts jobs in departments like Sanitation and Parks. Under the city's preliminary spending plan, the head count would decline by about 5,000 between January and the end of June, then hold steady for a year.
Even in a time of retrenchment, the city would continue to hire workers to replace some of those who leave. But Philip R. Michael, the city's Budget Director, said hiring would drop to 20,000 workers a year from an annual average of 35,000 over the last six years. State budget cuts could further reduce that hiring to 15,000, he added. Though continuing labor negotiations have already changed layoff calculations, the economy is getting worse, not better, so the downward pressure will probably grow. Those hurt most by the cuts are likely to be women and minorities. About 28 percent of all black workers in New York City are employed in government, against 15 percent of the city's white workers. About 20 percent of all female workers in the city have government jobs, against 16 percent of the male workers.
"The public sector is now to the minority community what manufacturing once was," said Mark Levinson, an economist with District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, the largest of the municipal unions. "These layoffs are going to disproportionately affect that community."
But fallout from a concerted effort to shrink city government over the next few years would affect more than those who lose city jobs. The impact of their income loss would deepen as it rippled through the boroughs, as workers cut from the city payroll reduce spending and as grocery stores, barber shops, restaurants, movie theaters and other businesses feel the pinch and trim their own payrolls in response.
 
An Econometric Model
 Matthew P. Drennan, a professor at New York University's Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service who has developed an econometric model based on 25 years of New York City data, calculates that each job lost in the city, including public-sector jobs, eventually means the loss of 2.2 jobs. He also estimates that every dollar in city workers' lost income -- or any government spending -- eventually means $2.40 will be removed from the city's economy.
So if 10,000 municipal workers are cut from the payroll, Mr. Drennan said, the city would lose an additional 12,000 jobs in private industry. And if the former city workers earned an average of $30,000 a year, their joblessness would result in an annual loss to the city's economy of $720 million, which, he said, was "nothing to sneeze at."
Using its own model, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey came up with a slightly lower multiplier; it has calculated that for every 1,000 government jobs lost, 400 to 600 more jobs would be eliminated.
 
Unemployment Benefits
 Apart from those indirect effects, Mr. Levinson, the union economist, said the costs to the city of making the layoffs would be high. If New York dismissed 15,000 workers paid an average of $24,000 a year, and all received unemployment benefits of about $230 a week for 26 weeks, it would cost the city $90 million, he said. If 6,000 workers then qualified for welfare, with half receiving benefits for a year and the other half for six months, it would cost an additional $32 million, of which the city would pay $8 million.
And the city would also lose about $10 million in taxes that would have been paid by the workers, bringing the total cost to the city, Mr. Levinson said, to $108 million in the first year, offsetting some of the $360 million in wages the city would save.
In the case of some social workers whose salaries are partly underwritten by the Federal and state governments, Mr. Michael, the Budget Director, noted, the city would actually pay more at first to remove them from the payroll than it would to keep them on it.
 
Higher Taxes for Wealthy?
 Mr. Levinson argues that instead of layoffs the city should raise the tax it levies on the incomes of the wealthy, those he said "who have really benefited in the last decade." Some have suggested that property taxes on some homes, which have lagged behind rates in the suburbs, should be raised.
Rosemary Scanlon, the Port Authority's chief economist, said she believed that many New Yorkers would willingly pay higher taxes if assured that city services would be maintained.
"I think that, where possible, if the private economy is in a sharp retreat, you try and buffer it, within reason," she said, adding that such a strategy, which would entail continuing the city's high level of capital spending, was preferrable to "slash and burn techniques that are going on in the private sector."
But Professor Drennan disputed the extent to which the city could spend its way out of trouble. "It's generally agreed by economists that only the Federal Government can pull the economy out of a recession by spending more than it brings in," he said. "No city or state can do that."
 
Reinforced by History
 Those who favor cutting the muncipal work force, including Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, an independent research organization sponsored by businesses, say it is a lesson reinforced by New York's recent history.
From 1969 to 1974, when the city's economy nearly collapsed, private industry lost 400,000 jobs but local government jobs increased by 45,000 as the city borrowed more and more money to pay its bills. Then, its credit gone and its access to the bond market lost, the city came close to going bankrupt. In five years, municipal employment plummeted by 64,000 jobs.
"The reason why the contraction was so huge," Mr. Horton said, "was that the adjustment wasn't made earlier."
Delaying cuts in jobs again by spending in the face of a downturn, he said, would be a "prescription for disaster."

HEADLINE: Soviet Plant Struggles To Join the Modern Era

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
Aleksandr Samsonov, a towering man of gruff voice and crunching handshake, has little need for Harvard Business School techniques in running Moscow Watch Factory No. 1.
Instead, Mr. Samsonov relies on tough Communist tactics and primitive capitalist instincts, and with this "do what I say" approach, he has made his factory a showcase by Soviet standards. By Western standards, however, the factory remains years behind the time. 
 Mr. Samsonov likes to tell visitors that his factory made the watch that Mikhail S. Gorbachev presented to Ronald Reagan. He boasts that 80 percent of his factory's watches are exported.
 
Shortcomings Remain
 But Watch Factory No. 1 also claims achievements that would embarrass watchmakers at Seiko and Patek Philippe. Managers proudly note that customers now return as defective just 1.5 percent of the factory's watches, down from 4 percent five years ago.
And Mr. Samsonov notes that the 6,500-employee factory produced more than six million watches last year, up 60 percent from 1985. This means the factory produced 1,000 watches for each worker -- one-tenth the ratio at Seiko.
Still, there is no denying that since 1985, when Mr. Samsonov left his ministry post overseeing the watch industry to take the factory's helm, he has made Factory No. 1 a far more efficient place.
Tough-talking and 53 years old, Mr. Samsonov installed millions of rubles' worth of new machinery, hoping to double production. He eagerly fired laggards, began an anti-alcohol campaign and created a stern corporate culture that demanded hard work.
"There is a tough rule here that people should behave according to certain norms," he said, stretching his hands across the 20-foot-long conference table in his office. "Some people who don't like tough discipline will go work at other places. That's fine with me."
His factory's watches generate large sums of much-needed hard currency. Selling under the name Poljot, the watches command a good price abroad, often selling in Britain and France for $200. Most exports are to Western Europe and East Asia, with only a few going to the United States.
With watches sturdier than most other Soviet types, Poljot has outraced its domestic competition in introducing designs and technologies.
"This is a vanguard enterprise," said Valentina Dvornikova, as she took a short break from her workbench. "There is a lot of attention to quality and discipline here."
The factory's new designs are stolid, classical types, with neither the panache of Swatches nor the swagger of Rolexes. It was only five years ago that the factory began making women's watches.
"They make good, durable, no-frills, workman's watches," said Joseph Thomson, editor in chief of Modern Jeweler. "They make it on price and, to some extent, durability. But technologically the world has passed them by." Seventy percent of the watches are quartz; the rest, mechanical.
 
Struggling to Advance
 On that front, Mr. Samsonov is struggling to advance. In the section of his cavernous factory that makes quartz watches, he has added automated machines that slashed the time needed to put hands on a watch to 1.5 seconds from 90 seconds.
But where mechanical watches are assembled, the floor is filled with decades-old equipment. Behind dozens of rows of tables, women, young and old, are hunched over, squinting as they delicately insert minuscule gears and other parts. Foremen pace the floor like examination proctors trying to make sure no one is slacking off. The factory was founded in 1930 when the Soviet Government purchased all the equipment of a bankrupt watch factory in Canton, Ohio.
"Some Swiss watch people who visited our factory were amazed that we could still get so much out of these old machines," said Mr. Samsonov, whose own gleaming watch looks as if it weighs half a pound. He says the factory's profits have tripled since he arrived but declined to disclose revenues and earnings.
 
No Ordinary Manager
 A visit to Mr. Samsonov's office reveals immediately that he is not just another Soviet manager. The Lenin portrait in his office is not the routine, faded print adorning most managers' offices; instead, his Lenin is a three-foot-tall masterpiece of intricately inlaid mahagony and blond wood.
Mr. Samsonov is also different because when not working as a hard-nosed manager, he works as a hard-line Communist Party deputy in the Soviet Parliament. He is remembered for having once suggested that some pro-democracy student demonstrators be shipped to labor camps to learn the meaning of hard work.
In the factory and in Parliament, he pursues the same crusade -- the need for discipline. "In this country, productivity is three, four times lower than in America," he said. "If people want to live well, then they have to work well. No one ever died because of normal work. People become healthy if they work a lot."
As a result of glasnost and perestroika, he complains, the Soviet people have become less disciplined at work and may not be ready for their new freedoms.
"Discipline has decreased dramatically all over the country," he said. "The level of democracy must be in harmony with the cultural level of our society."
 
Influential Ties
 One reason his factory works so well is that Mr. Samsonov is on a first-name basis with many party stalwarts and ministry bureaucrats. And because his factory generates so much hard currency, it enjoys advantages that make other managers jealous. It is far easier for Mr. Samsonov to buy equipment and components abroad than for many managers.
His factory buys computer chips from Japan and is planning to buy a sophisticated $1.5 million Swiss machine that makes watch casings. With the machine, the factory will need just 10 people, instead of 150, to make six million casings a year.
"We shouldn't have to invent everything ourselves," he said. "We have to get involved with people who can teach us new technologies. The most important thing is to integrate ourselves into the world economy."
But even the status of the factory and its manager have not saved it from the nation's deepening economic morass. The factory is having trouble getting metal springs from its regular supplier in Byelorussia because the government there restricts exports to other republics.
And the factory sometimes has to import sheet metal because it cannot obtain domestic metal thin enough or of adequate quality. What is more, as the factory gears up to increase production, its main supplier of computer chips, a factory in Leningrad, has said it cannot meet demand.
 
Forced Self-Sufficiency
 As a result of such conditions, Factory No. 1 is one of many Soviet plants that have adopted an autarkic, do-it-yourself mentality. This leads to huge inefficiencies: A watch factory that produces its own computer chips, for example, would have to make major investments and could not enjoy large economies of scale.
At Factory No. 1, engineers have developed and built 20 automatic machines, far less sophisticated than those in Japan, on which watch cases snake from worker to worker. About 1,800 employees work directly in assembling watches, and 60 percent of them are adjusters or checkers. Industry experts say this is an astonishingly high percentage.
Henry B. Fried, an American watch expert who visited the Moscow factory, said it needed so many adjusters because "its machines may be too old and its cutting tools may be left too long before they are sharpened." He added, "They're far behind on automation and ultra-precision."
Mr. Samsonov seeks to offset this technological backwardness by pushing his employees to work harder. When he arrived, he found 200 workers who drank continually. He had his foremen meet with these workers to tell them to shape up, but discovered that under existing labor rules he could not fire them.
Using his influence and forceful personality, he put pressure on the union to give him the right to fire these workers.
"If anybody is drunk here or if somebody steals a watch, that person is going to be fired the next day," he said. "I tell people, 'Drink as much as you want. Take what you want. It's your fate. It's your life.' "

HEADLINE: Fixing Antique Furniture In an Old Railroad Station

BYLINE: By HAROLD FABER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CLAVERACK, N.Y.,

 BODY:
An abandoned railroad station here in Columbia County, about 115 miles north of New York City, has become the center of a nationwide operation for the repair and restoration of antique furniture.
"We repair spectacular furniture as well as boring furniture," said John Stair, managing director of Sotheby's Restoration, an arm of the well-known auction house. "The range of our work is on chairs worth $100 to chairs worth $70,000 each." 
 Mr. Stair's 4 master craftsmen, 10 journeymen and 4 apprentices work in wooden frame buildings, painted barn red, which once were the railroad depot, storage buildings and office of the old Boston and Albany Railroad, which ceased operations in 1937.
In the light and airy workshops one day recently, John Hanna was polishing a 1790 dining room table, Bill Drinkwater repairing two Chinese lacquer trunks, Alan Hamilton completing an early 18th-century tilt-top chess table, Thomas Hom applying gold leaf to a 1760 Italian mirror, Julie Rutschmann restoring a Regency bench and Neil Van Alstyne and Temprace DiCintio laquering the surface of four dining room chairs made by Giles Grundy back in the 1740's.
 
'Seen a Lot of Chairs'
 In the cabinet shop, John Dunham carefully used his chisels to carve wood for four Russian Pavlosk chairs, with flower pots on top of the chair stiles and monkey heads at the ends of the armrests, copying the design from a book of Russian furniture.
"I've seen a lot of chairs, but to have geraniums growing out of pots on top. . ." Mr. Stair said, his voice trailing off in disbelief.
When completed, the Russian chairs will be sent to their owner in Southern California, the 1740 chairs to Manhattan, the chess table to Massachusetts, the Chinese lacquer trunks to Connecticut and the 1760 Italian mirror to New York City.
"Having antique furniture is a headache," Mr. Stair said, noting that it was not only expensive to buy but expensive to maintain.
As an example, he cited the chess table, valued at an estimated $4,000, which took 26 hours to repair and restore at a cost to the client of about $1,300. Another object, the small curved Regency bench, worth between $6,000 and $8,000, would be repaired in 24 hours of work for $1,200, he said.
 
'An Old-Fashioned Generalist'
 "I worry about mistakes," Mr. Stair said. "I wander about the shops all day -- that's my job, talking to and conferring with the people doing the work. I am an old-fashioned generalist in these days when everybody seems to be a specialist."
Mr. Stair, who is 48 years old, was born in Brooklyn and served for four years in the Marine Corps before following a family tradition into the art and antique business. His grandfather was an art dealer in London. His father, Alistair Stair, operated his own business in 18th-century furniture on 57th Street in addition to being president of the New York Art and Antique Dealers Association.
That family connection helped Mr. Stair get his first job as a trainee with Sotheby's in London in 1964. He worked in Toronto and Los Angeles before starting Sotheby's restoration business in New York in 1979.
The Claverack operation began in 1987, following a well-established pattern of movement into the Hudson Valley. Mr. Stair and his wife bought a summer house in Cold Spring. But he soon was looking around to find a way to do business near his home.
 
Hard to Find Good Help
 He found what he thought was an ideal location for a repair center in Claverack railroad station. A few craftsmen came up from New York, but Mr. Stair recruited most of his staff locally.
"The problem in New York was that we faced criminals, dope addicts and young people from good families who thought they wanted to work with their hands but who had a high dropout rate," he said. "Up here, we have found sincere young people who want to take advantage of the good opportunities we have for work and make a career out of it."
Mr. Stair said his workshops offer an active apprentice program, with 10,000 hours of training required, "just the same as they had in the 19th century."
The wage scale starts at $5 an hour for beginners, rising to $7 an hour after two years and then to $12 for experienced workers. Senior master artisans can make up to $50,000 a year, he said.
"Even at that pay, they could not live in New York City," he said. "But up here, you can live well on that, own your own home and enjoy all the things you can't do in New York."
One of the artisans, Mr. Hamilton, who came to Claverack from New York, looked up from the chess table he was repairing. He now lives in Hillsdale, a few miles east of Claverack.
I like the slower pace of life and work up here," he said. "There's a lot more space and the open spaces keep you calm."
Mr. Stair himself now lives on a nearby farm in Claverack with his wife, Lynne, and four children. Two of his sons have followed him into the restoration business. One son, Colin, is the manager at Claverack and Brian is an apprentice polisher at the restoration's small shop in New York City.
"It's been a good move," Mr. Stair said. "All our expenses are under control, which wasn't possible in New York. Our costs are down and the only thing that fluctuates is our payroll. When the economy turns around, we could be very busy, handling twice the work."

"I've seen a lot of chairs, but to have geraniums growing out of pots on top . . ." said John Stair, head of the center. (David Jennings for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Delay in Further Rate Cuts Is Seen

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
A number of credit market analysts think the Federal Reserve Board will probably delay further cuts in short-term interest rates because of indications that a possible end to the Middle East war may be in sight.
They cite Iraqi and Soviet proposals for negotiated settlements and evidence that a powerful and decisive United States ground attack is imminent as signs that the war could be nearing its conclusion. 
 The chairman of the Fed, Alan Greenspan, has said that had Iraq not invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, the economy would probably have avoided falling into recession. If this were the case, an end to the fighting soon would almost certainly give consumer confidence a much-needed lift and provide more tangible aid for pocketbooks if oil prices fall at war's end.
This possible course of events, which many analysts say is highly plausible, would alleviate the need for more interest-rate cuts by the Fed to stimulate the economy.
"The Fed is of the opinion that the recent decline in the economy is due to the outbreak of the war," said Joseph Carson, a senior economist at Chemical Bank. "Therefore, if the end of the war is much closer than we thought even a few days ago, it could put them on hold for a while, to see how quickly confidence comes back."
 
Reason to Pause
 The Fed had good reason to pause in its manipulation of interest rates even before the prospects of a conclusion to the war emerged. After having lowered the overnight Federal funds rate by 1.75 percentage points since early November, the Fed was bound to stop to assess how much impact the decline in rates had had on the slumping economy. As a rule of thumb, analysts say it generally takes about six months for a change in monetary policy to be reflected in the pace of economic activity.
"It's one thing to ease when things are horrible," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Corporation. "But when you sense that things are bottoming out, you sit on your hands."
One source of concern -- slow money growth -- is beginning to show the effects of the Fed's ministrations. After barely budging for much of the fourth quarter, M-2, the monetary aggregate the Fed monitors most carefully, has begun to grow at a more rapid pace since about mid-January.
"The money numbers through early February suggest we may have a rebound under way," said Neal M. Soss, chief economist at the First Boston Corporation. "But the Fed will want to see more of them, and consequently may take a wait-and-see attitude about another easing in policy until the next F.O.M.C. meeting in March." He was referring to the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee meeting, at which monetary policy is decided upon.
 
Improvement for Banks
 Another big problem, the financial health of America's banks, is also showing signs of improvement, some analysts said.
In addition to the cuts in the funds rate, the Fed's decision to lower reserve requirements for banks and to cut the discount rate by a full percentage point has "liquified and ventilated the banking system," said Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist at Bear Stearns & Company. "Through the steps they have taken, they have taken some pressure off banks."
There are also signs that investors are feeling more comfortable about the outlook for banks. These signs include sharp increases in the price of outstanding bonds of troubled organizations like Citicorp, Chemical Bank and others. In addition, interest-rate differentials between three-month bank certificates of deposit and three-month Treasury bills have narrowed substantially since late December, Mr. Kudlow said.
"Late last year, spreads between C.D.'s and Treasuries had gotten as wide as 170 basis points," he said. "Now they are down their normal range of 45 basis points to 50 basis points."
 
Troubling Evidence Remains
 Despite some reassuring signs, there remains substantial evidence that the economy is still quite weak. Mindful of those problems, a number of economists continue to insist that the Fed will need to do much more to end the current downturn, even if the war ended tommorrow.
"The list of risks to economic revival is substantial and includes more than just a prolonged war," said Alan Sinai, president of Boston Company Economic Advisors Inc.
"The odds on a turnaround happening six months after the Fed began to aggressively ease are very low," he added. "Between the time Iraq invaded Kuwait and now, a lot of income and jobs have been lost."
In order to redress the slide, Mr. Sinai said the Fed would probably have to push the funds rate down another 75 basis points, to 5.5 percent, by midyear.
 
Questions for Greenspan
 Mr. Greenspan will no doubt be questioned on many of these issues tomorrow and Thursday, when he is scheduled to provide Congress with his semiannual report on the economy and monetary policy.
After being jolted by the recent news that the Producer Price Index, e xcluding food and energy costs, rose five-tenths of 1 percent in January, traders and economists will be looking closely at new consumer price data, which are expected to be released on Friday. Some analysts said the report might not provide much support for the view that the recession was bringing down inflation.
Brian Jones, an economist at Salomon Brothers, predicted that higher excise taxes on items like airline tickets, tobacco and luxury goods helped to push the so-called core rate of consumer price inflation -- which excludes food and energy prices -- up by six-tenths of 1 percent in January. An increase of that size would be the largest since July.
But the overall January Consumer Price Index is likely to fare better, Mr. Jones said. Thanks to falling gasoline and heating-oil prices last month, the full Consumer Price Index probably rose by four-tenths of 1 percent last month, compared with the rise of three-tenths of 1 percent in December, Mr. Jones said.

HEADLINE: Congress Rushes to Pass Benefits for Gulf Veterans

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18

 BODY:
Military personnel serving in the Persian Gulf may soon get help from Congress in dealing with economic hardships at home.
In a rush to show support for the troops, the House has already passed a bill to provide aid, and after the Senate reconvenes Tuesday it will consider the measure. 
 The legislation would protect men and women in the reserves who are called to active duty by guaranteeing their right to return to their civilian jobs. The bill would also stipulate that families of service members generally could not be evicted from their homes for failure to pay rent if the monthly rent is $1,200 or less. Such protection is currently available only when the rent is $150 or less.
Members of Congress are drafting dozens of other proposals to assist the veterans. "When our forces are facing the threat of Scud missile attacks or ground force assault," said Representative Michael Bilirakis, Republican of Florida, "the last thing these men and women need to worry about is whether or not their families will be evicted from their homes because they cannot afford the rent, or suffer loss of re-employment rights."
The bill would allow doctors called up for service to suspend payment of premiums on their medical malpractice insurance. Even while on active duty, doctors need such insurance to protect them against claims that might be filed by private patients they treated months or even years ago.
 
Provision on Court Cases
 The legislation passed by the House is an amendment to the Soldiers' and Sailors' Civil Relief Act of 1940. It would also require courts to postpone judicial proceedings at the request of anyone serving in the gulf.
Some members of Congress, including Senator John Heinz, Republican of Pennsylvania, are prodding the Pentagon to avoid assigning single parents and married military couples to the Persian Gulf if they have young children.
"Is it in the best interest of the United States of America and the U.S. armed forces that we take new mothers, days after delivering their infants, and place them in the way of Saddam Hussein's missiles?" Mr. Heinz asked. "This, in my view, defeats the entire purpose of a volunteer Army."
But Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, oppose such exemptions, saying they would undermine the "cohesion and esprit de corps" of military units. In a letter to Congress stating their position, Mr. Cheney and General Powell said reassignment of people with young children would "weaken our combat capability by removing key personnel" from units in the glf.
In January, Congress extended the deadline for troops to file income tax returns to six months after the end of their service in the gulf. They could receive further tax relief for up to five years if they were hospitalized with wounds.
Beyond such measures, lawmakers are stitching together a sweeping package of other education, insurance, medical, pension, housing and economic benefits.
 
Variety of Benefits
 For example, Representative G. V. (Sonny) Montgomery, the Mississippi Democrat who is chairman of the Veterans Affairs Committee, has introduced a comprehensive measure that would increase education benefits under the G.I. Bill, authorize the Small Business Administration to guarantee bank loans to veterans and increase veterans' eligibility for home loans, medical care and life insurance. His bill would also double the maximum amount of unemployment compensation for men and women leaving the armed forces so they could get up to 26 weeks of benefits, and it would set a goal for the Federal Government of awarding 5 percent of its commerical contracts to small businesses owned by veterans.
Senators John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio, and John McCain, Republican of Arizona, are assembling a similar package of assistance. The breadth of the endeavor is suggested by the numerous Senate committees involved in the work: Armed Services, Finance (tax breaks), Governmental Affairs (Civil Service employment preferences), Small Business and Veterans Affairs, among others.
"This package should not really be termed 'benefits,' " Mr. Glenn said. "It should be termed a fairness package, as I see it, because that is what we are trying to achieve."
Mr. Glenn said the recent "flurry of bills" reflected not only support for military men and women in the Persian Gulf, but also unanticipated problems caused by the heavy reliance on reserve forces.
 
Finding the Financing
 Most of the new benefits will cost money. An explosive political question is how much of the new spending must be offset by cuts in other Federal programs, in compliance with the new budget enforcement procedures adopted last year. The costs of the war itself are exempt from the statutory limits on Federal spending, and proponents of new veterans' benefits contend that these costs should also be exempt.
But the Bush Administration maintains that the costs of the war should be defined narrowly. And Senator Robert C. Byrd, the West Virginia Democrat who heads the Appropriations Committee, also insists that the exemption applies only to "emergency requirements" directly related to military operations in the gulf.
Thus, he said, a general increase in unemployment benefits for people leaving the armed forces would not be exempt from the limit on spending for Federal benefit programs.
