HEADLINE: With Chicago Calm, Daley Glides Toward Primary

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Feb. 18

 BODY:
For much of the 1980's, politics in Chicago was a cross between a street fight and civil war.
Whites voted for whites and blacks voted for blacks. Politicians would switch parties to run as spoilers if it would keep a rival from winning. And at a tempestuous City Council meeting after the death of Mayor Harold Washington, at least one alderman wore a bulletproof vest just in case. 
 But the waters have calmed in the two years since Richard M. Daley, the low-key, 48-year-old son of Richard J. Daley, the longtime Mayor and Democratic boss of Chicago, won a special election to fill the remainder of Mr. Washington's term.
The younger Mayor Daley, with his Everyman demeanor and good-government mantle, has brought this fractious city an uncharacteristic stability that has frustrated his critics and helped make him the clear front-runner in his current re-election bid.
"The edge is off Chicago politics," said David Axelrod, a political consultant to the incumbent and former consultant to Mayor Washington. "After 10 years of turmoil and angry, divisive politics, we've settled into a comfortable, secure kind of a politics, where people are actually talking to each other, where you can disagree with people without defaming them."
People like Mr. Axelrod say Mr. Daley is the main reason for Chicago's relative peace. Critics say it is luck, timing and political pedigree. They say the Mayor has just been on good behavior until he wins his first full term.
Either way, with only a week remaining before the Feb. 26 Democratic primary, Mr. Daley leads the polls, while his opponents -- one black, one white -- grope for something to pin on him.
The black candidate, Danny K. Davis, is a Cook County commissioner whose campaign got a late and disorganized start and who has been unable to inspire a black electorate left fragmented since Mayor Washington's death. It is widely predicted that the black turnout on Primary Day will be low. The white candidate, former Mayor Jane M. Byrne, has not won an election since 1979 and has been all but ostracized by Democratic Party regulars. That has left her pulling single digits in the polls.
In the latest Chicago Tribune poll, published Sunday, Mr. Daley was favored by 53 percent of those who said they were most likely to vote Democratic, Mr. Davis by 21 percent and Mrs. Byrne by 6 percent. Eighteen percent of the blacks polled said they would vote for Mr. Daley, 45 percent said they would vote for Mr. Davis and 8 percent favored Mrs. Byrne.
Twenty percent of those polled were undecided, and most of those were black. The poll of 600 Chicago voters, taken Feb. 9-11, had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points.
 
Beyond His Father's Shadow
 Mr. Daley's huge lead in the polls, plus the distraction of war in the Persian Gulf, has fostered one of the quietest mayoral campaigns in recent memory and has fueled speculation not about whether Mr. Daley would continue to serve as Mayor, but for how much longer. Many say that he is already looking to the Governor's mansion to get beyond the shadow of his father, and that he was not especially disappointed that a Republican, Jim Edgar, won last November's race for governor, making it easier for Mr. Daley, as a Democrat, to run for governor if he wants to.
Whatever his ambitions, Mr. Daley is coming to be seen as a Mayor with a charmed administration. Not only has he not faced the career-ending blows of some of his predecessors but, like former President Ronald Reagan, he has also surrounded himself with shrewd political advisers.
The result is that Chicagoans will endure from Mayor Daley what they would not endure from other mayors. In 1979, for example, the city was slow to clear the roads in a winter of record snowfalls. Voters blamed Mayor Michael A. Bilandic and swept him out of office the first chance they got. But when a big snowstorm caught the Daley administration off guard last year, the Mayor shrugged it off and said he knew how people felt. It took him an hour to get home, too, he said. The voters and the press were satisfied.
Mayor Daley has also been blessed with a healthy economy and a welcoming City Council.
 
Support From the Council
 While Mr. Washington labored under a $90 million deficit, Mr. Daley got a $180 million windfall from the state in the form of an income tax surcharge in 1989, the year he took office. In the Washington years, a tightfisted Council majority led by Alderman Edward R. Vrdolyak opposed the Mayor at every turn. But Mayor Daley has had the solid support of 26 of the 50 aldermen 90 percent of the time, enough to pass virtually whatever he wanted, a recent University of Illinois study showed.
Critics, especially blacks who are still bitter over the roadblocks that Mr. Washington ran into, complain that white politicians are more willing to work with Mayor Daley. "The Daley name is paying off," said Lu Palmer, a radio talk show host who is a leader of black community affairs.
But the Mayor's supporters say that, like his father, he is a shrewd administrator who, despite his broken syntax, thick Chicago brogue and "gee whiz" manner, knows how to deflect detractors and keep the trains and sewers running.
"There's a lack of artifice about him," said Eugene Kennedy, who wrote a biography of the elder Mayor Daley. "He's not the candidate of photo opportunities and icon-making. He resists the cosmetics and manipulation of handlers. He's very comfortable being Mayor. He understands it. It is not at all a mystery to him."
To the frustration of his opponents, Mr. Daley anticipates their criticism and tries to pre-empt it. While he angered blacks early in his term when he cleared City Hall of appointees from the previous administration, he later made sure that 18 of his 44 department heads were black or Hispanic. And perhaps more important, he kept blacks in charge of the areas where his administration was considered most vulnerable, like the police department, schools and public housing.
Critics say that in a city with slightly more blacks than whites the percentage of black appointees is not high enough and that everyone knows the real power lies with the Mayor's inner circle, mostly white men from his South Side ward. But at least the official flow chart shows what the Mayor likes to call "a rainbow cabinet."
 
'A Positive Backlash'
 Probably the most enduring criticism of Mayor Daley is that he is not the intellectual Harold Washington was. Critics like to remind people that Mr. Daley failed the bar exam twice before he passed it. But even that has worked for him.
"He's gotten a positive backlash from it," said Don Rose, a Democratic political analyst who managed Mrs. Byrne's first mayoral campaign. "He comes out and says something resembling English, and people say, 'I didn't know he could talk!' It helps him."
Mayor Daley, a former Cook County State's Attorney, has rarely allowed himself to be on the defensive. Instead, he has been running a "feel-good" administration, bent on projects like building a new airport, doling out city services to private businesses, and most important, critics say, watching his step with an eye toward Election Day, April 2.
"He has been principally concerned with avoiding controversy," said Judson Miner, who was the corporation counsel for Mayor Washington.
Because campaign contributions from the business community have overwhelmingly gone to Mr. Daley in this race, some political analysts say the Mayor will soon be obligated to return the favor.
 
'Pinstripe Patronage' Predicted
 "He has been a very good boy for the last two years," Mr. Rose said. "We will begin to see the spoils system during the first full term. Pieces of the city will be sold off to keep him in office. Then we will see pinstripe patronage."
The Mayor makes no apologies for his courting of businesses, and says he has helped heal the city. "People were just sick and tired of everybody fighting for the sake of fighting and nothing was accomplished," Mr. Daley said in an interview. "I said, 'Hey, let's move on with it. Let's get it done.' "
While he may spend his working hours making deals in high places, many say he is hot dogs and White Sox at heart. He works in his father's old fifth-floor office at his father's desk beneath his father's portrait. And he lives with his wife, Maggie, and their three children in a modest brick bungalow a few blocks from where he and his father grew up in Bridgeport, a working-class, mostly white ethnic South Side community that once had an iron gate to keep out blacks from an adjacent neighborhood.
Critics say Mr. Daley's success has been mostly in public relations. "They've been masterful," said Jacky Grimshaw, a political analyst who was a top aide to Mayor Washington. "You don't see him on TV without a black woman. But their true Bridgeport selves will emerge after April 2."
The Mayor shrugs off such predictions. "What, I'm going to come out with big horns on me?" he said in the interview. "Fangs, blood, beating the little kids, shooting them and selling dope?"
 
The Politics of Pragmatism
 At the moment, critics do not pose a big problem for the Mayor. Mr. Davis, the black candidate, has had to watch as dozens of black ministers and business executives, wanting to go with a winner, extol Mr. Daley from the pulpit or act as host at $200-a-person fund-raising events for him.
Nate Clay, a black political analyst, predicts that the Mayor will win close to one-fourth of the black vote. He got 8 percent in 1989 "without even trying," Mr. Clay said.
Some black politicians are already preaching the politics of pragmatism. "It's a sad day when we've got people who go around saying it's got to be all black or it's got to be all white," Lemuel Austin Jr., a black alderman, said in a speech at a South Side church a few weeks ago.
Some blacks are already looking to 1995 as the next best hope, and have written off this election. "I don't want to see us embarrassed, but that's what's going to happen," Mr. Palmer said. "We don't have anybody who can beat Daley. I don't even know if there is a candidate in the white community. He was in before he even ran."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mayor Richard M. Daley of Chicago, center, campaigning for re-election at a Lutheran church on the North Side. With the Democratic primary only a week away, Mr. Daley leads his two opponents in the polls. (Steve Kagan for The New York Times) (pg. A14)

HEADLINE: Holtzman Sees Budget Gap Rise

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
The New York City Comptroller, Elizabeth Holtzman, warned yesterday that the city faced a larger budget gap over the next 16 months than what the Dinkins administration has announced so far.
Ms. Holtzman predicted that rising costs and shrinking revenues meant that the city faced a $300 million gap for the current fiscal year, ending June 30, even though the administration says it has balanced the budget through various measures. She also estimated that the gap for next year was $1.2 billion more than the $2.2 billion the administration had said it needed to close. 
 "We think that most of the city's major revenue projections are overly optimistic," the Comptroller said. "We believe tax revenues will fall and spending will increase." Her projections will be detailed later this week in a review of the city's latest financial plan, which Mayor David N. Dinkins issued last month.
The biggest single item cited by Ms. Holtzman as changing since then was Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's proposal to slash aid to localities because of the state's own fiscal troubles. The Comptroller estimated that would cost the city $635 million.
But she said other factors are widening the budget gap, including rising overtime bills and debt service costs and reduced collections from personal-income taxes and other revenues.
Eli Attie, a spokesman for Mayor David N. Dinkins, said the city administration was well aware of the threatened loss of state aid, which the Mayor's office estimated at more than $600 million. As for the rest of the projections, the Mayor's office reserved specific comment until the Comptroller's report was received and studied.
"The Comptroller has made these kinds of projections before," Mr. Attie said. "Sometimes they have been very helpful, and sometimes wildly pessimistic. We believe our data are at least as accurate as the Comptroller's. We will listen to what she has to say, but for now we stand by our own analysis."
Ms. Holtzman's economic model forecasts a greater loss of private and public jobs than the model on which the city's budget is based. She said the city could lose 110,000 private and public jobs this year, double the number predicted by the city's budget office. Next year she foresees the loss of another 68,000 jobs, in contrast to the budget's projection of 8,000 new jobs.

HEADLINE: Business and Health;
Accountability In Health Care

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
EMPLOYERS, insurers, medical societies and hospitals are pressing to create tests and guidelines that they hope will bring more order and economic accountability to a health-care system that has traditionally been based on the judgments of doctors who may often disagree.
In a major development last week, 11 large companies and their insurers decided to test a system in which employees and their doctors are asked about specific results of medical treatments.
Employees treated for lower back pain, for example, would be asked whether they could climb stairs, bend over to tie their shoes and do other things reflecting their health status.
The test will seek to determine whether the system is "a useful and valid way of demonstrating accountability," said Bill Goss, the health-care programs manager at the General Electric Company. Large employers spend hundreds of millions of dollars each year on employee health care. "But we are not really sure whether we are getting value from it," said Mr. Goss, who is chairman of the group conducting the test.
The companies and insurers taking part include American Telephone and Telegraph, with the Travelers; Ameritech, with Illinois Blue Cross and Blue Shield; Digital Equipment, with Fallon Community Health Plan, Harvard Community Health Plan and Matthew Thornton Health Plan, three New England health maintenance organizations; General Electric's aerospace unit, with U.S. Healthcare, and General Motors, with Blue Cross of Missouri and St. Louis and Kaiser Permanente in Cleveland.
Other participants are Hercules, with the Intermountain group in Salt Lake City; Honeywell, with<biCigna; James River, with Aetna; Marriott, with Prudential, and Proctor & Gamble and Promus, both with Metropolitan Life.
Doctors and patients will use questionnaires developed by medical authorities for Dr. Paul Ellwood, president of Interstudy, a nonprofit research group based in Excelsior, Minn. The sponsor is the American Managed Care Association, whose members include 150 large companies that use health maintenance organizations and networks of doctors and hospitals.
During 12 months, the 11 companies will all ask employees about the same two or three medical conditions. Lower back pain, angina (heart attack) and asthma are the most likely subjects, said John Doyle, the project's coordinator at Interstudy.
Dr. Ellwood said Interstudy questionnaires were already being used in a similar project at half a dozen group medical practices across the country, including the Cleveland Clinic in Ohio. The American Group Practices Association is the sponsor.
In yet another project, General Motors, Ford Motor, Chrysler and the United Automobile Workers union agreed this month to work on quality-ofcare measures with nine health maintenance organizations in southeastern Michigan. The H.M.O.'s will be required to meet certain standards and their members will be asked whether the H.M.O.'s provided satisfactory care.
The American Medical Association and several medical specialty professional groups are taking a different tack. They are developing guidelines for medical procedures and treatments that are based on a consensus of views of experienced doctors and from medical journals.
The A.M.A. says the guidelines will be parameters, leaving ample room for variations in particular cases. "The specialty societies' fear is that if they don't develop guidelines, the Government will do it for them," said Dr. David M. Eddy, a professor of health policy and management at Duke University.
Indeed, Congress has already ordered Federal studies of both guidelines and medical results that the Government calls patient outcome research. "At least we ought to know where we are getting the biggest bang for the buck without causing harm to patients," said Ira Raskin, an economist who is acting director of the Center for Medical Effectiveness at the Federal Public Health Service.
Hospitals are also developing practice guidelines and "statements of expected performance," said Dennis O'Leary, president of the Joint Commission on Accreditation of Health Care Organizations, which accredits hospitals.
"We used to assume that clinical judgment alone was an adequate source of truth," Dr. Eddy said. "Now we have to go out there and measure the consequences of different medical activities."
"The problem is: How do you measure the whole spectrum of health care?" said Margaret E. O'Kane, executive director of the National Committee for Quality Assurance, a nonprofit group that accredits health maintenance organizations. "There are whole areas where you just don't know the answers. We're all grappling for measurements."

HEADLINE: Texas Calls Halt to Waste-Disposal Sites

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18

 BODY:
Reacting to public concern over proposals to burn and bury thousands of tons of chemical wastes, Texas is about to become the first state to suspend development of new commercial hazardous-waste sites and stop expansions of existing ones.
The rules, requested by Gov. Ann Richards and to be enacted this week by the Texas Water Commission, halt until at least September actions to issue permits for commercial hazardous-waste projects in Texas, the nation's largest producer of chemical poisons. 
 The action, which stalls projects sought by 35 waste-disposal companies, is meant to give legislators time to find a balance between the needs of nearly 11,000 businesses that generate hazardous wastes and the concerns of residents unwilling to live near new dumps and incinerators.
But the moratorium also crystallizes more clearly than before the political, economic and environmental problems that Texas and other industrial states face in the disposal of wastes, problems that threaten to worsen.
 
Worries in Other States
 From New York to the Deep South, states are struggling over how to handle the wastes they generate, and are erecting barriers against outside wastes.
Industrial groups say more space is needed to dispose of wastes, or companies may have to curtail their businesses or dump illegally. The water commission, an environmental agency, does not deny that, but it says the problem is one that must be confronted by political leaders.
Buck Jim Wynne 3d, chairman of the water commission, said state lawmakers need to understand the emotional and economic issues in any proposal to establish hazardous-waste sites.
"With this dramatic action, we hope to generate the attention that's needed to take a hard look at the whole issue," said Mr. Wynne, who serves at the pleasure of the Governor. "The bottom line is that we need more landfills, more incinerators, more capacity to handle hazardous wastes. I hope we go beyond the slogans and focus on the hazardous-waste crisis coming in this state."
 
Putting Pressure on Industry
 Environmental leaders in Texas said Mr. Wynne's call for more disposal sites was misguided and politically impractical. One issue that most upsets Texans these days is any proposal to put a hazardous-waste site near a community. Public outcry reached a peak last year, with a proposal to build an incinerator near Houston.
"Texas is being turned into one big toxic-waste dump," said Rick Abraham, director of Texans United, an environmental group based in Houston. "People are upset. They realize these sites are dangerous. Industry needs to implement waste-reduction programs, but they aren't going to try that until they are forced to."
Governor Richards's letter to Mr. Wynne on Feb. 6 said in part, "I am convinced that the state is moving too quickly to grant permits to facilities that jeopardize public health and sensitive environments." She added, "Most, if not all, of these new projects have been strenuously opposed by citizens groups and local officials."
Texas is far from the only state grappling with safe disposal of industrial wastes. Last fall, New York alerted the owner of a new hazardous-waste site that it was restricting the wastes that could be dumped there to those generated in the state or from states that had agreements with New York.
 
Battles in the South
 South Carolina and North Carolina are battling over restrictions to interstate shipments of hazardous waste. The Alabama Legislature has sought to restrict the importing of hazardous wastes to the nation's largest commercial chemical waste landfill in Emelle, an action that was deemed unlawful by a Federal appellate court and that the state is appealing.
In 1976, when the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act was passed, Congress hoped to avoid such disputes by ending the practices that had led to leaky landfills and polluted swamps. In 1984, the law was amended to include strict rules for generating, transporting and disposing of hazardous wastes. The rules led companies to design specially engineered waste dumps, incinerators and deep wells for permanently storing hazardous wastes.
Most of the estimated 350 million tons of hazardous wastes generated each year are produced by large corporations and disposed of in their own incinerators or dumps. But smaller businesses must also meet the requirements of the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act. The law had the effect of concentrating the wastes of these smaller businesses at specific commercial sites. And because these businesses must pay to have their wastes taken care of, what had been worthless poisons have been turned into an extraordinarily valuable commodity.
 
More Lucrative Than Ever
 Last year, the commercial hazardous waste-disposal industry generated revenues of $3.5 billion to $4.5 billion, some industry analysts said, and is growing 20 percent annually.
In September, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency took steps to make the industry more profitable when it issued rules to broaden the types of wastes considered hazardous.
The nation's chemical-waste companies have besieged states with applications to build new incinerators, special landfills, deep well-injection systems and disposal plants. Texas, which generates 70 million tons of waste annually, has been a particular target.
More than 60 hazardous-waste businesses operate in Texas, according to the water commission. In 1990 alone, officials said, nine new hazardous-waste incinerators were proposed.
Texas environmental groups and community leaders reacted with dismay to the proposals and held public protests, filed court actions and filled city and county council meetings. Public outcry reached a peak last year, when Houston Chemical Services gained permission from the Texas Water Commission to build a commercial incinerator in La Porte. The permit was approved over the objections of the City Council, the county commissioners and the water commission's own hearing examiner.
In Robstown, 15 miles west of Corpus Christi, Texas Ecologists Inc. operates a 240-acre commercial hazardous-waste landfill and has asked for approval to put 15 percent to 30 percent more waste in each of the pits it digs. The permit has been put on hold.

HEADLINE: Barclays Plans To Cut Jobs

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 18

 BODY:
Barclays Bank P.L.C. said today that it intended to sharply reduce its work force, perhaps by 15 percent to 20 percent over approximately five years.
Barclays hopes 13,000 or more jobs can be eliminated through retirements and resignations, said a spokeswoman.
In an interview in today's issue of The Financial Times, the bank's chairman, Sir John Quinton, said the cuts in the work force of 87,000 were necessary because of the recession. The bank said details of the job cuts would be announced when financial results were disclosed on Feb. 28.
Barclays has about 8,000 employees in the United States.
The Barclays spokeswoman, who insisted on anonymity, said: "The 15 to 20 percent is very much a forecast still. We don't have an actual program of cuts up to that level to be implemented. It is a forecast we will be working with over the next five years or so."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Money Fund Investors' New Tack

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
Investors' headlong rush toward the safest type of money market funds seems to have slowed, perhaps reflecting lower interest rates and reduced fears about the fragility of America's financial system.
Since the beginning of 1991, investors have added money to ordinary money market funds at about the same pace as they have added cash to the super-safe funds that invest only in Federal Government securities. 
 "Yields have dropped to the point where investors are looking for a little pickup in yield," said Martha Wittbrodt, editor of IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report.
That is a sharp turnabout from the attitudes that prevailed in late 1990, when investors seemed to value safety above all else. In the final four months of the year, those money funds that do not promise to buy only Treasury securities, or Treasuries and Government agency paper, saw their total assets fall by $3.4 billion, or almost 1 percent, according to IBC/ Donoghue.
 
Shift in Last 2 Weeks
 By contrast, those funds that restricted their investments to Treasury securities picked up $8.3 billion over that period, a gain in assets of 41.7 percent. And funds that take on only a bit more risk, by adding Government agency securities to Treasuries, added $5.7 billion, raising their assets by 21.4 percent.
Adding together the two categories of super-safe funds, their share of the money market fund universe, which had been under 11 percent, rose to 15.2 percent by Jan. 29 of this year. But over the last two weeks, it has edged lower, to 15.1 percent.
That slight decline in market share has reflected a pickup in purchases of the general money market funds, not a loss in assets for the safer ones.
In part, the new move reflects the fact that investors who are willing to accept the slight increase in risk inherent in general money market funds are being well compensated for it. At the end of September, the 30-day yield on the average Treasury-only fund was 7.3 percent, only 19 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, less than the 7.49 percent offered by the average general fund.
By last week, the return on the Treasury funds had plunged to 6.28 percent, but the yield on general funds was down to only 6.74 percent, a difference of 46 basis points.
That rise in the difference is a bit puzzling. The tenor of the markets in recent weeks has been one of rising confidence that the recession is nearing an end, a move that would normally lead to a reduced quality differential.
No money market funds engage in practices that come even close to really risky investing. Those that venture past Government securities buy assets like short-term notes of corporations, called commercial paper, and bank certificates of deposit.
While they can buy securities that do not mature for at least a year, on average the maturities must be no longer than 120 days, a figure that will be cut to 90 under a rule approved last week by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Even those that buy commercial paper now restrict almost all of their buying to paper rated A-1 by the Standard & Poor's Corporation or P-1 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. Those are the top grades, and indicate minimal risk.
A few years ago, it was common for funds to venture into the next grade down, which is still investment grade. But there were two defaults involving commercial paper that had been rated at the second level, and that both scared fund managers and persuaded the S.E.C. to restrict the amount of such paper that funds can hold. The defaults did not cause money market fund investors to lose any money, but only because the sponsors of several funds stepped in to make up the losses.
As a result of the increased caution, many second-tier issuers have been forced to drastically scale back their issuances of commercial paper, further reducing the spread in quality between the safest money market fund investments and the most risky. That trend makes the rising spread even more puzzling.
One explanation is that the abrupt fall in interest rates has been brought on by the easing of credit by the Federal Reserve, whose actions are felt most sharply in the Government securities market.
"The Fed has really pressed on the accelerator," said Patricia Klink, president of the Discount Corporation of New York Advisers, a money management firm, adding that even with the increased spread, she did not believe there had yet been "a real classic flight to quality." Such a move, she said, would send Treasury bill rates falling even more abruptly.
One aspect of the money market fund figures that may also be surprising is that the funds have not lost assets in recent weeks, despite the surge of the stock market. On Jan. 15, just before the stock market took off, the funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue had $436.4 billion in assets. By Feb. 12, that figure had risen to $447.8 billion.
Wherever the money came from to propel the stock market's sharp rise, it would appear that the money market funds were not the source. If that indicates many individual investors are still on the sidelines, it could be a bullish indicator for stocks.

HEADLINE: Laws Encourage Car Alarms, But Din May Not Be Worth It

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY

 BODY:
It seemed a minor technicality, an amendment to section 167-d(12) of the New York State Insurance Law, and it took effect a decade ago very quietly. But since then every New Yorker has heard its consequences, often around 2 in the morning.
The new law required insurance companies to give discounts for cars equipped with anti-theft devices, and the discounts encouraged policyholders to install car alarms. 
 Ten years and countless false alarms later, there is no evidence that the wailing has reduced car theft in New York or anywhere else, which leads some sleep-deprived citizens to ask: Why is it public policy to subsidize car alarms? Why is it not public policy to outlaw them?
Insurance company actuaries view the discounts as unmerited and unfair to other policyholders. Criminologists say there are better and quieter ways to protect cars. Economists argue that the alarms' benefits, if any, are far outweighed by their social costs. Vigilantes have made their point by attacking noisy cars with eggs and baseball bats.
Yet the alarms continue to proliferate, and lobbyists for the car-alarm industry have helped persuade other states to adopt similar policies. Illinois, Kentucky, Massachusetts, Michigan and Rhode Island also require discounts, and the New Jersey Legislature is considering the most sweeping measure yet: a bill making alarms or other anti-theft devices mandatory in all cars worth more than $5,000.
"These laws are a private bonanza for the alarm industry, but they're ridiculous social policy," said Lawrence W. Sherman, a professor of criminology at the University of Maryland who is the president of the Crime Control Institute, a nonprofit research organization in Washington.
"Car alarms are a terrible urban blight with obvious social costs -- noise pollution, increased stress, wasted police manpower dealing with broken alarms -- and it's not clear there are any benefits in return. No study has demonstrated they reduce auto theft. Personally, in 10 years I've never seen anyone respond to one, because people know the vast majority of them are false alarms."
Studies of home burglar alarms have repeatedly shown that there are about 20 false alarms for every real one, and Dr. Sherman said there was no reason to think the ratio would be lower for car alarms. Some car alarms can be set off by vibrations from passing trucks, wind, rain, or a tap from another car's bumper, and some are designed to go off briefly every time the driver enters or leaves the car.
Even if the alarm attracts attention to a crime, will anyone interfere? Not likely, said Harold Takooshian, a professor of psychology at Fordham University who has run experiments near his office on Manhattan's West Side. He did not use car alarms, but he did study how bystanders react to car thieves.
In one study, a researcher pretended to be a thief nervously using a coat hanger to break into a car and steal from it. Most bystanders on the sidewalk who noticed the burglaries did nothing. In the minority of cases where people got involved, sometimes the bystanders called the police or questioned the thief, but twice as often their involvement consisted of helping the thief break in.
 
'This Is My Shtick'
 Most of these helpful souls apparently assumed, without asking, that it was the thief's own car. But a few clearly had larcenous ideas of their own. "Hey, baby, this is my shtick," said one youth, who took the hanger from the thief, used it to open the door, watched the thief remove a television from the car, and then asked for a tip.
These findings, together with similar results from 29 other American cities where Dr. Takooshian repeated the study, do not seem to show great benefit from alerting a neighborhood to car theft. Nor is there much support for car alarms to be found in insurance company statistics.
Some trends in car theft are unclear, such as the rate of theft nationally. The number of thefts reported to the police has been increasing in recent years, according to F.B.I. reports. At the same time, the number of theft claims reported to insurance companies has been declining, according to the Highway Loss Data Institute, which collects data for insurers. One trend that does seem clear in the data is that cars equipped with anti-theft devices, which are most commonly alarms, are more likely than other cars to be stolen or broken into.
"In New York, cars with these devices have a rate of claims that's three times higher than that of other cars," said Dale Nelson, an actuary with State Farm, the nation's largest car insurer. "The comparison is a little misleading, because these devices tend to be installed on theft-prone cars in high-crime areas, but it does indicate that these devices are not all that effective, which is why we don't think it makes sense to give discounts for them."
 
Better Than Nothing?
 That sentiment is shared by Sara Schlenker, an actuary at Allstate, the second-largest auto insurer. "We haven't seen any evidence to justify the discounts," she said. "Our gut feeling is that an audible alarm does very little if anything to limit losses."
Proponents of car alarms argue that the alarms are better than nothing. State Senator Ronald L. Rice, Democrat of Newark, the sponsor of the bill making anti-theft devices mandatory, said the auto-theft problem is so serious in his home district of Newark that his constituents are willing to endure the alarms' noise.
"I don't know if there's any real evidence the alarms are effective," said Mr. Rice, a former police officer. "I guess it's more of a subjective feeling than anything else, but I think anything you can do to deter a thief will help."
Mr. Rice's bill is being supported by a trade group, the Car Audio Specialists Association/Vehicle Security Association. The group's first vice-president, Barnet Fagel, said that car alarms could be both effective and non-polluting.
 
Measuring the Costs
 "There are no hard statistics that the alarms have worked," he said, "but my own experience in installing them tells me that they can be very effective if they're installed properly. The problem is that some systems are designed or installed badly, so they go off at the wrong times, and I'd be in favor of legislation to eliminate the bad systems. We know that noise pollution is a problem. The question is, do we curse the darkness or light a candle?"
But others doubt that the alarms' social costs could be justified in densely populated areas. It is hard to measure these costs -- the annoyance, for instance, of the Broadway audience that endured three alarms from the adjacent parking lot during a recent performance of "Mule Bone," or the frustration voiced by Woody Allen's partner in "Annie Hall" when sex is interrupted by a wailing vehicle.
But some ways to measure environmental costs have been developed by economists like Richard T. Carson, a professor at the University of California at San Diego, who is an expert on the impact of air and water pollution. He is currently working for the State of Alaska on the damage assessment of the Exxon Valdez oil spill.
One rule of thumb for measuring the cost of alarms waking people, Dr. Carson said, would be to value people's lost leisure time at half their normal wage. In New York City, where the average wage is $15 an hour, a car alarm that woke 500 people for 15 minutes would thus cause more than $900 in social costs -- greater than the value of the typical radio being protected.
 
$10,000 Social Cost
 And assuming that there are, say, 10 false alarms for every real one, then the social cost of protecting a car from one attempted theft would rise above $10,000. That is twice the value of the average car that is stolen.
"You can come up with various figures using other methods," Dr. Carson said, "but it probably wouldn't change the outcome of a cost-benefit analysis. We know that the social costs of car alarms are not small, and we don't know that there any benefits, so there's a fairly good case for either outlawing them or giving stiff fines for false alarms."
Councilman Sheldon S. Leffler of New York City, who unsuccessfully proposed banning car alarms several years ago, said last week that he thought the idea would be more popular today. Henry J. Stern, a former City Councilman who is the president of the Citizens Union, a private watchdog group, agreed with him.
"The time has come to end this nuisance," Mr. Stern said. "We should certainly eliminate the insurance discounts for the alarms. Back in 1980 I would have voted for the discounts, because the alarms seemed like a way to deter thieves, but all they seem to do is stop New Yorker from sleeping. They should go the way of leaded gasoline, another car pollutant."
Dr. Sherman of the Crime Control Institute said he would favor either banning the alarms or issuing a fine whenever an alarm went off without any sign of forced entry, a tactic many communities have adopted toward home burglar alarms.
"At the very least," Dr. Sherman said, "there ought to be some effort made to make people with car alarms ashamed of how rude they're being to their neighbors. Moral appeals can be very effective with this kind of problem. Perhaps the police could be empowered to slap a big sticker on the windshield saying, 'Noise Polluter'."
He and other criminologists said that there are more effective devices that frustrate the thief instead of the neighborhood. These devices also generally qualify for discounts. Statistics gathered by insurance companies and the Federal Government have a shown dramatic reduction in theft when cars have electronic systems that disable the engine unless the right key is used.
Several new systems use silent devices that transmit radio signals, allowing stolen cars to be tracked on a computer screen. There are also quiet low-technology solutions available like the Club, a $60 bar that locks the steering wheel in place, although it generally does not qualify for the same insurance discounts as an alarm.
"The Club is visible, so it deters thieves from even attempting the crime," said Robert D. McCrie, a professor of security management at John Jay College of Criminal Justice in Manhattan. "It's cheap, it's simple, and it doesn't pollute the environment."
The Fraternal Order of Police last week endorsed the Club and began selling it in local lodges. The national president, Dewey R. Stokes, said the group had decided against endorsing any alarm systems.
"A thief can turn off the alarm and be driving away in 15 seconds, so what difference does the noise make?" Mr. Stokes asked. "Are the neighbors going to do anything? Considering the noise, they're probably glad to see the car going away."

HEADLINE: Talks on Gulf Crisis Lift Foreign Stocks

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Talks on the Persian Gulf war between President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union and Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq lifted stock prices and the United States dollar yesterday on overseas markets. Oil prices headed lower.
The talks in Moscow brought a proposal from Mr. Gorbachev for an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, which Mr. Aziz is conveying to Baghdad, and raised hopes for peace. That set off a wave of buying of stocks and the dollar. 
 No trading occurred in the United States, where the financial and commodity markets were closed for the Washington's Birthday holiday.
In Tokyo, where the global trading day begins, the stock exchange's main index soared to a six-month high yesterday in brisk trading, then fell today on heavy profit taking.
The Nikkei average of 225 stocks rose 3.5 percent yesterday, to close at 26,230.01, but fell 63.03 points, or less than 1 percent, today. At the end to today's trading, the Nikkei was at 26,166.98. The gauge finished the morning session up 202.50 points, also less than 1 percent, to 26,432.51.
Stocks also rose yesterday in Europe. In London, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-stock index gained 21.4 points, or nine-tenths of a percent, to 2,318.3. But volume was below the level of Friday.
In Frankfurt, the German stock index picked up 41 points, or 2.7 percent, to close at 1,572.31.
In Canada, stocks rose slightly as interest rates were cut. The Toronto Stock Exchange composite index gained 25.99 points, to 3,532.54. Advancing issues led declines 340 to 206 on volume of 18.2 million shares.
Four of Canada's leading banks cut their prime lending rates yesterday by half a percentage point, to 11.25 percent, to match the Bank of Montreal, which had made a similar move last week.
 
Dollar Gains Overseas
 In foreign exchange trading, the dollar gained yesterday against leading currencies in Europe and Tokyo. Gold prices fell.
Currency dealers said an end to the fighting in the Persian Gulf would help deficit-cutting efforts in the United States, benefiting the economy and the dollar.
Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with the late Friday quotes, included: 1.4845 German marks, up from 1.4765; 1.2730 Swiss francs, up from 1.2685; 5.0518 French francs, up from 5.0310; 1.6725 Dutch guilders, up from 1.6635; 1,113.38 Italian lire, up from 1,110.00, and 1.1526 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1543.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.29 yen yesterday to close at 129.95 yen. The dollar was quoted in London at 130.45 yen.
Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $363 an ounce, from $365.25 late Friday. Gold fell in Zurich to $364, from $364.85, and it fell in Hong Kong to $365.98, from $369.97.
Silver bullion fell in London to a late bid price of $3.78 an ounce, from $3.84 on Friday.

HEADLINE: Plants May Teach How to Make Fuel From Sunbeams

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
SCIENTISTS believe they are on the verge of constructing test-tube versions of photosynthesis, the basic life process in which plants tap the sun's energy. Their aim is to open the way to new sources of usable energy based on the cheapest and most abundant of raw materials: sunlight, water and carbon dioxide.
In principle, the effort could eventually enable chemists to mount a new two-front attack on the threat of global warming posed by the buildup of carbon dioxide from burning fossil fuels. Artificial assemblies of photosynthetic molecules that converted the sun's energy into liquid fuels like hydrogen would both cut demand for oil, and remove carbon dioxide from the atmosphere. 
 "That's the dream," said Dr. Mark Wrighton, a chemist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who is in the forefront of photosynthesis research.
"We can see how to do it and we're embarking at this point on a faithful reproduction of the biological system," he said in an interview. "We hope we'll be able to make inexpensive molecules, make them efficiently and make them durable."
Dr. Wrighton was the main speaker on the subject at the Second Annual Frontiers of Science Symposium conducted recently by the National Academy of Sciences at Irvine, Calif., where many of the latest advances were described.
"Understanding has been developing very, very fast," and the close circle of scientists working on the problem has become "a very excited group of people," said Dr. George L. McLendon of the University of Rochester, another speaker.
In a critical step, chemists have already put together elegant artificial versions of the basic molecular mechanism that is at the heart of photosynthesis. In this mechanism, solar energy strikes molecules of chlorophyll inside the leaves of green plants. The energy infuses electrons with new force, sending them leaping and cascading from molecule to molecule, transferring energy as they go.
The chain of reactions ultimately results in the conversion of atmospheric carbon dioxide to the carbohydrates that sustain almost all life. Oxygen is released to the atmosphere as a byproduct.
Scientists believe they will be able in time to manipulate the process to produce not only carbohydrates, but also hydrogen, methane and other forms of chemical energy. Methane is the essential ingredient of natural gas, the burning of which emits less carbon dioxide than either coal or oil. The burning of hydrogen emits no carbon dioxide. It could be used to power motor vehicles or, combined with oxygen in a fuel cell, to make electricity.
Plants convert solar energy to chemical energy inside organs called chloroplasts, tiny components of plant cells. The parts of the chloroplast that capture solar energy and set off the cascade of electrons are known as photochemical reaction centers. These are complexes of proteins and the green-colored chlorophyll molecules that give plants their distinctive color.
Photosynthesis begins when particles of light, known as photons, strike molecules of chlorophyll. Each photon boosts an electron in the chlorophyll to a higher energy state. The excited electron then jumps across to a special "carrier" molecule nearby. This is the first in a sequence of leaps by electrons between molecules that are held in precise positions in a special membrane in the reaction center.
Along the way, the electrons give up some of the energy imparted to them by the photon. In a reaction separate from the chain of jumping electrons, this energy is harvested as a compound known as adenosine triphosphate, or ATP. This compound plays an important role in the subsequent manufacture of carbohydrates.
 
'Dark Photosynthesis'
 Back in the main stream of electron flow, the energy level of the leaping electrons is reboosted by a second photon, and the electrons cascade down a second series of molecules. This chain of events culminates in the creation ofa molecule called nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate hydride, or NADPH. The NADPH molecule is a sort of special-purpose battery that stores electrons for the vital reaction in which NADPH teams with ATP to convert carbon dioxide from the air into carbohydrates, or sugars.
These sugars provide food for plants and hence for almost all life. The reactions that create them constitute a second phase of the process, called "dark photosynthesis" because it is not directly dependent on sunlight.
The electron that is lost at the start of photosynthesis, when a photon strikes the first chlorophyll molecule, must be replaced so as to restore the system to its initial state. Replacement electrons come from water molecules through a mechanism that is not yet completely understood. In surrendering electrons, the water molecules split apart into hydrogen atoms and oxygen. The oxygen is released to the atmosphere.
Despite their considerable understanding of this mechanism, scientists have only recently gained insight into what Dr. McLendon calls the "basic ground rules that nature is playing with." These involve, for instance, such critical details as the way in which the parts of the system are physically arranged in relation to each other, the distances electrons must travel and the speeds at which the action takes place.
"There is nothing magic about the molecules used in photosynthesis," said Dr. Thomas E. Mallouk of the University of Texas at Austin, another participant in the Frontiers of Science symposium. "What's special about it is that they're organized in a certain spatial arrangement that allows the electrons to go in one direction in the chain."
How the leap of electrons happens "is one of the big things that's been worked out in the past six years," said Dr. McLendon. "The distances that the electron has to jump are very big compared to the sizes of the molecules. It is clear that in photosynthesis, electrons can jump a lot farther than we used to think."
 
Building Molecules That Work
 In the last few years, scientists in several laboratories have designed assemblies of molecules that mimic the photochemical reaction center in its ability to absorb photons and excite electrons. "We can make very complicated molecules now, and big ones," and they work, said Dr. Wrighton of M.I.T., whose laboratory is one of the makers.
The first such molecule was synthesized in 1983 by chemists at Arizona State University. It consisted of an electron-donating molecule, a light-absorbing molecule and an electron-accepting molecule, all linked in the right way to make the photochemical reaction possible.
Scientists say progress has been rapid since then, and several laboratories have produced synthetic molecules that duplicate the essence of photosynthesis.
One of the latest, reported last year, is a five-part molecule called the pentad system, produced by the Arizona State laboratory that first created the triad molecule. "We're basically using the same building blocks as nature, but we're controlling the structure differently," said Dr. Devens Gust, a leader of the Arizona team.
The pentad molecule is made of organic chemicals that absorb light and receive and donate electrons. The chemicals are porphyrins, quinones and sometimes materials derived from chlorophyll itself. But while nature embeds the molecules in protein, the Arizona State researchers hold them together through chemical bonds.
The salient advantage of the molecule, said Dr. Gust, is that it mimics the multistep cascading of electrons so as to maintain an energetic state long enough for useful products to be derived. If the chain is too short, the energy will simply dissipate before anything useful can happen.
 
'Microscopic Swiss Cheese'
 Dr. Mallouk's group at the University of Texas is duplicating the light-induced cascade of electrons with a chain of nonbiological molecules containing the metal ruthenium. These molecules absorb light like chlorophyll. The molecule was devised by Michael Gratzel, a Swiss chemist.
The Texas team has strung five of these molecules together, embedding them in a matrix made from minerals called zeolites. The zeolites are full of empty spaces, "like microscopic Swiss cheese," says Dr. Mallouk, and the spaces can be strung together to make tunnels about the size of a molecule.
By choosing zeolites with the right pore size, the Texas team believes it will be possible to solve a major problem: how to hold the molecules in place at proper distances and angles from each other. This orientation "is going to be central to getting high efficiency whether we make electricity or whether we make chemical fuel," said Dr. Wrighton.
In the first place, the molecule at one end of the electron-transfer chain must be kept away from the molecule at the other end; otherwise, the two molecules would exchange electrons and all the energy originally absorbed from the sun would be lost as heat. And even if they can be kept apart, molecules must be arranged in certain ways, relative to each other, for maximum efficiency of energy conversion from solar to chemical.
Most of the artificial assemblies of molecules until now have been suspended in an electrolyte solution. This means that although the early steps of photosynthesis can be carried out efficiently, the energy is ultimately dissipated. Apart from the Texas zeolite method, researchers are trying to embed the molecules in some sort of biological material, as in nature; to bind them to films, and to suspend them chemically, as Dr. Wrighton's group is trying to do, between two electrodes.
Researchers face an even more difficult problem in the question of how water molecules yield up electrons to replace those lost by chlorophyll. They do not fully understand this process, although they know that a manganese compound plays a critical role.
 
'Like a Tinker Toy Box'
 A group headed by Dr. Thomas J. Meyer of the University of North Carolina is approaching the problem by substituting a ruthenium compound for the manganese compound, which is hard to manipulate in an artificial system because it is so unstable. The more stable ruthenium mimics the action of manganese so well, said Dr. Meyer, that "we're beginning to get a good handle" on electron replacement.
Still another challenge is presented by "dark photosynthesis," the final part of the process in which NADPH and ATP are used to create carbohydrates from carbon dioxide. Duplicating this, says Dr. Meyer, "is difficult chemistry" and "no picnic."
How close are scientists to fashioning artificial photosynthetic systems that could produce usable energy?
"We could almost put all this together in a single device now, but we're not quite ready yet," said Dr. Meyer. "It's just like a Tinker Toy box. All the pieces are lying around, some of them assembled, but the complete assembly has yet to be done."
Dr. McLendon says that while "many people have done elegant synthesis and have made some lovely molecules," scientists understand the process "to about a 90 percent level.
"But that's like saying we understand engineering principles to within 90 percent of building a bridge," he said. "You wouldn't want to drive over it."
 
Economic Question Remains
 And even if all these problems are solved, years of further development will be required before any operational devices can be produced.
A major question is how much of the energy carried by photons can be converted to practical use. Theoretically, said Dr. Wrighton, 20 to 25 percent could be converted. This efficiency would rival that of conventional photovoltaic systems.
With such efficiencies, scientists believe, artificial photosynthesis might be used to produce a variety of fuels. In theory, chemists could manipulate the photochemical reaction center so as to produce methane or hydrogen in place of NADPH.
Once the technical problems are solved, the question of economic feasibility remains. But the prospect of converting the sun's energy directly into liquid fuels, and of removing unwanted carbon dioxide from the atmosphere, is too important to ignore. So scientists are pressing ahead on the basic science of the problem in the hope of an eventual payoff.
Dr. McLendon calls it "the scientific field-of-dreams approach" to technological advance: "If you build the foundation, it will come."
 
Green Power: Inside the Plant's Energy Factory
 
In photosynthesis, plants convert solar energy into the compounds ATP and NADPH, which play key roles in chemical reactions that create sugars out of atmospheric carbon dioxide. The sugars sustain almost all life, and the process releases oxygen to the atmosphere as a byproduct. All this takes place in tiny organs, called chloroplasts, within leaf cells. Scientists hope to open up new sources of energy by duplicating the process artificially.
 
The Chemical Cascade of Energy
 
Photosynthesis begins inside a complex of proteins and chorophyll, called a photochemical reaction center, when a photon, or particle of sunlight, strikes
a chlorophyll molecule.
 
The photon boosts an electron to a higher energy state, and it jumps to a special "carrier" molecule. This is the first in a sequence of such electron leaps. At the same time, protons accumulate in the lumen, or cell interior.
 
Electrons lose energy along the way. To regain it, they jump to a second chlorophyll molecule, where a second photon reboosts the energy level, and a second cascade of electrons begins. It ends with the synthesis of NADPH.
 
The protons that have accumulated in the lumen trigger the synthesis of ATP. Outside the photochemical reaction center, in the stroma, ATP and NADPH drive the manufacture of sugars from carbon dioxide.
 
To restore the system to its initial state, the electron that is lost from chlorophyll at the start must be replaced. It comes from water molecules which then react to release oxygen to the air.
 
Sources: Dr. Mark Wrighton; "Molecular Biology of the Cell"; "Molecular Cell Biology"
 
Giant That Lost Race to Moon
 
Soviet space officials have released details of the N1 rocket, designed to carry men to the Moon in the 1970's, a space ship whose existence was denied until a year ago. It failed because its many first-stage engines could not be mede to deliver stable, reliable thrust, the officials now say. Like the successful Unites States Saturn 5, it was about 370 feet long. The first three stages were to place the lunar module and Soyuz transport vehicle into Earth orbit. The fourth stage was to propel the vehicles toward the Moon, and the fifth stage was for insertion into lunar orbit, initial descent and return to Earth.
 
Source: Daniel Gauthier, Aviation Week & Space Technology.

HEADLINE: Mining Dead Cars for Money

 BODY:
Making use of new enforcement authority, New York City is slowly beating the blight of abandoned cars -- adding to the city's depleted treasury in the process. But help from Albany could permit a lot more progress.
Plateless hulks, cannibalized by scavengers and vandals, deface every city neighborhood. Last year the Sanitation Department had to remove an astonishing 121,000 dead cars from city streets, up from only 31,000 in 1981. 
 The problem is finally starting to shrink. The city's 1989 hulk count was a record 140,000. To some extent, the decline results from higher scrap metal prices and a sour economy that makes people more reluctant to junk old cars. But there's another factor: The city has finally embarked on a serious program of stiff fines.
Previous crackdowns failed mostly because of an impractical requirement that abandoned-car summonses be served in person. Two years ago, at the city's behest, the State Legislature changed the law. The Sanitation Department now may serve summonses by certified mail, and the minimum fine has been raised to a hefty $250.
Using the number found on most engine blocks and a computer link with the State Motor Vehicles Department, sanitation agents track hulks to the last registered owner, then mail out a summons; owners who report a theft are not liable.
The early results are impressive. During 1990, the first complete year of the new program, the city mailed out nearly 19,000 abandoned-car summonses and collected nearly $1 million in fines -- an amount the city says is about double its administrative costs. That compares with just 3,500 summonses issued and $73,000 collected the year before. The program's manager, Roy Pantangelo, estimates the city will mail out 50,000 summonses this year.

HEADLINE: Conserve Oil -- and Wilderness

 BODY:
The Arctic National Wildlife Refuge forms only a small part of Alaska. Smaller still is the coastal plain of the refuge, a narrow wilderness that flanks the Beaufort Sea. The frozen plain is home to maybe 200 Eskimos, 180,000 caribou and dozens of rare Arctic species. It may also contain the biggest undiscovered oilfield in the United States.
President Bush wants to open the plain for exploration. The proposal symbolizes everything that's wrong with what is known of Mr. Bush's energy strategy, which will be unveiled this week. It's not so much that he would exploit an ecological treasure, although to many environmentalists that is the heart of the matter. What's worse is that he would do so even though conservation could achieve the same results without risk to the environment. 
 The oil industry, which is running out of places to drill, makes a strong case for exploring the refuge. It says that only 12,700 acres of the plain -- less than 1 percent -- would be marred by the usual detritus: rigs, pipelines, drilling mud, airfields. Meanwhile, the Interior Department figures the odds are one in five of finding as much as 3.4 billion barrels of oil. By industry standards, those are good odds promising a huge return. By 2005, assuming quick discovery, the field could reach peak production of 800,000 barrels a day. That's 10 percent of all present U.S. production.
These numbers are almost big enough to obscure two counteraguments. One: The oil under the plain is not a renewable resource. Soon it will be gone. Two: If the objective is to reduce reliance on foreign oil and create a rational long-range energy policy -- and Mr. Bush says it is -- there may be far better ways of achieving it.
For example, assuming that the number of cars increases only slightly, a gradual increase in fuel economy standards from 27.5 miles per gallon to 40 could reduce demand by two million barrels of oil per day by 2005. That's far more than the coastal plain could produce. Besides, the conservation saving would be permanent.
Mandating tough fuel standards may not be the most fair or effective way to save oil. A good case can be made for a stiff gasoline tax that goes to the root of America's addiction to petroleum. In the bargain, it would raise money to develop other energy sources. Yet neither alternative is mentioned in the energy proposals now circulating in Washington. Nor is there more than a hint that consumption may be part of the energy equation. Give me the refuge, the President seems to say, and we will drill our way out of dependency.
Perhaps, someday, a stronger case can be made for exploring this fragile terrain. But Mr. Bush hasn't begun to make it. Until he does, the man who asks to be known as the Environment President sounds like the Expedient President instead.

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
The Soviet-Iraq Axis

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
There's no use getting mad at Mikhail Gorbachev and his partner, Saddam Hussein. Both are doing what comes naturally to two nervous dictators trying to get out of terminal trouble.
The Moscow-Baghdad axis, obviously and openly, is at work on a plan that would restore to the Soviet Union and Iraq the power that both have lost in the Middle East. It would also meet another objective of interest to both men -- survival. 
 Mr. Gorbachev needs some success to take Soviet minds off his stumbling leadership. It won't work for long, but at least in the Kremlin losers are shuffled off to a villa somewhere.
The Iraqi leader has an even more vivid interest involved. In the Middle East, a dacha is not prepared for a suddenly unemployed ruler -- just a grave.
The Moscow-Baghdad alliance was never dissolved. In the eternal struggle against naivete about the Kremlin and the third world, it helps to keep that in mind. The Soviet Union was Saddam Hussein's chief ally and source of weapons. Scud missiles landing in Saudi Arabia and the tanks facing American troops are Soviet made.
Of course, our Western allies also armed him while Washington smiled and appeased. Most of our current Arab allies toadied to him or stuffed his treasury with money. Saddam Hussein: he belongs to us all.
The difference is that Moscow never broke the axis with Baghdad, despite its clucking about Kuwait. The U.S. paid for this mouth support with fawning gratitude. Hardly a word did Washington say about the hundreds of Soviet military "technicians" who stayed on in Iraq to extend comradely help with Soviet weapons or the case of the Soviet ship caught with weapon parts destined for Iraq through Jordan. Politically, the Soviet Union kept working for Iraq through Mr. Gorbachev's personal envoy.
Now comes the mutual payoff. Saddam Hussein faces defeat. He knew it was coming. He is neither martyr, mystic nor moron. In meetings with Soviet diplomats, the Iraqis prepared their line of retreat and survival.
Saddam Hussein would withdraw from Kuwait -- with the U.S. accepting some formula on the importance of settling other Mideast issues. Washington would never use the word linkage, but Saddam Hussein would be strengthened because the world would know a deal when it smelled one.
Saddam Hussein would take his tanks and missiles with him. They would join the divisions he left in Iraq. Teheran would deliver the air armada he thoughtfully parked in Iran. Saddam Hussein would emerge battered, but still dangerous.
Moscow would be waiting to pitch in with arms and advisers, despite any international agreements. The Soviet Union's double-crossing on treaties is spelled out devastatingly in Arnold Beichman's new book "The Long Pretense" (Transaction Publishers).
With contempt, let's dispose of the argument already being heard that Americans opposed to a settlement that would strengthen the Moscow-Baghdad axis are itching to march on Baghdad and don't care about American casualties. That is brother to the one about how only Israel and its amen corner in the U.S. were beating the war drums against Iraq -- remember that one?
No march on Baghdad is necessary -- simply a continuation of President Bush's steady course. A ground attack should not start a day earlier or later than planned before the Gorbachev-Hussein maneuvers.
 Primary objectives should be Iraq out of Kuwait and Saddam Hussein out of power. If we do not achieve the second at once, we should work at it incessantly after he pulls out.
To rest with him in power would be hypocrisy crossing into criminality. The U.N. called for a restoration of international peace and security in the Persian Gulf area.
 Does anybody really believe Saddam Hussein would cooperate with that goal? Would he suddenly deal honestly with the international machinery needed to prevent him from getting new weapons, including chemical or nuclear ingredients? Anybody?
President Bush has advised Iraqis to get rid of their tyrant. The honesty horrified bureaucrats and former bureaucrats as official honesty usually does. Mr. Bush showed respect to Iraqis by speaking the truth to them -- peace and Saddam Hussein cannot exist together. Mr. Gorbachev is sophisticated enough to know that.
 No, it is not a firm Mideast peace Mr. Gorbachev and his axis partner seek but their own survival and renewed power. Did anybody expect anything else of either partner? Anybody?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Don't Call Today's Combat Soldier Low Skilled

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The issue in "The Killing Fields Aren't Level" (editorial, Jan. 28), as old as Socrates, is the citizen's debt to the democratic state. Stating that recruiters don't advertise the risk to life inherent to service is gratuitous. Airlines, motorcycle and automobile dealers, athletic clubs, hospitals and others don't advertise risks either.
You can't join the armed forces by accident. The system requires examinations, interviews and signed statements, continuing even after arrival at recruit training. The goal is to prevent anybody's joining any service with any disqualifications or false expectations, including risk. The benefit of the doubt goes to the recruit, to include enlistment voiding.
The oft-repeated "low-skill-combat-duty" aphorism is becoming conventional wisdom. "Platoon," "China Beach" and others set up this image. It is wrong. It does not follow that a task is low skill if not technically oriented and structured. Nor can high risk and low skill be logically coupled.
The skilled combat arms soldier or marine is the product of a lengthy training regime, progressing through basic skill qualification and then unit training. He is skilled in the employment of three or four individual weapons. He is not a mere ammunition mule and bullet hose holder. He understands both mechanized and foot-soldier tactics. He is skilled in the operation capabilities of helicopters and fixed-wing aircraft, for he is most often the controlling agent.
Directing aircraft means he understands antiaircraft weapons. He is skilled in geometry and navigation, to direct mortars and artillery. He integrates artillery, aircraft and direct-fire weapons simultaneously in the same airspace. The pilots trust him, not something they are likely to do for somebody with low skill. Armor and antiarmor, mine and countermine weapons and tactics, use of demolitions, computers, motor vehicles, laser designators, thermal sights, satellite communications gear and organization of supply and logistics are part of his kit.
Perhaps most significant, willingly firing upon the enemy, and discriminating between combatants and noncombatants, are acts of high initiative. These require sophisticated moral and ethical judgments not normally attributed to the low skilled.
Postwar, many of the new American success stories will be written by those who can operate in the unstructured chaos at the edge of the modern battlefield, generating solutions under the most severe stress imaginable. Who better to sort out the problems of our economy, industry, families, drug addiction and schools? Independent thinkers or structured technologists? Perhaps we will need less technical structure and more "low skill" solutions in the 1990's.
 
(Col.) W. C. GREGSON, U.S.M.C.
Military Fellow
Council on Foreign Relations
Washington, Jan. 30, 1991

HEADLINE: Don't Call Today's Combat Soldier Low Skilled;
Dependent Allowances

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Support the troops. What started as a simple call has grown into a crescendo. Even the opponents of our latest war make it clear that their activities are not meant to demean the men and women over there. We show support with snippets of ribbon, massive flag waving, a steady stream of letters to the front. New support symbols appear almost daily.
In war, as elsewhere, talk is cheap. Television reports remind us of the economic plight of the dependents of an unknown but obviously large number of the soldiers called to duty in the Persian Gulf. They are wives, husbands, young children, grandparents called suddenly to shoulder unanticipated burdens. One night's special case was a bedridden mother supported and cared for entirely by a son who was called up.
Symbols don't pay rent or feed children. I suggest an immediate increase in allowances for dependents of enlisted military personnel stationed in the war theater and enactment of a graduated income tax surcharge to finance the costs of the allowances.
 
SANFORD COHEN
Albuquerque, N.M., Feb. 11, 1991

HEADLINE: Eugene Fodor, Creator of Guides For Worldwide Travel, Dies at 85

BYLINE: By GLENN FOWLER

 BODY:
Eugene Fodor, whose travel guides have been carried by tourists to the far corners of the world for more than half a century, died last night at the Charlotte Hungerford Hospital in Torrington, Conn. He was 85 years old and lived in Litchfield, Conn.
He died of a brain tumor, said a business associate, Robert Fisher. 
 Mr. Fodor's approach to travel writing was set forth in his first book, "1936 . . . On the Continent," a guide to Europe for British travelers that he published in London. The joy of travel, he wrote, should not be derived solely from seeing "the sights," but from mingling with "peoples whose customs, habits and general outlook are different from your own."
Between "On the Continent" and Mr. Fodor's retirement a decade ago, the number of Fodor guides grew to more than 140 titles, many in languages other than English. Roughly 200 million Fodor guides, now published in the United States by Random House, are sold each year.
 
Spoke 5 Languages
 Mr. Fodor was born in Leva, Hungary, now part of Czechoslovakia. He left as a youth to study political economics at the Sorbonne and at the University of Grenoble in France. A desire to travel and an ability to speak five languages led him to work as an interpreter for a French shipping line.
In his spare time he wrote articles for the line's in-house magazine about life aboard ship and visits to exotic ports. Soon he was selling articles to newspapers in Hungary and France.
In 1934, while working for the Aldor Publishing Company in London, he suggested a guidebook to the Continent that would contain the "human element" he found lacking in guides of the day.
The book was a success, and in 1938, when it was published for American travelers, it became a best seller. He was in the United States on a business trip that year, and when Nazi Germany annexed the Sudetenland in Czechoslovakia, he concluded that World War II was imminent.
He stayed in the United States, went into the Army in 1942 and served five years in the intelligence branch, emerging a captain.
 
A C.I.A. Link Charged
 Three decades later E. Howard Hunt Jr., the former Central Intelligence Agency operative who figured in the Watergate scandal, asserted that Mr. Fodor had been a C.I.A. agent, which Mr. Fodor denied. He declined to comment, however, on Mr. Hunt's contention that the Fodor guides had provided operating cover for American intelligence agents abroad.
In 1950 the David McKay Company in New York began publishing a series of Fodor guides to individual countries, and Mr. Fodor set up a Paris headquarters. The first four guides covered France, Switzerland and Italy and, in a move that angered the Irish, combined Britain and Ireland in a single book. Subsequent guides dealt separately with Ireland.
Mr. Fodor returned to the United States in 1964 to live in Litchfield, Conn., and began compiling travel books about this country.
"America is still a little-known and little-understood country, and we don't do much to promote ourselves abroad," he said at the time. "We may go to Europe to visit our past, but the rest of the world comes to America to see their future."
Mr. Fodor is survived by his wife, the former Vlasta Zobel, whom he married in 1948.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Barnes Names a Chief From Outside Family

BYLINE: By Daniel F. Cuff

 BODY:
The Barnes Group, a 134-year-old industrial company in Bristol, Conn., has named William R. Fenoglio chief executive. He is the first executive from outside the Barnes family to lead the company.
Mr. Fenoglio, 51, will take over in April after Wallace Barnes steps down at age 65. Mr. Barnes will continue as chairman. 
 Barnes, with sales last year of $550 million, is in the precision spring and aircraft component businesses and the distribution of maintenance supplies.
The company was founded by Mr. Barnes's great-grandfather, and the family owns a third of the stock, which is traded on the New York Stock Exchange. Some Barnes family members serve on the board, including Carlyle F. Barnes, Mr. Barnes's first cousin and a retired executive officer of the company.
But there are no other Barneses in the company's executive offices. Mr. Fenoglio was recruited six years ago from the General Electric Company and joined Barnes as president and chief operating officer. Mr. Fenoglio will continue as president as well as being chief executive.
"There will be no dramatic changes in store," Mr. Fenoglio said. "We believe in focus. We've got three good business with a lot of opportunities."
The company is feeling the effects of recession, especially in the auto industry. "This is a fairly tough time, with the auto market a big part of our precision spring business," he said. "People are worried about the war and about having jobs. I don't see it being too short term," he said of the slump.
But he said that Barnes was a "well-managed company able to handle adversity."
Mr. Fenoglio is a graduate of the Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology in Terre Haute, Ind. From there he went to G.E., where he spent 23 years. In his last job at G.E., he was general manager of the component motor division in Fort Wayne, Ind.
Wallace Barnes was named president in 1964 and that year the company diversified away from its Associated Spring business with the acquisition of the Bowman Distribution Group. It entered the aerosapce business in the early 1980's.

HEADLINE: Harrods to Cut 600 From Work Force

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 19

 BODY:
Harrods department store, whose popularity with tourists has made it a London landmark, said it would slash 14 percent of its work force, partly because of a drop in tourism caused by the war in the Persian Gulf. Harrods said the 600 job cuts had also been caused by Britain's deepening recession.
The reductions among the 4,200 staff will be made mainly in sales, distribution and administrative departments, the company said. Last month, Harrods cut 90 jobs because of the drop-off in foreign visitors. Americans and Europeans have cut back their travel plans.
