HEADLINE: DEBATE ON SAVING RIVER LOCK SYSTEM

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: KAUKAUNA, Wis., Feb. 19

 BODY:
A battle to save one of the last hand-operated river navigation systems in the nation is pitting local interests against a Federal agency unwilling to pay a $20 million repair bill.
The system consists of 17 wooden locks along a 37-mile stretch of the Fox River, their gates and water valves cranked by hand. Once a vital link for moving goods between the Great Lakes and the Mississippi River, the 140-year-old locks have not been regularly used since the early 1960's, and some are falling apart. 
 For communities along the Fox, in northeastern Wisconsin, the locks are a historic jewel whose restoration could mean millions of dollars for local economies. For the Army Corps of Engineers, which has been responsible for the locks since they were built, they are an expensive nuisance that ought to be dismantled. Nearly nine years of negotiations have failed to settle the dispute.
 
A Matter for Congress
 The locks connect Green Bay, on Lake Michigan, with Lake Winnebago, a popular fishing and boating haven. Once they raised cargo boats 169 feet from Lake Michigan to Lake Winnebago, taking them through nine dams built to supply power for paper, lumber and flour mills. Now their condition is so precarious that the locks can be used only by special arrangement.
Congress would have to approve the Corps of Engineers' recommendation to dismantle the system. The Fox River communities hope their members of Congress will help them prevail despite the tight Federal budget.
"It is definitely going to be a tough battle; nobody doubts that at all," said Beverly Anthony, an aide to Senator Herb Kohl, a Democrat. "It is going to require a lot of work by every member of the Wisconsin delegation."
State and local officials say they are willing to assume operation of the locks, but not until they are repaired. They argue that the corps wrongly allowed the system to fall into disrepair.
Since at least 1982, the corps has worked to abandon the locks, refusing to do regular repairs or maintenance. A local group, the Fox River Management Commission, has leased and operated the locks since then.
One lock has been closed. It still has wooden logs for walls and could collapse with little warning. It would cost an estimated $2 million to rebuild.
 
Recreation and Development
 Friends of the Fox, a citizens' group formed to save the navigation system, say the locks would enhance recreational boating, preserve a historic treasure and insure future development in the Fox River Valley. "Would you build a new system? Probably not," said Mayor Ron Van De Hey of Kaukauna, co-chairman of the Fox River Management Commission. "Would you save the old one? Absolutely."
The corps estimates that restoring the locks to reasonable operating condition would cost $20 million; the local interests' estimate is $10 million. Jim Bonetti, project manager for the corps at Kaukauna, said it would cost about $4 million to dismantle them.
Richard Dexter, an archeologist with the State Historical Society, said historic reasons alone should justify the cost of repairs. The only other hand-operated system is on the Muskingum River in Ohio, where the state owns 10 locks and uses them entirely for pleasure boating.
"It is still a living, breathing and functioning system that you can maintain and preserve," Mr. Dexter said of the Fox River locks. "It is a major artifact. It clearly is the major reason you have the Fox River Valley as it is today."

HEADLINE: Nortek Halts Its Dividend

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 19

 BODY:
Nortek Inc. said today that it would suspend dividend payments after its fourth-quarter loss soared because of a 12.5 percent drop in sales.
Nortek lost $35.8 million on revenue of $224.6 million, compared with a loss of almost $6.7 million a year earlier on revenue of $256.8 million. 
 The building-products manufacturer said it saw no prospects for improvement until the economy improved and consumer uncertainty over the Persian Gulf war ended.
Nortek's yearly loss was $38.1 million, compared with a loss of $12.5 million in 1989. The company had sales of nearly $1.04 billion last year, 3.7 percent below its $1.08 billion in sales in 1989.
Richard L. Bready, Nortek's new chairman and chief executive, said that Nortek would indefinitely suspend quarterly dividends of 2.5 cents a share on its common stock and a cent a share on its special common stock.
Nortek, which was heavily involved in the "junk bond" market under its former chairman, Ralph R. Papitto, said it continued to consider restructuring debt, selling assets or seeking bank financing to cut costs.
Nortek's stock fell 62.5 cents today, to $3.125, on the New York Stock Exchange, where its 16.7 percent decline was the worst of the day.

HEADLINE: Marketing in the Classroom: Assets vs. Liabilities

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
When Whittle Communications introduced a daily television news program, with advertising, in schoolrooms last year, the action touched off a noisy debate among educators, corporations and consumer advocates about marketing to impressionable children.
But for years some of the nation's largest corporations have been quietly marketing to millions of schoolchildren, with little controversy and with the tacit or even open approval of school administrators. 
 Corporations hand out samples of Noxzema skin cream and Tampax tampons in home economics classes and distribute millions of Halloween "safety kits" with corporate trademarks like Kool-Aid emblazoned on the side.
Some educators describe such practices as ethically murky at best and exploitative at worst -- the dark side of corporate America's bid to help financially ailing schools. Others say school budgets are so tight that they welcome whatever help they can get.
"Schools are so under the gun that they are willing to accept anything," said Bill Honig, the state superintendent of public instruction in California, the nation's largest state school system with more than 4.9 million children. William L. Rukeyser, an aide to Mr. Honig who has studied the issue, said, "We don't want to see the nation's schools turn from a marketplace of ideas to simply a marketplace."
Next month, a not-for-profit group of educators and business executives, the National Association of Partners in Education, is scheduled to release the first draft of pioneer guidelines on corporate marketing in schools.
 
'Benefits Outweigh Pitfalls'
 As government expenditures for schools have declined, cash-strapped school districts appreciate corporate marketing because it is free. In Gallup, N.M., Susan M. Cave, county coordinator for elementary instruction, allows schools to use corporate-sponsored materials, because, she said,"the benefits outweigh the pitfalls for the few minutes of advertising."
Marketing exectives say critics exaggerate the dangers. "We are not descendants of Attila the Hun crashing through the window and pillaging the classroom," said Edwin L. Swanson, senior vice president of Modern Talking Picture Service Inc., another company that markets to schools. "Even philanthropy has to have a bottom line. Companies have an interest in helping kids, but they also have an interest in taking credit for their help."
The move to have guidelines drawn up by the National Association of Partners in Education was partly prompted by the Whittle marketing program, which many educators oppose.
 
Agreement With Schools
 Whittle, based in Knoxville, Tenn., agrees to provide about $50,000 worth of television and videocassette equipment to the average school in return for students watching 10 minutes of Whittle-produced news programs interspersed with two minutes of unobstrusive corporate advertising from companies like Burger King.
Some states, including New York and Rhode Island, have banned Whittle from their schools. In California, Mr. Honig has ruled that public schools cannot legally accept Whittle's program and has threatened to cut off those who do.
Some educators distinguish between the Whittle program and corporate-sponsored materials that teachers are free to use as they see fit. They also say the potential for controversy is most acute when marketing comes from companies that make products that children can readily buy.
Consumers Union, a group that tries to assess advertiser and product claims, has denounced virtually all corporate marketing in schools as "brainwashing and not advertising," and advocates that schools be declared "ad-free zones."
Mr. Swanson of Modern Talking Picture Service said such a move would be disastrous. "To make rules foolishly strict," he said, "is to make it hard for corporations to justify school aid to the bean counters. They're going to say, 'What are we getting for the money?' "
 
Pens and Creative Writing
 Lifetime Learning Systems Inc., in Fairfield, Conn., says it has produced 650 programs for 350 clients. One of its most popular programs, sponsored by Bic, the maker of pens, is designed to encourage creative writing. "Yes, it's an advertisement for Bic," said Roberta Nusim, the company's recently retired founder. "But does the benefit of this program outweigh the logo on this material? I would say yes."
Lois R. Van Wagner, a high school science teacher at East Rock School in New Haven said such materials are welcome. She said she spends about $400 of her own money for magazines, field trips and other ways of supplementing textbooks.
Ms. Wagner uses a free science program sponsored by the GTE Corporation called, "Discover the World of Science." If companies were banned from such marketing efforts, she said, "who else is going to pick up the tab?"

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
1,000 to 1,500 Job Cuts For Pratt & Whitney

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
The United Technologies Corporation said yesterday that it would eliminate between 1,000 and 1,500 jobs from its Pratt & Whitney division in the first half of this year.
The division, which makes military and commercial jet engines, cited continuing deterioration of the market for aircraft equipment. 
 United Technologies announced last August that it would eliminate 4,000 jobs by 1993 because of expected cutbacks in Defense Department contracts. But the company said yesterday that the layoffs would be accomplished at a quicker pace than originally expected.
"Events in the Persian Gulf and higher fuel prices are having an adverse impact on the world's airline industry," said James G. O'Connor, executive vice president of Pratt & Whitney. "Airlines are flying less and have decreased their spending for equipment."
The reductions will be accomplished largely through attrition, but layoffs have not been ruled out, the company said. Pratt & Whitney, the largest division of United Technologies, has a worldwide work force of about 45,000. The company said that most of the positions affected would be at Pratt & Whitney plants in Connecticut, with smaller cuts at plants in Maine, Georgia and Florida.
The announcement yesterday came three weeks after United Technologies reported an 8 percent drop in fourth-quarter net income. The company, which is based in Hartford, said its earnings were hurt by continuing losses at its military division.
In New York yesterday, Robert F. Daniell, chairman and chief executive, repeated a forecast for 1991, saying the year could be slow for the company without a significant revival in the domestic economy. "The first half will be down unless the nation gets a few pleasant surprises that jump-start the economy," he said.
Military contracts account for about 35 percent of Pratt & Whitney's business, and the company has been trying to shift its operation to more civilian products to offset Pentagon cutbacks. It has a huge business supplying engines for passenger jets, but its $20 billion backlog of orders is spread out over 10 years, lessening the company's ability to cushion immediate military cuts.
Citing military cuts in recent years, United Technologies has already laid off hundreds of workers at other divisions, including Sikorsky Aircraft, a maker of helicopters in Stratford, Conn., and Norden Systems Inc., an electronics and propulsion systems company in Norwalk, Conn.
United Technologies' stock was unchanged yesterday, closing at $47.50 on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A Rearrangement Of Damon Stock

BYLINE: Floyd Norris

 BODY:
THE Damon Corporation, an operator of clinical laboratories and one of the last leveraged buyouts financed by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., has done better than it was expected to when it was taken over in 1989. Sales are up, and while heavy debts have forced it to report losses, those losses are a bit less than expected.
Now it plans to restructure in a complicated transaction -- involving a subsidiary taking over its corporate parent -- in a way that will make it far easier for insiders to take out cash. The plan announced yesterday, if completed, would also create a larger public company that could attract investors seeking a pure play in the lab business. 
 Damon has benefited from being in a booming business, something rare in these recessionary days. A small conglomerate when it was acquired in 1989, it has since sold all its businesses except the clinical labs, which now provide laboratory services to more than 30,000 doctors and 300 hospitals in 26 states. It says it is the fifth-largest clinical lab company in the country.
Among the operations sold were companies that made centrifuges, Estes model rockets and Hi-Flier kites. Those companies generally were sold for more than expected, Robert L. Rosen, Damon's chairman and chief executive, said in an interview last month.
Mr. Rosen said the lab business had grown in part because the management had remained in place. For the year that ended in August, Damon reported sales of $216.4 million, compared with $183.2 million the year before and well above the $202.4 million the company had predicted in early 1989.
Understanding Damon's business, clinical labs, is relatively easy. Understanding its capital structure is more difficult. The convolutions there, while typical of Drexel deals, may have turned off some investors who would be interested in a pure play in a rapidly growing business.
The Damon situation involves a wide variety of securities in two companies with similar names. The plan announced yesterday, if it is completed, would both simplify the corporate structure and get rid of some of the looming financial obligations that existed as part of that structure.
The parent company is Damon Group, which used to be known as the American Magnetics Corporation. Traded over-the-counter, its shares have boomed in recent weeks, benefiting both from the general stock market surge and from the perception that things were going well at the Damon Corporation, the operating subsidiary. Damon Group's shares fell 25 cents yesterday, to $7.25, after trading earlier in the day at $7.625, the highest level since 1985.
While Damon Group has other assets, including a Florida shopping center that is up for sale, its value is largely dependent on the operations of the Damon Corporation, of which it owns about 25 percent. The remainder of the Damon Corporation is owned by a variety of holders, led by a partnership controlled by Mr. Rosen. Drexel owns nearly 5 percent of the company, a residue of its financing of the May 1989 buyout.
Under the proposal announced yesterday, the Damon Corporation will acquire Damon Group, the company that is now publicly traded, by issuing more stock. The effect of that will be to make Damon Corporation shares publicly tradable, offering insiders the possibility of getting cash for some of their holdings. Holders of the current Damon Group stock will end up with Damon Corporation shares.
Mr. Rosen, a former vice chairman of Maxxam Group, previously was an investment banker and a close aide to Sanford Weill when Mr. Weill ran a predecessor of Shearson Lehman Brothers.
Under the proposal announced yesterday, Damon Corporation preferred stock, which pays high dividends in more preferred stock, will be converted into common through a rights offering. The exact ratio of the exchange was not announced, and negotiating it could be a crucial part of the deal. Some preferred stock is held by institutions, and while nominally it is publicly traded, there seems to have been little activity.
Two insiders in Damon Group will sell out immediately, as part of the transaction. Harry S. Hendler and his brother, J. M. Hendler, both founders of American Magnetics, the predecessor of Damon Group, will sell their 20 percent stake, about one million shares, at $7 a share, and will collect additional payments of just over $1 million each to settle stock options and employment contracts. They will also agree not to compete with the company.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Higher on Optimism Over Soviet Peace Proposal

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished higher on world currency markets yesterday, advancing on optimism that a Soviet peace proposal may help bring the Persian Gulf war to a close soon.
Gold prices also advanced. On the New York Commodity Exchange, bullion for current delivery settled at $364.50 an ounce, up 10 cents from Friday. The Republic National Bank reported a late bid of $363.70, up 20 cents.
Financial markets in the United States were closed Monday in observance of the Washington's Birthday holiday. 
 President Bush received details of the Soviet-backed peace plan on Monday but he did not make them public. Even his comment that the plan "falls well short of what would be required" did not diminish investors' appetite for dollars.
 
Began Rising Friday
 An end to the war "would give a big boost to consumer confidence and therefore would lead to an upturn in the U.S. economy, which is positive for the dollar," said Earl Johnson, a vice president at Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago.
The dollar began rising on Friday after President Saddam Hussein proposed a conditional withdrawal from Kuwait even though the United States dismissed the offer as a "hoax."
"The dollar tends to be trading higher on peace news or quick war news," said Andrew Hodge, of Bank Brussels Lambert in New York.
Still, several traders said that it would be some time before the United States economy turned around. "We will still see weak economic data for a number of months," Mr. Johnson said.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 130.55 Japanese yen, from 129.95 yen on Monday. Later in London, it rose to 131.55 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 131.58 yen, up from 130.50 yen on Monday.
 
Pound Falls in London
 In London, the British pound fell to $1.9505, from $1.9600 late Monday. In New York it cost $1.9496 to buy one pound, cheaper than Friday's $1.9670.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's rates, included: 1.4935 German marks, up from 1.4777; 1.2785 Swiss francs, up from 1.2692; 5.0825 French francs, up from 5.0320; 1,112.00 Italian lire, up from 1,110.50, and 1.1528 Canadian dollars, unchanged.
Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $362.50 a troy ounce, from $364 bid late Monday. In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $362.30, from $364.00. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell 76 cents to close at a bid $365.22.
Silver prices declined. On the Comex in New York, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $3.687 a troy ounce, down from $3.780 on Friday. In London the metal fell to a late bid price of $3.69 a troy ounce from Monday's $3.79.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Security Prices Fall Slightly

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities dipped a bit further yesterday in light trading, as credit market participants lightened up positions on the eve of two days of Congressional testimony by Alan Greenspan on the economy and monetary policy.
Mr. Greenspan, who as chairman of the Federal Reserve is required by law to provide twice-yearly assessments of the nation's economic affairs, will address the Senate Banking Committee today and the House Banking Committee on Thursday. 
 At the moment, market participants are not expecting the Fed chairman to say much to further a rally that appears to be losing steam.
"The momentum that the bond market has had seems to be temporarily suspended," one Government bond trader said. "And people aren't counting on much from Greenspan. People think the Fed is on hold, and as a consequence the market is marking down prices a bit."
Michael R. Englund, a vice president and director of research at MMS International, an economic information and service company in Belmont, Calif., ticked off a list of points that Mr. Greenspan is likely to touch on, including the likely impact on the economy if peace comes suddenly in the Middle East, and the condition of the nation's financial system.
In general, Mr. Englund said, the nature of Mr. Greenspan's remarks are likely to be that while the economy is weak, there are signs it has bottomed out. Moreover, he said, Mr. Greenspan may take note of the signs that the deterioration in the banking system is slowing.
In sum, Mr. Englund said the substance of Mr. Greenspan's remarks "will lead to a somewhat negative tone for the market."
 
2- and 5-Year Note Sale
 The two days of testimony will also influence coming Treasury auctions of two- and five-year securities.
Late yesterday the two-year notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 6.86 percent. Meanwhile, the five-year notes were offered in when-issued trading at a price to yield 7.45 percent.
Concerns that the Fed will not move soon to lower short-term interest rates were reflected in bids at the weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills.
At the auction, three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 5.94 percent, up from the 5.86 percent average rate at last week's sale.
Bids on six-month bills produced an average discount rate of 5.91 percent, up from 5.85 percent a week ago.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 7 7/8 percent bonds of 2021 were offered in late trading at a price of 98 23/32, down 1/8 point, to yield 7.98 percent, up from 7.97 percent late Friday.
Traders said the quite modest price decline would have been more severe but for a large buyer of 30-year government bonds. The buyer reportedly bought more than $1 billion worth of securities.
Among note issues, the Treasury's 7 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at 99 21/32, down 5/32, to yield 7.68 percent. And the 7 5/8 percent three-year notes were offered at 101 9/32, down 1/8, to yield 7.23 percent.
 
Corporate Bond Market
 In the investment-grade corportae bond market, Security Pacific Financial Services Inc., a subsidiary of the Security Pacific Corporation, offered a total of $1.3 billion worth of securities backed by home equity loans.
The bulk of the huge three-part issue consists of $1 billion worth of 8.25 percent notes that carry a final maturity of May 10, 2003, but an average life of 1.80 years.
The notes were priced at $99.625, to yield 8.443, 1.60 percentage points over the prevailing when-issued yield on the new two-year Treasury notes to be auctioned today.
The First Boston Corporation acted as lead manager for the transaction. The first two classes of the issue are rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. The third class, consisting of $133.7 million of subordinated securities, is rated A-2 by Moody's and A-plus by Standard & Poor's.
In the market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, a $226 million offering of highly-rated securities issued by the State of Georgia was received with a tepid reception by investors.
A bid from a group led by Prudential-Bache Securities won the issue, which consists of serial bonds maturing from 1992 to 2011. The bonds were reoffered at yields from 5 percent in 1993 to 6.45 percent in 2011.
The bonds are rated AAA by Moody's and AA-plus by Standard & Poor's. Nevertheless, bankers familiar with the transaction said that by late yesterday underwriters retained an unsold balance of around $150 million worth of securities.
A poor tone was also evident in the secondary market for municipal bonds, traders said, where prices of most widely quoted issues fell by 1/4 point to 3/8 point.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills:

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Northwest Cutting Its Flights Abroad

BYLINE: REUTERS

DATELINE: ST. PAUL, Feb. 19

 BODY:
Northwest Airlines, a unit of NWA Inc., said it would cut 28 of its 144 weekly international flights in March because of light passenger loads. Northwest said the flights are from United States cities to Europe and Asia. For example, service to Tokyo from Minneapolis is being cut to no flights from three flights a week. Service to Tokyo from Honolulu is being cut to 14 flights from 21.
Northwest's flight reductions follow similar moves by other United States carriers to cut capacity as traffic ebbs because of the American recession and fears of terrorism.

HEADLINE: Holocaust Skeptic Who Gives Advice on Death Faces Trial

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MALDEN, Mass., Feb. 19

 BODY:
A judge in this Boston suburb refused today to dismiss the case against a Holocaust revisionist and execution-machine builder who prosecutors say has been practicing engineering without a license.
The defendant, Fred Leuchter Jr., who has published articles contending that the number of people killed in the Holocaust has been exaggerated, must stand trial May 9 under the ruling of the judge, J. W. Killam 3d of Malden District Court. 
 Mr. Leuchter (pronounced LOOT-cher) specializes in building electric chairs and other execution devices and serves as a capital punishment consultant to some states. He claims to have an engineering degree but has refused to provide any documentation.
After the Malden Holocaust Committee, a private group, had begun raising questions about his background, the authorities reviewed his qualifications and charged him with practicing engineering without a license. The penalty for the crime in Massachusetts is up to three months in jail and a $500 fine.
Mr. Leuchter has vowed to sue the Holocaust Committee and other groups that he says "have sought to destroy my family, my livelihood, my life."
His lawyer, Kirk D. Lyons, contends that Mr. Leutcher is a victim of selective prosecution. "Only someone very naive would believe that if Fred Leuchter had not written his Leuchter report that we would be standing here now," Mr. Lyons, who has represented white supremacist groups in Idaho and elsewhere, said today.
Outside the courthouse, supporters and opponents of Mr. Leuchter, perhaps 30 people in all, engaged in a scuffle. Three of them were arrested, and an elderly woman was treated by paramedics.
"By coming out with their signs and their expressions of hatred, they only expose what kind of people they are," said Suzanne D. Tabasky, a spokeswoman for the Holocaust Committee. "In tough economic times like we have now, hate groups come out of the woodwork.'
Across the street, near a sign that said, "The Holocaust Is the Hoax of the 20th Century," a supporter of Mr. Leutcher, C. D. DiGiambattista, said his prosecution "is part of a whole pattern of getting at people who expose the Holocaust myth."

HEADLINE: Salomon Taking A 700-Job Unit Out of New York

BYLINE: By ROBERT E. TOMASSON

 BODY:
Salomon Brothers announced yesterday that it would move the 700 jobs in its domestic operations division to Tampa, Fla., the first major investment banking concern to relocate a large division out of New York City, the traditional capital of investment banking.
Salomon officials said that they needed to build a new technology center for the division, which handles such tasks as billings and stock transfers, and that it was less expensive to do so in Florida. They also cited Tampa's lower wage scales and work force, which they said was well qualified to handle the office machines and computers in the new center. They did not criticize New York's work force. 
 The company's decision to move nearly a quarter of its 3,000 employees came after extensive lobbying by officials from Florida and Ohio. Company officials said that in the final stages of their decision they also considered relocating within the New York metropolitan area or in Columbus, Ohio.
 
'Cost-Effective' Center
 "We will build a state-of-the-art, cost-effective processing facility that will take us well into the 21st century," said Bruce V. Carp, chief administrative officer of Salomon.
While a site has not yet been selected, Tampa officials said the building or renting costs of doing business there were one-third of those in New York.
The move is expected to be completed early in 1993. The company's world headquarters is now in the process of moving into 7 World Trade Center from One New York Plaza in the Wall Street area.
The decision came two weeks after Gov. Lawton Chiles of Florida led a delegation of 12 Floridians to visit Salomon executives in New York.
New York has found it tough to counter corporate moves when the motive is to find a more readily available and cheaper work force, said Jeanne Nathan, a spokeswoman for Sally Hernandez-Pinero, Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development. "When dealing with overall costs, the city can do something with tax breaks and other incentives, but when it involves a different work force and wage scales, there is little we can do," she said.
Tampa, with a population of about 860,000 in the city and its suburbs, is already home, its Mayor, Sandra Freedman, said, to computer operations of several New York-based corporations, including Citicorp, Chase Manhattan and Time-Life.
